--Word--
p 
--Type--
abbreviation
UnKnownKind, abbreviation
UnKnownKind, noun
--Meanings--
Page.
Para-
Penny or pence.
Piano (softly).
(in units of measurement) pico- (10⁻¹²)
Denoting electrons and orbitals possessing one unit of angular momentum.
Pressure.
Probability.
(in tables of sports results) games played.
(on an automatic gear shift) park.
(on road signs and street plans) parking.
(in units of measurement) peta- (10¹⁵)
Poise (unit of viscosity).
Portugal (international vehicle registration).
Proprietary.
The chemical element phosphorus.
The sixteenth letter of the alphabet.
Denoting the next after O (or N if O is omitted) in a set of items, categories, etc.
--Examples--
‘see p 784’
‘p-xylene’
‘a 5p coin’
‘a 220 pf capacitor’
‘p-electrons’
‘pV = nRT’
‘this difference was significant (p = 0.0008)’
‘27 PBq of radioactive material’

--Word--
Paar, Jack 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1918–2004), US television personality; full name Jack Harold Paar. He was host of The Tonight Show 1957–62 (officially The Jack Paar Show from 1959).

paca 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

pacay 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The edible, pulpy fruit of any of several tropical South American trees, especially Inga feuillei and Prosopis juliflora (family Mimosaceae (Leguminosae)).

pacarana 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
pace 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A single step taken when walking or running.
A unit of length representing the distance between two successive steps in walking.
A gait of a horse or other animal, especially one of the recognized trained gaits of a horse.
A person's manner of walking or running.
Speed in walking, running, or moving.
The speed or rate at which something happens or develops.
The state of a wicket as affecting the speed of the ball.
Walk at a steady speed, especially without a particular destination and as an expression of anxiety or annoyance.
Measure (a distance) by walking it and counting the number of steps taken.
(of a trained horse) move in a distinctive lateral gait in which both legs on the same side are lifted together.
Move or develop (something) at a particular rate or speed.
Lead (another runner in a race) in order to establish a competitive speed.
Do something at a slow and steady rate in order to avoid overexertion.
--Examples--
‘Kirov stepped back a pace’
‘her eyes could size up a lad's wallet at fifty paces’
‘I steal with quiet pace’
‘he's an aggressive player with plenty of pace’
‘the ring road allows traffic to flow at a remarkably fast pace’
‘the industrial boom gathered pace’
‘the story rips along at a cracking pace’
‘he can cope with the pace of the Australian wickets’
‘we paced up and down in exasperation’
‘she had been pacing the room’
‘I paced out the dimensions of my new home’
‘he will suddenly pace for a few steps, then go back into normal walk’
‘the action is paced to the beat of a perky march’
‘our fast-paced daily lives’
‘McKenna paced us for four miles’
‘Frank was pacing himself for the long night ahead’
--Word--
pace 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A single step taken when walking or running.
A unit of length representing the distance between two successive steps in walking.
A gait of a horse or other animal, especially one of the recognized trained gaits of a horse.
A person's manner of walking or running.
Speed in walking, running, or moving.
The speed or rate at which something happens or develops.
The state of a wicket as affecting the speed of the ball.
Walk at a steady speed, especially without a particular destination and as an expression of anxiety or annoyance.
Measure (a distance) by walking it and counting the number of steps taken.
(of a trained horse) move in a distinctive lateral gait in which both legs on the same side are lifted together.
Move or develop (something) at a particular rate or speed.
Lead (another runner in a race) in order to establish a competitive speed.
Do something at a slow and steady rate in order to avoid overexertion.
--Examples--
‘Kirov stepped back a pace’

--Word--
pacemaking 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
pacemaker 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or animal who sets the pace at the beginning of a race, sometimes in order to help a runner break a record.
A person who sets standards of achievement for others.
A device for stimulating the heart muscle and regulating its contractions.
The part of the heart muscle (the sino-atrial node) which normally regulates contractions.
The part of an organ or of the body which controls rhythmic physiological activity.
--Examples--
‘he acted as a pacemaker for Bannister when he broke the four-minute mile’
‘unbeaten Rangers are the surprise pacemakers’
‘the brain's circadian pacemaker which regulates our ‘biological clock’’
--Word--
pacemaker 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or animal who sets the pace at the beginning of a race, sometimes in order to help a runner break a record.
A person who sets standards of achievement for others.
A device for stimulating the heart muscle and regulating its contractions.
The part of the heart muscle (the sino-atrial node) which normally regulates contractions.
The part of an organ or of the body which controls rhythmic physiological activity.
--Examples--
‘he acted as a pacemaker for Bannister when he broke the four-minute mile’
‘unbeaten Rangers are the surprise pacemakers’
‘the brain's circadian pacemaker which regulates our ‘biological clock’’

Pachelbel, Johann 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1653–1706), German composer and organist. His compositions include seventy-eight chorale preludes, thirteen settings of the Magnificat, and the Canon and Gigue in D for three violins and continuo.

--Type--

--Word--
Pachydermata 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally, in Cuvier's system of classification: an order of mammals comprising elephants and related animals, and hoofed quadrupeds that do not chew the cud such as rhinoceroses, hippopotamuses, pigs, horses, etc. (now historical). In later use (treated as plural, in form pachydermata): animals belonging to this order; pachyderms.
--Examples--
--Word--
pachydermatocele 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A pendulous skin lesion seen in neurofibromatosis, consisting of a neurofibroma of the dermis or subcutaneous tissue with hypertrophy of overlying skin.

--Word--
pachyodont 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having thick or massive teeth; specifically of, relating to, or designating (the dentition of) a bivalve mollusc characterized by one to three heavy, blunt teeth in the hinge of the shell, as typical of the extinct rudists (sometimes classified in an order Pachyodonta).
A pachyodont bivalve mollusc. rare.

--Word--
pachisi 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A four-handed Indian board game in which cowrie shells are thrown to determine the movements of pieces around the board.
A modern version of the game of pachisi, using four marbles per player and dice.
--Examples--
--Word--
pachytene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The third stage of the prophase of meiosis, following zygotene, during which the paired chromosomes shorten and thicken, the two chromatids of each separate, and exchange of segments between chromatids may occur.
--Examples--
--Word--
pachnolite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hydrated fluoride of aluminium, calcium, and sodium, NaCaAlF₆·H₂O, occurring as small white monoclinic crystals on cryolite.
--Examples--
--Word--
pachometer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various instruments used to measure thickness, originally of the glass of mirrors, but later also of paper, concrete, etc.; (Ophthalmology) an instrument for measuring the thickness of the cornea of the eye, typically using either light from a slit lamp or ultrasound.
--Examples--

pacifico 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Cuba or the Philippines who, in the 1890s, did not actively support the uprisings against the Spanish government. Also occasionally more generally (informal): a pacifist.

--Word--
pacifism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The belief that war and violence are unjustifiable and that all disputes should be settled by peaceful means.
--Examples--
‘there remains a powerful undercurrent of pacifism’
‘the case for absolute pacifism’
--Word--
pacifism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The belief that war and violence are unjustifiable and that all disputes should be settled by peaceful means.
--Examples--
‘there remains a powerful undercurrent of pacifism’
‘the case for absolute pacifism’
--Word--
pacifist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who believes that war and violence are unjustifiable.
Holding the belief that war and violence are unjustifiable.
--Examples--
‘she was a committed pacifist all her life’
--Word--
pacifistic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Holding the belief that war and violence are unjustifiable; peaceable.
--Examples--
‘a gentle, pacifistic people’
‘a pacifistic message’

pacifistically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a pacifistic manner; towards pacifism.

--Word--
pacifist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who believes that war and violence are unjustifiable.
Holding the belief that war and violence are unjustifiable.
--Examples--

--Word--
pace 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A single step taken when walking or running.
A unit of length representing the distance between two successive steps in walking.
A gait of a horse or other animal, especially one of the recognized trained gaits of a horse.
A person's manner of walking or running.
Speed in walking, running, or moving.
The speed or rate at which something happens or develops.
The state of a wicket as affecting the speed of the ball.
Walk at a steady speed, especially without a particular destination and as an expression of anxiety or annoyance.
Measure (a distance) by walking it and counting the number of steps taken.
(of a trained horse) move in a distinctive lateral gait in which both legs on the same side are lifted together.
Move or develop (something) at a particular rate or speed.
Lead (another runner in a race) in order to establish a competitive speed.
Do something at a slow and steady rate in order to avoid overexertion.
--Examples--
‘Kirov stepped back a pace’
‘her eyes could size up a lad's wallet at fifty paces’
‘I steal with quiet pace’
‘he's an aggressive player with plenty of pace’
‘the ring road allows traffic to flow at a remarkably fast pace’
‘the industrial boom gathered pace’
‘the story rips along at a cracking pace’
‘he can cope with the pace of the Australian wickets’
‘we paced up and down in exasperation’
‘she had been pacing the room’
‘I paced out the dimensions of my new home’
‘he will suddenly pace for a few steps, then go back into normal walk’
‘the action is paced to the beat of a perky march’
‘our fast-paced daily lives’
‘McKenna paced us for four miles’
‘Frank was pacing himself for the long night ahead’
--Word--
Pacinian corpuscle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An encapsulated ending of a sensory nerve that acts as a receptor for pressure and vibration.

pack 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small cardboard or paper container and the items contained within it.
A set of playing cards.
A collection of related documents, especially one kept in a folder.
A quantity of fish, fruit, or other foods packed or canned in a particular season.
A group of wild animals, especially wolves, living and hunting together.
A group of hounds kept and used for hunting.
An organized group of Cub Scouts or Brownies.
The main body of competitors following the leader or leaders in a race or competition.
A group of similar things or people, especially one regarded as unpleasant.
A team's forwards considered as a group.
A rucksack.
An expanse of large pieces of floating ice driven together into a nearly continuous mass, as occurs in polar seas.
A hot or cold pad of absorbent material, especially as used for treating an injury.
Fill (a suitcase or bag) with clothes and other items needed for travel.
Place (something) in a container for transport, storage, or sale.
Be capable of being folded up for transport or storage.
Store (something perishable) in a specified substance in order to preserve it.
Cram a large number of things into.
(of a large number of people) crowd into and fill (a place)
Cover, surround, or fill (something)
(of players) form a scrum.
Carry (a gun)
--Examples--
‘a pack of cigarettes’
‘an information pack’
‘a pack of wolves will encircle an ailing prey’
‘the lead hound gives tongue and the pack takes off, following the line of scent’
‘Price broke from the pack to pursue him’
‘Japanese cars are ahead of the pack in this category’
‘the reports were a pack of lies’
‘this unsavoury pack of rogues’
‘a pack of girls in Georgia's class have been making her life a misery’
‘I had doubts about Swansea's pack at the beginning of the season’
‘we picked up our packs and trudged off’
‘I packed a bag and left’
‘she had packed and checked out of the hotel’
‘I packed up my stuff and drove to Detroit’
‘a pneumatic igloo tent that packs away compactly’
‘the organs were packed in ice’
‘it was a large room, packed with beds jammed side by side’
‘a packed Merseyside pub’
‘if you have a nosebleed, try packing the nostrils with cotton wool’
‘we often packed down with only seven men’
‘he packs a gun and keeps it at the ready’
‘a pistol-packing cop’

Combine (various products) for sale as one unit.

Present (someone or something) in an attractive or advantageous way.

--Word--
bearing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person's way of standing or moving.
The way a person behaves or conducts themselves.
Relation; relevance.
The ability to tolerate something bad or to be tolerated.
A part of a machine that allows one part to rotate or move in contact with another part with as little friction as possible.
The direction or position of something, or the direction of movement, relative to a fixed point. It is usually measured in degrees, typically with magnetic north as zero.
Awareness of one's position relative to one's surroundings.
A device or charge.
--Examples--
‘a man of precise military bearing’
‘she has the bearing of a First Lady’
‘the case has no direct bearing on the issues being considered’
‘school was bad enough, but now it's past bearing’
‘the Point is on a bearing of 015°’
‘there were no steeples or bridges from which to take a bearing’
‘he flashed the torch around, trying to get his bearings’
‘armorial bearings’

adjective

--Word--
pad 
--Type--
noun, verb, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A thick piece of soft material, typically used to protect or shape something, or to absorb liquid.
A protective guard worn by a sports player to protect a part of the body.
The fleshy underpart of an animal's foot or of a human finger.
A number of sheets of blank paper fastened together at one edge, used for writing or drawing.
A flat-topped structure or area used for helicopter take-off and landing or for rocket-launching.
A person's home.
A flat area on a track of a printed circuit or on the edge of an integrated circuit to which wires or component leads can be attached to make an electrical connection.
Fill or cover (something) with a soft material in order to protect or shape it or to make it more comfortable.
Lengthen a speech or piece of writing with unnecessary material.
Defraud by adding false items to (an expenses claim or bill)
Put on protective pads in order to play a sport, especially cricket.
(of a batsman) deliberately use one's pads to block a ball.
Walk with steady steps making a soft dull sound.
Tramp along (a road or route) on foot.
The soft dull sound of steady steps.
--Examples--
‘a pad of cotton wool’
‘cricket pads’
‘a dog's pads will bleed profusely if cut’
‘she sketched something on a big white pad’
‘an office building with a helicopter pad’
‘the police raided my pad’
‘a padded envelope’
‘don't pad out your answer to make it seem impressive’
‘padded expenses for government work reaped billions of dollars for the Mafia’
‘at the age of 90, he still pads up ready to bat’
‘Childs fooled the youngster into padding up to a ball which didn't spin away’
‘she padded along the corridor’
‘he was padding the streets’
‘he heard the pad of feet’

A person who or thing which pads.
Textiles. A machine for impregnating fabric with a liquid or paste by pressing between rollers.
Electronics. A capacitor (usually adjustable) connected in series in a tuned circuit in order to improve the tracking with another tuned circuit at low frequencies when the tuning of the two circuits is ganged (as in a superheterodyne).
A kind of bat with a rounded solid wooden head, for playing padder tennis.
--Examples--
--Word--

noun, noun
--Meanings--
A person who or thing which pads.

--Word--
paddle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A short pole with a broad blade at one or both ends, used without a rowlock to move a small boat or canoe through the water.
An act of paddling a boat.
A paddle-shaped instrument used for mixing food, or stirring or mixing in industrial processes.
A short-handled bat used in table tennis.
A paddle-shaped instrument used to administer corporal punishment.
Each of the boards fitted round the circumference of a paddle wheel or mill wheel.
The fin or flipper of an aquatic mammal or bird.
A flat array of solar cells projecting from a spacecraft.
A plastic-covered electrode used in cardiac stimulation.
Move through the water in a boat using a paddle or paddles.
Propel a boat along (a stretch of water) using paddles.
(of bird or other animal) swim with short fast strokes.
Beat (someone) with a paddle as a punishment.
--Examples--
‘we dug in deep with our paddles’
‘paddle strokes’
‘a gentle paddle on sluggish water’
‘she paddled along the coast’
‘he was teaching trainees to paddle canoes’
‘a legal right to paddle Scottish rivers’
‘the swan paddled away’
‘ask the mother if she minds the offspring getting paddled from time to time’

paddlewood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tropical South American tree, Aspidosperma excelsum (family Apocynaceae) (also "paddlewood tree"); the light, elastic wood of this tree, used especially to make paddles for canoes.

paddock 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--

‘horses paddocked on a hillside’

--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1860–1941), Polish pianist, composer, and statesman, prime minister 1919. He was the first prime minister of independent Poland, but resigned after only ten months in office and resumed his musical career.

--Word--
pad 
--Type--
noun, verb, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A thick piece of soft material, typically used to protect or shape something, or to absorb liquid.
A protective guard worn by a sports player to protect a part of the body.
The fleshy underpart of an animal's foot or of a human finger.
A number of sheets of blank paper fastened together at one edge, used for writing or drawing.
A flat-topped structure or area used for helicopter take-off and landing or for rocket-launching.
A person's home.
A flat area on a track of a printed circuit or on the edge of an integrated circuit to which wires or component leads can be attached to make an electrical connection.
Fill or cover (something) with a soft material in order to protect or shape it or to make it more comfortable.
Lengthen a speech or piece of writing with unnecessary material.
Defraud by adding false items to (an expenses claim or bill)
Put on protective pads in order to play a sport, especially cricket.
(of a batsman) deliberately use one's pads to block a ball.
Walk with steady steps making a soft dull sound.
Tramp along (a road or route) on foot.
The soft dull sound of steady steps.
--Examples--
‘a pad of cotton wool’
‘cricket pads’
‘a dog's pads will bleed profusely if cut’
‘she sketched something on a big white pad’
‘an office building with a helicopter pad’
‘the police raided my pad’
‘a padded envelope’
‘don't pad out your answer to make it seem impressive’
‘padded expenses for government work reaped billions of dollars for the Mafia’
‘at the age of 90, he still pads up ready to bat’
‘Childs fooled the youngster into padding up to a ball which didn't spin away’
‘she padded along the corridor’
‘he was padding the streets’
‘he heard the pad of feet’

A kind of bat with a rounded solid wooden head, for playing padder tennis.

--Meanings--

paenula 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In Roman History: a sleeveless hooded cloak. Also: an ecclesiastical garment of similar shape, originally worn outdoors by monks and priests and later used by priests as a chasuble.

--Meanings--
A metrical foot of one long syllable and three short syllables in any order.
--Examples--

paff 
--Type--
exclamation
--Meanings--
Used to represent the sound of an impact, blow, explosion, etc.: ‘bang!’, ‘pow!’.
Used as an expression of contempt: ‘nonsense!’, ‘rubbish!’ rare.

--Word--
pagan 
--Type--
noun, adjective, proper noun
--Meanings--
A person holding religious beliefs other than those of the main world religions.
A non-Christian.
A member of a modern religious movement which seeks to incorporate beliefs or practices from outside the main world religions, especially nature worship.
Relating to pagans or their beliefs.
A town in Burma, situated on the River Irrawaddy south-east of Mandalay. It is the site of an ancient city, founded in about AD 849, which was the capital of a powerful Buddhist dynasty from the 11th to the end of the 13th centuries.
--Examples--
‘a Muslim majority had to live in close proximity to large communities of Christians and pagans’
‘a pagan god’

Paganini, Niccolò 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1782–1840), Italian violinist and composer. His virtuoso violin recitals, including widespread use of pizzicato and harmonics, established him as a major figure of the romantic movement.

--Word--
page 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
One or both sides of a sheet of paper in a book, magazine, newspaper, or other collection of bound sheets.
The material written or printed on a page.
A page of a newspaper or magazine set aside for a particular topic.
A section of stored data, especially that which can be displayed on a screen at one time.
A significant event or period considered as a part of a longer history.
Look through the pages of (a book, magazine, etc.)
Move through and display (text) one page at a time.
Divide (a piece of software or data) into sections, keeping the most frequently accessed in main memory and storing the rest in virtual memory.
Assign numbers to the pages in (a book or periodical); paginate.
--Examples--
‘a book of not less than 40 pages’
‘he was turning the pages of his Sunday newspaper’
‘she silently read several pages’
‘the Letters Page’
‘the vote will form a page in the world's history’
‘she was paging through a pile of Sunday newspapers’
‘a text file reader enables you to page through the authors text file using indexes’
--Word--
pageant 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A public entertainment consisting of a procession of people in elaborate, colourful costumes, or an outdoor performance of a historical scene.
Something regarded as a series of interesting and varied events.
A scene erected on a fixed stage or moving vehicle as a public show.
A beauty contest.
--Examples--
‘they brought the history books to life at the town's pageant’
‘the pageant of public life’
‘it's all part of life's rich pageant’

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Word--
Pagnol, Marcel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1895–1974), French playwright, film director, and writer. As a director Pagnol is best known for the humorous film trilogy Marius (1931), Fanny (1932), and César (1936). His novels include La Gloire de mon père (1957) and Le Chateau de ma mère (1958).

--Word--
Pahari 
--Type--
noun, noun, adjective, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of any of several peoples inhabiting the Himalayan regions of Nepal and northern India.
A group of Indic languages spoken in the Himalayan regions of Nepal and northern India, of which the most important is Nepali.
In South Asia: a person from the hills; specifically a member of any of a number of peoples inhabiting the Himalayan regions of Nepal and northern India.
Any of a group of northern Indo-Aryan languages or their dialects spoken by the Paharis, including Western Pahari, Kumaoni and Garhwali, and Nepali.
Relating to the Pahari or their languages.
Of, relating to, or designating the Paharis or their languages. Also more generally: of or characteristic of the hill or mountain regions of northern India.
--Examples--
--Word--
Paharia 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
In South Asia: a person from the hills; specifically a member of any of a number of indigenous peoples of the hill areas of northern India originally speaking Munda or Dravidian languages.
Any of the Munda or Dravidian languages of the Paharias; an unspecified non-Indo-Aryan dialect spoken in the hills.
Of, relating to, or designating the Paharias or their languages.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pahari 
--Type--
noun, noun, adjective, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of any of several peoples inhabiting the Himalayan regions of Nepal and northern India.
A group of Indic languages spoken in the Himalayan regions of Nepal and northern India, of which the most important is Nepali.
In South Asia: a person from the hills; specifically a member of any of a number of peoples inhabiting the Himalayan regions of Nepal and northern India.
Any of a group of northern Indo-Aryan languages or their dialects spoken by the Paharis, including Western Pahari, Kumaoni and Garhwali, and Nepali.
Relating to the Pahari or their languages.
Of, relating to, or designating the Paharis or their languages. Also more generally: of or characteristic of the hill or mountain regions of northern India.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pahlavi 
--Type--
proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
The name of two shahs of Iran.
Reza (1878–1944), ruled 1925–41; born Reza Khan. An army officer, he took control of the Persian government after a coup in 1921. He was elected Shah in 1925 but abdicated following the occupation of Iran by British and Soviet forces.
Muhammad Reza (1919–80), ruled 1941–79, son of Reza Pahlavi; also known as Reza Shah. Opposition to his regime culminated in the Islamic revolution of 1979 under Ayatollah Khomeini; Reza Shah was forced into exile and died in Egypt.
An Aramaic-based writing system used in Persia from the 2nd century BC to the advent of Islam in the 7th century AD. It was also used for the recording of ancient Avestan sacred texts.
The form of the Middle Persian language written in Pahlavi, used in the Sassanian empire.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pahlavi 
--Type--
proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
The name of two shahs of Iran.
Reza (1878–1944), ruled 1925–41; born Reza Khan. An army officer, he took control of the Persian government after a coup in 1921. He was elected Shah in 1925 but abdicated following the occupation of Iran by British and Soviet forces.
Muhammad Reza (1919–80), ruled 1941–79, son of Reza Pahlavi; also known as Reza Shah. Opposition to his regime culminated in the Islamic revolution of 1979 under Ayatollah Khomeini; Reza Shah was forced into exile and died in Egypt.
An Aramaic-based writing system used in Persia from the 2nd century BC to the advent of Islam in the 7th century AD. It was also used for the recording of ancient Avestan sacred texts.
The form of the Middle Persian language written in Pahlavi, used in the Sassanian empire.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A wooden prayer stick decorated with plumes of feathers and usually painted, used by members of the Hopi North American Indian people in their snake dance and other rituals.
Pan American Health Organization, an agency formed to coordinate and promote the work of health-care organizations in member states throughout the Americas;.

--Word--
pay 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Give (someone) money that is due for work done, goods received, or a debt incurred.
Give (a sum of money) in exchange for goods or work done or to settle a debt.
Hand over or transfer the amount due of (a debt, wages, etc.) to someone.
(of work, an investment, etc.) provide someone with (a sum of money)
(of a business, activity, or an attitude) be profitable or advantageous.
Suffer a misfortune as a consequence of an action.
Give what is due or deserved to.
Give (attention, respect, or a compliment) to (someone)
Make (a visit or call) to (someone)
The money paid to someone for regular work.
--Examples--
‘the traveller paid a guide to show him across’
‘I'll pay for your ticket’
‘the company was rumoured to have paid 450p a share’
‘they paid him an annual retainer’
‘I always prefer to pay all my bills by cheque’
‘jobs that pay £5 an hour’
‘crime doesn't pay’
‘it pays to choose varieties carefully’
‘the destroyer would have to pay with his life’
‘‘I'll pay you for that,’ he snarled’
‘it was his way of paying out Maguire for giving him the push’
‘no one paid them any attention’
‘she has been prevailed upon to pay us a visit’
‘an entitlement to sickness pay’
--Word--
pay 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Give (someone) money that is due for work done, goods received, or a debt incurred.

Hand over or transfer the amount due of (a debt, wages, etc.) to someone.

Suffer a misfortune as a consequence of an action.
Give what is due or deserved to.
Give (attention, respect, or a compliment) to (someone)
Make (a visit or call) to (someone)
The money paid to someone for regular work.

‘an entitlement to sickness pay’
--Word--
payability 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Ability or willingness to pay; (also of a debt, sum of money, etc.) the quality of having to be paid.
Mining. Of a mine or mining area: the capacity to be worked profitably.
More generally: the quality of being profitable or remunerative.
--Examples--
--Word--
payable 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of money) required to be paid; due.
Able to be paid.
Debts owed by a business; liabilities.
--Examples--
‘interest is payable on the money owing’
‘it costs just $195, payable in five monthly instalments’
‘accounts payable (excluding customer refunds and construction payables)’
--Word--
payable 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of money) required to be paid; due.
Able to be paid.
Debts owed by a business; liabilities.
--Examples--

‘it costs just $195, payable in five monthly instalments’
‘accounts payable (excluding customer refunds and construction payables)’

--Word--
payable 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of money) required to be paid; due.
Able to be paid.

--Word--
pay 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Give (someone) money that is due for work done, goods received, or a debt incurred.
Give (a sum of money) in exchange for goods or work done or to settle a debt.
Hand over or transfer the amount due of (a debt, wages, etc.) to someone.
(of work, an investment, etc.) provide someone with (a sum of money)
(of a business, activity, or an attitude) be profitable or advantageous.
Suffer a misfortune as a consequence of an action.
Give what is due or deserved to.
Give (attention, respect, or a compliment) to (someone)
Make (a visit or call) to (someone)
The money paid to someone for regular work.
--Examples--
‘the traveller paid a guide to show him across’
‘I'll pay for your ticket’
‘the company was rumoured to have paid 450p a share’
‘they paid him an annual retainer’
‘I always prefer to pay all my bills by cheque’
‘jobs that pay £5 an hour’
‘crime doesn't pay’
‘it pays to choose varieties carefully’
‘the destroyer would have to pay with his life’
‘‘I'll pay you for that,’ he snarled’
‘it was his way of paying out Maguire for giving him the push’
‘no one paid them any attention’
‘she has been prevailed upon to pay us a visit’
‘an entitlement to sickness pay’
--Word--
pay as you go 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A system of meeting costs as they arise or paying for a service before it is used.
--Examples--
‘a pay-as-you-go phone’
‘healthcare on a pay-as-you-go basis’
--Word--
payback 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Profit from an investment equal to the initial outlay.
An act of revenge or retaliation.
--Examples--
‘a long time lag between investment and payback’
‘we aim to achieve a payback of the cost within eight years’
‘the drive-by shootings are mainly paybacks’

paid 
--Type--
verb, adjective
--Meanings--
(of work or leave) for or during which one receives pay.
(of a person in a specified occupation) in receipt of pay.
--Examples--
‘five weeks paid holiday a year’
‘a paid informer’

--Word--
Paige, Satchel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1906–82), US baseball player; born Leroy Robert Paige. A pitcher for the Negro leagues 1924–47 and the major leagues, he threw 55 career no-hitters. He pitched for the Cleveland Indians 1948–49, the St. Louis Browns 1951–53, and the Kansas City Athletics 1965. Baseball Hall of Fame (1971).
--Examples--

payload 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The part of a vehicle's load, especially an aircraft's, from which revenue is derived; passengers and cargo.
Equipment, personnel, or satellites carried by a spacecraft.
An explosive warhead carried by an aircraft or missile.
The actual information or message in transmitted data, as opposed to automatically generated metadata.
The effects of a virus on a computer system.

noun

--Word--
pain 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Highly unpleasant physical sensation caused by illness or injury.
Mental suffering or distress.
An annoying or tedious person or thing.
Great care or trouble.
Cause mental or physical pain to.
(of a part of the body) hurt.
--Examples--
‘she's in great pain’
‘chest pains’
‘the pain of loss’
‘she's a pain’
‘it's not a huge problem—just a bit of a pain’
‘she took pains to see that everyone ate well’
‘it pains me to say this’
‘her legs had been paining her’
‘sometimes my right hand would pain’

--Word--
Stewart, Payne 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1957–1999), US golfer; full name William Payne Stewart. His championship titles include the PGA (1989), and the US Open (1991, 1999). He owned a clothing line that featured his familiar plus fours (baggy knickers worn as traditional golfing attire). Stewart died in an airplane crash.
--Examples--

Great care or trouble.
Cause mental or physical pain to.
(of a part of the body) hurt.
--Examples--
‘she's in great pain’
‘chest pains’
‘the pain of loss’
‘she's a pain’
‘it's not a huge problem—just a bit of a pain’
‘she took pains to see that everyone ate well’
‘it pains me to say this’
‘her legs had been paining her’
‘sometimes my right hand would pain’

--Word--
paip 
--Type--
noun

--Word--
pair 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A set of two things used together or regarded as a unit.
Two playing cards of the same denomination.
Two people related in some way or considered together.
The second member of a pair in relation to the first.
A mated couple of animals.
Two horses harnessed side by side.
Either or both of two members of a legislative assembly on opposite sides who absent themselves from voting by mutual arrangement, leaving the relative position of the parties unaffected.
An article consisting of two joined or corresponding parts not used separately.
Put together or join to form a pair.
(of animals) form a pair for breeding purposes.
Form a romantic or sexual relationship.
Give (a member of a legislative assembly) another member as a pair, to allow both to absent themselves from a vote without affecting the result.
--Examples--
‘a pair of gloves’
‘three pairs of shoes’
‘Jacobs had two pairs’
‘a company run by a pair of brothers’
‘get out, the pair of you’
‘each course member tries to persuade his pair of the merits of his model’
‘76 pairs of red kites’
‘she enjoys driving her pair’
‘one minister was flatly refused a pair by his Tory opposite number’
‘a pair of jeans’
‘a pair of scissors’
‘a cardigan paired with a matching skirt’
‘killer whales pair for life’
‘my friends had paired off and I was the only one playing the field’
‘arrangements are usually made between the party whips for an absent member on one side to be paired with an absentee on the other’
--Word--
paired 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Occurring in pairs or as a pair.
--Examples--
‘a characteristic arrangement of paired fins’
--Word--
rent 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A tenant's regular payment to a landlord for the use of property or land.
A sum paid for the hire of equipment.
Pay someone for the use of (something, typically property, land, or a car)
(of an owner) allow someone to use (something) in return for payment.
Be let or hired out at a specified rate.
--Examples--
‘I cannot even afford to pay the rent on this flat’
‘the rise in council house rents’
‘they rented a house together in Sussex’
‘he purchased a large tract of land and rented it out to local farmers’
‘skis or snowboards rent for $60–80 for six days’

(of animals) form a pair for breeding purposes.
Form a romantic or sexual relationship.
Give (a member of a legislative assembly) another member as a pair, to allow both to absent themselves from a vote without affecting the result.
--Examples--
‘a pair of gloves’
‘three pairs of shoes’
‘Jacobs had two pairs’
‘a company run by a pair of brothers’
‘get out, the pair of you’
‘each course member tries to persuade his pair of the merits of his model’
‘76 pairs of red kites’
‘she enjoys driving her pair’
‘one minister was flatly refused a pair by his Tory opposite number’
‘a pair of jeans’
‘a pair of scissors’
‘a cardigan paired with a matching skirt’
‘killer whales pair for life’
‘my friends had paired off and I was the only one playing the field’
‘arrangements are usually made between the party whips for an absent member on one side to be paired with an absentee on the other’
--Word--
pairwise 
--Type--
adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
Involving or forming a pair or pairs.
In pairs.
--Examples--
‘all possible pairwise combinations of the four operations’
‘cells were incubated singly or pairwise’
--Word--
pais 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
"in pais": in or within the country; relating to or designating actions, matters, etc., which are legally recognized despite not being formally recorded or performed. Also (and now frequently) in "estoppel in pais": estoppel in respect of things expressed or implied by one party, which may not subsequently be disavowed to the detriment of the other party.
--Examples--
--Word--
pay 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Give (someone) money that is due for work done, goods received, or a debt incurred.
Give (a sum of money) in exchange for goods or work done or to settle a debt.
Hand over or transfer the amount due of (a debt, wages, etc.) to someone.
(of work, an investment, etc.) provide someone with (a sum of money)
(of a business, activity, or an attitude) be profitable or advantageous.
Suffer a misfortune as a consequence of an action.
Give what is due or deserved to.
Give (attention, respect, or a compliment) to (someone)
Make (a visit or call) to (someone)
The money paid to someone for regular work.
--Examples--
‘the traveller paid a guide to show him across’
‘I'll pay for your ticket’
‘the company was rumoured to have paid 450p a share’
‘they paid him an annual retainer’
‘I always prefer to pay all my bills by cheque’
‘jobs that pay £5 an hour’
‘crime doesn't pay’
‘it pays to choose varieties carefully’
‘the destroyer would have to pay with his life’
‘‘I'll pay you for that,’ he snarled’
‘it was his way of paying out Maguire for giving him the push’
‘no one paid them any attention’
‘she has been prevailed upon to pay us a visit’
‘an entitlement to sickness pay’

Palaearctic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a zoogeographical region comprising Eurasia north of the Himalayas, together with North Africa and the temperate part of the Arabian peninsula. The fauna is closely related to that of the Nearctic region.
The Palaearctic region.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaechinoid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: an extinct echinoid (sea urchin) belonging to the former subclass Palaechinoidea, comprising all or most Palaeozoic echinoids, typically having more than two series of interambulacral plates. Now usually: a member of a more restricted group of Palaeozoic echinoids (sometimes classified as an order Palaechinoida) including the genus Palaechinus.

--Examples--
--Word--
palaeoniscoid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or characteristic of a large group of extinct actinopterygian fishes with heterocercal tails, mainly of Palaeozoic times (thought to be related to the modern sturgeons and paddlefishes); specifically designating the diamond-shaped ganoid scales characteristic of these fishes.
A palaeoniscoid fish; specifically one of the suborder Palaeoniscoidei.

--Word--
palaeontology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The branch of science concerned with fossil animals and plants.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeontologist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeopathology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The branch of science concerned with the pathological conditions found in ancient human and animal remains.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeopedology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The behaviour and characteristics of soils in the geological past; the branch of science that deals with this.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeophis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A primitive snake of the extinct genus Palaeophis, of the late Cretaceous or early Tertiary. Also (in form Palaeophis): the genus itself.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeophysiography 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The physical and topographical features of the earth's surface at some time in the past; the branch of science that deals with these.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeophysiology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The physiology of extinct and fossil organisms.
--Examples--
--Word--
Palaeophytic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Originally: designating a division of geological time during which land plants evolved and lower vascular plants (ferns, horsetails, cycads, etc.) became dominant. Now also: designating or relating to the type of plant or vegetation characteristic of this time (though overlapping in occurrence with the later Mesophytic flora).
Chiefly with the. The Palaeophytic era.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeophytology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Palaeobotany.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeophytological 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to palaeophytology; palaeobotanical.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeoplain 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A peneplain which existed at some time in the past and became overlain by other strata, being now buried or re-exposed.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeopsychology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The study of the evolutionary development of the mind, or of the mind as it was in earlier stages of human development; the psychological characteristics of the prehistoric human mind.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeopsychological 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to palaeopsychology.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeornithology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The branch of palaeontology or ornithology that deals with extinct and fossil birds.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeornithological 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to palaeornithology.

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the palaeostriatum.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeostriatum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The phylogenetically older portion of the corpus striatum, corresponding (in mammals) to the globus pallidus.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeotechnic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating, relating to, or characterized by an early stage of industrial and technological development, especially as dominated by heavy machinery and the exploitation of mineral resources and fossil fuels. Also, in wider use: designating or relating to technology which is regarded as old-fashioned or outmoded.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeothalamus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The phylogenetically older portion of the thalamus, usually taken to include its anterior and medial parts.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeothere 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An ungulate mammal of an extinct group of perissodactyls, including the genus Palaeotherium, which lived in Eocene and Oligocene times.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeotherium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fossil ungulate mammal (palaeothere) of the genus Palaeotherium, regarded as an early relative of the horse. Also (in form Palaeotherium): the genus itself.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeotype 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A system for phonetic transcription which uses only unmodified Roman letters and other commonly used symbols.
--Examples--
--Word--
Palaeotropical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a phytogeographical kingdom comprising Africa, tropical Asia, New Guinea, and many Pacific islands (excluding Australia and New Zealand).
Relating to or denoting a zoogeographical region comprising the tropical parts of the Old World.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeo-volcanic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating volcanic rocks of a period older than the Tertiary.

adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the era between the Precambrian aeon and the Mesozoic era.
The Palaeozoic era or the system of rocks deposited during it.

palagonite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A yellowish or brownish siliceous substance formed by the hydration and chemical alteration of basaltic glass, and occurring in vitreous basaltic tuffs that have undergone rapid chilling.
--Examples--

--Type--

--Word--
palay 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Rice that has not been husked.
The African rubber vine Cryptostegia grandiflora (family Asclepiadaceae), a woody twining plant containing a milky latex, widely cultivated in the tropics and a serious weed in northern Australia. More fully "palay rubber" and "palay rubber vine".
--Examples--
‘her husband harvested only three sacks of palay’
--Word--
Palaic 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An ancient Indo-European language of the Anatolian subgroup, closely allied to Hittite and Luwian, and known from cuneiform inscriptions of the 2nd millennium b.c. found in the Hittite archives.
Of, relating to, written in, or attested in Palaic.

palatal 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the palate.
(of a speech sound) made by placing the blade of the tongue against or near the hard palate (e.g. y in yes).

--Examples--

palatalization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
palatalize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make (a speech sound) palatal, especially by changing a velar to a palatal by moving the point of contact between tongue and palate further forward in the mouth.
(of a speech sound) become palatal.
--Examples--
‘the sound is palatalized in some dialects’
‘the frontal allophone of ‘g’ appears to have palatalized first’
--Word--
palatalize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make (a speech sound) palatal, especially by changing a velar to a palatal by moving the point of contact between tongue and palate further forward in the mouth.
(of a speech sound) become palatal.
--Examples--
‘the sound is palatalized in some dialects’
‘the frontal allophone of ‘g’ appears to have palatalized first’

palatine 
--Type--
adjective, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of an official or feudal lord) having local authority that elsewhere belongs only to a sovereign.
(of a territory) subject to palatine authority.
Relating to the palate or the palatine bone.
Each of two bones within the skull forming parts of the eye socket, the nasal cavity, and the hard palate.

palato-velar 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a speech sound: articulated with the tongue simultaneously or successively touching the palate and velum. Also (occasionally): either palatal or velar.
--Examples--
--Word--
palato-alveolar 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Physical Anthropology and Anatomy. Of or relating to the palate and the alveolar ridge; palatomaxillary.
Phonetics. Of a consonant: articulated with the tongue raised towards the palate and the tip of the tongue against the alveolar ridge.
Phonetics. A palato-alveolar consonant.
--Examples--
--Word--
palato-dental 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A palato-dental consonant.
--Examples--
--Word--
palatoglossal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or involving the palate and the tongue; specifically of or relating to the palatoglossus muscle. Also as noun: the palatoglossus muscle (rare).
--Examples--
--Word--
palatoglossus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A muscle that arises from the palate and inserts into the side of the tongue, forming the anterior arch of the fauces and serving to raise the back of the tongue and constrict the fauces.
--Examples--
--Word--
palatogram 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A diagram produced by palatography.
--Examples--
--Word--
palatograph 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An instrument for recording contact between the tongue and the roof of the mouth in the articulation of speech sounds.
--Examples--
--Word--
palatography 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various techniques for recording contact between the tongue and the roof of the mouth in the articulation of speech sounds.
--Examples--
--Word--
palatomaxillary 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Anatomy, Zoology, and Physical Anthropology. Of, relating to, or connecting the palate and the maxilla.

palatonasal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the palate and the nose.

--Word--
palatopharyngeal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or involving the palate and the pharynx; (also) of or relating to the palatopharyngeus muscle. Also as noun: the palatopharyngeus muscle (rare).
--Examples--
--Word--
palatopharyngeus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A muscle that arises from the palate and inserts into the thyroid cartilage, forming the posterior arch of the fauces and serving to constrict the fauces and draw the larynx and pharynx upwards.
--Examples--
--Word--
palatoplasty 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Plastic surgery of the palate, specifically repair of a cleft palate; an instance of this.
--Examples--
--Word--
palatopterygoid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or consisting of the palatine and pterygoid bones or cartilages.
A bone of the upper jaw of some vertebrates, composed of a fused palatine and pterygoid; (in certain fishes) a cartilage equivalent to this.
--Examples--
--Word--
palatoquadrate 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or consisting of the palatine and quadrate bones or cartilages.
A bone of the upper jaw of some vertebrates, composed of a fused palatine and quadrate; (in certain fishes) a cartilage equivalent to this.

Palau 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A group of islands in the western Pacific Ocean, an independent republic since 1990; population 21,000 (estimated 2015); capital, Ngerulmud. It was part of the Pacific Islands Trust Territory administered by the US 1947–80.

--Word--
pale 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Light in colour or shade; containing little colour or pigment.
(of a person or their complexion) having less colour than usual, typically as a result of shock, fear, or ill health.
(of a light) not strong or bright.
Inferior or unimpressive.
Become pale in one's face from shock or fear.
Seem or become less important.
--Examples--
‘choose pale floral patterns for walls’
‘she looked pale and drawn’
‘a pale dawn’
‘the new cheese is a pale imitation of continental cheeses’
‘I paled at the thought of what she might say’
‘all else pales by comparison’
--Word--

--Word--
Palaearctic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a zoogeographical region comprising Eurasia north of the Himalayas, together with North Africa and the temperate part of the Arabian peninsula. The fauna is closely related to that of the Nearctic region.
The Palaearctic region.

--Word--
bright 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
Giving out or reflecting much light; shining.
Full of light.
(of a period of time) having sunny, cloudless weather.
(of colour) vivid and bold.
Having a vivid colour.
Intelligent and quick-witted.
Cheerful and lively.
(of someone's future) likely to be successful and happy.
(of sound) clear, vibrant, and typically high-pitched.
Brightly.
Bold and vivid colours.
Headlights switched to full beam.
--Examples--
‘the sun was dazzlingly bright’
‘her bright, dark eyes’
‘the rooms are bright and spacious’
‘the long, bright days of June’
‘the bright green leaves’
‘a bright tie’
‘a bright idea’
‘a bright young journalist’
‘at breakfast she would be persistently bright and chirpy’
‘she gave a bright smile’
‘these young people have a bright future ahead of them’
‘her voice is fresh and bright’
‘a full moon shining bright’
‘a choice of colours from pastels through to brights’
‘he turned the brights on and we drove along the dirt road’

--Word--
pale 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Light in colour or shade; containing little colour or pigment.
(of a person or their complexion) having less colour than usual, typically as a result of shock, fear, or ill health.
(of a light) not strong or bright.
Inferior or unimpressive.
Become pale in one's face from shock or fear.
Seem or become less important.
--Examples--
‘choose pale floral patterns for walls’
‘she looked pale and drawn’
‘a pale dawn’
‘the new cheese is a pale imitation of continental cheeses’
‘I paled at the thought of what she might say’
‘all else pales by comparison’

Palenque 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The site of a former Mayan city in south-eastern Mexico, south-east of present-day Villahermosa. The well-preserved ruins of the city, which existed from about AD 300 to 900, include notable examples of Mayan architecture and extensive hieroglyphic texts.

--Word--
Paleo diet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A diet based on the types of foods presumed to have been eaten by early humans, consisting chiefly of meat, fish, vegetables, and fruit and excluding dairy or cereal products and processed food.
--Examples--
‘I've recently started the Paleo diet and have also given up caffeine’

--Word--
Palaeophytic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Originally: designating a division of geological time during which land plants evolved and lower vascular plants (ferns, horsetails, cycads, etc.) became dominant. Now also: designating or relating to the type of plant or vegetation characteristic of this time (though overlapping in occurrence with the later Mesophytic flora).
Chiefly with the. The Palaeophytic era.
--Examples--
--Word--
Palaeo-Siberian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Denoting or belonging to a group of languages spoken in eastern Siberia, formerly thought to constitute a phylum or superfamily. The most important is Chukchi.
--Examples--
--Word--
palaeosol 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A stratum or soil horizon which was formed as a soil in a past geological age.

adjective

Relating to or denoting a phytogeographical kingdom comprising Africa, tropical Asia, New Guinea, and many Pacific islands (excluding Australia and New Zealand).
Relating to or denoting a zoogeographical region comprising the tropical parts of the Old World.

palette 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A thin board or slab on which an artist lays and mixes colours.
The range of colours used by a particular artist or in a particular picture.
The range or variety of tonal or instrumental colour in a musical piece.
(in computer graphics) the range of colours or shapes available to the user.

--Examples--
‘Pollock's hard, bright palette’
‘he commands the sort of tonal palette which this music needs’
‘our Essential Eyes palette has eight mix-and-match shades’

--Word--
paliform 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling or having the form of a stake; specifically (in corals) of the nature of a palus; designating or relating to a vertical projection resembling a palus but joined to the adjacent septum (especially in "paliform lobe", "paliform tooth").

palygorskite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A silicate of magnesium and aluminium that occurs as soft, light-coloured, fibrous layers, and has a structure based on silica tetrahedra arranged in double chains.
--Examples--

palilalia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A speech disorder characterized by involuntary repetition of words, phrases, or sentences.
--Examples--

palilogy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The (especially immediate) repetition of a word or phrase, usually for emphasis; (occasionally) an instance of this.

palimbacchius 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A metrical foot consisting of three syllables, two long and one short.

--Word--
palimony 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Compensation made by one member of an unmarried couple to the other after separation.
--Examples--
‘she is suing for palimony’
‘a palimony trial in California’
--Word--
palimpsest 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A manuscript or piece of writing material on which later writing has been superimposed on effaced earlier writing.
Something reused or altered but still bearing visible traces of its earlier form.
--Examples--
‘Sutton Place is a palimpsest of the taste of successive owners’

palimpsestic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
palimpsest 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A manuscript or piece of writing material on which later writing has been superimposed on effaced earlier writing.
Something reused or altered but still bearing visible traces of its earlier form.
--Examples--
‘Sutton Place is a palimpsest of the taste of successive owners’

palinal

adjective
--Meanings--
Characterized by or involving backward motion, especially of the lower jaw in chewing. Contrasted with proal.

palinody 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An ode or song in which the author retracts a view or sentiment expressed in a former poem; (more generally) a recantation or retraction, especially of a formal kind.
--Examples--
--Word--
palinodial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the nature of a retraction or recantation.
--Examples--
--Word--
palinodic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to a palinode, renunciatory.
Prosody. Designating verse in which two corresponding stanzas or stanzaic groups are separated by two others, also of a corresponding form, but differing from the former.
--Examples--
--Word--
palinodist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A writer of palinodes; a composer of palinodic verse.
--Examples--
--Word--
palynology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The study of pollen grains and other spores, especially as found in archaeological or geological deposits. Pollen extracted from such deposits may be used for radiocarbon dating and for studying past climates and environments by identifying plants then growing.
--Examples--
--Word--
palynologically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
By means of palynology; from the point of view of palynology.
--Examples--
--Word--
palynological 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
palynologically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
By means of palynology; from the point of view of palynology.
--Examples--
--Word--
palynologist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
palynomorph 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A microscopic fossil found in a palynological sample, such as a pollen grain or spore, a protist, or a fragment of a larger organism.
--Examples--
--Word--
pali 
--Type--
noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
(in Hawaii) a cliff.
An Indic language, closely related to Sanskrit, in which the sacred texts of Theravada Buddhism are written. Pali developed in northern India in the 5th–2nd centuries BC.
Relating to Pali.
--Examples--
--Word--
palisade 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A fence of wooden stakes or iron railings fixed in the ground, forming an enclosure or defence.
A strong pointed wooden stake fixed in the ground with others in a close row, used as a defence.
A line of high cliffs.
A ridge of high basalt cliffs that line the western side of the Hudson River, in New Jersey and in New York, beginning across from New York City in New Jersey and extending north to Newburgh in New York.
Enclose or provide (a building or place) with a palisade.
--Examples--
‘at this time fortifications consisted mainly of earth banks and wooden palisades’
‘a palisaded earthwork once lay across the neck of the promontory’

--Meanings--
(c.1510–90), French potter, known for his richly coloured earthenware decorated with reliefs of plants and animals.

--Word--
paliurus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: the spiny shrub Paliurus spina-christi, also called Christ's thorn. Later also: any of the Eurasian shrubs and small trees which constitute the genus Paliurus (family Rhamnaceae); (in form Paliurus) the genus itself.

--Word--
pall 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A cloth spread over a coffin, hearse, or tomb.
A dark cloud of smoke, dust, etc.
Something regarded as enveloping a situation with an air of gloom or fear.
An ecclesiastical pallium.
A Y-shaped charge representing the front of an ecclesiastical pallium.
Become less appealing or interesting through familiarity.
--Examples--
‘a pall of black smoke hung over the quarry’
‘torture and murder have cast a pall of terror over the villages’
‘the novelty of the quiet life palled’

--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 46, a rare silvery-white metal resembling platinum.
A safeguard or source of protection.
--Examples--
‘he regarded himself as the palladium of the American cause’
--Word--
Palladian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the neoclassical style of Andrea Palladio, in particular with reference to the phase of English architecture from c.1715, when there was a revival of interest in Palladio and his English follower, Inigo Jones, and a reaction against the baroque.
--Examples--
--Word--
Palladianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
palladic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or containing palladium, especially in the trivalent or tetravalent state.
--Examples--
--Word--
Palladio, Andrea 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1508–80), Italian architect. He led a revival of classical architecture, in particular promoting the Roman ideals of harmonic proportions and symmetrical planning. A notable example of his many villas, palaces, and churches is the church of San Giorgio Maggiore in Venice.

pallet 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A straw mattress.
A crude or makeshift bed.
A portable platform on which goods can be stacked, stored, and moved.
A flat wooden blade with a handle, used to shape clay or plaster.
A projection on a machine part, serving to change the mode of motion of a wheel.
(in a clock or watch) a projection transmitting motion from an escapement to a pendulum or balance wheel.
The diminutive of the pale, a narrow vertical strip, usually borne in groups of two or three.

--Word--
palliate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make (a disease or its symptoms) less severe without removing the cause.
Disguise the seriousness of (an offence)
Allay or moderate (fears or suspicions)
--Examples--
‘treatment works by palliating symptoms’
‘pharmaceutical drugs palliate, they do not cure’
‘there is no way to excuse or palliate his dirty deed’
‘this eliminated, or at least palliated, suspicions aroused by German unity’

--Word--
palliative 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of a medicine or medical care) relieving pain without dealing with the cause of the condition.
(of an action) intended to alleviate a problem without addressing the underlying cause.
A palliative medicine, measure, etc.
--Examples--
‘orthodox medicines tend to be palliative rather than curative’
‘short-term palliative measures had been taken’
‘antibiotics and other palliatives’
‘social projects presented as palliatives for the urban crisis’

--Word--
pallium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A woollen vestment conferred by the Pope on an archbishop, consisting of a narrow circular band placed round the shoulders with a short lappet hanging from front and back.
A man's large rectangular cloak, especially as worn by Greek philosophical and religious teachers.
The mantle of a mollusc or brachiopod.
The cerebral cortex, especially of a mammal.

--Word--
pall-mall 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A 16th- and 17th-century game in which a boxwood ball was driven through an iron ring suspended at the end of a long alley. The street Pall Mall in London was on the site of a pall-mall alley.
--Examples--
--Word--
pall-mall 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A 16th- and 17th-century game in which a boxwood ball was driven through an iron ring suspended at the end of a long alley. The street Pall Mall in London was on the site of a pall-mall alley.

noun

Become less appealing or interesting through familiarity.
--Examples--
‘a pall of black smoke hung over the quarry’
‘torture and murder have cast a pall of terror over the villages’
‘the novelty of the quiet life palled’
--Word--
palm 
--Type--
noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
An unbranched evergreen tree of tropical and warm regions, with a crown of very long feathered or fan-shaped leaves, and typically having old leaf scars forming a regular pattern on the trunk.
A leaf of a palm tree awarded as a prize or viewed as a symbol of victory.
The inner surface of the hand between the wrist and fingers.
A part of a glove that covers the palm.
A hard shield worn on the hand by sailmakers to protect the palm.
The palmate part of a deer's antler.
Conceal (a small object) in the hand, especially as part of a trick or theft.
(of a goalkeeper) deflect (the ball) with the palm of the hand.
--Examples--
‘the consensus was that the palm should go to Doerner’
‘she held the bird in the palm of her hand’
‘a palm print’
‘batting gloves with leather reinforced palms’
‘he was a deft hand with the palm and needle’
‘he would spin wild tales while palming your wristwatch’
‘Jason palmed the ball out of danger’

--Word--
bearing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person's way of standing or moving.
The way a person behaves or conducts themselves.
Relation; relevance.
The ability to tolerate something bad or to be tolerated.
A part of a machine that allows one part to rotate or move in contact with another part with as little friction as possible.
The direction or position of something, or the direction of movement, relative to a fixed point. It is usually measured in degrees, typically with magnetic north as zero.
Awareness of one's position relative to one's surroundings.
A device or charge.
--Examples--
‘a man of precise military bearing’
‘she has the bearing of a First Lady’
‘the case has no direct bearing on the issues being considered’
‘school was bad enough, but now it's past bearing’
‘the Point is on a bearing of 015°’
‘there were no steeples or bridges from which to take a bearing’
‘he flashed the torch around, trying to get his bearings’
‘armorial bearings’

--Word--
palmella 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of the unicellular green algae constituting (or formerly included in) the genus Palmella (family Tetrasporaceae or Palmellaceae), which divide to form colonies of non-motile cells embedded in mucilaginous masses; (in form Palmella) the genus itself.
A phase in the life cycle of various single-celled algae or unicellular flagellates during which they divide by fission to form colonies of non-motile cells within a mucilaginous matrix; an organism in this stage of its life cycle; the colony thus formed. Frequently attributive, especially in "palmella stage".
--Examples--
--Word--
palmelloid 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling or characteristic of algae of the genus Palmella; specifically of, relating to, or designating the palmella stage.
--Examples--

palolo worm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A marine bristle worm which swarms in response to changes in light intensity, particularly that of the moon. The worm's posterior segments detach themselves and swim to the surface where the reproductive cells are released into the sea.
--Examples--

--Word--
palsy 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Paralysis, especially that which is accompanied by involuntary tremors.
A condition of incapacity or helplessness.
Affect with paralysis and involuntary tremors.
--Examples--
‘a kind of palsy had seized him’
‘is the calmness of philosophy, or the palsy of insensibility, to be looked for?’
‘she feels as if the muscles on her face are palsied’
‘the old boy network laid its palsied hand upon the business of wealth creation’

--Type--
adjective, noun

Pamir Mountains 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A mountain system of central Asia, centred in Tajikistan and extending into Kyrgyzstan, Afghanistan, Pakistan, and western China. The highest peak in the Pamirs, Ismail Samani Peak in Tajikistan, rises to 7,495 m (24,590 ft).

pampean 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Geology and Palaeontology (In form Pampean). Designating or relating to a series of sedimentary deposits of the Pleistocene epoch present across much of the pampas of South America, and the fauna (especially mammals) extant during their period of deposition.
Generally. Of, relating to, or characteristic of the pampas, or the region of South America dominated by the pampas.

Pamplona 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in northern Spain, capital of the former kingdom and modern region of Navarre; population 197,275 (2008). It is noted for the fiesta of San Fermin, held there in July, which is celebrated with the running of bulls through the streets of the city.

pampootie

noun

--Word--
pan 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A metal container used for cooking food in.
An amount of something contained in a pan.
A bowl fitted at either end of a pair of scales.
The bowl of a toilet.
A large container used in a technical or manufacturing process for subjecting a material to heat or a mechanical or chemical process.
A steel drum.
A shallow bowl in which gold is separated from gravel and mud by agitation and washing.
A part of the lock that held the priming in old types of gun.
A hollow in the ground in which water may collect or in which a deposit of salt remains after water has evaporated.
A hard stratum of compacted soil.
A person's face.
Criticize severely.
Wash gravel in a pan to separate out (gold)
(of gravel) yield gold.
--Examples--
‘heat the olive oil in a heavy pan’
‘a pan of hot water’
‘she sifted flour on to the wide brass pan of the scales’
‘peroxide is what they put down the lavatory to disinfect the pan’
‘he washed the gold-free surface gravel out over the rim of the pan’
‘prime the pan, pour the powder down the barrel, then ram in the cartridge's paper and ball’
‘heavy spikes can be useful in breaking a surface pan in grassland’
‘the movie was panned by the critics’
‘the old-timers panned gold’
‘prospectors panned for gold in the Yukon’

--Examples--
--Word--
Panay 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island in the central Philippines; population 3,403,900 (est. 2007); chief town, Iloilo.

panama 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A wide-brimmed hat of strawlike material, originally made from the leaves of a particular tropical palm tree, worn chiefly by men.
A country in Central America; population 3,900,000 (estimated 2015); official language, Spanish; capital, Panama City.

--Word--
Arabia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A peninsula of south-western Asia, largely desert, lying between the Red Sea and the Persian Gulf and bounded on the north by Jordan and Iraq. The original homeland of the Arabs and the historic centre of Islam, it comprises the states of Saudi Arabia, Yemen, Oman, Bahrain, Kuwait, Qatar, and the United Arab Emirates.

Panathenaea 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An important civic festival formerly held annually in Athens in honour of Athene, the patron goddess of the city, including a great procession through the agora to the Acropolis, followed by numerous animal sacrifices.

--Word--
panax 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: any of various plants reputed to have universal healing powers, especially Opopanax chironium. Later (in form Panax): a genus of perennial herbs of the family Araliaceaenative to eastern Asia and North America, including ginseng, P. ginseng, and American ginseng, P. quinquefolius, whose roots are used medicinally; (also panax) a plant of this genus.

--Word--
pancake 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A thin, flat cake of batter, fried on both sides in a pan and typically rolled up with a sweet or savoury filling.
Make-up consisting of a flat solid layer of compressed powder, used especially in the theatre.
(with reference to an aircraft) make or cause to make a pancake landing.
Flatten or become flattened.
--Examples--
‘crispy pancakes filled with cheese’
‘pancake batter’
‘the plane landed, pancaking down on the runway’
‘Hurley's car was pancaked’

--Meanings--

panchax 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a fish of the former genus Panchax of small Old World tropical killifishes (family Poeciliidae); (in form Panchax) the genus itself. In later use more widely: any of numerous killifishes, especially of the genus Aplocheilus, and including many popular aquarium species.

china 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A fine white or translucent vitrified ceramic material.
Household tableware or other objects made from china or a similar material.
A friend.
A country in East Asia, the fourth largest and most populous in the world; population 1,376,000,000 (estimated 2015); language, Chinese (of which Mandarin is the official form); capital, Beijing.

‘a china cup’
‘she had begun to remove the breakfast china’
--Word--
Villa, Pancho 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1878–1923), Mexican revolutionary; born Doroteo Arango. After playing a prominent role in the revolution of 1910–11 he overthrew the dictatorial regime of General Victoriano Huerta in 1914 together with Venustiano Carranza, but then rebelled against Carranza's regime with Emiliano Zapata.

--Word--
pancratium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Greek History. A sporting contest combining wrestling and boxing. Also (occasionally) figurative.
Botany. Any of various bulbous African, Mediterranean, and South Asian plants of the genus Pancratium (family Amaryllidaceae), bearing umbels of fragrant white flowers; especially the sea-daffodil, P. maritimum, of southern Europe. Also (in form Pancratium): the genus itself.
--Examples--

--Type--

--Meanings--
= pancratiast.
--Examples--
--Word--
pancratium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Greek History. A sporting contest combining wrestling and boxing. Also (occasionally) figurative.
Botany. Any of various bulbous African, Mediterranean, and South Asian plants of the genus Pancratium (family Amaryllidaceae), bearing umbels of fragrant white flowers; especially the sea-daffodil, P. maritimum, of southern Europe. Also (in form Pancratium): the genus itself.

--Word--
pancreas 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large gland behind the stomach which secretes digestive enzymes into the duodenum. Embedded in the pancreas are the islets of Langerhans, which secrete into the blood the hormones insulin and glucagon.
--Examples--
--Word--
pancreas 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large gland behind the stomach which secretes digestive enzymes into the duodenum. Embedded in the pancreas are the islets of Langerhans, which secrete into the blood the hormones insulin and glucagon.

pandanus

noun
--Meanings--
A tropical tree or shrub with a twisted and branched stem, stilt roots, spiral tufts of long, narrow spiny leaves, and fibrous edible fruit.

pandaric 
--Type--

--Examples--
--Word--
Pandarus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A Lycian fighting on the side of the Trojans, described in the Iliad as breaking the truce with the Greeks by wounding Menelaus with an arrow. The role as the lovers' go-between that he plays in Chaucer's (and later Shakespeare's) story of Troilus and Cressida originated with Boccaccio and is also the origin of the word pander.
--Examples--
--Word--
panda 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A large bearlike mammal with characteristic black and white markings, native to certain mountain forests in China. It feeds almost entirely on bamboo and has become increasingly rare.
A Brahmin expert in genealogy, who provides religious guidance and acts as a family priest.
--Examples--

--Meanings--
An itinerant musician; a minstrel. Now rare.

A pimp.
A person who assists the immoral desires or evil designs of others.
--Examples--
‘newspapers are pandering to people's baser instincts’
‘the lowest panders of a venal press’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The practice or occupation of a pander; pimping; procuration.

pander 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Gratify or indulge (an immoral or distasteful desire or taste or a person with such a desire or taste)
A pimp.

--Word--
pandy 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
A stroke on the palm of the hand with a tawse, ruler, or rod, given as a punishment to children in schools.
A sepoy; specifically a sepoy participating in the Mutiny of 1857–8.
Attributive and in the genitive. Designating a test for the presence of globulins in cerebrospinal fluid, in which the protein is precipitated by a dilute aqueous solution of phenol (or one of several other reagents); chiefly in "Pandy('s) test".
To strike or beat (a person, especially a schoolchild) on the palm of the hand with a tawse, ruler, cane, etc., as a punishment.
--Examples--
--Word--
pandiabolism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The belief or doctrine that the Devil is the informing spirit of the whole universe.
--Examples--
--Word--
pandybat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bat used to strike or beat schoolchildren on the palm of the hand as a punishment.
--Examples--
--Word--
pandiculation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The act of stretching (extending the limbs and neck), as a manifestation of weariness, a sign of disease, etc. In later use also: yawning (rare).
--Examples--
