pandit 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Hindu scholar learned in Sanskrit and Hindu philosophy and religion, typically also a practising priest.
A wise man or teacher.
A talented musician (used as a respectful title or form of address)
--Examples--
‘the pandit chants the marriage mantras’
‘Pandit Misir’
‘Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya’
‘Panditji played the refrain’
--Word--
pandit 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Hindu scholar learned in Sanskrit and Hindu philosophy and religion, typically also a practising priest.
A wise man or teacher.
A talented musician (used as a respectful title or form of address)
--Examples--
‘the pandit chants the marriage mantras’
‘Pandit Misir’
‘Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya’
‘Panditji played the refrain’
--Word--
pandour 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a military force originally organized in Croatia in 1741 by Baron Franz von Trenck (1711–94) to clear the country near the Turkish border of robbers, and later enrolled as a regiment in the Austrian army, becoming renowned for their ferocity and brutality. Hence more generally: a fearsome or brutal soldier from Croatia. Also figurative. Now historical.
In Hungary, Croatia, and other parts of eastern Europe: a guard; an armed servant or retainer; a member of a local constabulary.
South African. A member of a chiefly Khoekhoe regiment established in 1793 by the Dutch East India Company for the defence of the Cape of Good Hope. Compare "Hottentot". Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
pandora 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A burrowing bivalve mollusc with a fragile shell, the unequal valves of which form a ‘box’ with a lid.
The first mortal woman. In one story she was created by Zeus and sent to earth with a jar or box of evils in revenge for Prometheus' having brought the gift of fire back to the world. She let out all the evils from the container to infect the earth; hope alone remained to assuage the lot of humankind.
--Examples--
--Word--
pandora 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A burrowing bivalve mollusc with a fragile shell, the unequal valves of which form a ‘box’ with a lid.
The first mortal woman. In one story she was created by Zeus and sent to earth with a jar or box of evils in revenge for Prometheus' having brought the gift of fire back to the world. She let out all the evils from the container to infect the earth; hope alone remained to assuage the lot of humankind.
--Examples--
--Word--
pandoura 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Graeco-Roman stringed instrument of the lute type, having a small body, a long thick neck, and usually three strings, which has survived in various forms in the Balkans, Turkey, Egypt, and parts of western Asia.

paned 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
panel 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A flat or curved component, typically rectangular, that forms or is set into the surface of a door, wall, or ceiling.
A thin piece of metal forming part of the outer shell of a vehicle.
A piece of material forming part of a garment.
A decorated area within a larger design containing a separate subject.
One of several drawings making up a cartoon strip.
A flat board on which instruments or controls are fixed.
A small group of people brought together to investigate or decide on a particular matter.
A list of medical practitioners registered in a district as accepting patients under the National Health Service or, formerly, the National Insurance Act.
A list of available jurors or a jury.
A person or people charged with an offence.
Cover (a wall or other surface) with panels.
--Examples--
‘a layer of insulating material should be placed between the panels and the wall’
‘body panels for the car trade’
‘the dress has a panel of lace over the bodice’
‘the central panel depicts the Crucifixion’
‘the cartoon strip has four panels’
‘a control panel’
‘an interview panel’
‘an elegant panelled dining room’
--Word--
panela 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In Central and South America: unrefined brown sugar, frequently made into blocks or cone shapes for eating.
--Examples--
--Word--
panelized 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of timber: cut into panels. Of a building, construction, etc.: constructed using precut building materials, especially panels of wood.

--Word--
Europe 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A continent of the northern hemisphere, separated from Africa to the south by the Mediterranean Sea and from Asia to the east roughly by the Bosporus, the Caucasus Mountains, and the Ural Mountains. Europe contains approximately 20 per cent of the world's population.
The European Union.
The mainland of continental Europe as distinct from the British Isles.
--Examples--
‘the Prime Minister who took Britain into Europe’
‘A Guide to the Birds of Britain and Europe’
--Word--
pan-European 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to, affecting, or extending over the whole of Europe; advocating cooperation between the countries of Europe.
--Examples--
--Word--
fire pan 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A pan for holding or carrying burning fuel; a brazier, a portable grate.
Mining. An iron basket for holding burning coals which can be lowered down a shaft to create a current of air through the workings or to provide illumination. Now historical.
A pan for holding the priming or powder in a firearm; = priming pan. Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
panfish 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A fish suitable for frying whole in a pan, especially one caught by an angler rather than bought.
Fish for panfish.
--Examples--
‘panfishing picks up considerably during the fall and spring’

--Word--
Pangaea 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A vast continental area or supercontinent comprising all the continental crust of the earth, which is postulated to have existed in late Palaeozoic and Mesozoic times before breaking up into Gondwana and Laurasia.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Meanings--

Pangasinan 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A Northern Philippine language spoken by a people of the Lingayen gulf area of central Luzon island in the Philippines.
A member of a people inhabiting the central area (principally the Pangasinan province) of the island of Luzon in the Philippines and speaking Pangasinan.
Of, relating to, or designating the Pangasinan or their language.

pangene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Hugo de Vries' term for: a supposed particle embodying a heritable character which is present in a cell nucleus and is transmitted to each daughter nucleus during cell division.
--Examples--

pangene 
--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
pangenesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A theory postulated by Darwin to explain the phenomena of heredity, according to which every constituent unit of an organism reproduced itself by contributing particles (gemmules) to the organism's reproductive cells.
--Examples--
--Word--
pangenetic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or of the nature of pangenesis.
--Examples--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or of the nature of pangenesis.

pan-Germany

pangful 
--Type--

--Meanings--

--Word--
pangolin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An African and Asian mammal that has a body covered with horny overlapping scales, a small head with an elongated snout, a long sticky tongue for catching ants and termites, and a tapering tail.
--Examples--
--Word--
pangolin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An African and Asian mammal that has a body covered with horny overlapping scales, a small head with an elongated snout, a long sticky tongue for catching ants and termites, and a tapering tail.
--Examples--
--Word--
Gothic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the Goths or their extinct language, which belongs to the East Germanic branch of the Indo-European language family. It provides the earliest manuscript evidence of any Germanic language (4th–6th centuries AD).
Of or in the style of architecture prevalent in western Europe in the 12th–16th centuries (and revived in the mid 18th to early 20th centuries), characterized by pointed arches, rib vaults, and flying buttresses, together with large windows and elaborate tracery. English Gothic architecture is divided into Early English, Decorated, and Perpendicular.
Belonging to or redolent of the Dark Ages; portentously gloomy or horrifying.
(of lettering) of or derived from the angular style of handwriting with broad vertical downstrokes used in western Europe from the 13th century, including Fraktur and black-letter typefaces.
Relating to goths or goth music.
The extinct language of the Goths.
The Gothic style of architecture.
Gothic type.
--Examples--
‘19th-century Gothic horror’
--Word--
pangrammatist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A writer who uses every letter of the alphabet in a single sentence, line of verse, etc.; a composer of pangrams.
--Examples--
--Word--
pang 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A sudden sharp pain or painful emotion.
Crammed or densely packed.
--Examples--
‘Lindsey experienced a sharp pang of guilt’
‘the snack bar will keep those hunger pangs at bay’
‘pang full of meat and bread’
--Word--
panged 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
panguingue 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A card game of Filipino origin, resembling gin rummy, usually played with eight or ten decks (frequently with certain of their number cards removed).
--Examples--
--Word--
panhandle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A narrow strip of territory projecting from the main territory of one state into another.
Beg in the street.
Beg for something from (someone) in the street.
--Examples--
‘the Oklahoma Panhandle’
‘she went back to the streets to panhandle for money’
‘a bum panhandled him for a cup of coffee’

--Word--
panharmonicon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mechanical musical instrument resembling a barrel organ and operated by a pinned cylinder, with a variety of pipes and percussion instruments enabling it to imitate various orchestral sounds. Compare "orchestrion".
--Examples--
--Word--
pan head 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A head of a rivet, bolt, screw, etc., shaped like an inverted flat-bottomed pan; frequently attributive.
A mechanism at the top of a tripod or other mount that allows the camera to move in both horizontal and vertical planes; a pan-and-tilt head.
--Examples--
--Word--
Panhellenic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or representing all people of Greek origin or ancestry.
Relating to, advocating, or denoting the idea of a political union of all Greeks.
--Examples--
‘Homer is a Panhellenic poet, claimed by many’
--Word--
Panhellenism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Panhellenic spirit or ideals; specifically (in ancient times) patriotism based on the idea of Greek culture as a whole rather than individual cities and states; (in the 19th and early 20th centuries) advocacy of a political union of all Greek-speaking peoples, Greek irredentism.
--Examples--
--Word--
Panhellenist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A believer in or advocate of Panhellenism; specifically (in ancient times) a person whose patriotism was related to Greek culture as a whole, rather than to an individual city or state; (in the 19th and early 20th centuries) an advocate of the political union of all Greek-speaking peoples, a Greek irredentist.
Of or relating to a Panhellenist; characterized by Panhellenism.
--Examples--
--Word--
panhypopituitarism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Diminished or absent secretion of all of the anterior pituitary hormones.
--Examples--
--Word--

adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Spain or to Spanish-speaking countries, especially those of Central and South America.

A Spanish-speaking person, especially one of Latin American descent, living in the US.

‘the New York Hispanic community’

panyar 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
panic 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Sudden uncontrollable fear or anxiety, often causing wildly unthinking behaviour.
A state of widespread financial alarm provoking hasty action.
A frenzied hurry to do something.
Feel or cause to feel panic.
Drive someone through panic into (hasty action)
--Examples--
‘she hit him in panic’
‘he ran to the library in a blind panic’
‘he caused an economic panic by his sudden resignation’
‘panic selling’
‘a workload of constant panics and rush jobs’
‘the crowd panicked and stampeded for the exit’
‘talk of love panicked her’
‘we are not going to be panicked into a decision’
--Word--
panically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a panicky or panic-stricken manner; with panic-like fear.
--Examples--
--Word--
panically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a panicky or panic-stricken manner; with panic-like fear.

--Word--
prone 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Likely or liable to suffer from, do, or experience something unpleasant or regrettable.
Lying flat, especially face downwards.
Denoting the position of the forearm with the palm of the hand facing downwards.
With a downward slope or direction.
--Examples--
‘farmed fish are prone to disease’
‘he was written off by many as too injury-prone’
‘I was lying prone on a foam mattress’
‘a prone position’

panicum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of numerous grasses of the genus Panicum, which includes European millet, P. miliaceum, and several other important cereals and fodder grasses; panic grass; (in form Panicum) the genus itself.

panini 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A sandwich made with Italian bread, usually toasted.
Indian grammarian. Sources vary as to when he lived, with dates ranging from the 4th to the 7th century BC. He is noted as the author of the Ashtadhyayi, a grammar of Sanskrit.

--Word--
Pankhurst 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Mrs Emmeline (1858–1928), Christabel (1880–1958), and (Estelle) Sylvia (1882–1960), English suffragettes. In 1903 Emmeline and her daughters founded the Women's Social and Political Union, with the motto ‘Votes for Women’. Following the imprisonment of Christabel in 1905, Emmeline initiated the militant suffragette campaign which continued until the outbreak of the First World War.
--Examples--
--Word--
pankin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
English regional (Yorkshire). A large earthenware vessel; a pancheon.
--Examples--

--Word--
panleukopenia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Reduction in the number of all types of leucocyte in the blood; specifically (more fully "feline panleukopenia") an infectious disease of the domestic cat and other felids (also affecting mustelids and procyonids) characterized by this, and by fever, vomiting, and diarrhoea.
--Examples--
--Word--
panleukopenia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Reduction in the number of all types of leucocyte in the blood; specifically (more fully "feline panleukopenia") an infectious disease of the domestic cat and other felids (also affecting mustelids and procyonids) characterized by this, and by fever, vomiting, and diarrhoea.

Mongolian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Mongolia.
The language of Mongolia, a member of the Altaic family with an unusual vertical cursive script. It has some 2 million speakers, and related forms are spoken by over 3 million people in northern China.
Relating to Mongolia, its people, or their language.

Panmunjom 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A village in the demilitarized zone between North and South Korea. It was here that the armistice ending the Korean War was signed on July 27, 1953.

--Word--
pan 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A metal container used for cooking food in.
An amount of something contained in a pan.
A bowl fitted at either end of a pair of scales.
The bowl of a toilet.
A large container used in a technical or manufacturing process for subjecting a material to heat or a mechanical or chemical process.
A steel drum.
A shallow bowl in which gold is separated from gravel and mud by agitation and washing.
A part of the lock that held the priming in old types of gun.
A hollow in the ground in which water may collect or in which a deposit of salt remains after water has evaporated.
A hard stratum of compacted soil.
A person's face.
Criticize severely.
Wash gravel in a pan to separate out (gold)
(of gravel) yield gold.
--Examples--
‘heat the olive oil in a heavy pan’
‘a pan of hot water’
‘she sifted flour on to the wide brass pan of the scales’

‘he washed the gold-free surface gravel out over the rim of the pan’
‘prime the pan, pour the powder down the barrel, then ram in the cartridge's paper and ball’

‘the movie was panned by the critics’
‘the old-timers panned gold’
‘prospectors panned for gold in the Yukon’

pannicle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Anatomy and Zoology. Originally: a membrane or thin sheet or layer of tissue in a human or animal body; specifically (more fully "carnous pannicle", "fleshy pannicle") the panniculus carnosus. In later use: a sheet or pad of adipose tissue. Now rare.
--Examples--

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--

panniculus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A membrane or sheet of tissue; specifically the panniculus carnosus or panniculus adiposus.

--Word--
pannierman 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A man in charge of a pannier or panniers; especially a hawker of fish, etc., who transports his goods to market in a pannier or panniers. Now rare (chiefly English regional (northern) in later use).
A paid officer at the Inns of Court, who brought provisions from market and (in later times at least) had duties relating to the serving of meals. Compare "pannier". Now historical.

--Word--
Pannonia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient country and former province of the Roman Empire lying south and west of the River Danube, in present-day Austria, Hungary, Slovenia, and Croatia. It lost its separate identity after the Romans withdrew at the end of the 4th century.
--Examples--

Pano 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An extinct Panoan language; also called Panobo.
A member of any of a number of Panoan-speaking peoples of the Amazon basin in eastern Peru and neighbouring parts of Bolivia and Brazil, especially those formerly speaking Pano (Panobo); these peoples collectively, considered as a linguistic group.

--Word--
panosteitis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Inflammation of all of the tissues of a bone; osteomyelitis; (Veterinary Medicine) a self-limited disorder of uncertain aetiology seen in young dogs of large breeds, characterized by intermittent shifting lameness with radiological changes in the medulla and cortex of affected bones (especially the long bones of the forelegs).

pipe 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A tube used to convey water, gas, oil, or other fluid substances.
A cylindrical vein of ore or rock, especially one in which diamonds are found.
A cavity in cast metal.
A duct, vessel, or tubular structure in the body, or in an animal or plant.
A connection to the Internet or to a website.
A device for smoking tobacco, consisting of a narrow tube made from wood, clay, etc. with a bowl at one end in which the tobacco is burned, the smoke from which is drawn into the mouth.
A quantity of tobacco held by a pipe.
A device for smoking illegal drugs.
A wind instrument consisting of a single tube with holes along its length that are covered by the fingers to produce different notes.
Bagpipes.
A set of musical pipes joined together, as in pan pipes.
Any of the cylindrical tubes by which notes are produced in an organ.
A boatswain's whistle.
A high-pitched cry or song, especially of a bird.
A command which causes the output from one routine to be the input for another.
The symbol |.
A cask for wine, especially as a measure equal to two hogsheads, usually equivalent to 105 gallons (about 477 litres)
Convey (water, gas, oil, or other fluid substances) through a pipe or pipes.
Transmit (music, a radio or television programme, signal, etc.) by wire or cable.
Play (a tune) on a pipe or pipes.
Play a pipe or pipes as a ceremonial accompaniment to the arrival or departure of (someone)
Use a boatswain's whistle to summon (the crew) to work or a meal.
(of a bird) sing in a high or shrill voice.
Say something in a high, shrill voice.
Decorate (clothing or soft furnishings) with thin cord covered in fabric and inserted into a seam.
Arrange (food, particularly icing or cream) in decorative lines or patterns.
Propagate (a pink or similar plant) by taking a cutting at the joint of a stem.

‘a smell of pipe tobacco’
‘they were sharing a pipe of tobacco’
‘a crack pipe’
‘the tone of a reed pipe’
‘the sad little pipe of the ringed plover’
‘a fresh pipe of port’
‘water from the lakes is piped to Manchester’
‘he was watching a movie piped to his room on one of the hotel's video channels’
‘he believed he'd heard music—a tune being piped’
‘the Duke was piped on board’
‘the hands were piped to breakfast’
‘outside at the back a curlew piped’
‘‘No, miss,’ piped Lucy’
‘she had been piping cream round a flan’

noun
--Meanings--
The theory that life on the earth originated from microorganisms or chemical precursors of life present in outer space and able to initiate life on reaching a suitable environment.
--Examples--
--Word--
panspermic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating the theory of panspermia.
--Examples--
--Word--
panspermism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Panspermia.
--Examples--
--Word--
panspermist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who advocates the theory of panspermia.
--Examples--
--Word--
pant 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Breathe with short, quick breaths, typically from exertion or excitement.
Run or go in a specified direction while panting.
Say something breathlessly.
Long for or to do something.
(of the heart or chest) throb or heave from strong emotions.
A short, quick breath.
A throb or heave of a person's heart or chest.
--Examples--
‘he was panting when he reached the top’
‘they panted up the stairs’
‘‘We'll never have time,’ she panted’
‘the opening song makes you pant for more’
‘his breast panted with alarms’
‘Robyn was breathing rather fast, in shallow pants’
‘I felt the quick pant of my bosom’
--Word--
pant 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--

‘I felt the quick pant of my bosom’
--Word--
pantas 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Falconry. A disorder of hawks characterized by difficult or noisy breathing (probably representing a variety of respiratory infections). Now historical.
--Examples--

--Word--
pantagamy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A communal system of marriage in which all the men and women of a household or community are regarded as married to each other, formerly practised by the Perfectionist community at Oneida, New York State (1848–79).
--Examples--

pantaleon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large dulcimer capable of extensive dynamic variation and influential in the development of the piano, having 185 double strings of metal and gut sounded by means of hand-held hammers or sticks.

pantaloonery 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Clowning or foolery, especially by a Pantaloon in a pantomime or harlequinade; comic entertainment. Also figurative: a travesty, a farce.

--Word--
pantelegraph 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A form of facsimile telegraph invented by Giovanni Caselli in 1856 for transmitting images along a line connecting two isochronously oscillating pendulums, one of which guides an iron point over the original (written or drawn in non-conducting ink on metallic paper), so setting up equivalent motions in the other, which carries a pencil to reproduce the image.
--Examples--
--Word--
panteleologism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The theory that all phenomena have a final cause; (originally) specifically (in Lotze's metaphysics) the theory that all phenomena are caused by the activity of God.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pantelleria 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A volcanic Italian island in the Mediterranean, situated between Sicily and the coast of Tunisia. It was used as a place of exile by the ancient Romans, who called it Cossyra.
--Examples--
--Word--
pantellerite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A peralkaline variety of rhyolite containing phenocrysts of anorthoclase, cossyrite, and other minerals in a dark green to black groundmass.
--Examples--
--Word--
panter 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
The officer in a household who supplied the bread and had charge of the pantry (an office later merged with that of butler); the controller of the bread or food supplies in general in a large establishment, especially a royal court. Formerly also: †a baker (obsolete).
A person who or animal which pants for breath. Also figurative: one who is desperate for, or chases after, something.
--Examples--
--Word--
pan-Teutonism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The idea or principle of a union of all the Germanic peoples.

pantheon

noun
--Meanings--

‘the pantheon of the all-time greats’

noun

pantometer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various instruments for measuring angles and heights; specifically (a) a nonius quadrant (now historical and rare); (b) a device in the form of an adjustable parallelogram, for measuring the angle of inclination of a slope.

--Word--
pantomime 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A theatrical entertainment, mainly for children, which involves music, topical jokes, and slapstick comedy and is based on a fairy tale or nursery story, usually produced around Christmas.
A dramatic entertainment, originating in Roman mime, in which performers express meaning through gestures accompanied by music.
An absurdly exaggerated piece of behaviour.
An absurd or confused situation.
Express or represent by exaggerated mime.
--Examples--
‘a pantomime villain’
‘he is currently appearing in pantomime in Manchester’
‘he made a pantomime of checking his watch’
‘the drive to town was a pantomime’
‘they pantomimed picking up dropped food’
--Word--
pantomime 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A theatrical entertainment, mainly for children, which involves music, topical jokes, and slapstick comedy and is based on a fairy tale or nursery story, usually produced around Christmas.
A dramatic entertainment, originating in Roman mime, in which performers express meaning through gestures accompanied by music.
An absurdly exaggerated piece of behaviour.
An absurd or confused situation.
Express or represent by exaggerated mime.
--Examples--
‘a pantomime villain’
‘he is currently appearing in pantomime in Manchester’
‘he made a pantomime of checking his watch’
‘the drive to town was a pantomime’
‘they pantomimed picking up dropped food’

pantomime 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A theatrical entertainment, mainly for children, which involves music, topical jokes, and slapstick comedy and is based on a fairy tale or nursery story, usually produced around Christmas.

--Word--
pantomimus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dramatic performer popular in the Roman Empire who represented mythological stories through gestures and actions, supported by music and a chorus, playing all the roles in a piece, each role having its own mask.
--Examples--
--Word--
pantomorphic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Assuming any or all forms; compare "pantamorphic" (and see note in etymology).
--Examples--
--Word--
pantonal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a musical composition: not in any one key but moving between numerous discernible keys without becoming atonal; including many tonalities. Also (occasionally): = "atonal".
--Examples--
--Word--
pantonality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Musical composition which is not in any one key but moves between numerous discernible keys without becoming atonal; the use of many keys or tonalities. Also (occasionally): = "atonality".
--Examples--

pantophobia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: †hydrophobia (rabies) (obsolete). Later: a condition characterized by groundless or irrational fears; fear of everything; generalized anxiety.
--Examples--

pantophobic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to or suffering from pantophobia.
A person suffering from pantophobia.
--Examples--
--Word--
pantopod 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of the Pantopoda, the only living order in the class Pycnogonida of marine arthropods; a sea spider or pycnogonid.
--Examples--
--Word--
pantopragmatic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Originally: †of or relating to ‘pantopragmatics’ (obsolete). Now more generally: interfering in or occupied with everything; incessantly meddling. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
panto 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
pantoscope 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
US. A moving panorama, especially that of a large section of the gold country of California and the route west to it, painted from daguerreotypes of the area taken by John Wesley Jones (1824–1905), and displayed in the north-eastern United States from 1852 to 1854. Now historical and rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
pantoscopic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating bifocal spectacles or (occasionally) reading glasses with the top part of the lenses removed. Now historical and rare.
"pantoscopic camera"noun a panoramic camera. Now historical and rare.
All-seeing; having a wide range of vision or coverage.
--Examples--
--Word--
pantothenate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A salt or ester of pantothenic acid.
--Examples--
--Word--
pantothenic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A vitamin of the B complex, found in rice, bran, and many other foods, and essential for the oxidation of fats and carbohydrates.
--Examples--
--Word--
pantothere 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small early therian mammal of the extinct group Pantotheria, known from fossils of the Upper Triassic to Lower Cretaceous periods and thought to have given rise to both placental and marsupial mammals.
--Examples--
--Word--
pantotherian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the extinct mammalian group Pantotheria. Also as noun, a pantothere.
--Examples--
--Word--
pantoum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Malay verse form, also imitated in French and English, with a rhyme scheme abab.
--Examples--
‘smart's the word for pantoums and haiku’
‘we could end as a line of pantoum’

panung 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A traditional Thai garment consisting of a long piece of cloth (usually silk or cotton) wrapped round the lower part of the body and secured around the waist, sometimes with a further pass between the legs.

Sancho Panza 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
pao-tzu 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
paolo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a papal silver coin, first struck during the pontificate of Paul III (1543–9), roughly equivalent in value to the giulio and circulating throughout the papal territories. Later also: a similar coin circulating locally in another Italian state, especially one produced in Tuscany from the 16th to the 19th centuries.
--Examples--
--Word--
pap 
--Type--
noun, adjective, noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Bland soft or semi-liquid food such as that suitable for babies or invalids.
(in Africa and the Caribbean) porridge, usually made with maize meal.
Worthless or trivial reading matter or entertainment.
(of food) lacking flavour and firmness.
(of a person) lacking physical or emotional strength; feeble.
(of an inflatable object) under-inflated; flat.
A woman's breast or nipple.
A paparazzo.
Take a photograph of (a celebrity) without permission.
--Examples--
‘a trayful of tasteless pap’
‘limitless channels serving up an undemanding diet of pap’
‘the apple is so pap I won't eat it’
‘this flu makes people feel pap’
‘my wheel was pap so I had to push the bike home’
‘she can't go to the gym or pop to the shops without being papped’
--Word--
papa

noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--

‘Papa had taught her to ride a bicycle’

--Word--
Papago 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The Uto-Aztecan language of the Tohono O'odham, a form of Pima with around 10,000 speakers.
--Examples--
--Word--
papaya 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tropical fruit shaped like an elongated melon, with edible orange flesh and small black seeds.
The fast-growing tree which bears the papaya, native to warm regions of America. It is widely cultivated for its fruit, both for eating and for papain production.
--Examples--
--Word--
papaya 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tropical fruit shaped like an elongated melon, with edible orange flesh and small black seeds.
The fast-growing tree which bears the papaya, native to warm regions of America. It is widely cultivated for its fruit, both for eating and for papain production.
--Examples--
--Word--
papain 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A protein-digesting enzyme obtained from unripe papaya fruit, used to tenderize meat and as a food supplement to aid digestion.
--Examples--
--Word--
papain 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A protein-digesting enzyme obtained from unripe papaya fruit, used to tenderize meat and as a food supplement to aid digestion.
--Examples--
--Word--
papayotin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dried extract of papaya latex, containing papain.

papalize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
papalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Adherence to or support for the Pope or the papacy; specifically belief in or support for a system of ecclesiastical government in which the highest authority of the Church is embodied in the Pope (often opposed to conciliarism). Also: the papal system, the papacy, Roman Catholicism.
--Examples--
--Word--
papalist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A supporter of the papacy, especially an advocate of papal supremacy.
--Examples--
--Word--
papality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Papal office, authority, or sovereignty; the fact or state of being Pope; the Pope's (political or spiritual) dominion; the papacy.

--Word--
paper 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Material manufactured in thin sheets from the pulp of wood or other fibrous substances, used for writing, drawing, or printing on, or as wrapping material.
Wallpaper.
A sheet of paper with something written or printed on it.
A newspaper.
Personal documents.
Documents attesting identity; credentials.
A government report or policy document.
Denoting something that is officially documented but has no real existence.
A set of examination questions to be answered at one session.
The written answers to examination questions.
An essay or dissertation, especially one read at an academic lecture or seminar or published in an academic journal.
Free passes of admission to a theatre or other entertainment.
Apply wallpaper to (a wall or room)
Cover a hole or blemish with wallpaper.
Disguise an awkward problem instead of resolving it.
Fill (a theatre) by giving out free tickets.
--Examples--
‘a sheet of paper’
‘a paper napkin’
‘toffee papers’
‘the walls were damp—paper hung away in long strips’
‘he riffled through the papers on his desk’
‘the story made the front page of the local paper’
‘the personal papers of major political figures’
‘two men stopped us and asked us for our papers’
‘a recently leaked cabinet paper’
‘a paper profit’
‘we had to sit a three-hour paper’
‘you need to test your students, mark their papers, and place them in the right class’
‘he published a highly original paper on pattern formation’
‘the walls were papered in a Regency stripe’
‘interior panels can be of fairly basic wood that will be papered over’
‘the unions tried to paper over their differences’
‘surely the theatre could at least have papered the house if the box office was looking so poor’

--Word--
cutting 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The action of cutting something.
A piece cut off from something, especially what remains when something is being trimmed or prepared.
An article or other piece cut from a newspaper or periodical.
A piece cut from a plant for propagation.
An open passage excavated through higher ground for a railway, road, or canal.
Capable of cutting something.
(of a comment) causing emotional pain; hurtful.
(of the wind) bitterly cold.
--Examples--
‘the cutting of the cake’
‘tax-cutting’
‘grass cuttings’
‘an archive of newspaper cuttings’
‘take cuttings of Christmas cactus and pot them on’
‘they found the cutting and scrambled down the slope’
‘the cutting blades of the hedge trimmer’
‘a cutting remark’
‘cutting winter winds’
--Word--
drilling 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
The action of making a hole in something by boring with a drill.
The action of sinking a borehole in order to obtain oil or water.
The action of cutting away part of a tooth before filling it.
Instruction or training in military exercises.
The action of planting the ground in furrows.
--Examples--
‘the windows vibrated all day from the sound of drilling’
‘drilling should begin next year’
‘some new dental technologies have eliminated the use of drilling’
‘our days often began with military drilling’
‘accurate ridging and drilling make hoeing much easier’
--Word--
paper 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Material manufactured in thin sheets from the pulp of wood or other fibrous substances, used for writing, drawing, or printing on, or as wrapping material.
Wallpaper.
A sheet of paper with something written or printed on it.
A newspaper.
Personal documents.
Documents attesting identity; credentials.
A government report or policy document.
Denoting something that is officially documented but has no real existence.
A set of examination questions to be answered at one session.
The written answers to examination questions.
An essay or dissertation, especially one read at an academic lecture or seminar or published in an academic journal.
Free passes of admission to a theatre or other entertainment.
Apply wallpaper to (a wall or room)
Cover a hole or blemish with wallpaper.
Disguise an awkward problem instead of resolving it.
Fill (a theatre) by giving out free tickets.
--Examples--
‘a sheet of paper’
‘a paper napkin’
‘toffee papers’
‘the walls were damp—paper hung away in long strips’
‘he riffled through the papers on his desk’
‘the story made the front page of the local paper’
‘the personal papers of major political figures’
‘two men stopped us and asked us for our papers’
‘a recently leaked cabinet paper’
‘a paper profit’
‘we had to sit a three-hour paper’
‘you need to test your students, mark their papers, and place them in the right class’
‘he published a highly original paper on pattern formation’
‘the walls were papered in a Regency stripe’
‘interior panels can be of fairly basic wood that will be papered over’
‘the unions tried to paper over their differences’
‘surely the theatre could at least have papered the house if the box office was looking so poor’

--Word--
paper 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Material manufactured in thin sheets from the pulp of wood or other fibrous substances, used for writing, drawing, or printing on, or as wrapping material.
Wallpaper.
A sheet of paper with something written or printed on it.
A newspaper.
Personal documents.
Documents attesting identity; credentials.
A government report or policy document.
Denoting something that is officially documented but has no real existence.
A set of examination questions to be answered at one session.
The written answers to examination questions.
An essay or dissertation, especially one read at an academic lecture or seminar or published in an academic journal.
Free passes of admission to a theatre or other entertainment.
Apply wallpaper to (a wall or room)
Cover a hole or blemish with wallpaper.
Disguise an awkward problem instead of resolving it.
Fill (a theatre) by giving out free tickets.

‘a paper napkin’
‘toffee papers’

--Word--
thick 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adverb
--Meanings--
With opposite sides or surfaces that are far or relatively far apart.
(of a garment or other knitted or woven item) made of heavy material.
(of writing or printing) consisting of broad lines.
Made up of a large number of things or people close together.
Densely filled or covered with.
(of the air or atmosphere, or a substance in the air) opaque, dense, or heavy.
(of a person's head) having a dull pain or heavy feeling, especially as a result of a hangover or illness.
(of a liquid or a semi-liquid substance) relatively firm in consistency; not flowing freely.
Of low intelligence; stupid.
(of a voice) not clear or distinct; hoarse or husky.
(of an accent) very marked and difficult to understand.
Having a very close, friendly relationship.
The most active or crowded part of something.
In or with deep, dense, or heavy mass.
--Examples--
‘thick slices of bread’
‘thick metal cables’
‘the walls are 5 feet thick’
‘a thick sweater’
‘a headline in thick black type’
‘his hair was long and thick’
‘the road winds through thick forest’
‘the ground was thick with yellow leaves’
‘the air was thick with tension’

‘a thick cloud of smoke’
‘influenza can cause a thick head’
‘Stephen woke late, his head thick and his mouth sour’

‘he's a bit thick’
‘Guy's voice was thick with desire’
‘a snarling thick voice’
‘a thick French accent’
‘he's very thick with the new master’
‘we were in the thick of the battle’

papyrus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A material prepared in ancient Egypt from the pithy stem of a water plant, used in sheets throughout the ancient Mediterranean world for writing or painting on and also for making articles such as rope.
A document written on papyrus.
The tall aquatic sedge from which papyrus is obtained, native to central Africa and the Nile valley.
--Examples--
‘the text was preserved, probably on papyrus’
‘a papyrus scroll’
‘a remarkable papyrus recently acquired by the British Museum’

Papp, Joseph 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1921–91), US producer and director; born Joseph Papirofsky. He managed Hollywood's Actors Laboratory 1948–1950 and then founded the Shakespearean Theatre Workshop in 1954 that became the New York Shakespeare Festival. in 1960. He also founded the off-Broadway Public Theater in 1967 and directed the theaters at Lincoln Center from 1973 until 1978.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pappenheimer body 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A basophilic inclusion body containing iron, found in erythrocytes in certain types of anaemia and hyposplenism. Usually in plural.
--Examples--
--Word--
pappus 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
The tuft of hairs on each seed of thistles, dandelions, and similar plants, which assists dispersal by the wind.
(fl.c.300–350 AD), Greek mathematician; known as Pappus of Alexandria. Little is known of his life, but his Collection of six books (another two are missing) is the principal source of knowledge of the mathematics of his predecessors.
--Examples--

--Examples--
--Word--
pappus 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
The tuft of hairs on each seed of thistles, dandelions, and similar plants, which assists dispersal by the wind.
(fl.c.300–350 AD), Greek mathematician; known as Pappus of Alexandria. Little is known of his life, but his Collection of six books (another two are missing) is the principal source of knowledge of the mathematics of his predecessors.
--Examples--
--Word--
paprika 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A powdered spice with a deep orange-red colour and a mildly pungent flavour, made from the dried and ground fruits of certain varieties of pepper.
A deep orange-red colour.
--Examples--
--Word--
paprika 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A powdered spice with a deep orange-red colour and a mildly pungent flavour, made from the dried and ground fruits of certain varieties of pepper.
A deep orange-red colour.
--Examples--
--Word--
pap 
--Type--
noun, adjective, noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Bland soft or semi-liquid food such as that suitable for babies or invalids.
(in Africa and the Caribbean) porridge, usually made with maize meal.
Worthless or trivial reading matter or entertainment.
(of food) lacking flavour and firmness.
(of a person) lacking physical or emotional strength; feeble.
(of an inflatable object) under-inflated; flat.
A woman's breast or nipple.
A paparazzo.
Take a photograph of (a celebrity) without permission.
--Examples--
‘a trayful of tasteless pap’
‘limitless channels serving up an undemanding diet of pap’
‘the apple is so pap I won't eat it’
‘this flu makes people feel pap’
‘my wheel was pap so I had to push the bike home’
‘she can't go to the gym or pop to the shops without being papped’
--Word--
Papua 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A province of Indonesia comprising most of the western part of the island of New Guinea, with some offshore islands; capital, Jayapura. Until its incorporation into Indonesia in 1963 it was known as Dutch New Guinea.
A name for the island of New Guinea.
--Examples--
--Word--
Papuan 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Papua, or of Papua New Guinea.
A heterogeneous group of around 750 languages spoken by some 3 million people in Papua New Guinea and neighbouring islands.
Relating to Papua or its people or their languages.
--Examples--

--Word--
petits paquets 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Politics. In French Colonial Africa: pieces of legislation or administrative actions limited in scope or significance, passed or undertaken in isolation. Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
par 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The number of strokes a first-class player should normally require for a particular hole or course.
A par score at a hole.
The face value of a share or other security, as distinct from its market value.
The recognized value of one country's currency in terms of another's.
Play (a hole) in par.
--Examples--
‘Woosnam had advanced from his overnight position of three under par’
‘the sixteenth is a par five’
‘a card that showed 16 pars, one eagle, and one birdie’
‘the 9 per cent unsecured loan stock is redeemable at par’
‘par value’
‘he calmly parred the 17th’

par-

par.

abbreviation

‘see par. 3.1 above’
--Word--
para 
--Type--
proper noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A state in northern Brazil, on the Atlantic coast at the delta of the Amazon; capital, Belém. It is a region of dense rainforest.
A paratrooper.
A paragraph.
A monetary unit of Serbia, equal to one hundredth of a dinar.
--Examples--
--Word--
para- 
--Type--
prefix, prefix
--Meanings--
Beside; adjacent to.
Beyond or distinct from, but analogous to.
Denoting substitution at diametrically opposite carbon atoms in a benzene ring, e.g. in 1,4 positions.
Denoting something that protects or wards off.
--Examples--
‘parataxis’
‘parathyroid’
‘paramilitary’
‘paratyphoid’
‘paradichlorobenzene’
‘parachute’
‘parasol’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
parabasal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Zoology. Designating or relating to a specialized type of Golgi complex found near the nucleus and kinetosome in certain protozoans. In early use also: a kinetoplast (now rare or disused). Chiefly in "parabasal body".
Histology. Designating cells located just above the basal layer of an epithelium, especially of the cervix.
--Examples--
--Word--
parabasis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in ancient Greek comedy) a direct address to the audience, sung or chanted by the chorus on behalf of the author.
A digression in a fictional work in which the author addresses the reader.

parablast 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Embryology. Especially in the terminology of W. His: a layer of cells that gives rise to the blood vessels and connective tissue of the embryo (embryonic mesenchyme), (supposedly) located outside the blastoderm. Now historical.

--Word--
parablepsy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Scribal oversight, especially the erroneous assimilation of the spelling of a word to that of another in the text; an instance of this. Chiefly in relation to the editing of old, especially classical, texts.
--Examples--
--Word--
parableptic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to parablepsis.

--Word--
parabola 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A symmetrical open plane curve formed by the intersection of a cone with a plane parallel to its side. The path of a projectile under the influence of gravity follows a curve of this shape.
--Examples--
--Word--
Parabolanus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the Church in Alexandria and Constantinople in the 5th and 6th centuries: a member of a class of unordained helpers who attended the sick in times of plague, etc. Usually in plural.

paracasein 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The form of casein produced when the protein in milk is coagulated by rennin, and consisting of phosphoproteins (usually bonded to calcium ions).

paracaseinate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A compound containing paracasein bonded to ions of a metal (especially calcium).

--Word--
paracelsian 
--Type--
noun, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
A follower or adherent of Paracelsus, or of his medical or philosophical principles.
Of, relating to, or characteristic of Paracelsus, or of his teachings or followers.
A colourless or pale yellow mineral of the monoclinic system which is a barium-containing feldspar dimorphous with celsian (into which it is changed on heating).

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
Paracelsus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1493–1541), Swiss physician: born Theophrastus Phillipus Aureolus Bombastus von Hohenheim. He developed a new approach to medicine and philosophy based on observation and experience. He saw illness as having a specific external cause (rather than resulting from an imbalance of the bodily humours), and introduced chemical remedies to replace traditional ones.
--Examples--
--Word--
paracentesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The perforation of a cavity of the body or of a cyst or similar outgrowth, especially with a hollow needle to remove fluid or gas.

--Word--
paracentral 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Located beside the centre or a central structure; specifically (a) Anatomy designating or relating to an area of the cerebral cortex located on the medial aspect of the parietal lobe beside the central fissure (especially in "paracentral lobule"); (b) Medicine designating or relating to the part of the retina beside the fovea; parafoveal.
--Examples--
--Word--
paracentric inversion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A reversal of the normal order of genes in a chromosome segment involving only the part of a chromosome at one side of the centromere.

paracetamol

noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
parachor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A numerical quantity (found empirically to be constant over a wide range of temperature) equal to the molecular weight of a liquid multiplied by the fourth root of its surface tension and divided by the difference between the density of the liquid and that of its vapour.
--Examples--
--Word--
parachordal 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Situated beside the notochord; specifically designating either of a pair of cartilaginous plates which form the foundation of the skull in mammalian embryos.
A parachordal cartilage.

--Word--
parachute 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A cloth canopy which fills with air and allows a person or heavy object attached to it to descend slowly when dropped from an aircraft, or which is released from the rear of an aircraft on landing to act as a brake.
Drop from an aircraft by parachute.
Appoint or be appointed in an emergency or from outside the existing hierarchy.
--Examples--
‘the saviour of many pilots has been the parachute’
‘the planes came over the coast and started to drop supplies by parachute’
‘a parachute regiment’
‘airborne units parachuted in to secure the airport’
‘an air operation to parachute relief supplies into the region’
‘the former Conservative minister was controversially parachuted into the safe seat’

paracresol 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The para-isomer of cresol, a low-melting crystalline solid with disinfectant properties, present in coal tar; 4-methylphenol, (CH₃)C₆H₄OH.
--Examples--
--Word--
paracusis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Disturbance or impairment of hearing; specifically †(a) (in early use) tinnitus (obsolete); (b) (more fully "paracusis of Willis") an apparent improvement in the ability to hear conversation in the presence of loud background noise, thought to be characteristic of certain types of conductive hearing loss, especially otosclerosis.
--Examples--
--Word--
parade 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A public procession, especially one celebrating a special day or event.
A formal march or gathering of troops for inspection or display.
A series of people or things appearing or being displayed one after the other.
A boastful or ostentatious display.
A public square or promenade.
A row of shops.
A parade ground.
(of troops) assemble for a formal inspection or ceremonial occasion.
Walk or march through a public place in a formal procession or in an ostentatious way.
Display (someone or something) while marching or moving around a place.
Display (something) in order to impress or attract attention.
Appear falsely as; masquerade as.
--Examples--
‘a St George's Day parade’
‘the festival began with a parade of the competitors’
‘a military parade’
‘the men massed for parade’
‘the parade of Hollywood celebrities who troop on to his show’
‘a pompous parade of erudition’
‘we were walking along South Parade’
‘a shopping parade’
‘the recruits were due to parade that day’
‘officers will parade through the town centre’
‘carefree young men were parading the streets’
‘they paraded national flags’
‘he paraded his knowledge’
‘these untruths parading as history’
--Word--
parade 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A public procession, especially one celebrating a special day or event.
A formal march or gathering of troops for inspection or display.
A series of people or things appearing or being displayed one after the other.
A boastful or ostentatious display.
A public square or promenade.
A row of shops.
A parade ground.

Walk or march through a public place in a formal procession or in an ostentatious way.
Display (someone or something) while marching or moving around a place.
Display (something) in order to impress or attract attention.
Appear falsely as; masquerade as.

‘these untruths parading as history’

Appear falsely as; masquerade as.
--Examples--
‘a St George's Day parade’
‘the festival began with a parade of the competitors’
‘a military parade’
‘the men massed for parade’
‘the parade of Hollywood celebrities who troop on to his show’
‘a pompous parade of erudition’
‘we were walking along South Parade’
‘a shopping parade’
‘the recruits were due to parade that day’
‘officers will parade through the town centre’
‘carefree young men were parading the streets’
‘they paraded national flags’
‘he paraded his knowledge’
‘these untruths parading as history’
--Word--
paradiastole 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A figure of speech in which a favourable turn is given to something unfavourable by the use of an expression that conveys only part of the truth; euphemism effected by the substitution of a positive synonym for a negative word or phrase.
--Examples--
--Word--
paradichlorobenzene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A volatile crystalline compound, C₆H₄Cl₂, which has a penetrating odour and is used as a deodorizer and insecticidal fumigant, especially in mothballs.
--Examples--
--Word--
paradichlorobenzene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A volatile crystalline compound, C₆H₄Cl₂, which has a penetrating odour and is used as a deodorizer and insecticidal fumigant, especially in mothballs.
--Examples--
--Word--
paradiddle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
One of the basic patterns (rudiments) of drumming, consisting of four even strokes played in the order ‘left right left left’ or ‘right left right right’.
--Examples--

paradidymal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the paradidymis.

--Word--
paradidymis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small group of vestigial tubules located above the epididymis, representing a remnant of the mesonephros in the male; also called "organ of Giraldès".
--Examples--
--Word--
paradigm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A typical example or pattern of something; a pattern or model.
A world view underlying the theories and methodology of a particular scientific subject.
A set of linguistic items that form mutually exclusive choices in particular syntactic roles.
(in the traditional grammar of Latin, Greek, and other inflected languages) a table of all the inflected forms of a particular verb, noun, or adjective, serving as a model for other words of the same conjugation or declension.
--Examples--
‘society's paradigm of the ‘ideal woman’’
‘the discovery of universal gravitation became the paradigm of successful science’
‘English determiners form a paradigm: we can say ‘a book’ or ‘his book’ but not ‘a his book’’
--Word--
paradigmatic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Serving as a typical example of something.
Of or denoting the relationship between a set of linguistic items that form mutually exclusive choices in particular syntactic roles.
--Examples--
‘his biography is paradigmatic of the experiences of this generation’
--Word--
paradigmatical

adjective
--Meanings--

adverb
--Meanings--

--Type--
verb
--Meanings--

--Word--
parade 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A public procession, especially one celebrating a special day or event.
A formal march or gathering of troops for inspection or display.
A series of people or things appearing or being displayed one after the other.
A boastful or ostentatious display.
A public square or promenade.
A row of shops.
A parade ground.
(of troops) assemble for a formal inspection or ceremonial occasion.
Walk or march through a public place in a formal procession or in an ostentatious way.
Display (someone or something) while marching or moving around a place.
Display (something) in order to impress or attract attention.
Appear falsely as; masquerade as.
--Examples--
‘a St George's Day parade’
‘the festival began with a parade of the competitors’
‘a military parade’
‘the men massed for parade’
‘the parade of Hollywood celebrities who troop on to his show’
‘a pompous parade of erudition’
‘we were walking along South Parade’
‘a shopping parade’
‘the recruits were due to parade that day’
‘officers will parade through the town centre’
‘carefree young men were parading the streets’
‘they paraded national flags’
‘he paraded his knowledge’
‘these untruths parading as history’

paradiplomatic

adjective
--Meanings--

paradise 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘martyrs who die in battle with the ungodly earn instant transmission to paradise’
‘the surrounding countryside is a walker's paradise’
‘my idea of paradise is to relax on the seafront’

--Word--
paradox 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A seemingly absurd or contradictory statement or proposition which when investigated may prove to be well founded or true.
A statement or proposition which, despite sound (or apparently sound) reasoning from acceptable premises, leads to a conclusion that seems logically unacceptable or self-contradictory.
A person or thing that combines contradictory features or qualities.
--Examples--
‘the uncertainty principle leads to all sorts of paradoxes, like the particles being in two places at once’
‘the liar paradox’
‘Parmenides was the original advocate of the philosophical power of paradox’
‘cathedrals face the paradox of having enormous wealth in treasures but huge annual expenses’
--Word--
paradoxal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Nautical. Relating to or designating a navigational course in which a ship follows a rhumb line, i.e., a course which cuts meridians at a constant angle (other than a right angle). Chiefly in "paradoxal compass"noun a projection on which such a course could be plotted, and on which it would appear as part of a spiral curve. Now historical.
Generally. Paradoxical.
--Examples--
--Word--
paradoxer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A propounder of paradoxes.
--Examples--
--Word--
paradox 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A seemingly absurd or contradictory statement or proposition which when investigated may prove to be well founded or true.

‘the liar paradox’

paraffin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A flammable, whitish, translucent, waxy solid consisting of a mixture of saturated hydrocarbons, obtained by distillation from petroleum or shale and used in candles, cosmetics, polishes, and sealing and waterproofing compounds.
A colourless, flammable, oily liquid similarly obtained and used as fuel, especially kerosene.

--Word--
paraformaldehyde 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A white crystalline solid, obtained by the evaporation of an aqueous solution of formaldehyde (methanal), which is a polymer of formaldehyde and is used as a disinfectant, fumigant, and bactericide, and as an intermediate in chemical synthesis; polyoxymethylene, (HCHO)ₙ.

paraganglion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of the small aggregates of chromaffin cells found in association with autonomic ganglia and nerves. Also: any of the small collections of glomus cells found in association with certain blood vessels, acting as chemoreceptors.

--Word--
parage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Lineage, descent, or rank; especially noble or high lineage. Also: the qualities of courtesy, generosity, etc., held to be proper to a person of noble lineage. Now historical.
Feudal Law. A system of land tenure under which a fief is divided among brothers, the younger brothers holding from the eldest by right of equality, and the eldest rendering fealty to the lord in respect of the whole fief.

--Word--
paragonimiasis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Infection of humans or other mammals with lung flukes (trematodes of the genus Paragonimus), which results from the ingestion of metacercariae in uncooked crustaceans and causes chiefly pulmonary disease with chronic cough and haemoptysis.
--Examples--

--Word--
paragraph 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A distinct section of a piece of writing, usually dealing with a single theme and indicated by a new line, indentation, or numbering.

‘the information set out in paragraph 3’
‘his style deploys a lack of conventional paragraphing’

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to paragraphs; = "paragraphic".
--Examples--
--Word--
paragraphically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In, by means of, or in terms of paragraphs; paragraph by paragraph.
--Examples--
--Word--
paragraph 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A distinct section of a piece of writing, usually dealing with a single theme and indicated by a new line, indentation, or numbering.
Arrange (a piece of writing) in paragraphs.
--Examples--
‘the concluding paragraph’
‘the information set out in paragraph 3’
‘his style deploys a lack of conventional paragraphing’
--Word--
paragraphism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The study of the paragraphs or sections of a text and their interrelations. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
paragraphist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A journalist (usually freelance) who writes newspaper paragraphs.
--Examples--
--Word--
paragraphize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To be formed into paragraphs.
--Examples--
--Word--
paragraph 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A distinct section of a piece of writing, usually dealing with a single theme and indicated by a new line, indentation, or numbering.
Arrange (a piece of writing) in paragraphs.
--Examples--
‘the concluding paragraph’
‘the information set out in paragraph 3’
‘his style deploys a lack of conventional paragraphing’
--Word--
Paraguay 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A landlocked country in central South America; population 6,600,000 (estimated 2015); languages, Spanish (official), Guarani; capital, Asunción.
--Examples--
--Word--
Paraguayan 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of Paraguay or its people.
A native or inhabitant of Paraguay.
--Examples--
‘the great Paraguayan novelist’
‘the film had a cast mainly of Paraguayans’
--Word--
Paraguayan 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of Paraguay or its people.
A native or inhabitant of Paraguay.
--Examples--
‘the great Paraguayan novelist’
‘the film had a cast mainly of Paraguayans’
--Word--
paraheliotropic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or characterized by paraheliotropism; (of leaves or their movements) turning to reduce intense illumination.
--Examples--
--Word--
paraheliotropism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of tropism in which a plant's leaves move to reduce injuriously intense illumination, usually by keeping their blades parallel to the light rays.
--Examples--
--Word--
parahydrogen 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The form of molecular hydrogen in which the two nuclei in the molecule have antiparallel spins (so that the spectrum exhibits no hyperfine structure) and which forms about 25 per cent of hydrogen under normal conditions.
--Examples--
--Word--
parahypnosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Abnormal or artificially induced sleep.
--Examples--
--Word--
parahopeite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A rare, colourless mineral of the triclinic crystal system, consisting of a hydrated zinc phosphate.
--Examples--
--Word--
parahormone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A substance involved in or produced by metabolic processes that acts like a hormone or modifies hormonal activity.
--Examples--
--Word--
Paraíba 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state of eastern Brazil, on the Atlantic coast; capital, João Pessoa.
--Examples--
--Word--
parakeet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small parrot with predominantly green plumage and a long tail.
--Examples--

parakeet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small parrot with predominantly green plumage and a long tail.
--Examples--
--Word--
parakeratosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: abnormal keratinization or cornification; any disorder characterized by this. Later: specifically retention of nuclei by cells of the stratum corneum, as a normal or abnormal finding.
--Examples--
--Word--
parakinesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Disordered motor function; dyskinesia.
--Examples--
--Word--
parakinesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Disordered motor function; dyskinesia.
--Examples--
--Word--
parakite 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A parachute which is towed along against the wind at high speed by a vehicle or (now usually) a motor boat, and is used to launch a person into the air.
A kind of tailless kite devised by Gilbert Woglom in 1896 for aerial photography and other purposes.
--Examples--
--Word--
paralanguage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The non-lexical component of communication by speech, for example intonation, pitch and speed of speaking, hesitation noises, gesture, and facial expression.
--Examples--
--Word--
paralaurionite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A rare, colourless mineral of the monoclinic crystal system, consisting of a hydroxide and chloride of lead, Pb(OH)Cl.
--Examples--
--Word--
paraldehyde 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A liquid made by treating acetaldehyde with acid, used medicinally as a sedative, hypnotic, and anticonvulsant.
--Examples--
--Word--
paralegal 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person trained in subsidiary legal matters but not fully qualified as a lawyer.
Relating to auxiliary aspects of the law.
--Examples--
--Word--
paralipsis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The device of giving emphasis by professing to say little or nothing of a subject, as in not to mention their unpaid debts of several millions.
--Examples--
--Word--
paralexia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The substitution of a word, syllable, or letter for another in reading; an instance of this.
--Examples--
--Word--
paralexic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or characteristic of paralexia; affected by paralexia.
--Examples--
--Word--
Paralian 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who lives by the sea; specifically (in ancient Greece) a member of a people living on the coast near Athens in the 6th cent.
--Examples--
--Word--
paralinguistic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting paralanguage or the non-lexical elements of communication by speech.
--Examples--
--Word--
paralinguistics 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The branch of linguistics which studies non-phonemic aspects of speech, such as tone of voice, tempo, etc.; non-phonemic characteristics of communication; paralanguage.
--Examples--
--Word--
paralipomena 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
Things omitted from a work and added as a supplement.
(in the Vulgate Bible and some other versions) the name of the books of Chronicles, regarded as supplementary to the books of Kings.
--Examples--
--Word--
paralipsis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The device of giving emphasis by professing to say little or nothing of a subject, as in not to mention their unpaid debts of several millions.
--Examples--
--Word--
paralysation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
paralyse 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Cause (a person or part of the body) to become partly or wholly incapable of movement.
Make (someone) unable to think or act normally, especially through panic or fear.
Stop (a system, place, or organization) from operating by causing disruption.
--Examples--
‘Mrs Burrows had been paralysed by a stroke’
‘some people are paralysed by the thought of failure’
‘the regional capital was paralysed by a general strike’
--Word--
paralysed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a person or part of the body) partly or wholly incapable of movement; disabled.
--Examples--
‘he became partially paralysed’
--Word--
paralyser 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A paralysing agent; a paralysant.
--Examples--
--Word--
paralysis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The loss of the ability to move (and sometimes to feel anything) in part or most of the body, typically as a result of illness, poison, or injury.
Inability to act or function properly.
--Examples--
‘the fast-acting venom causes paralysis, breathing difficulties, and sometimes death’
‘a creeping paralysis accompanied by nausea and vomiting’
‘the paralysis gripping the country’
--Word--
paralysing 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Causing a person or part of the body to become partly or wholly incapable of movement.
Causing an inability to think or act normally, especially through panic or fear.
--Examples--
‘the snake's paralysing venom’
‘her paralysing shyness’

adjective, noun

--Meanings--

--Word--
parallactical 
--Type--

--Examples--
--Word--
parallax 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The effect whereby the position or direction of an object appears to differ when viewed from different positions, e.g. through the viewfinder and the lens of a camera.
The angular amount of parallax in a particular case, especially that of a star viewed from different points in the earth's orbit.
--Examples--
‘what you see in the viewfinder won't be quite what you get in the photograph because of parallax error’
‘he succeeded in measuring the parallax of the star 61 Cygni’
--Word--
parallax 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The effect whereby the position or direction of an object appears to differ when viewed from different positions, e.g. through the viewfinder and the lens of a camera.
The angular amount of parallax in a particular case, especially that of a star viewed from different points in the earth's orbit.
--Examples--
‘what you see in the viewfinder won't be quite what you get in the photograph because of parallax error’
‘he succeeded in measuring the parallax of the star 61 Cygni’
--Word--
parallel 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
(of lines, planes, or surfaces) side by side and having the same distance continuously between them.
Occurring or existing at the same time or in a similar way; corresponding.
Of or denoting electrical components or circuits connected to common points at each end, rather than one to another in sequence.
Involving the simultaneous performance of operations.
A person or thing that is similar or analogous to another.
A similarity or comparison.
Each of the imaginary parallel circles of constant latitude on the earth's surface.
Two parallel lines (‖) as a reference mark.
Be side by side with (something extending in a line), always keeping the same distance; run or lie parallel to.
Be similar or corresponding to.
--Examples--
‘parallel lines never meet’
‘the road runs parallel to the Ottawa River’
‘a parallel universe’
‘they shared a flat in London while establishing parallel careers’
‘highly parallel multiprocessor systems’
‘a challenge which has no parallel in peacetime this century’
‘she draws a parallel between personal destiny and social forces’
‘a big concrete gutter that paralleled the road’
‘the increase in the quality of wines has paralleled the rise of interest in food’
--Word--
parallelable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That can be paralleled or made parallel; capable of being paralleled or matched. Now chiefly (Electrical Engineering): (of electrical apparatus) that can be connected in parallel.
--Examples--
--Word--
parallel

adjective, noun, verb

adjective, noun, verb

‘special software parallelizes C-based programs’
--Word--
parallelism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state of being parallel or of corresponding in some way.
The use of successive verbal constructions in poetry or prose which correspond in grammatical structure, sound, metre, meaning, etc.
The use of parallel processing.
--Examples--
‘Greek thinkers who believed in the parallelism of microcosm and macrocosm’
‘parallelism suggests a connection of meaning through an echo of form’
‘the parallelisms are reinforced by frequent alliteration’
‘massive parallelism gives neural networks a high degree of fault tolerance’
--Word--
parallelism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state of being parallel or of corresponding in some way.
The use of successive verbal constructions in poetry or prose which correspond in grammatical structure, sound, metre, meaning, etc.
The use of parallel processing.
--Examples--
‘Greek thinkers who believed in the parallelism of microcosm and macrocosm’
‘parallelism suggests a connection of meaning through an echo of form’
‘the parallelisms are reinforced by frequent alliteration’
‘massive parallelism gives neural networks a high degree of fault tolerance’
--Word--
parallelist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who draws parallels or comparisons.
Psychology. An advocate or adherent of the theory that mental phenomena can be correlated to physical events in the brain or nervous system.
Cultural Anthropology. An advocate or adherent of the theory that widely separated or independent cultures may develop in similar ways.

parallel-veined

adjective
--Meanings--

noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
paralogia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In early use: delirium. Later: illogical or incoherent speech or thinking, especially as seen in psychosis.
--Examples--
--Word--
paralogic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or characterized by paralogism; = "paralogical".

--Word--
paralogical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to a form of reasoning which does not conform to the rules of logic.
--Examples--
‘these thought forms belong to a paralogical world of symbol and fantasy’

noun
--Meanings--

noun

--Word--
paramedic 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person trained to give emergency medical care to people who are seriously ill with the aim of stabilizing them before they are taken to hospital.
--Examples--
‘the government hope to have a paramedic on every emergency ambulance’
‘a paramedic team was on its way’
--Word--
paramedical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to services and professions which supplement and support medical work but do not require a fully qualified doctor (such as nursing, radiography, emergency first aid, physiotherapy, and dietetics).
--Examples--
--Word--
paramedic 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person trained to give emergency medical care to people who are seriously ill with the aim of stabilizing them before they are taken to hospital.
--Examples--
‘the government hope to have a paramedic on every emergency ambulance’
‘a paramedic team was on its way’
--Word--
paramelaconite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An oxide of copper, Cu₄O₃, containing both mono- and divalent copper, forming black prismatic crystals and belonging to the tetragonal crystal system.
--Examples--
--Word--
paramenia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Abnormal menstruation.
--Examples--
--Word--
parament 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A decorated robe; a robe of state; an ecclesiastical robe. Now historical and rare.
An ornament or decoration, especially an ecclesiastical ornament. Now usually: an embroidered hanging for the altar, pulpit, etc. Now chiefly US.
--Examples--
--Word--
parament 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A decorated robe; a robe of state; an ecclesiastical robe. Now historical and rare.
An ornament or decoration, especially an ecclesiastical ornament. Now usually: an embroidered hanging for the altar, pulpit, etc. Now chiefly US.
--Examples--
--Word--
paramere 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Either of the halves of a bilaterally symmetrical animal, or of a segment or somite of such an animal; specifically either of a pair of lobes on either side of the external male genitalia of certain insects.
--Examples--
--Word--
paramese 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The note immediately above the mese; the lowest note of the higher of a pair of disjunct tetrachords; (in the Greater Perfect System) the lowest note of the third tetrachord from the bottom. Hence occasionally: the fifth string (counting from the bottom) of an eight-stringed lyre (now rare).
--Examples--
--Word--
parameter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A numerical or other measurable factor forming one of a set that defines a system or sets the conditions of its operation.
A quantity whose value is selected for the particular circumstances and in relation to which other variable quantities may be expressed.
A numerical characteristic of a population, as distinct from a statistic of a sample.
A limit or boundary which defines the scope of a particular process or activity.
--Examples--
‘there are three parameters by which a speaker is able to modify the meaning of the utterance—pitch, volume, and tempo’
‘the parameters within which the media work’

parameterization

noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Meanings--
--Examples--

parameterize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Describe or represent in terms of a parameter or parameters.
--Examples--
‘the nuclear charge distribution can be parameterized directly using a suitable mathematical form’

--Word--
parametral 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to a parameter or parameters; parametric. Chiefly in Crystallography.
--Examples--
--Word--
parametric 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or expressed in terms of a parameter or parameters.
Assuming the value of a parameter for the purpose of analysis.
Relating to or denoting a process in which amplification or frequency conversion is obtained using a device modulated by a pumping frequency, which enables power to be transferred from the pumping frequency to the signal.
--Examples--
‘variables with normal distribution were compared by means of parametric tests’

--Word--
paramyoclonus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "paramyoclonus multiplex". An inherited (autosomal dominant) form of myoclonus beginning early in life, involving chiefly the muscles of face, neck, trunk, and proximal limbs, and having a non-progressive course without associated neurological symptoms.
--Examples--
--Word--
paramyosin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A protein which forms the thick filaments of the contractile units of unstriated muscle in molluscs and some other invertebrates.
--Examples--
--Word--
paramyotonia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Atypical myotonia; specifically (more fully "congenital paramyotonia", "paramyotonia congenita") a familial (autosomal dominant) disorder characterized by attacks of myotonia typically triggered by exposure to cold, with intermittent flaccid muscle weakness, caused by mutations of the skeletal muscle sodium channel.
--Examples--
--Word--
paramyxovirus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a group of RNA viruses similar to the myxoviruses but larger and haemolytic, including those causing mumps, measles, distemper, rinderpest, and various respiratory infections (parainfluenza).
--Examples--
--Word--
paramnesia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A condition or phenomenon involving distorted memory or confusions of fact and fantasy, such as confabulation or déjà vu.
