--Meanings--
A high treeless plateau in tropical South America.

--Meanings--

paramount 
--Type--
adjective, proper noun
--Meanings--
More important than anything else; supreme.
Having supreme power.
A city in south-western California, south-east of Los Angeles; population 55,236 (est. 2008).
A US film production and distribution company established in 1912. A major studio of the silent era, Paramount acted as an outlet for many of the films of Cecil B. de Mille and helped to create stars such as Mary Pickford and Rudolf Valentino.
--Examples--
‘the interests of the child are of paramount importance’
‘a paramount chief’
--Word--

noun
--Meanings--
The state or fact of being of greater importance than anything else.
Supreme power or authority.
--Examples--
‘he must stress the paramountcy of diplomacy and dialogue’
‘the paramountcy of our Parliament’

--Word--
Paraná 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river of South America, which rises in south-eastern Brazil and flows some 3,300 km (2,060 miles) southwards to the River Plate estuary in Argentina. For part of its length it forms the south-eastern border of Paraguay.
A river port in eastern Argentina, on the Paraná River; population 249,500 (est. 2005).
A state of southern Brazil, on the Atlantic coast; capital, Curitiba.

paranatellon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In ancient astronomy and contemporary astrology: a star or constellation that rises at the same time as another; specifically one that rises at the same time as a constellation of the zodiac. Usually with of.

--Examples--
--Word--
paranete 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The second highest note of the higher of two tetrachords; (in the Greater and Lesser Perfect systems) the second highest note of the two highest tetrachords and of the highest tetrachord respectively. Hence occasionally: the seventh string (counting from the bottom) of an eight-stringed lyre (now rare).
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A Malayan machete.
A variety of Trinidadian folk music, traditionally played at Christmas by groups which travel from house to house.
--Examples--
--Word--
parangi 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In Sri Lanka: a contagious tropical disease, yaws. Now rare or historical.
Usually derogatory. Also with capital initial. In South India and Sri Lanka: a European; a Christian, especially an Indian or Sri Lankan one; a person of mixed Indian or Sri Lankan and European heritage.

--Word--
paranoia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mental condition characterized by delusions of persecution, unwarranted jealousy, or exaggerated self-importance, typically worked into an organized system. It may be an aspect of chronic personality disorder, of drug abuse, or of a serious condition such as schizophrenia in which the person loses touch with reality.
Unjustified suspicion and mistrust of other people.
--Examples--
‘mild paranoia afflicts all prime ministers’
--Word--
paranoiac 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Suffering from or relating to paranoia.
Showing unjustified suspicion and mistrust of other people.
A person suffering from paranoia.
A person showing unjustified suspicion and mistrust of other people.
--Examples--
‘psychotic and paranoiac tendencies’
‘nonsensical paranoiac ramblings’
‘the violent defensiveness of the paranoiac is directed against all who challenge his power’
‘a bunch of paranoiacs and conspiracy theorists’

--Word--
paranoid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Characterized by or suffering from the mental condition of paranoia.
Unreasonably or obsessively anxious, suspicious, or mistrustful.
A person who is paranoid.
--Examples--
‘paranoid schizophrenia’
‘you think I'm paranoid but I tell you there is something going on’
‘further accusations would sound like the ramblings of a paranoid’

--Word--
paranthelion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A diffuse, bright spot in the sky seen at the same altitude as the sun and at an angular distance from it varying from 90° to 140°, caused by refraction of sunlight through prismatic ice crystals in the atmosphere.
--Examples--
--Word--
paranthracene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A crystalline hydrocarbon, C₂₈H₂₀, which is a dimer of anthracene; usually called dianthracene.
--Examples--

parapet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A low protective wall along the edge of a roof, bridge, or balcony.

--Word--
phenetidine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of three isomeric oily liquid amines having the formula (C₂H₅O)C₆H₄NH₂, which are ortho-, meta-, and para-amino derivatives of phenetole and are used in the manufacture of dyes.
--Examples--
--Word--
paraphenylenediamine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A white or reddish crystalline compound, C₆H₄(NH₂)₂, used as a photographic developer, for dyeing hair and fur, and in the manufacture of dyes.
--Examples--
--Word--
parapherna 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Roman Law. Those articles of property held by a wife over and above the dowry she brought to her husband, and which remained under her own control.
--Examples--
--Word--
paraphernal 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
In plural A married woman's paraphernalia. By extension (Scottish): miscellaneous belongings; odds and ends, bits and pieces. Also occasionally in singular: an item of paraphernalia.
Of, belonging to, or of the nature of a married woman's paraphernalia. Also: (of things, especially personal belongings) miscellaneous, that are pieces of paraphernalia.
--Examples--
--Word--
paraphernalia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Miscellaneous articles, especially the equipment needed for a particular activity.
Trappings associated with a particular institution or activity that are regarded as superfluous.
--Examples--
‘drills, saws, and other paraphernalia necessary for home improvements’
‘the rituals and paraphernalia of government’

--Word--
paraphrase 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Express the meaning of (something written or spoken) using different words, especially to achieve greater clarity.
A rewording of something written or spoken.
--Examples--
‘you can either quote or paraphrase literary texts’
‘scattered here and there in the text are frank paraphrases of lines from Virgil, Cicero, and Quintilian’
‘it is characteristic of poetic metaphors that they are not susceptible to paraphrase’
--Word--

--Meanings--

paraphrastically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
paraphrenia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In early use: insanity, madness Later: specifically mental illness with prominent paranoid or other delusional symptoms; paranoid schizophrenia.
--Examples--
--Word--
paraphrenic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or of the nature of paraphrenia; suffering from paraphrenia.
A person suffering from paraphrenia.
--Examples--

paraph 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A flourish after a signature, originally as a precaution against forgery.

--Word--
paraplasm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Cytoplasmic inclusions (vacuoles, granules, crystals, etc.). Compare earlier metaplasm. Now rare.

adjective, noun

‘a paraplegic hospital’
‘researchers hope the treatment might enable paraplegics to walk again’

--Word--
parapodium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in a polychaete worm) each of a number of paired muscular bristle-bearing appendages used in locomotion, sensation, or respiration.
(in a sea slug or other mollusc) a lateral extension of the foot used as an undulating fin for swimming.
--Examples--

noun

parapsis 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A lateral region of the mesoscutum of certain hymenopteran insects, delineated medially by grooves or lines. Usually in plural.
Abnormality of the sense of touch.

pararosaniline 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A colourless, crystalline alcohol, (H₂NC₆H₄)₃COH, which is used in making triphenylmethane dyes and whose red hydrochloride is used as a stain in microscopy.

--Word--
para 
--Type--
proper noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A state in northern Brazil, on the Atlantic coast at the delta of the Amazon; capital, Belém. It is a region of dense rainforest.
A paratrooper.
A paragraph.
A monetary unit of Serbia, equal to one hundredth of a dinar.
--Examples--
--Word--
parasang 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A unit of length used in ancient Persia, originally the distance travelled in an hour and usually reckoned to be approx. 6 km (3.7 miles).
Figurative and in extended use.

parascenium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The part of an ancient Greek or Roman theatre on either side of the stage, in which props were stored and to which the actors retired.

--Word--
parasexual 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Genetics. Designating any form of genetic recombination that occurs by a process other than the fusion of gametes, as (in certain fungi) by the fusion of nuclei, (in bacteria) by conjugation, transduction, or transformation, or (in viruses) by exchange of genes within a host cell.
Having sexual aspects but not involving full sexual relations.
--Examples--
--Word--
parasexuality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Parasexual behaviour or activity; (Genetics) parasexual recombination.
--Examples--
--Word--
parashah 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In Jewish liturgy: each of several portions of the Torah read at a Sabbath morning synagogue service; these portions collectively, a sedra.
--Examples--
--Word--
parasympathetic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the part of the autonomic nervous system which balances the action of the sympathetic nerves. It consists of nerves arising from the brain and the lower end of the spinal cord and supplying the internal organs, blood vessels, and glands.
--Examples--
--Word--
parasympathomimetic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Producing physiological effects similar to those produced by stimulation of the parasympathetic nervous system.
A parasympathomimetic agent.
--Examples--
--Word--
parasynapsis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Side-by-side pairing of chromosomes at meiosis.
--Examples--
--Word--
parasynaptic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Situated or occurring near a synapse.
Acting upon neurons or the nervous system at a site other than a synapse; involving or relating to such activity.
--Examples--
--Word--
parasynthesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A process by which a term is formed by adding a bound morpheme (e.g. -ed) to a combination of existing words (e.g. black-eyed from black eye(s) + -ed).

parasyphilitic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating manifestations of disease (specifically those of tabes dorsalis and general paresis) believed to be associated with or exacerbated by prior syphilitic infection, but not directly caused by it.

--Word--
parasital 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or characteristic of a parasite; caused by parasites; parasitic.
--Examples--
--Word--
parasite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An organism that lives in or on an organism of another species (its host) and benefits by deriving nutrients at the other's expense.
A person who habitually relies on or exploits others and gives nothing in return.
--Examples--
‘the parasite attaches itself to the mouths of fishes’
‘an intestinal parasite of cattle’
‘the capitalist is really a parasite on the workers’
--Word--
parasitaemia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The demonstrable presence of parasites in the blood.
--Examples--
--Word--
parasite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An organism that lives in or on an organism of another species (its host) and benefits by deriving nutrients at the other's expense.
A person who habitually relies on or exploits others and gives nothing in return.
--Examples--
‘the parasite attaches itself to the mouths of fishes’
‘an intestinal parasite of cattle’
‘the capitalist is really a parasite on the workers’
--Word--
parasitize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Infest or exploit (an organism or part) as a parasite.
--Examples--
‘these small worms parasitize the alimentary tract of animals and birds’
‘dodder parasitizes other plants for its nutrients and water’
--Word--
parasitic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of an organism) living as a parasite.
Resulting from infestation by a parasite.
Habitually relying on or exploiting others.
(of a speech sound) inserted without etymological justification (e.g. the b in thimble); epenthetic.
--Examples--
‘mistletoe is parasitic on trees’
‘mortality from parasitic diseases’
‘attacks on the parasitic existence of Party functionaries’

parasitism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The practice of living as a parasite on or with another animal or organism.
Infestation by a parasite.
Habitual reliance on or exploitation of others.
--Examples--
‘the study of nest parasitism by cuckoos’
‘many species are susceptible to fungal parasitism’
‘billionaires whose wealth is bound up with parasitism, corruption and criminality’

--Examples--
--Word--
parathesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally (chiefly Printing): a square bracket; the use of square brackets; (also) the word, clause, or phrase inserted within such brackets. In later use more generally: a parenthesis or (treated as plural) a pair of parentheses. Now rare.
Grammar. The placing of a word or phrase beside, or in syntactic parallelism with, another; the juxtaposition of two or more grammatically parallel words or phrases (as in our friend the doctor); = "apposition". Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
parathetic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or characterized by parathesis; (Grammar) appositive.
--Examples--

parathion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A highly toxic synthetic organophosphorus compound containing phosphorus and sulphur, used as an agricultural insecticide.

noun
--Meanings--

para 
--Type--
proper noun, noun, noun

--Examples--
--Word--
paratonic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Medicine. Of or relating to strain or spasm (of muscle); specifically designating muscle rigidity occurring in response to passive movement, seen in various disorders of the cerebral cortex.
Originally: designating or relating to movements of plants in response to change in the intensity of light; nyctinastic. Later: designating plant movements caused by external stimuli of any kind.
--Examples--
--Word--
paratonic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Medicine. Of or relating to strain or spasm (of muscle); specifically designating muscle rigidity occurring in response to passive movement, seen in various disorders of the cerebral cortex.
Originally: designating or relating to movements of plants in response to change in the intensity of light; nyctinastic. Later: designating plant movements caused by external stimuli of any kind.

paravail 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
"tenant paravail"noun a tenant of a tenant, a subtenant; (specifically in English Law from the 16th cent.) the lowest tenant, the person who actually worked or occupied the land. Opposed to "paramount [noun, adverb]" Now historical.

--Word--
paravane 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A device towed behind a boat at a depth regulated by its vanes or planes, so that the cable to which it is attached can cut the moorings of submerged mines.

--Word--
paravauxite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A brittle, whitish or colourless mineral of the triclinic crystal system, consisting of a hydrated basic phosphate of ferrous iron and aluminium and usually occurring as a secondary mineral in association with vauxite and wavellite.

adverb
--Meanings--
In a direction or position alongside or parallel to an axis.
--Examples--
--Word--
paraxylene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The para-isomer of xylene, C₆H₄(CH₃)₂, a low-melting solid present in petroleum naphtha and used especially as an intermediate in chemical manufacture.
--Examples--
--Word--
Parazoa 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In some zoological classifications: a division (originally a phylum, now a subkingdom) comprising the sponges.
--Examples--
--Word--
parazoan 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the division Parazoa or sponges.
A member of the Parazoa; a sponge.
--Examples--
--Word--
parazonium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small sword or dagger worn on the belt by the ancient Greeks and (later) the Romans.
--Examples--
--Word--
parbleu 
--Type--
exclamation
--Meanings--
An exclamation expressing surprise, emphatic confirmation, etc.
--Examples--
--Word--
parboil 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Partly cook (food) by boiling.
--Examples--
‘parboil the vegetables in salted water for about 5 minutes’

--Word--
parbuckle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A loop of rope arranged like a sling, used for raising or lowering casks and other cylindrical objects.
Raise or lower with a parbuckle.
--Examples--
‘the gun has to be parbuckled across a ditch’

parc 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The total number of vehicles considered collectively; the vehicle population.
--Examples--
--Word--
Parcae 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The Fates.
--Examples--
--Word--
parcel 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An object or collection of objects wrapped in paper in order to be carried or sent by post.
A quantity or amount of something, especially as dealt with in one commercial transaction.
A piece of land, especially one considered as part of an estate.
A group of people of a specified sort.
A portion of a larger body of air or other fluid considered as a discrete element.
Make (something) into a parcel by wrapping it.
Divide into portions and then distribute.
Wrap (rope) with strips of tarred canvas, before binding it with yarn as part of a traditional technique to reduce chafing.
--Examples--
‘the lorry was carrying a large number of Royal Mail parcels’
‘a brown paper parcel’
‘a parcel bomb’
‘a parcel of shares’
‘she decided to divide her property into three parcels and invite sealed bids’
‘a parcel of rogues’
‘an inversion forms a barrier to a rising parcel of air’
‘he parcelled up the goods and sent them back’
‘the farmers argue that parcelling out commercial farmland in small plots will reduce productivity’

--Word--
divine 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of or like God or a god.
Devoted to God; sacred.
Very pleasing; delightful.
A cleric or theologian.
Providence or God.
Discover (something) by guesswork or intuition.
Have supernatural or magical insight into (future events)
Discover (water) by dowsing.
--Examples--
‘heroes with divine powers’
‘paintings of shipwrecks being prevented by divine intervention’
‘divine liturgy’
‘he had the most divine smile’
‘mum had divined my state of mind’
‘they had divined that he was a fake’
‘frauds who claimed to divine the future in chickens' entrails’
‘he showed him how to divine water’

guilty 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Culpable of or responsible for a specified wrongdoing.
Justly chargeable with a particular fault or error.

Causing a feeling of guilt.

‘he was found guilty of manslaughter’
‘Williams pleaded guilty to three separate offences’
‘she was guilty of a serious error of judgement’
‘he felt guilty about the way he had treated her’
‘a guilty conscience’
‘a guilty secret’

learned 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
stupid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having or showing a great lack of intelligence or common sense.
Dazed and unable to think clearly.
Used to express exasperation or boredom.
A stupid person (often used as a term of address)
--Examples--
‘I was stupid enough to think she was perfect’
‘how could she be so stupid?’
‘that is such a stupid question’
‘apprehension was numbing her brain and making her stupid’
‘she told him to stop messing about with his stupid painting’
‘you're not a coward, stupid!’
--Word--
terrestrial 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
On or relating to the earth.
Denoting television broadcast using equipment situated on the ground rather than by satellite.
(of a planet) similar in size or composition to the earth, especially being one of the four inner planets.
Relating to the earth as opposed to heaven.
Of or on dry land.
(of an animal) living on or in the ground; not aquatic, arboreal, or aerial.
(of a plant) growing on land or in the soil; not aquatic or epiphytic.
An inhabitant of the earth.
--Examples--
‘increased ultraviolet radiation may disrupt terrestrial ecosystems’
‘a fifth terrestrial channel’
‘a submarine eruption will be much more explosive than its terrestrial counterpart’

parch 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make or become dry through intense heat.
Roast (corn, peas, etc.) lightly.
--Examples--
‘a piece of grassland parched by the sun’
‘his crops parched during the last two summers’
--Word--
parching 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Causing dryness through intense heat.
--Examples--
‘a fierce parching heat has set in’
‘months of parching sun’
--Word--
parched 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Dried out with heat.
Extremely thirsty.
Lightly roasted.
--Examples--
‘the parched earth’
‘I'm parched—I'll die without a drink’
‘parched corn’
--Word--
pachisi 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A four-handed Indian board game in which cowrie shells are thrown to determine the movements of pieces around the board.
A modern version of the game of pachisi, using four marbles per player and dice.
--Examples--

--Word--
parchment 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A stiff, flat, thin material made from the prepared skin of an animal, usually a sheep or goat, and used as a durable writing surface in ancient and medieval times.
A manuscript written on parchment.
A type of stiff translucent paper treated to resemble parchment and used for lampshades, as a writing surface, and in baking.
A diploma or other formal document.
--Examples--
‘he borrowed a quill and a piece of parchment’
‘his skin stretched like old parchment over his cheeks’
‘parchment rolls’
‘a large collection of ancient parchments’
‘line a 2 lb loaf tin with baking parchment’
‘she taught for two years till she got her parchment’

--Word--
parchmentizing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of making parchment-like in texture, specifically the conversion of paper into parchment paper.
--Examples--
--Word--
parchmentized 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Made parchment-like in texture, especially (of thread or fabric) by means of treatment with acid; (of paper) converted into parchment paper.
--Examples--
--Word--
parchmentizing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of making parchment-like in texture, specifically the conversion of paper into parchment paper.

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Word--
parchment 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A stiff, flat, thin material made from the prepared skin of an animal, usually a sheep or goat, and used as a durable writing surface in ancient and medieval times.
A manuscript written on parchment.
A type of stiff translucent paper treated to resemble parchment and used for lampshades, as a writing surface, and in baking.
A diploma or other formal document.
--Examples--
‘he borrowed a quill and a piece of parchment’
‘his skin stretched like old parchment over his cheeks’
‘parchment rolls’
‘a large collection of ancient parchments’
‘line a 2 lb loaf tin with baking parchment’
‘she taught for two years till she got her parchment’
--Word--
parchment skin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Skin resembling parchment.
--Examples--
--Word--
parchment 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A stiff, flat, thin material made from the prepared skin of an animal, usually a sheep or goat, and used as a durable writing surface in ancient and medieval times.
A manuscript written on parchment.
A type of stiff translucent paper treated to resemble parchment and used for lampshades, as a writing surface, and in baking.
A diploma or other formal document.
--Examples--
‘he borrowed a quill and a piece of parchment’
‘his skin stretched like old parchment over his cheeks’
‘parchment rolls’
‘a large collection of ancient parchments’
‘line a 2 lb loaf tin with baking parchment’
‘she taught for two years till she got her parchment’

--Meanings--

pardalote 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small short-billed Australian songbird related to the flowerpeckers, typically having white spots or streaks on the dark wings and crown.

--Word--
pardao 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various, usually silver, coins or monetary units used in the Portuguese colonies of India, especially Goa, from the 16th to the 19th centuries, and usually said to be equivalent to 300 or 360 reis.
--Examples--

--Type--

--Word--
pardon 
--Type--
noun, verb, exclamation
--Meanings--
The action of forgiving or being forgiven for an error or offence.
A cancellation of the legal consequences of an offence or conviction.
An indulgence, as widely sold in medieval Europe.
Forgive or excuse (a person, error, or offence)
Release (an offender) from the legal consequences of an offence or conviction, and often implicitly from blame.
Used to indicate that someone is justified in doing or thinking a particular thing given the circumstances.
A request to a speaker to repeat something because one did not hear or understand it.
--Examples--
‘he obtained pardon for his sins’
‘he offered a full pardon to five convicted men’
‘I know Catherine will pardon me’
‘he was pardoned for his treason’
‘one can be pardoned the suspicion that some of his errors were deliberate’
‘‘Pardon?’ I said, cupping a hand to my ear’
--Word--
pardonable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Able to be forgiven; excusable.
--Examples--
‘no mistake, even a tiny one, is pardonable’
--Word--

--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Word--
pare 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Trim (something) by cutting away its outer edges.
Cut off (the outer skin) of something.
Reduce (something) in size, extent, or quantity in a number of small successive stages.
--Examples--
‘Carlo pared his thumbnails with his knife’
‘pare off the rind using a peeler’
‘union leaders publicly pared down their demands’
‘we pared costs by doing our own cleaning’
--Word--
paroecious 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a bryophyte: having the male and female reproductive organs in close proximity but not mixed, especially when the antheridia are in the axils of bracts immediately below those surrounding the archegonia.
--Examples--

--Word--
parenchyma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The functional tissue of an organ as distinguished from the connective and supporting tissue.
The cellular tissue, typically soft and succulent, found chiefly in the softer parts of leaves, pulp of fruits, bark and pith of stems, etc.
Cellular tissue lying between the body wall and the organs of invertebrate animals lacking a coelom, such as flatworms.
--Examples--
‘the liver parenchyma’
‘xylem parenchyma cells’
--Word--
parenchymal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or affecting the functional tissue of an organ.
--Examples--
‘minimal or no parenchymal fibrosis is present’
--Word--
parenchymatic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Parenchymatous.
--Examples--
--Word--
parenchymatous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Consisting of or relating to the cellular tissue making up the softer parts of leaves, pulp of fruits, bark and pith of stems, etc.
--Examples--
‘parenchymatous cells are rare in the twigs and roots’

--Word--
parent 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A person's father or mother.
A forefather or ancestor.
An animal or plant from which new ones are derived.
A source or origin of a smaller or less important part.
An organization or company which owns or controls a number of subsidiaries.
Be or act as a parent to (a child)
--Examples--
‘the parents of the bride’
‘his adoptive parents’
‘God's hand had written in the hearts of our first parents all the rules of good’
‘stems will root down, creating a new crown near the parent’
‘some of the whetstones have been transported up to 400 km from the parent rock’
‘policy considerations were determined largely by the parent company’
‘all children are special to those who parent them’
‘we are losing our intuitive ability to parent’
--Word--

noun
--Meanings--
The identity and origins of one's parents.
The origin of something.
--Examples--
‘a boy of Jamaican parentage’
‘this ice cream boasts American parentage’

parental 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to a person's parent or parents.

‘parental leave’
‘parental roots in adult plants’
‘the decision to sever ties with the parental organization’
‘I may revisit this diner if the parentals are in town’
--Word--
parentalia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Among the ancient Romans: periodical observances in honour of dead parents or relations; (with capital initial) the ancient Roman festival held to honour dead relations. Hence in extended use: any similar rites or observances.
--Examples--

--Word--
parenthesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A word or phrase inserted as an explanation or afterthought into a passage which is grammatically complete without it, in writing usually marked off by brackets, dashes, or commas.
A pair of round brackets ( ) used to mark off a parenthetical word or phrase.
An interlude or interval.
--Examples--
‘in a challenging parenthesis, Wordsworth comments on the evil effects of contemporary developments’
‘the stage number is added in parentheses to the name or formula’
‘the three months of coalition government were a lamentable political parenthesis’
--Word--
parenthesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A word or phrase inserted as an explanation or afterthought into a passage which is grammatically complete without it, in writing usually marked off by brackets, dashes, or commas.
A pair of round brackets ( ) used to mark off a parenthetical word or phrase.
An interlude or interval.
--Examples--
‘in a challenging parenthesis, Wordsworth comments on the evil effects of contemporary developments’
‘the stage number is added in parentheses to the name or formula’
‘the three months of coalition government were a lamentable political parenthesis’

Pareoean 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
In the theories of T. W. Kingsmill and A. C. Haddon: designating any of various southern Mongolian peoples from whom some of the peoples of mainland and insular South-East Asia are thought to be descended.
A member of any of these southern Mongolian peoples.

noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--

‘he pursued astronomy as a parergon’

--Word--
paresis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A condition of muscular weakness caused by nerve damage or disease; partial paralysis.
Inflammation of the brain in the later stages of syphilis, causing progressive dementia and paralysis.
--Examples--
‘examination indicates paresis of the upper left limb’
‘some patients had pareses of the arms or legs’

--Word--
paraesthesia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An abnormal sensation, typically tingling or pricking (‘pins and needles’), caused chiefly by pressure on or damage to peripheral nerves.
--Examples--
‘patients complain of painful paraesthesiae in the hands’
‘side effects include paraesthesia’

Pareto 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Denoting or involving the theories and methods of the Italian economist and sociologist Vilfredo Pareto (1848–1923), especially a formula used to express the income distribution of a society.

noun
--Meanings--
The unravelling of gold or silver thread from laces, epaulettes, or tassels, fashionable as a pastime among ladies, especially in France, in the latter part of the 18th cent.
--Examples--
--Word--
parfleche 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hide, especially a buffalo's hide, with the hair removed, dried by being stretched on a frame in a manner traditional among some North American Indian peoples.
An article, especially a bag, made from parfleche.
--Examples--
‘parfleche panniers beautifully painted’
--Word--
parfocal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating or relating to two or more lenses (especially in a microscope) the focal points of which lie in the same plane, so that they may be interchanged without the need to adjust the focus.
--Examples--
--Word--
parfocality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The property of being parfocal.
--Examples--
--Word--
parfocalize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To make (lenses or a lens system) parfocal.
--Examples--
--Word--
parfum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The version of a perfume that has the highest concentration of fragrant essential oils.
--Examples--
‘Chanel No. 5 is available in a number of types including parfum, eau de parfum, and eau de toilette’

parfumerie 
--Type--
noun

A place where perfume is sold or made.

pargasite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A green or greenish-blue variety of hornblende; specifically a calcium- and magnesium-rich monoclinic mineral of the amphibole group.

pargyline 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A monoamine oxidase inhibitor synthesized from propargyl bromide and benzylmethylamine, (formerly) used to treat depression and hypertension; N-methyl-N-propargylbenzylamine, C₆H₅CH₂N(CH₃)CH₂C≡CH.

Parian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the Greek island of Paros or the fine white marble for which it is renowned.
Denoting a form of fine white unglazed hard-paste porcelain likened to Parian marble.
A native or inhabitant of Paros.
Parian ware (porcelain).
--Examples--
‘a copy in Parian marble of a bronze statue’
‘Parian ware’

parrilla 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Now especially in some Latin American countries: a structure resembling a metal grid used as an instrument of torture, to which the victim is secured to be electrocuted or (formerly) burned.

A (usually outdoor) grill used to cook such a dish; a barbecue.
A restaurant specializing in Argentinian-style grilled meats.

pare 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Trim (something) by cutting away its outer edges.

--Word--
Paris 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of France, on the River Seine; population 2,203,817 (2006).
A Trojan prince, the son of Priam and Hecuba. Appointed by the gods to decide who among the three goddesses Hera, Athene, and Aphrodite should win a prize for beauty, he awarded it to Aphrodite, who promised him the most beautiful woman in the world—Helen, wife of Menelaus king of Sparta. He abducted Helen, bringing about the Trojan War, in which he killed Achilles but was later himself killed.
--Examples--
--Word--
Paris 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of France, on the River Seine; population 2,203,817 (2006).
A Trojan prince, the son of Priam and Hecuba. Appointed by the gods to decide who among the three goddesses Hera, Athene, and Aphrodite should win a prize for beauty, he awarded it to Aphrodite, who promised him the most beautiful woman in the world—Helen, wife of Menelaus king of Sparta. He abducted Helen, bringing about the Trojan War, in which he killed Achilles but was later himself killed.
--Examples--
--Word--
parish 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in the Christian Church) a small administrative district typically having its own church and a priest or pastor.
The smallest unit of local government, constituted only in rural areas.
(in Louisiana) a territorial division corresponding to a county in other states.
--Examples--
‘a parish church’
‘a parish councillor’

parisis 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A coin, especially a denier, minted at Paris, worth one quarter more than one minted at Tours.

--Word--
parity 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
The state or condition of being equal, especially as regards status or pay.
Equivalent value of one currency in terms of another at an established exchange rate.
(of a number) the fact of being even or odd.
The property of a spatial wave equation that either remains the same (even parity) or changes sign (odd parity) under a given transformation.
The value of a quantum number corresponding to parity.
A function whose being even (or odd) provides a check on a set of binary values.
The fact or condition of having borne children.
The number of children previously borne.
--Examples--
‘parity of incomes between rural workers and those in industrial occupations’
‘the euro's parity with the dollar’
‘an attempt to maintain exchange rate parities within the ERM’
‘the relationship between breast cancer and parity was investigated’
‘very high parity (six children or more)’
--Word--
parity 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
The state or condition of being equal, especially as regards status or pay.
Equivalent value of one currency in terms of another at an established exchange rate.
(of a number) the fact of being even or odd.
The property of a spatial wave equation that either remains the same (even parity) or changes sign (odd parity) under a given transformation.
The value of a quantum number corresponding to parity.
A function whose being even (or odd) provides a check on a set of binary values.
The fact or condition of having borne children.
The number of children previously borne.

‘the euro's parity with the dollar’

‘the relationship between breast cancer and parity was investigated’
‘very high parity (six children or more)’
--Word--
park 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large public garden or area of land used for recreation.
A large enclosed piece of ground attached to a country house.
A large enclosed area of land used to accommodate wild animals in captivity.
A children's playground.
(in soccer) the pitch.
An enclosed sports ground.
An area devoted to a specified purpose.
An area for motor vehicles to be left in.
(in a car with automatic transmission) the position of the gear selector in which the gears are locked, preventing the vehicle's movement.
Bring (a vehicle that one is driving) to a halt and leave it temporarily, typically in a car park or by the side of the road.
Leave (something) in a convenient place until required.
Sit down.
Postpone consideration of (an idea or plan) until a later date.
--Examples--
‘a walk round the park’
‘a country park’
‘the house is set in its own park’
‘penguin chicks are reared regularly at the park’
‘a panda cub is drawing the crowds at a wildlife park’
‘Marcus had the park's swings and slides to himself’
‘he was the liveliest player on the park’
‘an industrial park’
‘a coach park’
‘he parked his car outside her house’
‘he couldn't find anywhere to park’
‘come on in, and park your bag by the door’
‘after dinner, we parked ourselves on a pair of couches’
‘could I suggest we park that suggestion for the moment?’
--Word--
parka 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large windproof jacket with a hood, designed to be worn in cold weather.
A hooded jacket made of animal skin, worn by the Inuit.
--Examples--
‘he pulled on his fur-lined parka, ready to brave the elements’

--Word--
Parker, Dorothy 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1893–1967), American humorist, literary critic, and writer; full name Dorothy Rothschild Parker. From 1927 Parker wrote book reviews and short stories for the New Yorker magazine, becoming one of its legendary wits.
--Examples--
--Word--
parkerizing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A process for rustproofing iron or steel by brief immersion in a hot acidic solution of a metal phosphate.
--Examples--

parkin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A kind of dark gingerbread, typically with a soft, dry texture, made with oatmeal and treacle or molasses, especially in Yorkshire around Bonfire Night.
--Examples--
‘here's an apple and a piece of parkin’

--Word--
Parkman, Francis 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1823–93), US historian. He traveled the Oregon Trail in 1846 to improve his health and later wrote an account of his journey in The California and Oregon Trail (1849). He also wrote The Discovery of the Great West (1869) and A Half-Century of Conflict (1892).
--Examples--

--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
Parliament.
Parliamentary.
--Examples--
--Word--
Parl. 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
Parliament.
Parliamentary.
--Examples--
--Word--
parlay 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Turn an initial stake or winnings from a previous bet into (a greater amount) by gambling.
Transform into (something greater or more valuable)
A cumulative series of bets in which winnings accruing from each transaction are used as a stake for a further bet.
--Examples--
‘parlaying a small bankroll into big winnings’
‘a banker who parlayed a sizeable inheritance into a financial empire’
‘an excellent performance is quickly parlayed into lucrative contracts’
--Word--

--Word--
parlance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A particular way of speaking or using words, especially a way common to those with a particular job or interest.
--Examples--
‘dated terms that were once in common parlance’
‘medical parlance’

--Word--
parlando 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, noun
--Meanings--
(with reference to singing) expressive or declamatory in the manner of speech.
Composition or performance in a parlando manner.
--Examples--
‘the high-lying parlando of Siegfried's narration’
--Word--
parlatory 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The reception room or room for conversation in a convent. Hence also: †conversation (obsolete rare).
--Examples--

--Word--
parley 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A conference between opposing sides in a dispute, especially a discussion of terms for an armistice.
Hold a conference with the opposing side to discuss terms.
--Examples--
‘a parley is in progress and the invaders may withdraw’
‘they disagreed over whether to parley with the enemy’

--Word--
parleyvoo 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
The French language; (especially) French as studied, spoken, or understood by an English person. Formerly also in plural: French utterances or talk.
French; foreign. Now rare.
To speak French; to speak a foreign language; (more generally) to palaver, chat. Also with object: to talk to or address in French; to say in French.
--Examples--
--Word--
parle 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To speak; to talk. Now archaic and English regional.
--Examples--
--Word--
parly 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "parly train". A parliamentary train.
--Examples--
--Word--
parliament 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in the UK) the highest legislature, consisting of the Sovereign, the House of Lords, and the House of Commons.
The members of Parliament between one dissolution and the next.
A legislature similar to the UK Parliament in other nations and states.
A group of rooks or owls.
--Examples--
‘the Secretary of State will lay proposals before Parliament’
‘an Act of Parliament’
‘the act was passed by the last parliament of the reign’
‘the Russian parliament’
‘it is uncommon to see a parliament of owls in the wild’
--Word--
parliamental 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, belonging to, or relating to Parliament, or a parliament; parliamentary.
--Examples--
--Word--
parliamentary 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to, enacted by, or suitable for a parliament.
--Examples--
‘a parliamentary candidate’
‘parliamentary legislation’
--Word--
parliamentarian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a parliament, especially one well versed in its procedure and experienced in debate.
A supporter of Parliament in the English Civil War; a Roundhead.
Relating to a parliament or its members.
Relating to the Roundheads.
--Examples--
‘the Prime Minister and the Foreign Secretary are sound parliamentarians’
‘her family were prominent and staunch parliamentarians’
‘parliamentarian committees’
‘parliamentarian sympathies’
--Word--
parliamentarianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--

adverb
--Meanings--

--Word--
parlour 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A sitting room in a private house.
A room in a public building for receiving guests.
A room in a monastery or convent that is set aside for conversation.
A shop or business providing specified goods or services.
A room or building equipped for milking cows.
Denoting a person who professes belief in but does not actively support a specified (especially radical) political view.
--Examples--
‘they had lunch in the parlour’
‘she knocked on the parlour door’
‘the mayor's parlour’
‘an ice-cream parlour’
‘a funeral parlour’
‘the parlour Socialists of the late Victorian period’
--Word--
parlourmaid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A maid employed to wait at table.
--Examples--

parlous 
--Type--
adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
Full of danger or uncertainty; precarious.
Greatly or excessively.
--Examples--
‘the parlous state of the economy’
‘the General's position was parlous’
‘she is parlous handsome’

--Word--
Parma 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A province of northern Italy, south of the River Po in Emilia-Romagna.
A city in northern Italy, the capital of Parma; population 182,389 (2008). Founded by the Romans in 183 BC, it became a bishopric in the 9th century AD and capital of the duchy of Parma and Piacenza in about 1547. The city is associated with the production of Parma ham and Parmesan cheese.
--Examples--
--Word--
parmeliaceous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Belonging to or characteristic of the genus Parmelia of foliose lichens or the large family Parmeliaceae to which this genus belongs.
--Examples--
--Word--
parmelioid 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Characteristic of or resembling the genus Parmelia of foliose lichens.
--Examples--
--Word--
Parmenidean 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or belonging to Parmenides; relating to or characteristic of his philosophy that everything in existence is but a manifestation of a single eternal reality.
A follower or supporter of Parmenides, or an adherent of his philosophy. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
Parmenides 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(fl. 5th century BC), Greek philosopher. Born in Elea in south-western Italy, he founded the Eleatic school of philosophers. In his work On Nature, written in hexameter verse, he maintained that the apparent motion and changing forms of the universe are in fact manifestations of an unchanging and indivisible reality.
--Examples--
--Word--
Parmentier 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a dish) made with or accompanied by potatoes.
--Examples--
‘potage Parmentier’
--Word--
Parmesan 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A hard, dry cheese used chiefly in grated form, especially on Italian dishes.
(of a dish) cooked or served with Parmesan.
--Examples--
‘spoon some pasta into each bowl, season with freshly ground black pepper, and sprinkle with Parmesan’
‘a chicken parmesan with chips and salad’
‘a varied menu including parmesans, home-made steak pies, steaks, curries, and burgers’
‘we ordered the calamari, gnocchi, and veal Parmesan’
‘the bolognese sauce was delicious, but the Parmesan risotto lacked flavour’

Parmigiana 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a dish) cooked or served with Parmesan cheese.
--Examples--
‘veal Parmigiana’
--Word--
Parmigianino 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1503–40), Italian painter; born Girolano Francesco Maria Mazzola. He made an important contribution to early Mannerism, and is noted for the elongated and graceful forms of his figures, as in Madonna with the Long Neck (1534).
--Examples--
--Word--
Parmigianino 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1503–40), Italian painter; born Girolano Francesco Maria Mazzola. He made an important contribution to early Mannerism, and is noted for the elongated and graceful forms of his figures, as in Madonna with the Long Neck (1534).

parnas 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The lay head or warden of a Jewish congregation or synagogue.
--Examples--
--Word--
Parnassia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of small damp-loving plants of the family Parnassiaceae (often included in Saxifragaceae), natives of temperate or cold regions of the northern hemisphere, which have solitary, usually white, prominently veined flowers and mostly radical ovate or cordate leaves; (also parnassia) a plant of this genus, especially grass of Parnassus, P. palustris.
--Examples--
--Word--
Parnassian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to poetry; poetic.
Denoting a group of French poets of the late 19th century who emphasized strictness of form, named from the anthology Le Parnasse contemporain (1866)
A member of the Parnassian group of poets.
--Examples--
‘the Parnassian movement’
‘the poetic values of the Parnassians’
--Word--
Parnassianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The poetic technique developed by and characteristic of the French Parnassian poets, emphasizing precise structural formality and strict emotional restraint. See "Parnassian".
--Examples--
--Word--
grass of Parnassus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A herbaceous plant of north temperate regions, which bears a solitary white flower.
--Examples--
--Word--
parnel 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A prostitute; a loose woman; (also) †a priest's mistress (obsolete). Also in extended use: a weak or effeminate man. In later use archaic or regional.
--Examples--
--Word--
Parnellism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The principles or policy of the Home Rule faction in the House of Commons, led by Parnell from 1880 to 1891, whose aim was to establish Home Rule in Ireland; support or advocacy of these principles.
--Examples--
--Word--
Parnellism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The principles or policy of the Home Rule faction in the House of Commons, led by Parnell from 1880 to 1891, whose aim was to establish Home Rule in Ireland; support or advocacy of these principles.
--Examples--

adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the Irish nationalist leader Charles Stewart Parnell or his policies.

--Examples--
‘the new young Parnellite lieutenants’
‘he became the Parnellite most likely to be chosen for electoral conflicts’

--Word--
parode 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In ancient Greek drama: the first ode sung by the chorus after its entrance.
--Examples--
--Word--
parody 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An imitation of the style of a particular writer, artist, or genre with deliberate exaggeration for comic effect.
An imitation or version of something that falls far short of the real thing; a travesty.
Produce a humorously exaggerated imitation of (a writer, artist, or genre)
Mimic humorously.
--Examples--
‘the film is a parody of the horror genre’
‘his provocative use of parody’
‘he gave her a parody of a smile’
‘his speciality was parodying schoolgirl fiction’
‘he parodied his friend's voice’
--Word--
parodiable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Capable of being parodied.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or of the nature of a parody; = "parodic".

adjective

adjective

--Word--
paroecious 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a bryophyte: having the male and female reproductive organs in close proximity but not mixed, especially when the antheridia are in the axils of bracts immediately below those surrounding the archegonia.
--Examples--
--Word--

paroemiac 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Ancient Greek Prosody. The short line with which an anapaestic system usually ends.
Ancient Greek Prosody. Of, relating to, or designating verse which ends with a paroemiac.

--Word--
parol 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Given or expressed orally.
(of a document) agreed orally, or in writing but not under seal.
--Examples--
‘the parol evidence’
‘there was a parol agreement’
--Word--
parole 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The temporary or permanent release of a prisoner before the expiry of a sentence, on the promise of good behaviour.
A promise or undertaking given by a prisoner of war to return to custody or act as a non-belligerent if released.
The actual linguistic behaviour or performance of individuals, in contrast to the linguistic system of a community.
Release (a prisoner) on parole.
--Examples--
‘he committed a burglary while on parole’
‘I took their paroles of honour’
‘a good many French officers had been living on parole in Melrose’
‘he was paroled after serving nine months of a two-year sentence’
--Word--
parole 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The temporary or permanent release of a prisoner before the expiry of a sentence, on the promise of good behaviour.
A promise or undertaking given by a prisoner of war to return to custody or act as a non-belligerent if released.
The actual linguistic behaviour or performance of individuals, in contrast to the linguistic system of a community.
Release (a prisoner) on parole.
--Examples--
‘he committed a burglary while on parole’
‘I took their paroles of honour’
‘a good many French officers had been living on parole in Melrose’
‘he was paroled after serving nine months of a two-year sentence’
--Word--
parole 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The temporary or permanent release of a prisoner before the expiry of a sentence, on the promise of good behaviour.
A promise or undertaking given by a prisoner of war to return to custody or act as a non-belligerent if released.
The actual linguistic behaviour or performance of individuals, in contrast to the linguistic system of a community.
Release (a prisoner) on parole.
--Examples--
‘he committed a burglary while on parole’
‘I took their paroles of honour’
‘a good many French officers had been living on parole in Melrose’
‘he was paroled after serving nine months of a two-year sentence’

--Meanings--
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--

paronychia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Medicine. An inflammation around a toenail or fingernail; a whitlow; the condition of having this.
Any of various small carpet-forming plants constituting the genus Paronychia (family Illecebraceae), which have minute apetalous flowers in dense axillary clusters almost concealed by large usually silvery stipules; also called whitlow-wort (several species being formerly reputed to cure whitlows); (in form Paronychia) the genus itself.

Paros 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A Greek island in the southern Aegean, in the Cyclades. It is noted for the translucent white Parian marble which has been quarried there since the 6th century BC.

parotoid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Either of a pair of cutaneous glandular areas which form large warty swellings behind the eyes in some amphibians, especially toads, sometimes extending on to the neck or shoulder and often producing a toxic secretion.
Designating or relating to such a gland.
--Examples--

parramatta

--Word--
par 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The number of strokes a first-class player should normally require for a particular hole or course.
A par score at a hole.
The face value of a share or other security, as distinct from its market value.
The recognized value of one country's currency in terms of another's.
Play (a hole) in par.
--Examples--
‘Woosnam had advanced from his overnight position of three under par’
‘the sixteenth is a par five’
‘a card that showed 16 pars, one eagle, and one birdie’
‘the 9 per cent unsecured loan stock is redeemable at par’
‘par value’
‘he calmly parred the 17th’

parry 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Ward off (a weapon or attack) with a countermove.
Answer (a question or accusation) evasively.
An act of parrying something.
--Examples--
‘he parried the blow by holding his sword vertically’
‘he parried questions from reporters outside the building’
‘the swords clashed in a parry’
‘her question met with a polite parry’

--Word--
parrock 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An enclosed area of ground; a small field or paddock, especially one close to a farmhouse. Also figurative. In early use also (occasionally): †a fence or set of hurdles for enclosing an area of ground (obsolete). Now chiefly English regional.
Scottish. A group of people, animals, or things packed closely together; a crowd, a mob.
Especially in Kent and Sussex: a meeting or assembly of a kind once thought to have been held in order to take account of rents and pannage. historical. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
parrot 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A bird, often vividly coloured, with a short downcurved hooked bill, grasping feet, and a raucous voice, found especially in the tropics and feeding on fruits and seeds. Many are popular as cage birds, and some are able to mimic the human voice.
Repeat mechanically.
--Examples--
‘encouraging students to parrot back information’
--Word--
parrotbeak 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various plants with flowers that resemble parrot's beaks; especially the kaka-beak, Clianthus puniceus. Usually in form "parrot's beak".
Chiefly Archaeology. A tool that resembles or is likened to a parrot's beak.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A water milfoil, Myriophyllum aquaticum, with whorls of green feather-like foliage, native to South America and now grown and naturalized widely elsewhere.
--Examples--
--Word--
Parrott 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In full "Parrott gun". A cast iron, muzzle-loading, rifled cannon with the breech reinforced with wrought iron rings.
--Examples--
--Word--
parrot-toed 
--Type--
adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
Pigeon-toed.
In a pigeon-toed manner.
--Examples--
--Word--
parrotwise 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In the manner of a parrot; parrot-fashion.
--Examples--
--Word--
parr 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A young salmon (or trout) between the stages of fry and smolt, distinguished by dark rounded patches evenly spaced along its sides.
--Examples--
--Word--
par 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The number of strokes a first-class player should normally require for a particular hole or course.
A par score at a hole.
The face value of a share or other security, as distinct from its market value.
The recognized value of one country's currency in terms of another's.
Play (a hole) in par.
--Examples--
‘Woosnam had advanced from his overnight position of three under par’
‘the sixteenth is a par five’
‘a card that showed 16 pars, one eagle, and one birdie’
‘the 9 per cent unsecured loan stock is redeemable at par’
‘par value’
‘he calmly parred the 17th’
--Word--
parsable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Able to be parsed. Also in extended use: analysable.
--Examples--
--Word--
parse 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Resolve (a sentence) into its component parts and describe their syntactic roles.
Analyse (a string or text) into logical syntactic components.
An act of parsing a string or a text.
--Examples--
‘I asked a couple of students to parse these sentences for me’
‘a user question input is parsed into an internal conceptual representation’
‘a failed parse was retried’
--Word--
parsec 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A unit of distance used in astronomy, equal to about 3.26 light years (3.086 × 10¹³ kilometres). One parsec corresponds to the distance at which the mean radius of the earth's orbit subtends an angle of one second of arc.
--Examples--
--Word--
parsec 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A unit of distance used in astronomy, equal to about 3.26 light years (3.086 × 10¹³ kilometres). One parsec corresponds to the distance at which the mean radius of the earth's orbit subtends an angle of one second of arc.

--Word--
Parsee 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An adherent of Zoroastrianism, especially a descendant of those Zoroastrians who fled to India from Muslim persecution in Persia during the 7th–8th centuries.

parsonsite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
part 
--Type--
noun, verb, adverb
--Meanings--
An amount or section which, when combined with others, makes up the whole of something.
An element or constituent that is essential to the nature of something.
A manufactured object assembled with others to make a machine; a component.
A division of a book, periodical, or broadcast serial.
A measure allowing comparison between the amounts of different ingredients used in a mixture.
Some but not all of something.
A point on or area of something.
A region, especially one not clearly specified or delimited.
A role played by an actor or actress.
The words and directions to be learned and performed by an actor in a role.
A melody or other constituent of harmony assigned to a particular voice or instrument in a musical work.
The contribution made by someone or something to an action or situation.
The appropriate or expected behaviour in a particular role or situation; one's duty.
Abilities.
A line of scalp revealed in a person's hair by combing the hair away in opposite directions on either side; a parting.
(of two things) move away from each other.
Divide to leave a central space.
Leave someone's company.
Give up possession of; hand over.
Separate (the hair of the head on either side of the parting) with a comb.
To some extent; partly (often used to contrast different parts of something)
--Examples--
‘divide the circle into three equal parts’
‘the early part of 1999’
‘body parts’
‘I was part of the family’
‘the production of aircraft parts’
‘this theme will be further explored in Parts Four and Five of the book’
‘Part Four of the series’
‘use a mix of one part cement to five parts ballast’
‘the painting tells only part of the story’
‘hold the furthest part of your leg that you can reach’
‘those of you who jet off to foreign parts for your holidays’
‘she played a lot of leading parts’
‘he took the part of Prospero’
‘she was memorizing a part’
‘he coped well with the percussion part’
‘he played a key part in ending the revolt’
‘he may be jailed for his part in the robbery’
‘in such a place his part is to make good’
‘the part in her hair was white and straight’
‘his lips parted in a smile’
‘at that moment the mist parted’
‘she parted the ferns and looked between them’
‘there was a good deal of kissing before we parted’
‘she can't bear to be parted from her daughter again’
‘even quite small companies parted with large sums’
‘his hair was centrally parted’
‘the city is now part slum, part consumer paradise’

--Type--
noun, verb, adverb
--Meanings--

(of two things) move away from each other.
Divide to leave a central space.
Leave someone's company.
Give up possession of; hand over.
Separate (the hair of the head on either side of the parting) with a comb.
To some extent; partly (often used to contrast different parts of something)

--Word--
partage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of dividing, especially into shares; division (especially of inheritable property), partition; sharing. Now rare.
Specifically. The practice of appropriating cultural artefacts or works of art from poorer countries for display in Western museums.

done 
--Type--
verb, adjective, exclamation
--Meanings--

‘her hunting days were done’
‘therapy was not the done thing then’

--Word--
part 
--Type--
noun, verb, adverb
--Meanings--
An amount or section which, when combined with others, makes up the whole of something.
An element or constituent that is essential to the nature of something.
A manufactured object assembled with others to make a machine; a component.
A division of a book, periodical, or broadcast serial.
A measure allowing comparison between the amounts of different ingredients used in a mixture.
Some but not all of something.

A role played by an actor or actress.
The words and directions to be learned and performed by an actor in a role.
A melody or other constituent of harmony assigned to a particular voice or instrument in a musical work.
The contribution made by someone or something to an action or situation.
The appropriate or expected behaviour in a particular role or situation; one's duty.
Abilities.
A line of scalp revealed in a person's hair by combing the hair away in opposite directions on either side; a parting.
(of two things) move away from each other.
Divide to leave a central space.
Leave someone's company.
Give up possession of; hand over.
Separate (the hair of the head on either side of the parting) with a comb.
To some extent; partly (often used to contrast different parts of something)

--Word--
Parthenian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Belonging to or associated with the region of Mount Parthenios in Arcadia (on the southern Greek mainland).
--Examples--
--Word--
parthenic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or characteristic of a virgin or virginity; that is a virgin; unviolated, pure.
--Examples--
--Word--
parthenium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In form Parthenium: a genus of herbs and shrubs of the family Asteraceae (Compositae), native to North America and the West Indies and having alternate, usually aromatic leaves and white or yellowish flowers with inconspicuous ray florets; (also parthenium) a plant of this genus, especially (more fully "parthenium ragweed", "parthenium weed", "ragweed parthenium") Parthenium hysterophorus, an invasive weed which may cause a severe contact dermatitis in allergic individuals. Also: †a medicinal preparation of this plant or of Parthenium integrifolium, used as an antipyretic, especially in the treatment of malaria (obsolete).
--Examples--
--Word--
parthenocarpy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The development of a fruit without prior fertilization.

--Meanings--

--Word--
parthenogenesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Reproduction from an ovum without fertilization, especially as a normal process in some invertebrates and lower plants.
--Examples--
‘cyclic parthenogenesis is well displayed in aphids’

--Word--
parthenogeny

parthenolatry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
Parthenon 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The temple of Athene Parthenos, built on the Acropolis in 447–432 BC by Pericles to honour Athens' patron goddess and to commemorate the recent Greek victory over the Persians. It was designed by Ictinus and Callicrates with sculptures by Phidias.
--Examples--
--Word--
Parthenopean 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or belonging to Naples; specifically designating the short-lived republic established in Naples by French revolutionary forces in 1799 (now historical).
--Examples--
--Word--
parthenospore 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A thick-walled spore resembling a zygospore but produced parthenogenetically in certain algae and fungi.
--Examples--
--Word--
Parthia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient kingdom which lay south-east of the Caspian Sea in present-day Iran. From c.250 BC to c.230 AD the Parthians ruled an empire stretching from the Euphrates to the Indus.
--Examples--
--Word--
Parthian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the ancient kingdom of Parthia or its inhabitants.
A native or inhabitant of the ancient kingdom of Parthia.
--Examples--
‘he pursued a Parthian army into the Syrian desert’
‘he was captured by the Parthians’
--Word--
par. 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘see par. 3.1 above’
--Word--
Parti Québécois 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A French-Canadian political party which advocates independence or greater autonomy for the province of Quebec.
--Examples--
--Word--
party 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A social gathering of invited guests, typically involving eating, drinking, and entertainment.
A formally constituted political group that contests elections and attempts to form or take part in a government.
A group of people taking part in a particular activity or trip.
A person or people forming one side in an agreement or dispute.
A person, especially one with specified characteristics.
Enjoy oneself at a party or other lively gathering, typically with drinking and music.
--Examples--
‘an engagement party’
‘draft the party's election manifesto’
‘the visiting party will be asked to conform to safety procedures whilst on site’
‘a contract between two parties’
‘an old party has been coming in to clean’
‘put on your glad rags and party!’

‘the paper gave a distorted and very partial view of the situation’
‘you know I'm partial to bacon and eggs’
‘strings would like to oscillate as closely as possible to harmonic partials’

--Word--
participle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A word formed from a verb (e.g. going, gone, being, been) and used as an adjective (e.g. working woman, burnt toast) or a noun (e.g. good breeding). In English participles are also used to make compound verb forms (e.g. is going, has been).
--Examples--
--Word--
participle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A word formed from a verb (e.g. going, gone, being, been) and used as an adjective (e.g. working woman, burnt toast) or a noun (e.g. good breeding). In English participles are also used to make compound verb forms (e.g. is going, has been).
--Examples--
--Word--
particle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A minute portion of matter.
Any of numerous subatomic constituents of the physical world that interact with each other, including electrons, neutrinos, photons, and alpha particles.
A hypothetical object having mass but no physical size.
The least possible amount.
(in English) any of the class of words such as in, up, off, over, used with verbs to make phrasal verbs.
(in ancient Greek) any of a class of words used for contrast and emphasis, such as de and ge.
--Examples--
‘tiny particles of dust’
‘he agrees without hearing the least particle of evidence’
--Word--
particled 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Composed of particles; particulate.

--Word--
particular 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Used to single out an individual member of a specified group or class.
Denoting a proposition in which something is asserted of some but not all of a class.
Especially great or intense.
Insisting that something should be correct or suitable in every detail; fastidious.
A detail.
Detailed information about someone or something.
An individual item, as contrasted with a universal quality.
--Examples--
‘the action seems to discriminate against a particular group of companies’
‘when handling or checking cash the cashier should exercise particular care’
‘she is very particular about cleanliness’
‘he is wrong in every particular’
‘a clerk took the woman's particulars’
‘universals can be simultaneously exemplified by different particulars in different places’

--Word--
particularism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Exclusive attachment to one's own group, party, or nation.
The principle of leaving each state in an empire or federation free to govern itself and promote its own interests, without reference to those of the whole.
The doctrine that some but not all people are elected and redeemed.
--Examples--
‘such barriers are created by local particularism and privilege’
‘religious and cultural particularisms’

particularity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of being individual.
Fullness or minuteness of detail in the treatment of something.
Small details.
The doctrine of God's incarnation as Jesus as a particular person at a particular time and place.
--Examples--
‘the central figures of his novels are stripped of their particularity’
‘the quality of the grapes is as significant as the particularity of the soil’
‘parties must present their case with some degree of accuracy and particularity’
‘the tedious particularities of daily life’

particularly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
To a higher degree than is usual or average.
Used to single out a subject to which a statement is especially applicable.
So as to give special emphasis to a point; specifically.
--Examples--
‘I don't particularly want to be reminded of that time’
‘particularly able students’
‘the team's defence is excellent, particularly their two centre backs’
‘he particularly asked that I should help you’

--Word--
partyism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Excessive attachment to a particular (especially political) party; party spirit. Also: the political system by which elections, debates, etc., are contested by parties.
--Examples--
--Word--
partyist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A partisan; a supporter of a particular (especially political) party.
Of or relating to a political partyist. Also, of a political system: consisting of parties that compete for election to government.
--Examples--

--Word--
mortgage 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A legal agreement by which a bank, building society, etc. lends money at interest in exchange for taking title of the debtor's property, with the condition that the conveyance of title becomes void upon the payment of the debt.
The amount of money borrowed in a mortgage.
A deed effecting a mortgage.
Convey (a property) to a creditor as security on a loan.
Expose to future risk or constraint for the sake of immediate advantage.
--Examples--
‘I put down a hundred thousand in cash and took out a mortgage for the rest’
‘a £60,000 mortgage’
‘the estate was mortgaged up to the hilt’
‘a heavily mortgaged farm’
‘some people worry that selling off state assets mortgages the country's future’

parting 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of leaving or being separated from someone.
The action of dividing something into parts.
A line of scalp revealed in a person's hair by combing the hair away in opposite directions on either side.
--Examples--
‘they exchanged a few words on parting’
‘an emotional parting from her two young children’
‘the parting of the Red Sea’
‘his hair was dark, with a side parting’

--Word--
partisan 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A strong supporter of a party, cause, or person.
A member of an armed group formed to fight secretly against an occupying force, in particular one operating in German-occupied Yugoslavia, Italy, and parts of eastern Europe in the Second World War.
Prejudiced in favour of a particular cause.
--Examples--
‘partisans of the exiled Stuarts’
‘the partisans opened fire from the woods’
‘it is not in the nature of partisan warfare to produce victory in the field’
‘newspapers have become increasingly partisan’
--Word--
partisanism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Partisanship; partisan spirit.
--Examples--
--Word--
partisanly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In the manner of a partisan; specifically over-zealously, with bias.
--Examples--
--Word--
partisanry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Partisanship; a partisan act or feeling.
--Examples--
--Word--
partisan 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A strong supporter of a party, cause, or person.
A member of an armed group formed to fight secretly against an occupying force, in particular one operating in German-occupied Yugoslavia, Italy, and parts of eastern Europe in the Second World War.
Prejudiced in favour of a particular cause.
--Examples--
‘partisans of the exiled Stuarts’
‘the partisans opened fire from the woods’
‘it is not in the nature of partisan warfare to produce victory in the field’
‘newspapers have become increasingly partisan’
--Word--
partisanly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In the manner of a partisan; specifically over-zealously, with bias.
--Examples--
--Word--
partisanship 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Prejudice in favour of a particular cause; bias.
--Examples--
‘an act of blatant political partisanship’
--Word--
partisanship 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Prejudice in favour of a particular cause; bias.
--Examples--
‘an act of blatant political partisanship’
--Word--
partyship 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or condition of being a party; partisanship.

--Word--
partite 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Divided into parts.
(especially of a leaf or an insect's wing) divided to or nearly to the base.
--Examples--
‘multipartite’
--Word--
partition 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
(especially with reference to a country with separate areas of government) the action or state of dividing or being divided into parts.
The distribution of a solute between two immiscible or slightly miscible solvents in contact with one another, in accordance with its differing solubility in each.
A structure dividing a space into two parts, especially a light interior wall.
Each of a number of portions into which some operating systems divide memory or storage.
Divide into parts.
Divide (a room) into smaller rooms or areas by erecting partitions.
--Examples--
‘the country's partition into separate states’
‘partition chromatography’
‘the cafe was divided up by glass partitions’
‘this takes a copy of hard disk partition information during installation’
‘an agreement was reached to partition the country’
‘the hall was partitioned to contain the noise of the computers’
‘partition off part of a large bedroom to create a small bathroom’
--Word--
partitional 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or of the nature of a partition; characterized by partition.
--Examples--
--Word--
partitionary 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or concerned with partition, especially of land or territory.
--Examples--

--Word--
partitive 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Denoting a grammatical construction used to indicate that only a part of a whole is referred to, for example a slice of bacon, a series of accidents, some of the children.
A partitive construction.
A noun or pronoun used as the first term in a partitive construction.
--Examples--
--Word--
partitively 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
partlet 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Originally (more fully "Dame Partlet") a name traditionally applied to: a hen. More generally: a hen; (in extended use) a woman.
An item of clothing worn over the neck and upper part of the chest, especially by women to cover a low décolletage. Also (occasionally): a bodice or chemisette.
--Examples--
--Word--
partlet 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Originally (more fully "Dame Partlet") a name traditionally applied to: a hen. More generally: a hen; (in extended use) a woman.
An item of clothing worn over the neck and upper part of the chest, especially by women to cover a low décolletage. Also (occasionally): a bodice or chemisette.
--Examples--
--Word--
partly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
To some extent; not completely.
--Examples--
‘the result is partly a matter of skill and partly of chance’
‘you're only partly right’
--Word--
partner 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Either of a pair of people engaged together in the same activity.
A person or group that takes part with another or others in doing something.
Any of a number of individuals with interests and investments in a business or enterprise, among whom expenses, profits, and losses are shared.
Either member of a married couple or of an established unmarried couple.
A person with whom one has sex; a lover.
A friendly form of address by one man to another.
Be the partner of.
Associate or work together as partners.
A timber framework secured to and strengthening the deck of a wooden ship around a hole through which a mast, capstan, pump, etc. pass.
--Examples--
‘arrange the children in pairs so that each person has a partner’
‘the striker looked sharp and eager as Jackson's partner in attack’
‘she and her dance partner were on the show for seven weeks’
‘he began to call potential coalition partners about forming a new government’
‘Scotland is the rest of the UK's second biggest trading partner’
‘a partner in a prosperous legal practice’
‘a junior partner’
‘she lived with her partner’
‘make sure that you or your partner are using an effective method of contraception’
‘how you doing, partner?’
‘young farmers who partnered Isabel to the village dance’
‘we've partnered with several venues and organizations to bring fun science events to the city’
‘the mast was not chocked at the partners as it should have been’

noun, verb, noun

--Word--
partnership 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state of being a partner or partners.
An association of two or more people as partners.
A business or firm owned and run by two or more partners.
A position as one of the partners in a business or firm.
The number of runs added by a pair of batsmen before one of them is dismissed or the innings ends.
--Examples--
‘we should go on working together in partnership’
‘an increase in partnerships with housing associations’
‘the partnership now owns 22 department stores’
‘she will be eligible for a partnership after a few years’
‘their 176-run third-wicket partnership’
--Word--
partnership 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state of being a partner or partners.
An association of two or more people as partners.
A business or firm owned and run by two or more partners.
A position as one of the partners in a business or firm.
The number of runs added by a pair of batsmen before one of them is dismissed or the innings ends.
--Examples--
