‘an increase in partnerships with housing associations’
‘the partnership now owns 22 department stores’
‘she will be eligible for a partnership after a few years’
‘their 176-run third-wicket partnership’
--Word--
part 
--Type--
noun, verb, adverb
--Meanings--
An amount or section which, when combined with others, makes up the whole of something.
An element or constituent that is essential to the nature of something.
A manufactured object assembled with others to make a machine; a component.
A division of a book, periodical, or broadcast serial.
A measure allowing comparison between the amounts of different ingredients used in a mixture.
Some but not all of something.
A point on or area of something.
A region, especially one not clearly specified or delimited.
A role played by an actor or actress.
The words and directions to be learned and performed by an actor in a role.
A melody or other constituent of harmony assigned to a particular voice or instrument in a musical work.
The contribution made by someone or something to an action or situation.
The appropriate or expected behaviour in a particular role or situation; one's duty.
Abilities.
A line of scalp revealed in a person's hair by combing the hair away in opposite directions on either side; a parting.
(of two things) move away from each other.
Divide to leave a central space.
Leave someone's company.
Give up possession of; hand over.
Separate (the hair of the head on either side of the parting) with a comb.
To some extent; partly (often used to contrast different parts of something)
--Examples--
‘divide the circle into three equal parts’
‘the early part of 1999’
‘body parts’
‘I was part of the family’
‘the production of aircraft parts’
‘this theme will be further explored in Parts Four and Five of the book’
‘Part Four of the series’
‘use a mix of one part cement to five parts ballast’
‘the painting tells only part of the story’
‘hold the furthest part of your leg that you can reach’
‘those of you who jet off to foreign parts for your holidays’
‘she played a lot of leading parts’
‘he took the part of Prospero’
‘she was memorizing a part’
‘he coped well with the percussion part’
‘he played a key part in ending the revolt’
‘he may be jailed for his part in the robbery’
‘in such a place his part is to make good’
‘the part in her hair was white and straight’
‘his lips parted in a smile’
‘at that moment the mist parted’
‘she parted the ferns and looked between them’
‘there was a good deal of kissing before we parted’
‘she can't bear to be parted from her daughter again’
‘even quite small companies parted with large sums’
‘his hair was centrally parted’
‘the city is now part slum, part consumer paradise’

Parton, Dolly

proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1946), US country music singer and songwriter; her hits include ‘Jolene’ (1974); full name Dolly Rebecca Parton.

--Word--
partridge-wood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several attractively variegated kinds of wood used especially in cabinet work, especially that of the cabbage-bark tree or angelin, Andira inermis; (also) the wood of an Australian cabbage palm, Livistona inermis, and of the Venezuelan tree Caesalpinia granadillo (family Caesalpiniaceae (Leguminosae)).
A speckled condition in the heartwood of oak resulting from infection by the basidiomycete fungus Stereum frustulatum.
--Examples--
--Word--
partridge-wood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several attractively variegated kinds of wood used especially in cabinet work, especially that of the cabbage-bark tree or angelin, Andira inermis; (also) the wood of an Australian cabbage palm, Livistona inermis, and of the Venezuelan tree Caesalpinia granadillo (family Caesalpiniaceae (Leguminosae)).
A speckled condition in the heartwood of oak resulting from infection by the basidiomycete fungus Stereum frustulatum.
--Examples--

--Word--
part 
--Type--
noun, verb, adverb
--Meanings--
An amount or section which, when combined with others, makes up the whole of something.
An element or constituent that is essential to the nature of something.
A manufactured object assembled with others to make a machine; a component.
A division of a book, periodical, or broadcast serial.
A measure allowing comparison between the amounts of different ingredients used in a mixture.
Some but not all of something.
A point on or area of something.
A region, especially one not clearly specified or delimited.
A role played by an actor or actress.
The words and directions to be learned and performed by an actor in a role.
A melody or other constituent of harmony assigned to a particular voice or instrument in a musical work.
The contribution made by someone or something to an action or situation.
The appropriate or expected behaviour in a particular role or situation; one's duty.
Abilities.
A line of scalp revealed in a person's hair by combing the hair away in opposite directions on either side; a parting.
(of two things) move away from each other.
Divide to leave a central space.
Leave someone's company.
Give up possession of; hand over.
Separate (the hair of the head on either side of the parting) with a comb.
To some extent; partly (often used to contrast different parts of something)
--Examples--
‘divide the circle into three equal parts’
‘the early part of 1999’
‘body parts’
‘I was part of the family’
‘the production of aircraft parts’
‘this theme will be further explored in Parts Four and Five of the book’
‘Part Four of the series’
‘use a mix of one part cement to five parts ballast’
‘the painting tells only part of the story’
‘hold the furthest part of your leg that you can reach’
‘those of you who jet off to foreign parts for your holidays’
‘she played a lot of leading parts’
‘he took the part of Prospero’
‘she was memorizing a part’
‘he coped well with the percussion part’
‘he played a key part in ending the revolt’
‘he may be jailed for his part in the robbery’
‘in such a place his part is to make good’
‘the part in her hair was white and straight’
‘his lips parted in a smile’
‘at that moment the mist parted’
‘she parted the ferns and looked between them’
‘there was a good deal of kissing before we parted’
‘she can't bear to be parted from her daughter again’
‘even quite small companies parted with large sums’
‘his hair was centrally parted’
‘the city is now part slum, part consumer paradise’

Pasadena 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in California, in the San Gabriel Mountains on the north-eastern side of the Los Angeles conurbation; population 143,080 (est. 2008). It is the site of the Rose Bowl stadium, venue for the American Football Super Bowl.

pascal 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
The SI unit of pressure, equal to one newton per square metre (approximately 0.000145 pounds per square inch, or 9.9 × 10^-6 atmospheres).
A high-level structured computer programming language used for teaching and general programming.

pasigraphy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A system of writing intended to be intelligible to speakers of any language (like the numerals 1, 2, 3, etc.), with characters or numbers rather than words used to represent ideas. Also in extended use: any universal language.

pasmo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A disease of flax, first reported from Argentina in 1911, caused by the fungus Mycosphaerella linorum, and characterized by circular brown or yellowish lesions on the leaves and stems. More fully "pasmo disease".

Peruvian Paso

--Meanings--
A breed of horse originating in Peru (although originally from Spanish stock), known for its smooth, ambling gait; a horse of this breed.

--Word--
Pasolini, Pier Paolo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1922–75), Italian film director and novelist. A Marxist, he drew on his experiences in the slums of Rome for his work, but became recognized for his controversial, bawdy literary adaptations, such as The Gospel According to St Matthew (1964) and The Canterbury Tales (1972).

--Examples--
--Word--
Pasquin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The person popularly supposed to be represented by a statue in Rome on which satirical Latin verses were annually posted in the 16th cent.; the statue itself. Hence: an imaginary person to whom anonymous lampoons were ascribed; a composer of lampoons. Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
pasquinade 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A satire or lampoon, originally one displayed or delivered in a public place.
--Examples--
‘he delivered a long pasquinade at the expense of my friend’

--Word--
pass 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Move or cause to move in a specified direction.
Change from one state or condition to another.
Die.
Go past or across; leave behind or on one side in proceeding.
Go beyond the limits of; surpass or exceed.
Hit a winning shot past (an opponent).
(of time) elapse; go by.
Spend or use up (a period of time)
Come to an end.
Happen; be done or said.
Transfer (something) to someone, especially by handing or bequeathing it to the next person in a series.
Be transferred from one person or place to another, especially by inheritance.
(in soccer, rugby, and other games) kick, hit, or throw (the ball) to another player of one's own side.
Put (something, especially money) into circulation.
(especially of money) circulate; be current.
(of a candidate) be successful in (an examination, test, or course)
Judge the performance or standard of (someone or something) to be satisfactory.
Be accepted as or taken for.
Be accepted as adequate; go unremarked.
(of a legislative or other official body) approve or put into effect (a proposal or law) by voting on it.
(of a proposal) be approved by a legislative or other official body.
Pronounce (a judgement or judicial sentence)
Utter (something, especially criticism)
Adjudicate or give a judgement on.
Discharge (something, especially urine or faeces) from the body.
Forgo one's turn in a game or an offered opportunity to do or have something.
Said when one does not know the answer to a question, for example in a quiz.
(of a company) not declare or pay (a dividend)
Make no bid when it is one's turn during an auction.
An act or instance of moving past or through something.
An act of passing the hands over something, as in conjuring or hypnotism.
A thrust in fencing.
A juggling trick.
A single scan through a set of data or a program.
A success in an examination, test, or course.
An achievement of a university degree without honours.
A card, ticket, or permit giving authorization for the holder to enter or have access to a place, form of transport, or event.
(in South Africa) an identity book which black people had to carry between 1952 and 1986, used to limit the movement of black people to urban areas.
(in soccer, rugby, and other games) an act of kicking, hitting, or throwing the ball to another player on the same side.
An amorous or sexual advance made to someone.
A state or situation of a specified, usually undesirable, nature.
An act of refraining from bidding during the auction.
--Examples--
‘he passed through towns and villages’
‘a plane was passing lazily overhead’
‘he passed a weary hand across his forehead’
‘pass an electric current through it’
‘homes which have passed from public to private ownership’
‘I was with him the night he passed’
‘on the way to the station she passed a cinema’
‘the two vehicles had no room to pass each other’
‘we will not let you pass’
‘the Portuguese trade passed its peak in the 1760s’
‘this item has passed its sell-by date’
‘the day and night passed slowly’
‘this was how they passed the time’
‘the danger had passed’
‘not another word passed between them’
‘this fact has passed almost unnoticed’
‘your letter has been passed to Mr Rich for action’
‘pass the milk’
‘the poem was passed from generation to generation’
‘he passed her a cup’
‘if Ann remarried the estate would pass to her new husband’
‘his intent was to pass the ball forward rather than knock it back’
‘persons who have passed bad cheques’
‘racegoers had formed card schools, and cash was passing briskly’
‘she passed her driving test’
‘he was passed fit by army doctors’
‘he could pass for a native of Sweden’
‘she couldn't agree, but let it pass’
‘the bill was passed despite fierce opposition’
‘the Bill passed by 164 votes to 107’
‘passing judgement on these crucial issues’
‘it is now my duty to pass sentence upon you’
‘she would pass remarks about the Peebles in their own house’
‘a jury could not be trusted to pass upon the question of Endacott's good faith’
‘she may have difficulty in passing urine’
‘we pass on pudding and have coffee’
‘to the enigmatic question we answered ‘Pass’’
‘the company has already passed its interim dividend’
‘South bids 1NT. North passes’
‘repeated passes with the swipe card’
‘an unmarked plane had been making passes over his house’
‘an A-level pass in Music’
‘a 100 per cent pass rate’
‘a bus pass’
‘you could only get in with a pass’
‘his cross-field pass to Giggs’
‘she made a pass at Stephen’
‘if this was what was being taught these days in colleges things had come to a pretty pass’
--Word--
pass 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Move or cause to move in a specified direction.
Change from one state or condition to another.
Die.

passade 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

passado 
--Type--

--Examples--
--Word--
passage 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The action or process of moving through or past somewhere on the way from one place to another.
The action or process of moving forward.
The right to pass through somewhere.
A journey by sea or air.
(of a migrating bird) the action of passing through a place en route to its final destination.
A narrow way allowing access between buildings or to different rooms within a building; a passageway.
A duct, vessel, or other channel in the body.
The process of transition from one state to another.
The passing of a bill into law.
A short extract from a book or other printed material.
A section of a piece of music.
An episode in a spell of longer activity such as a sporting event.
The propagation of microorganisms or cells in a series of host organisms or culture media, so as to maintain them or modify their virulence.
Subject (a strain of microorganisms or cells) to a passage.
--Examples--
‘there were moorings for boats wanting passage through the lock’
‘despite the passage of time she still loved him’
‘we obtained a permit for safe passage from the embassy’
‘I booked a passage on the next ship’
‘the species occurs regularly on passage’
‘a passage migrant’
‘the larger bedroom was at the end of the passage’
‘an allegory on the theme of the passage from ignorance to knowledge’
‘a catalyst for the unrest was the passage of a privatization law’
‘he picked up the newspaper and read the passage again’
‘an orchestral passage’
‘a neat passage of midfield play’
‘cultured cells can replicate on serial passage for predictable periods of time’
‘each recombinant virus was passaged nine times successively’
--Word--
passageable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Especially of tumour or tissue cells: capable of being subjected to passage.
--Examples--
--Word--
passage boat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A passenger boat crossing regularly between two places; a ferry.
--Examples--

passager 
--Type--

--Meanings--
Passage hawk.
--Examples--
--Word--
passage 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The action or process of moving through or past somewhere on the way from one place to another.
The action or process of moving forward.
The right to pass through somewhere.
A journey by sea or air.
(of a migrating bird) the action of passing through a place en route to its final destination.
A narrow way allowing access between buildings or to different rooms within a building; a passageway.
A duct, vessel, or other channel in the body.
The process of transition from one state to another.
The passing of a bill into law.
A short extract from a book or other printed material.
A section of a piece of music.
An episode in a spell of longer activity such as a sporting event.
The propagation of microorganisms or cells in a series of host organisms or culture media, so as to maintain them or modify their virulence.
Subject (a strain of microorganisms or cells) to a passage.
--Examples--
‘there were moorings for boats wanting passage through the lock’
‘despite the passage of time she still loved him’
‘we obtained a permit for safe passage from the embassy’
‘I booked a passage on the next ship’
‘the species occurs regularly on passage’
‘a passage migrant’
‘the larger bedroom was at the end of the passage’
‘an allegory on the theme of the passage from ignorance to knowledge’
‘a catalyst for the unrest was the passage of a privatization law’
‘he picked up the newspaper and read the passage again’
‘an orchestral passage’
‘a neat passage of midfield play’
‘cultured cells can replicate on serial passage for predictable periods of time’
‘each recombinant virus was passaged nine times successively’
--Word--
passager 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Passage hawk.
--Examples--
--Word--
passageway 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A long, narrow way, typically having walls either side, that allows access between buildings or to different rooms within a building.
--Examples--
‘her hotel was at the end of a narrow passageway off the main street’
‘the palace was full of secret passageways’
--Word--
passageway 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A long, narrow way, typically having walls either side, that allows access between buildings or to different rooms within a building.
--Examples--
‘her hotel was at the end of a narrow passageway off the main street’
‘the palace was full of secret passageways’
--Word--
passagework 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Music notable chiefly for the scope it affords for virtuoso playing.
--Examples--
‘some of the passagework in early Beethoven is very awkward’
--Word--
passage 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The action or process of moving through or past somewhere on the way from one place to another.

--Word--
Passaic 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An industrial city in northeastern New Jersey, on the Passaic River; population 66,884 (est. 2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
passalid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the scarabaeoid family Passalidae of glossy black beetles with somewhat flattened and elongated bodies, found in decaying wood in warm forest regions and noted for the way they tend their young.
A beetle of the family Passalidae.
--Examples--
--Word--
Passamaquoddy 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a North American people inhabiting parts of south-eastern Maine and south-western New Brunswick.
The Algonquian language of the Passamaquoddy, now with few speakers.
Relating to the Passamaquoddy or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
passement 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A strip of braiding, usually made with gold or silver wire or with silk, used as decorative trimming in interior design and fashion; usually in plural Also: such strips collectively, as a material; passementerie; = "lace".
--Examples--
--Word--
passamezzo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A slow dance of Italian origin in 2/4 time, related to the pavane; a piece of music for this.
--Examples--
--Word--
passant 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of an animal) represented as walking, with the right front foot raised. The animal is depicted in profile facing the dexter side with the tail raised, unless otherwise specified (e.g. as ‘passant guardant’).
--Examples--
--Word--
passaree 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A rope used in square-rigged ships to spread a foresail or mainsail when sailing before the wind, by hauling the clews to the end of a lower studdingsail boom.
--Examples--
--Word--
passata 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A thick paste made from sieved tomatoes and used especially in Italian cooking.
--Examples--
--Word--
passback 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Amer. Football. A backward pass from the centre to put the ball in play.
Association Football. A defensive pass directed backwards to a teammate, usually the goalkeeper.
--Examples--
--Word--
passband 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A frequency band within which signals are transmitted by a filter without attenuation.

--Meanings--

pass-by 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An act of passing by. rare before late 20th cent.
A passer-by. rare.
Mining. A place on a railway where vehicles can pass one another. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
bye 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The transfer of a competitor directly to the next round of a competition in the absence of an assigned opponent.
A run scored from a ball that passes the batsman without being hit (recorded as an extra, not credited to the individual batsman).
One or more holes remaining unplayed after a match has been decided.
--Examples--
‘he has a bye into the second round’
--Word--
passbook 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A book issued by a bank or building society to an account holder, recording sums deposited and withdrawn.
(in South Africa under apartheid) a black person's pass.

passé 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
No longer fashionable; out of date.
(especially of a woman) past one's prime.
--Examples--
‘minis are passé—the best skirts are knee-length’
--Word--
pass 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Move or cause to move in a specified direction.
Change from one state or condition to another.
Die.
Go past or across; leave behind or on one side in proceeding.
Go beyond the limits of; surpass or exceed.
Hit a winning shot past (an opponent).
(of time) elapse; go by.
Spend or use up (a period of time)
Come to an end.
Happen; be done or said.
Transfer (something) to someone, especially by handing or bequeathing it to the next person in a series.
Be transferred from one person or place to another, especially by inheritance.
(in soccer, rugby, and other games) kick, hit, or throw (the ball) to another player of one's own side.
Put (something, especially money) into circulation.
(especially of money) circulate; be current.
(of a candidate) be successful in (an examination, test, or course)
Judge the performance or standard of (someone or something) to be satisfactory.
Be accepted as or taken for.
Be accepted as adequate; go unremarked.
(of a legislative or other official body) approve or put into effect (a proposal or law) by voting on it.
(of a proposal) be approved by a legislative or other official body.
Pronounce (a judgement or judicial sentence)
Utter (something, especially criticism)
Adjudicate or give a judgement on.
Discharge (something, especially urine or faeces) from the body.
Forgo one's turn in a game or an offered opportunity to do or have something.
Said when one does not know the answer to a question, for example in a quiz.
(of a company) not declare or pay (a dividend)
Make no bid when it is one's turn during an auction.
An act or instance of moving past or through something.
An act of passing the hands over something, as in conjuring or hypnotism.
A thrust in fencing.
A juggling trick.
A single scan through a set of data or a program.
A success in an examination, test, or course.
An achievement of a university degree without honours.
A card, ticket, or permit giving authorization for the holder to enter or have access to a place, form of transport, or event.
(in South Africa) an identity book which black people had to carry between 1952 and 1986, used to limit the movement of black people to urban areas.
(in soccer, rugby, and other games) an act of kicking, hitting, or throwing the ball to another player on the same side.
An amorous or sexual advance made to someone.
A state or situation of a specified, usually undesirable, nature.
An act of refraining from bidding during the auction.
--Examples--
‘he passed through towns and villages’
‘a plane was passing lazily overhead’
‘he passed a weary hand across his forehead’
‘pass an electric current through it’
‘homes which have passed from public to private ownership’
‘I was with him the night he passed’
‘on the way to the station she passed a cinema’
‘the two vehicles had no room to pass each other’
‘we will not let you pass’
‘the Portuguese trade passed its peak in the 1760s’
‘this item has passed its sell-by date’
‘the day and night passed slowly’
‘this was how they passed the time’
‘the danger had passed’
‘not another word passed between them’
‘this fact has passed almost unnoticed’
‘your letter has been passed to Mr Rich for action’
‘pass the milk’
‘the poem was passed from generation to generation’
‘he passed her a cup’
‘if Ann remarried the estate would pass to her new husband’
‘his intent was to pass the ball forward rather than knock it back’
‘persons who have passed bad cheques’
‘racegoers had formed card schools, and cash was passing briskly’
‘she passed her driving test’
‘he was passed fit by army doctors’
‘he could pass for a native of Sweden’
‘she couldn't agree, but let it pass’
‘the bill was passed despite fierce opposition’
‘the Bill passed by 164 votes to 107’
‘passing judgement on these crucial issues’
‘it is now my duty to pass sentence upon you’
‘she would pass remarks about the Peebles in their own house’
‘a jury could not be trusted to pass upon the question of Endacott's good faith’
‘she may have difficulty in passing urine’
‘we pass on pudding and have coffee’
‘to the enigmatic question we answered ‘Pass’’
‘the company has already passed its interim dividend’
‘South bids 1NT. North passes’
‘repeated passes with the swipe card’
‘an unmarked plane had been making passes over his house’
‘an A-level pass in Music’
‘a 100 per cent pass rate’
‘a bus pass’
‘you could only get in with a pass’
‘his cross-field pass to Giggs’
‘she made a pass at Stephen’
‘if this was what was being taught these days in colleges things had come to a pretty pass’

passenger 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A traveller on a public or private conveyance other than the driver, pilot, or crew.
A member of a team or group who does far less effective work than the other members.
--Examples--
‘more than 50 passengers escaped injury when a train was derailed’
‘a passenger ferry’
‘he had been a superlative teacher but his health was gone and he was now a passenger’
--Word--
passenger mile 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
One mile travelled by one passenger, as a unit of traffic.
--Examples--
--Word--
passenger pigeon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An extinct long-tailed North American pigeon, noted for its long migrations in huge flocks. It was relentlessly hunted, the last individual dying in captivity in 1914.

passepartout 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A picture or photograph mounted between a piece of glass and a sheet of card (or two pieces of glass) stuck together at the edges with adhesive tape.

passer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who gives or transfers something to someone else.
(in soccer, rugby, and other games) a player who kicks, hits, or throws the ball to another on their side.
A legislative or other official body that approves or puts into effect a proposal or law by voting on it.
--Examples--
‘the passer of the note’
‘he is an excellent passer of the ball’
‘one of the league's most accurate passers’
‘a passer of legislation’

--Type--

--Meanings--

‘he leaned out of the window and waved at passers-by’

--Word--
Passeres 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Treated as plural. A large order of birds (now usually called Passeriformes), comprising the perching birds and (formerly) some others; the perching birds collectively, the passerines.
--Examples--
--Word--
passeriform 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling a sparrow in form or structure; specifically of or relating to the order Passeriformes of perching birds.
--Examples--
--Word--
passerine 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting birds of a large order distinguished by having feet that are adapted for perching, including all songbirds.
A passerine bird; a perching bird.
--Examples--

--Word--
guard 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Watch over in order to protect or control.
Watch over (someone) to prevent them from escaping.
Stay close to (an opponent) in order to prevent them getting or passing the ball.
Protect against damage or harm.
Take precautions against.
A person who keeps watch, especially a soldier or other person assigned to protect a person or to control access to a place.
A body of soldiers serving to protect a place or person.
The household troops of the British army.
A member of the Irish police force; a Garda.
A prison warder.
A device worn or fitted to prevent injury or damage.
A defensive posture that is adopted in a boxing or martial arts contest or in a fight.
A state of vigilance or preparedness against adverse circumstances.
An official who rides on and is in general charge of a train.
Each of two players either side of the centre.
Each of two players chiefly responsible for marking opposing players.
--Examples--
‘two men were left to guard the stockade’
‘the gates were guarded by soldiers’
‘his task was to help guard Japanese prisoners’
‘when a player is so closely guarded he cannot pass the ball’
‘the company fiercely guarded its independence’
‘farmers must guard against sudden changes in the market’
‘a security guard’
‘soldiers on guard duty’
‘he's the captain of the palace guard’
‘There's bends all the way from Portlaoise to Carlow. The responsibility for speeding traffic rests with the guards’
‘a retractable blade guard’
‘before Seb could raise his guard Boz swung a wild punch’
‘he let his guard slip enough to make some unwise comments’

--Word--
passing 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Going past.
(of a period of time) going by.
Carried out quickly and lightly.
(of a resemblance or similarity) slight.
The passage of something, especially time.
(in sport) the action of passing a ball to another team member.
The end of something.
A person's death.
--Examples--
‘passing cars’
‘she detested him more with every passing second’
‘a passing glance’
‘with the passing of the years she had become a little eccentric’
‘his play showed good passing and control’
‘the passing of the Cold War’
‘her passing will be felt deeply by many people’

--Examples--
--Word--
passion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Strong and barely controllable emotion.
A state or outburst of strong emotion.
Intense sexual love.
An intense desire or enthusiasm for something.
A thing arousing great enthusiasm.
The suffering and death of Jesus.
An account of the Passion from any of the Gospels.
A musical setting of any of the biblical accounts of the Passion.
--Examples--
‘a man of impetuous passion’
‘oratory in which he gradually works himself up into a passion’
‘their all-consuming passion for each other’
‘she nurses a passion for Thomas’
‘the English have a passion for gardens’
‘modern furniture is a particular passion of Bill's’
‘meditations on the Passion of Christ’
‘an aria from Bach's St Matthew Passion’
--Word--
passional 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or marked by passion.
A book about the sufferings of saints and martyrs, for reading on their feast days.
--Examples--
‘a current of passional electric energy’
--Word--
passionary 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A book containing accounts of the sufferings of saints and martyrs, for reading on their feast days; a martyrology. In early use also (occasionally): a written account of a particular saint's life.
--Examples--
--Word--
passionary 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A book containing accounts of the sufferings of saints and martyrs, for reading on their feast days; a martyrology. In early use also (occasionally): a written account of a particular saint's life.
--Examples--
--Word--
passionate 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having, showing, or caused by strong feelings or beliefs.
Arising from intense feelings of sexual love.
--Examples--
‘passionate pleas for help’
‘he's passionate about football’
‘a passionate kiss’
--Word--
passionately 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that shows strong feelings or beliefs.
With or involving intense feelings of sexual love.
--Examples--
‘he argued passionately against war’
‘Ruth was passionately interested in politics’
‘he fell passionately in love with her’

passionateness

noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

passionateness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
blazing 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Very hot.
(of an argument) very heated.
--Examples--
‘the delicious cool of marble corridors after the blazing heat outside’
‘she had a blazing row with Eddie and stormed out’
--Word--
breathing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process of taking air into and expelling it from the lungs.
A sign in Greek (῾ or ᾿) indicating the presence of an aspirate (rough breathing) or the absence of an aspirate (smooth breathing) at the beginning of a word.
--Examples--
‘his breathing was shallow’

adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
passion flower 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An evergreen climbing plant of warm regions, which bears distinctive flowers with parts that supposedly resemble instruments of the Crucifixion.
--Examples--
--Word--
passion flower 
--Type--
noun

--Word--
fraught 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a situation or course of action) filled with or likely to result in (something undesirable)
Causing or affected by anxiety or stress.
--Examples--
‘marketing any new product is fraught with danger’
‘there was a fraught silence’
‘she sounded a bit fraught’
--Word--
frenzied 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Wildly excited or uncontrolled.
--Examples--
‘a frenzied attack’
--Word--
passion fruit 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The edible purple fruit of a kind of passion flower that is grown commercially, especially in tropical America and the Caribbean.
--Examples--
--Word--
guided 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Conducted by a guide.
Directed by remote control or by internal equipment.
--Examples--
‘a guided tour of the castle’
‘a guided missile’
--Word--
Passionist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Roman Catholic Church. A member of the Congregation of the Passion, a religious order devoted to keeping alive the memory of Christ's Passion, founded by Paolo Francesco Danei (St Paul of the Cross) in Italy in 1720.
Of or relating to a Passionist or Passionists.
--Examples--

--Word--
kindling 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Small sticks or twigs used for lighting fires.
(in neurology) a process by which a seizure or other brain event is both initiated and its recurrence made more likely.
--Examples--
--Word--
led 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, noun
--Meanings--
A light-emitting diode (a semiconductor diode which glows when a voltage is applied)
--Examples--
‘light sources can be fluorescent tubes, optical fibres, or LEDs’
‘an LED display’
--Word--
passionless 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Lacking strong emotion; unemotional.
--Examples--
‘the voice is passionless, monotone’
--Word--
passionlessly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a passionless manner; having or expressing no passion, enthusiasm, or excitement.
--Examples--

passionlessness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or condition of being or appearing passionless.
--Examples--
--Word--
passionometer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An (especially imaginary) instrument used to measure passion or emotion.
--Examples--
--Word--
proud 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Feeling deep pleasure or satisfaction as a result of one's own achievements, qualities, or possessions or those of someone with whom one is closely associated.
(of an event, achievement, etc.) causing someone to feel proud.
Having or showing a high or excessively high opinion of oneself or one's importance.
Conscious of one's own dignity.
Imposing; splendid.
Slightly projecting from a surface.
Denoting flesh that has grown round a healing wound with excessive granulation of the tissues.
--Examples--
‘a proud grandma of three boys’
‘she got nine passes and he was so proud of her’
‘we have a proud history of innovation’
‘he was a proud, arrogant man’
‘I was too proud to go home’
‘bulrushes emerge tall and proud from the middle of the pond’
‘balls standing proud of the fabric’

--Word--
wasted 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Used or expended carelessly or to no purpose.
(of an action) not producing the desired result.
(of a person or a part of the body) weak or emaciated.
Under the influence of alcohol or illegal drugs.
--Examples--
‘wasted fuel’
‘a wasted opportunity’
‘I'm sorry you've had a wasted journey’
‘her wasted arm’
‘he looked kind of wasted’

--Word--
passival 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating an intransitive verb with a passive meaning. Now rare (chiefly historical with reference to Henry Sweet).
--Examples--
--Word--
passivate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make (a metal or other substance) unreactive by altering the surface layer or coating the surface with a thin inert layer.
Coat (a semiconductor) with inert material to protect it from contamination.
--Examples--
‘components are made from passivated and anodized aluminium’
‘the process both cleans and passivates stainless steel’
--Word--
passivation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
passive 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Accepting or allowing what happens or what others do, without active response or resistance.
Denoting a voice of verbs in which the subject undergoes the action of the verb (e.g. they were killed as opposed to the active form he killed them).
(of a circuit or device) containing no source of electromotive force.
(of radar or a satellite) receiving or reflecting radiation from a transmitter or target rather than generating its own signal.
(of a heating system) making use of incident sunlight as an energy source.
(of a metal) made unreactive by a thin inert surface layer of oxide.
A passive form of a verb.
The passive voice.
--Examples--
‘the women were portrayed as passive victims’
‘a passive optical network is to be installed in 2000 homes’
‘passive sensors detect the emissions from enemy radar’
‘bananas can be grown at the highest altitude using passive solar heating alone’
--Word--
passively 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an accepting manner, without active response or resistance.
Using the passive voice.
From a transmitter or target rather than by generating a signal.
By making use of incident sunlight as an energy source.
--Examples--
‘we don't have to sit passively by while others decide our fate’
‘they will not passively accept defeat’
‘it is passively expressed that he was "carried up"’
‘some cell phones passively receive data from geosynchronous satellites’
‘passively heated homes’
--Word--
passive 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Accepting or allowing what happens or what others do, without active response or resistance.

(of radar or a satellite) receiving or reflecting radiation from a transmitter or target rather than generating its own signal.

--Word--
passive 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
passivism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality or condition of being passive; a passive attitude or way of behaving; especially the principle or practice of using passive resistance.
Psychology. The condition of being passive or submissive in sexual practices, especially when manifesting as masochism in males. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
passivist 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or characterized by an opposition to war or violence; pacifist.
Characterized by the habit or practice of being passive, accepting, or non-resistant.
Philosophy. Denoting or relating to the theory of the passive acquisition of knowledge through the senses.
A person who is passive, especially one who allows things to happen without taking active measures to resist or alter them.
Psychology. A man who takes a passive sexual role; especially a male masochist.
Frequently derogatory. A person who passively resists or opposes war; a pacifist.
--Examples--
--Word--
passivity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Acceptance of what happens, without active response or resistance.
The state of inactivity of a metal made unreactive by a thin inert surface layer of oxide.
--Examples--
‘the perceived passivity of the populace is deceptive’
‘the passivity of television watching’
‘nickel increases the overall passivity of the iron’

--Word--
passless 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That cannot be passed, impassable. In early use chiefly poetic and literary.
Of a person: without a pass or authorization document.
--Examples--
--Word--
passman 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
At Oxford and Cambridge Universities: a (male) student who reads for and takes a pass degree, as opposed to an honours degree; a student who passes a degree without attaining honours. Compare honour man; "class-man". Compare also "pass-woman". Now historical.
Slang. A male prisoner who is allowed to leave his cell as a special privilege, especially in order to perform certain duties.
--Examples--
--Word--
passman 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
At Oxford and Cambridge Universities: a (male) student who reads for and takes a pass degree, as opposed to an honours degree; a student who passes a degree without attaining honours. Compare honour man; "class-man". Compare also "pass-woman". Now historical.
Slang. A male prisoner who is allowed to leave his cell as a special privilege, especially in order to perform certain duties.

--Type--

--Word--
Passover 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The major Jewish spring festival which commemorates the liberation of the Israelites from Egyptian slavery, lasting seven or eight days from the 15th day of Nisan.
--Examples--
--Word--
passoverish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Suggestive of the Passover; especially resembling the traditional Passover meal.
--Examples--
--Word--
Passover 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The major Jewish spring festival which commemorates the liberation of the Israelites from Egyptian slavery, lasting seven or eight days from the 15th day of Nisan.
--Examples--
--Word--
passport 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An official document issued by a government, certifying the holder's identity and citizenship and entitling them to travel under its protection to and from foreign countries.
A thing that ensures admission to or the achievement of something.
--Examples--
‘a British citizen with a valid passport does not need a visa to visit the US’
‘a passport photograph’
‘good qualifications are a passport to success’
--Word--
passportless 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Without a passport, not possessing a passport. Also (occasionally) as noun.
--Examples--

--Word--
password 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A secret word or phrase that must be used to gain admission to a place.
A string of characters that allows access to a computer system or service.
--Examples--
‘if you don't know the password you can't come in’
‘each user has a password in order to log on to the network’
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
passwording 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of supplying or requiring a password; (especially in Computing) protection by means of a password.
--Examples--
--Word--
past 
--Type--
adjective, noun, preposition, adverb
--Meanings--
Gone by in time and no longer existing.
Belonging to a former time.
(of a specified period of time) occurring before and leading up to the time of speaking or writing.
(of a tense) expressing an action that has happened or a state that previously existed.
The time before the moment of speaking or writing.
The history of a person or place.
A part of a person's history that is considered to be shameful.
A past tense or form of a verb.
To or on the further side of.
In front of or from one side to the other of.
Beyond in time; later than.
No longer capable of.
Beyond the limits or scope of.
So as to pass from one side of something to the other.
Used to indicate the lapse of time.
--Examples--
‘the danger is now past’
‘they made a study of the reasons why past attempts had failed’
‘he is a past chairman of the society’
‘the band has changed over the past twelve months’
‘she found it hard to make ends meet in the past’
‘the war-damaged church is preserved as a reminder of the past’
‘the monuments act as guidelines through the country's colourful past’
‘the heroine was a lady with a past’
‘a simple past of the first conjugation’
‘he rode on past the crossroads’
‘he began to drive slowly past the houses’
‘by this time it was past 3.30’
‘my watch said twenty past twelve’
‘he is past giving the best advice’
‘I was long past caring and immediately fell asleep on the bed’
‘a flotilla of glossy limousines swept past’
‘a week went past and nothing changed’
--Word--
pasta 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dish originally from Italy consisting of dough made from durum wheat and water, extruded or stamped into various shapes and typically cooked in boiling water.
--Examples--

past-due 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
paste 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A thick, soft, moist substance typically produced by mixing dry ingredients with a liquid.
A paste used as an adhesive, especially for sticking paper.
A savoury spread.
A mixture consisting mainly of clay and water that is used in making ceramic ware, especially a mixture of low plasticity based on kaolin for making porcelain.
A hard vitreous composition used in making imitation gems.
Coat with paste.
Fasten or stick (something) with paste.
Insert (a piece of text or other data copied from elsewhere).
Beat or defeat severely.
--Examples--
‘blend onions, sugar, and oil to a paste’
‘wallpaper paste’
‘salmon paste’
‘paste brooches’
‘when coating walls with fabric, paste the wall, not the fabric’
‘the posters were pasted up on to street noticeboards’
‘he pasted the guy and tied his ankles together’
--Word--
pasteboard 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of thin board made by pasting together sheets of paper.
--Examples--
‘a pasteboard ticket’

--Word--
Pasternak, Boris 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1890–1960), Russian poet, novelist, and translator; full name Boris Leonidovich Pasternak. His best-known novel, Doctor Zhivago (1957), describes the experience of the Russian intelligentsia during the Revolution; it was banned in the Soviet Union.
--Examples--

pasterned 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A thick, soft, moist substance typically produced by mixing dry ingredients with a liquid.
A paste used as an adhesive, especially for sticking paper.
A savoury spread.

--Word--
Pasteur treatment 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A therapeutic method, used especially for rabies, involving successive inoculations with attenuated virus gradually increasing in virulence. Compare Pasteurism. Now chiefly historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pasteurella 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of bacteria (family Pasterellaceae) comprising small, Gram-negative, usually aerobic, rod-shaped or coccoid forms which are parasites of mammals and birds and cause systemic and localized infections including fowl cholera and haemorrhagic septicaemia; (also pasteurella) a bacterium of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pasteurella 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of bacteria (family Pasterellaceae) comprising small, Gram-negative, usually aerobic, rod-shaped or coccoid forms which are parasites of mammals and birds and cause systemic and localized infections including fowl cholera and haemorrhagic septicaemia; (also pasteurella) a bacterium of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
pasteurellosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bacterial infection commonly affecting animals and sometimes transferred to humans through bites and scratches.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pasteurian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or relating to Louis Pasteur or his ideas and methods.
A supporter of Pasteur's theories; a person who uses Pasteur's methods.

pasteurization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
pasteurize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Subject (milk, wine, or other products) to a process of partial sterilization, especially one involving heat treatment or irradiation, thus making the product safe for consumption and improving its keeping quality.
--Examples--
‘pasteurized milk’
‘a temperature high enough to pasteurize the milk’

pastiche 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An artistic work in a style that imitates that of another work, artist, or period.
An artistic work consisting of a medley of pieces imitating various sources.
Imitate the style of (an artist or work)
--Examples--
‘the operetta is a pastiche of 18th century style’
‘the songs amount to much more than blatant pastiche’
‘a pastiche of literary models and sources’
‘Gauguin took himself to a Pacific island and pastiched the primitive art he found there’

pastophorium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Ancient History. The apartment of the pastophori in an Egyptian temple.
Archaeology and Orthodox Church. Each of a pair of rooms in some churches, especially Byzantine ones, that are used as sacristies and usually flank the apse.
--Examples--
--Word--
pastophorus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In ancient Egypt: a priest of an order responsible for carrying the shrines of gods in procession.

--Word--
pastoral 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of land) used for the keeping or grazing of sheep or cattle.
Associated with country life.
(of a work of art) portraying or evoking country life, typically in a romanticized or idealized form.
(in the Christian Church) concerning or appropriate to the giving of spiritual guidance.
Relating to or denoting a teacher's responsibility for the general well-being of pupils or students.
A work of literature portraying an idealized version of country life.
--Examples--
‘scattered pastoral farms’
‘the view was pastoral, with rolling fields and grazing sheep’
‘pastoral and doctrinal issues’
‘clergy doing pastoral work’
‘the pastoral care of boarders’
‘the story, though a pastoral, has an actual connection with the life of agricultural labour’
--Word--
pastorale 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A slow instrumental composition in compound time, usually with drone notes in the bass.
A simple musical play with a rural subject.
--Examples--
‘the pastorales in Handel's Messiah and Corelli's Christmas Concerto’
‘these two short pastorales are considered the earliest true operas in French’

--Word--
past 
--Type--
adjective, noun, preposition, adverb
--Meanings--
Gone by in time and no longer existing.
Belonging to a former time.
(of a specified period of time) occurring before and leading up to the time of speaking or writing.
(of a tense) expressing an action that has happened or a state that previously existed.
The time before the moment of speaking or writing.
The history of a person or place.
A part of a person's history that is considered to be shameful.
A past tense or form of a verb.
To or on the further side of.
In front of or from one side to the other of.
Beyond in time; later than.
No longer capable of.
Beyond the limits or scope of.
So as to pass from one side of something to the other.
Used to indicate the lapse of time.
--Examples--
‘the danger is now past’
‘they made a study of the reasons why past attempts had failed’
‘he is a past chairman of the society’
‘the band has changed over the past twelve months’
‘she found it hard to make ends meet in the past’
‘the war-damaged church is preserved as a reminder of the past’
‘the monuments act as guidelines through the country's colourful past’
‘the heroine was a lady with a past’
‘a simple past of the first conjugation’
‘he rode on past the crossroads’
‘he began to drive slowly past the houses’
‘by this time it was past 3.30’
‘my watch said twenty past twelve’
‘he is past giving the best advice’
‘I was long past caring and immediately fell asleep on the bed’
‘a flotilla of glossy limousines swept past’
‘a week went past and nothing changed’

pasture 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Land covered with grass and other low plants suitable for grazing animals, especially cattle or sheep.

‘grassy pastures’
‘a range of pasture grasses’
‘she left the office for pastures new’

‘the livestock pastured and the crops grew’

--Word--
Patagonia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A region of South America, in southern Argentina and Chile. Consisting largely of a dry barren plateau, it extends from the Colorado River in central Argentina to the Strait of Magellan and from the Andes to the Atlantic coast.

--Word--
Patarene 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of any of various heretical groups in the 12th cent., and (later) those with extreme rigorist or Manichaean tendencies, especially the Cathars. [Chiefly used, with derogatory implication, by their opponents.]
A member of a radical group based in 11th-cent. Milan which originally aimed to reform clerical behaviour and campaigned particularly to promote celibacy in the priesthood.
Designating or relating to the Patarenes or their beliefs.

--Word--
patch 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A piece of cloth or other material used to mend or strengthen a torn or weak point.
A pad or shield worn over a sightless or injured eye.
A piece of cloth sewn on to clothing as a badge or distinguishing mark.
An adhesive piece of drug-impregnated material worn on the skin so that the drug may be absorbed gradually over a period of time.
A small disc of black silk worn attached to the face for adornment by women in the 17th and 18th centuries.
A part of something marked out from the rest by a particular characteristic.
A small area or amount of something.
A small piece of ground, especially one used for gardening.
An area for which someone is responsible or in which they operate.
A particular period of time.
A temporary electrical or telephone connection.
A preset configuration or sound data file in an electronic musical instrument, especially a synthesizer.
A small piece of code inserted into a program to improve its functioning or to correct a fault.
Mend or strengthen (fabric or clothing) with a patch.
Place a patch over (a good eye) in order to encourage a lazy eye to work.
Cover small areas of (a surface) with something different, causing it to appear variegated.
Treat someone's injuries or repair the damage to something in an improvised way.
Construct something hastily from unsuitable components.
Restore peaceful or friendly relations after a quarrel or dispute.
Connect by a temporary electrical, radio, or telephonic connection.
Improve or correct (a routine or program) by inserting a patch.
--Examples--
‘the jacket was of well-worn tweed with leather patches on the elbows’
‘on his sleeve there was a red ‘Freedom’ patch’
‘once the patch is removed, the drug clears from the body tissue after twenty minutes’
‘his hair was combed forward to hide a growing bald patch’
‘the bird has a bright red patch under its wing’
‘patches of bluebells in the grass’
‘they spent Sundays digging their vegetable patch’
‘we didn't want any secret organizations on our patch’
‘he may have been going through a bad patch’
‘the guitar player has a certain patch on his FX which he's happy with’
‘synth patches over an endless drum pattern’
‘a program patch that fixes a bug’
‘her jeans were neatly patched’
‘the amblyopia may be treated by patching the good eye’
‘the grass was patched with sandy stretches’
‘they did their best to patch up the gaping wounds’
‘lean-tos patched together from aluminium siding and planks’
‘any ill feeling could be patched up with a phone call’
‘they sent him home to patch things up with his wife’
‘patch me through to number nine’
‘had he patched our system to recognize a magic password?’

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Capable of being repaired or strengthened with a patch.
Capable of being electrically patched.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

noun
--Meanings--
The condition of being open or unobstructed.
The condition of showing detectable parasite infection.
--Examples--
‘the procedure was successful in restoring the patency of the fallopian tubes’
‘patency rates’
‘a complication, once patency is established in the bitch, is contamination of the environment with eggs’
--Word--
patentor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
paten 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plate, typically made of gold or silver, used for holding the bread during the Eucharist and sometimes as a cover for the chalice.
A shallow metal plate or dish.
--Examples--
--Word--
patent 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A government authority or licence conferring a right or title for a set period, especially the sole right to exclude others from making, using, or selling an invention.
Patent leather.
Easily recognizable; obvious.
(of a vessel, duct, or aperture) open and unobstructed; failing to close.
(of a parasitic infection) showing detectable parasites in the tissues or faeces.
Made and marketed under a patent; proprietary.
Obtain a patent for (an invention)
--Examples--
‘he took out a patent for an improved steam hammer’
‘designs in a wide range of textures featuring super-chic patent, soft suede, or sophisticated nappa’
‘he wore black trousers and black patent shoes’
‘she was smiling with patent insincerity’
‘the patient is usually left with a patent vessel’
‘there are a few recorded cases of patent infection in man’
‘patent milk powder’
‘an invention is not your own until it is patented’

noun, adjective, verb

--Word--
paternalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The policy or practice on the part of people in authority of restricting the freedom and responsibilities of those subordinate to or otherwise dependent on them in their supposed interest.
--Examples--
‘attitudes in society reinforce a degree of paternalism among doctors’

--Word--
paternoster 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in the Roman Catholic Church) the Lord's Prayer, especially in Latin.
Any of a number of special beads occurring at regular intervals in a rosary, indicating that the Lord's Prayer is to be recited.
A lift consisting of a series of linked compartments moving continuously on an endless belt.
A fishing line to which hooks or weights are attached at intervals.
--Examples--
--Word--
paternosterer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A maker of rosaries. Now historical.

--Word--
path 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A way or track laid down for walking or made by continual treading.
The course or direction in which a person or thing is moving.
A course of action or way of achieving a specified result.
A schedule available for allocation to an individual railway train over a given route.
A definition of the order in which an operating system or program searches for a file or executable program.
(chiefly in computing and railway contexts) allocate a path.
--Examples--
‘the path continues alongside the river for half a mile’
‘the missile traced a fiery path in the sky’
‘a chosen career path’
‘a vegetarian diet could be the path to a longer life’

--Word--
Pathé, Charles 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1863–1957), French film pioneer. In 1896 he and his brothers founded a company which came to dominate the production and distribution of films. It became internationally known for its newsreels, first introduced in France in 1909.
--Examples--

adverb

‘she threw her arms around him and sobbed pathetically’

--Word--
pathfinder 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A person who goes ahead and discovers or shows others a path or way.
An aircraft sent ahead to locate and mark the target area for bombing.
An experimental plan or forecast.
An unmanned American spacecraft which landed on Mars in 1997, deploying a small robotic rover (Sojourner) to explore the surface and examine the rocks.
--Examples--
‘a pathfinder prospectus’

--Word--
pathography 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The study of the life of an individual or the history of a community with regard to the influence of a particular disease or psychological disorder.
--Examples--
‘pathography is a psychoanalytic approach to the realm of art that depends on detailed knowledge of an artist's personal life history’
‘in representing the relationship between her illness and her art, I have attempted to avoid the perspective of a pathography’

--Word--
pathology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The science of the causes and effects of diseases, especially the branch of medicine that deals with the laboratory examination of samples of body tissue for diagnostic or forensic purposes.
Pathological features considered collectively; the typical behaviour of a disease.
A pathological condition.
Mental, social, or linguistic abnormality or malfunction.
--Examples--
‘research people skilled in experimental pathology’
‘the pathology of Huntington's disease’
‘the dominant pathology is multiple sclerosis’
‘the city's inability to cope with the pathology of a burgeoning underclass’
--Word--
pathological 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to pathology.
Involving or caused by a physical or mental disease.
Compulsive; obsessive.
--Examples--
‘the interpretation of pathological studies’
‘glands with a pathological abnormality’
‘a pathological gambler’
--Word--
pathological 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to pathology.
Involving or caused by a physical or mental disease.
Compulsive; obsessive.
--Examples--
‘the interpretation of pathological studies’
‘glands with a pathological abnormality’
‘a pathological gambler’
--Word--
pathologically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that relates to pathology or disease.
In a way that is psychologically unhealthy or abnormal; compulsively.
--Examples--
‘bronchiectasis is defined pathologically as permanent dilatation of the bronchi’
‘pathologically abnormal or enlarged spleens’
‘I am pathologically shy’
‘she was pathologically obsessed with her weight’
--Word--
pathology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The science of the causes and effects of diseases, especially the branch of medicine that deals with the laboratory examination of samples of body tissue for diagnostic or forensic purposes.
Pathological features considered collectively; the typical behaviour of a disease.

--Word--
path 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A way or track laid down for walking or made by continual treading.
The course or direction in which a person or thing is moving.
A course of action or way of achieving a specified result.
A schedule available for allocation to an individual railway train over a given route.
A definition of the order in which an operating system or program searches for a file or executable program.
(chiefly in computing and railway contexts) allocate a path.
--Examples--
‘the path continues alongside the river for half a mile’
‘the missile traced a fiery path in the sky’
‘a chosen career path’
‘a vegetarian diet could be the path to a longer life’
--Word--
pathway 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A track that constitutes or serves as a path.
A way of achieving a specified result; a course of action.
A route, formed by a chain of nerve cells, along which impulses of a particular kind usually travel.
A sequence of chemical reactions undergone by a compound or class of compounds in a living organism.
--Examples--
‘a tree-lined pathway’
‘the crags and cornices of the mountainous pathways’
‘research has indisputably been part of the pathway to progress’
‘these neural pathways control vocalization’
‘enzymes of the glycolytic pathway’
‘the principal regulatory step in the biosynthetic pathway of cholesterol’
--Word--
pathwayed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a pathway; patterned with pathways or lines.
--Examples--

--Word--
patience 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The capacity to accept or tolerate delay, problems, or suffering without becoming annoyed or anxious.
Any of various forms of card game for one player, the object of which is to use up all one's cards by forming particular arrangements and sequences.
--Examples--
‘you can find bargains if you have the patience to sift through the rubbish’
‘I have run out of patience with her’
--Word--
patience dock 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
English regional (northern). The plant bistort, Polygonum bistorta.
A dock, Rumex patientia, formerly much grown as a pot-herb.
--Examples--
--Word--
patience 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The capacity to accept or tolerate delay, problems, or suffering without becoming annoyed or anxious.
Any of various forms of card game for one player, the object of which is to use up all one's cards by forming particular arrangements and sequences.
--Examples--
‘you can find bargains if you have the patience to sift through the rubbish’
‘I have run out of patience with her’
--Word--
patiency 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of being acted on, passivity. Chiefly in contrast with agency.
--Examples--
--Word--
patient 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Able to accept or tolerate delays, problems, or suffering without becoming annoyed or anxious.
A person receiving or registered to receive medical treatment.
The semantic role of a noun phrase denoting something that is affected or acted upon by the action of a verb.
--Examples--
‘be patient, your time will come’
‘a patient and painstaking approach’
‘many patients in the hospital were more ill than she was’
--Word--
patiently 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that shows tolerance of delays, problems, or suffering without becoming annoyed or anxious.
--Examples--
‘the assembled hordes waited patiently to get in’
‘he patiently explained the pros and cons’
--Word--
patientless 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a doctor, hospital, etc.: having no patients.
--Examples--
--Word--
patiently 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that shows tolerance of delays, problems, or suffering without becoming annoyed or anxious.
--Examples--
‘the assembled hordes waited patiently to get in’
‘he patiently explained the pros and cons’

--Word--
patina 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A green or brown film on the surface of bronze or similar metals, produced by oxidation over a long period.
A gloss or sheen on a surface resulting from age or polishing.
The impression or appearance of something.
--Examples--
‘many bronzes have been overcleaned, their original patina removed and artificially replaced’
‘the dining table will acquire a warm patina with age’
‘plankton added a golden patina to the shallow, slowly moving water’
‘he carries the patina of old money and good breeding’
--Word--
patinaed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Patinated.
--Examples--
--Word--
patina 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A green or brown film on the surface of bronze or similar metals, produced by oxidation over a long period.
A gloss or sheen on a surface resulting from age or polishing.
The impression or appearance of something.
--Examples--
‘many bronzes have been overcleaned, their original patina removed and artificially replaced’
‘the dining table will acquire a warm patina with age’
‘plankton added a golden patina to the shallow, slowly moving water’
‘he carries the patina of old money and good breeding’
--Word--
patinate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To cause to develop a patina; to cover with a patina.
--Examples--
--Word--
patinated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a metal) having a green or brown film produced by oxidation.
Having a gloss or sheen resulting from age or polishing.
--Examples--
‘a patinated bronze sculpture’
‘patinated red leather upholstery’
--Word--
patination 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The production by oxidation of a green or brown film on the surface of bronze or similar metals.
The production or formation of a gloss or sheen.
--Examples--
‘natural patination on ancient bronzes’
‘the sheets are chemically treated to bring about a green patination’
‘tan interior leather with just a little patination from regular use’

--Word--
Patmos 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A Greek island in the Aegean Sea, one of the Dodecanese group. It is believed that St John was living there in exile (from AD 95) when he had the visions described in Revelation.
--Examples--
--Word--
Patmore, Coventry 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1823–96), English poet; full name Coventry Kersey Dighton Patmore. His most important work is The Angel in the House (1854–63), a sequence of poems in praise of married love.
--Examples--
--Word--
Patmos 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A Greek island in the Aegean Sea, one of the Dodecanese group. It is believed that St John was living there in exile (from AD 95) when he had the visions described in Revelation.
--Examples--
--Word--
Patna 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in north-eastern India, on the Ganges, capital of the state of Bihar; population 1,814,000 (est. 2009). An important city in ancient times, it had become deserted by the 7th century but was refounded in 1541 by the Moguls and became a viceregal capital.

patness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
patois 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The dialect of a particular region, especially one with low status in relation to the standard language of the country.
The jargon or informal speech used by a particular social group.
--Examples--
‘the nurse talked to me in a patois that even Italians would have had difficulty in understanding’
‘the raunchy patois of inner-city kids’
--Word--
patola 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Brightly coloured fine silk cloth made by dyeing the thread before weaving; a cloth or sari made of this.
--Examples--
--Word--
Paton, Alan 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1903–88), South African writer and politician; full name Alan Stewart Paton. He is best known for his novel Cry, the Beloved Country (1948), a passionate indictment of the apartheid system.
--Examples--

--Word--
Patras 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An industrial port in the north-western Peloponnese, on the Gulf of Patras; population 167,400 (est. 2009). It was the site in 1821 of the outbreak of the Greek war of independence. Greek name Pátrai /ˈpatrɛ/.

patria 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
One's native country or homeland.
Heaven, regarded as the true home from which the soul is exiled while on earth.
--Examples--
‘they remained faithful to their patria, Spain’
--Word--
parens patriae 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The monarch, or any other authority, regarded as the legal protector of citizens unable to protect themselves.
The principle that political authority carries with it the responsibility for such protection.
--Examples--
‘parens patriae jurisdiction’
--Word--
patrial 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person with the right to live in the UK through the British birth of a parent or grandparent.
--Examples--
‘the 1971 Act classified people as patrials and non-patrials’
--Word--
patriarch 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The male head of a family or tribe.
An older man who is powerful within an organization.
The male founder of something.
Any of those biblical figures regarded as fathers of the human race, especially Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and their forefathers, or the sons of Jacob.
A bishop of one of the most ancient Christian sees (Alexandria, Antioch, Constantinople, Jerusalem, and formerly Rome).
The head of an autocephalous or independent Orthodox Church.
A Roman Catholic bishop ranking above primates and metropolitans and immediately below the Pope, often the head of a Uniate community.
--Examples--
‘Hollywood's reigning patriarch rose to speak’
‘he's the patriarch of all spin doctors’
‘Patriarch of Moscow and All Russia’
‘Patriarch of Venice’
--Word--
patriarchal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a system of society or government controlled by men.
Relating to a patriarch.
--Examples--
‘a patriarchal society’
‘patriarchal values’
‘a tall man who cut a patriarchal figure as he strode the floor of his busy factory’
--Word--
patriarchalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The principle or practice of patriarchal rule, authority, or government; a patriarchal system of society.

adverb

--Word--
patriarchy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A system of society or government in which the father or eldest male is head of the family and descent is reckoned through the male line.
A system of society or government in which men hold the power and women are largely excluded from it.
A society or community organized on patriarchal lines.
--Examples--
‘the thematic relationships of the ballad are worked out according to the conventional archetypes of the patriarchy’
‘the dominant ideology of patriarchy’
‘we live in a patriarchy’

--Word--
Neal, Patricia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1926–2010), US stage and movie actress; born Patsy Louise Neal. She was an award-winning actress when she suffered several massive strokes in 1965. Her long, hard recovery was remarkable, and she returned to acting in 1968. Among the many movies in which she appeared were Hud (1963), The Subject Was Roses (1968), and Cookie's Fortune (1999).
--Examples--

White, Patrick 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1912–90), Australian novelist, born in Britain; full name Patrick Victor Martindale White. White's reputation is chiefly based on the two novels The Tree of Man (1955) and Voss (1957). Nobel Prize for Literature (1973).

adjective

A person who believes that God the Father suffered on the Cross with or in the person of the Son; especially a member of any of various heretical sects in the early Church who held this belief.

--Word--
patrol 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An expedition to keep watch over an area, especially by guards or police walking or driving around at regular intervals.
A person or group of people sent to keep watch over an area.
The action of keeping watch over an area.
A routine operational voyage of a ship or aircraft.
An official who controls traffic where children cross the road.
A unit of six to eight Scouts or Guides forming part of a troop.
Keep watch over (an area) by regularly walking or travelling around it.
--Examples--
‘we were ordered to investigate on a night patrol’
‘a police patrol stopped the man and searched him’
‘the police were on patrol when they were ordered to investigate the incident’
‘a submarine patrol’
‘there were two schools but no crossing patrol’
‘break the Cubs into sixes and Scouts into patrols’
‘the garrison had to patrol the streets to maintain order’
‘pairs of men were patrolling on each side of the thoroughfare’
--Word--
patrol 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An expedition to keep watch over an area, especially by guards or police walking or driving around at regular intervals.
A person or group of people sent to keep watch over an area.
The action of keeping watch over an area.
A routine operational voyage of a ship or aircraft.
An official who controls traffic where children cross the road.
A unit of six to eight Scouts or Guides forming part of a troop.
Keep watch over (an area) by regularly walking or travelling around it.
--Examples--
‘we were ordered to investigate on a night patrol’
‘a police patrol stopped the man and searched him’
‘the police were on patrol when they were ordered to investigate the incident’
‘a submarine patrol’
‘there were two schools but no crossing patrol’
‘break the Cubs into sixes and Scouts into patrols’
‘the garrison had to patrol the streets to maintain order’
‘pairs of men were patrolling on each side of the thoroughfare’

patroller

--Meanings--
--Examples--

patroller 
--Type--

--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
patrol 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An expedition to keep watch over an area, especially by guards or police walking or driving around at regular intervals.
A person or group of people sent to keep watch over an area.
The action of keeping watch over an area.
A routine operational voyage of a ship or aircraft.
An official who controls traffic where children cross the road.
A unit of six to eight Scouts or Guides forming part of a troop.
Keep watch over (an area) by regularly walking or travelling around it.
--Examples--
‘we were ordered to investigate on a night patrol’
‘a police patrol stopped the man and searched him’
‘the police were on patrol when they were ordered to investigate the incident’
‘a submarine patrol’
‘there were two schools but no crossing patrol’
‘break the Cubs into sixes and Scouts into patrols’
‘the garrison had to patrol the streets to maintain order’
‘pairs of men were patrolling on each side of the thoroughfare’

--Word--
patron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who gives financial or other support to a person, organization, or cause.
A distinguished person who takes an honorary position in a charity.
A customer of a shop, restaurant, etc., especially a regular one.
A patrician in relation to a client.
The former owner and (frequently) protector of a freed slave.
A person or institution with the right to grant a benefice to a member of the clergy.
--Examples--
‘a celebrated patron of the arts’
‘the Mental Health Foundation, of which Her Royal Highness is Patron’
‘we surveyed the plushness of the hotel and its sleek, well-dressed patrons’
--Word--
patronage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The support given by a patron.
The power to control appointments to office or the right to privileges.
A patronizing or condescending manner.
The regular custom attracted by a shop, restaurant, etc.
The rights and duties or position of a patron.
--Examples--
‘the arts could no longer depend on private patronage’
‘recruits are selected on merit, not through political patronage’
‘a twang of self-satisfaction—even patronage—about him’
‘the direct train link was ending because of poor patronage’

--Word--
patronize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Treat in a way that is apparently kind or helpful but that betrays a feeling of superiority.
Frequent (a shop, restaurant, or other establishment) as a customer.
Give financial or other support to (a person, organization, or cause)
--Examples--
‘she was determined not to be put down or patronized’
‘restaurants and bars regularly patronized by the stars were often crowded with paparazzi’
‘she patronizes worthy causes’

patronite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

pat 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Touch quickly and gently with the flat of the hand.
Draw attention to (something) by tapping it gently.
Mould into shape or put in position with gentle taps.
A quick, light touch with the hand.
A compact mass of soft material.
--Examples--
‘he patted him consolingly on the shoulder’
‘he patted the bench beside him and I sat down’
‘she patted down the earth in each pot’
‘giving him a friendly pat on the arm, she went off to join the others’
‘a pat of butter’

patte 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A paw; (humorously) a hand. rare.
A short band or strap, attached by one end and buttoning at the other, used to fasten a coat or other garment whose edges do not overlap. Also: a similar band attached at both ends for holding a belt or sash in place, or sewn on simply as a decorative trimming. Now historical.
