--Word--
pattern 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A repeated decorative design.
An arrangement or design regularly found in comparable objects.
A regular and intelligible form or sequence discernible in the way in which something happens or is done.
A model or design used as a guide in needlework and other crafts.
A set of instructions to be followed in making a sewn or knitted item.
A wooden or metal model from which a mould is made for a casting.
A sample of cloth or wallpaper.
An example for others to follow.
Decorate with a recurring design.
Give a regular or intelligible form to.
Give something a form based on that of (something else)
--Examples--
‘a neat blue herringbone pattern’
‘the house had been built on the usual pattern’
‘a complicating factor is the change in working patterns’
‘the murders followed a repeated pattern’
‘the school is located a few kilometers away and is run on the pattern of other army schools’
‘make a pattern for the zigzag edge’
‘the bag contained wool, needles, and a pattern for a sweater’
‘to make a split mould a wooden pattern has to be made first’
‘it is easier to choose carpets from the roll than from a pattern book’
‘he set the pattern for subsequent study’
‘rosebud patterned wallpapers’
‘the brain not only receives information, but interprets and patterns it’
‘the clothing is patterned on athletes' wear’
--Word--
patternable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Capable of being arranged in a pattern or being made into a pattern.
--Examples--
--Word--
pattern-bomb 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To bomb (a target) from a number of aircraft in a predetermined pattern.

--Word--
Patterson, Floyd 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1935–2006), US boxer. An Olympic middleweight champion 1952, he was also the world heavyweight champion 1956–59, 1960–62, becoming the first heavyweight to regain the title.

--Word--
Patton, George 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1885–1945), US army general; full name George Smith Patton, Jr. During World War II, he commanded the ground forces in the Allied invasion of northwest Africa 1942–43, the US Seventh Army in the Allied invasion of Sicily 1943, and the US Third Army in the drive through France 1944. His story was told in the movie Patton (1971).
--Examples--
--Word--
pattu 
--Type--

--Meanings--
A woollen fabric typically made of the coarse overhair of the Kashmir goat.
That is made of this fabric.
--Examples--
--Word--
patu 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Maori weapon in the form of a short club made of stone or bone.
--Examples--
‘he threatened people with a patu at a wedding’
--Word--
patulin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A heterocyclic antibiotic compound, C₇H₆O₄, which has carcinogenic properties and is obtained from any of several moulds (originally from Penicillium patulum).
--Examples--
--Word--
patulous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(especially of the branches of a tree) spreading.
Open; expanded.
--Examples--
‘I found him on a remote bench beneath a patulous tree’
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of being patulous; openness.

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Tortelier, Paul 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1914–90), French cellist. He was noted for his interpretations of Bach and Elgar, and was appointed professor at the Paris Conservatoire in 1957.
--Examples--
--Word--
Radcliffe, Paula 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1973), English long-distance runner; full name Paula Jane Radcliffe. She broke the women's world record for the marathon in the Chicago Marathon of 2002 and again in the London Marathon the following year.
--Examples--
--Word--
pouldron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A piece of armour covering the shoulder; a shoulder plate.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pauli, Wolfgang 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1900–58), Austrian-born American physicist. He made a major contribution to quantum theory with the Pauli exclusion principle. In 1931 he postulated the existence of the neutrino, later discovered by Enrico Fermi. Nobel Prize for Physics (1945).
--Examples--
--Word--
PAU 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
Pan American Union.
--Examples--
--Word--
Paulian 
--Type--
noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
= Paulianist.
Theology. A follower or disciple of St Paul. rare.
Theology. Of, relating to, characteristic of, or following St Paul; = "Pauline". Now also: reminiscent or suggestive of St Paul; = "Pauline".
--Examples--
--Word--
Paulianist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a sect founded by Paul of Samosata in the 3rd cent. a.d., which rejected the separate personalities of the Logos and the Holy Spirit. Also (occasionally) as adjective.
--Examples--
--Word--
Paulician 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a religious sect which arose in Armenia in the 7th century AD, professing a modified form of Manichaeism.
--Examples--
--Word--
Paulicianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

paulin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tarpaulin or other waterproof covering.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pauline 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of St Paul, his writings, or his doctrines.
(in the Roman Catholic Church) relating to Pope Paul VI, or the liturgical and doctrinal reforms pursued during his pontificate (1963–78) as a result of the Second Vatican Council.
--Examples--
‘the Pauline Epistles’
‘Ratzinger's embrace of Gamber was dissent on the Pauline reform’
--Word--
Pauling, Linus Carl 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1901–94), American chemist. He is renowned for his study of molecular structure and chemical bonding, for which he received the 1954 Nobel Prize for Chemistry. His suggestion of a helical structure for proteins formed the foundation for the elucidation of the structure of DNA.
--Examples--

--Word--
Paulist 
--Type--
noun, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
In India, especially the former Portuguese colony of Goa: a Jesuit. Now historical.
A member of the Missionary Society of St Paul the Apostle, founded in 1858 as a Roman Catholic organization for missionary work in New York.
Of or belonging to the Paulists.
= Paulista.
--Examples--
--Word--
Paulista 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(A) A person of mixed Portuguese and Brazilian Indian descent, especially one who was among the explorers or settlers of the hinterlands of southern Brazil. Chiefly historical. (b) A native or inhabitant of the city or province of São Paulo in southern Brazil.
--Examples--
--Word--
Paulite 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of the Order of St Paul the First Hermit, an order of monks originating from the union of two Hungarian monasteries in 1250.
Of or belonging to the Paulites.
--Examples--
--Word--
São Paulo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state of southern Brazil, on the Atlantic coast.
The capital city of São Paulo; population 10,886,500 (est. 2007).
--Examples--
--Word--
paulo-post 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That is a little subsequent (to some event, etc.). Of a tense: expressing an action that occurs shortly after something else. Also as preposition: shortly after.
--Examples--
--Word--
paulo-post-future 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Grammar. Designating a tense of the passive voice of Greek verbs, chiefly used to indicate that an event will take place immediately. Also in figurative context. Now archaic.
--Examples--

--Word--
paunch 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large or protruding belly.
A thick strong mat used to give protection from chafing on a mast or spar.
Disembowel (an animal)
--Examples--
‘his body was powerful and square, with the beginnings of a paunch’
‘one of the things I had to do was to paunch and skin a hare’

pauper 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A very poor person.
A recipient of relief under the provisions of the Poor Law or of public charity.
A poor person who may bring a legal action without payment of costs.
--Examples--
‘he died a pauper’
‘he was buried in a pauper's grave’

pauraque 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A long-tailed nightjar found mainly in Central and South America.
--Examples--
--Word--
paurometabolous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of an insect: characterized by a relatively slight change of form during development, the immature form being a nymph resembling the adult though lacking wings, as in members of the orders Orthoptera and Hemiptera. Also: of, relating to, or included in a division Paurometabola which, in some classifications, comprises various insect orders characterized by development of this kind.
--Examples--
--Word--
pauropod 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Pauropoda 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A small class of myriapod invertebrates which resemble the centipedes. They are small soft-bodied animals with one pair of legs per segment, living chiefly in forest litter.
--Examples--
--Word--
pauser 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who pauses; a person who stops something.
--Examples--
--Word--
pausal 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or relating to a pause in speech; specifically (in the grammar of Arabic, Hebrew, and other Semitic languages) designating the form which a word receives in pause, whereby, in certain cases, a vowel is changed (usually lengthened), or a weakened vowel reappears in full.
A pausal form of a word. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pausanias 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(2nd century), Greek geographer and historian. His Description of Greece (also called the Itinerary of Greece) is a guide to the topography and remains of ancient Greece and is still considered an invaluable source of information.
--Examples--
--Word--
pausation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of pausing; temporary cessation of activity; a pause, an intermission. "†to make pausation": to pause, to hesitate (obsolete).
--Examples--
--Word--
pause 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Interrupt action or speech briefly.
Temporarily interrupt the operation of (a process or device)
A temporary stop in action or speech.
A mark over a note or rest that is to be lengthened by an unspecified amount.
A control allowing the temporary interruption of recording, playback, or other process.
--Examples--
‘she paused, at a loss for words’
‘she had paused a tape on the VCR’
‘she dropped me outside during a brief pause in the rain’
‘he chattered away without pause’
--Word--

‘he chattered away without pause’

pauxi 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several curassows. Now chiefly (in form Pauxi): a genus comprising the (northern) helmeted curassow, Pauxi pauxi, of Venezuela and Colombia, and the related P. unicornis.

--Examples--
--Word--
Cherenkov, Pavel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1904–90), Soviet physicist; full name Pavel Alekseevich Cherenkov. He investigated the effects of high-energy particles and shared the 1958 Nobel Prize for Physics for discovering the cause of blue light emitted by radioactive substances underwater.
--Examples--
--Word--
pavement 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A raised paved or asphalted path for pedestrians at the side of a road.
Any paved area or surface.
The hard surface of a road or street.
A horizontal expanse of bare rock or cemented fragments.
--Examples--
‘he fell and hit his head on the pavement’
‘a pavement cafe’
‘the pavements and columns of these ancient ruins provided the material for more recent structures’

--Word--
pavementing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of "pavement". Now chiefly: (Medicine) the adherence of leucocytes to the inside wall of a blood vessel in a layer resembling a pavement epithelium.
Stone or other material suitable for use in the construction of pavements; pavements collectively. rare.

--Word--
Pavese, Cesare 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1908–50), Italian novelist, poet, and translator. He is best known for his last novel La Luna e i falò (1950), in which he portrays isolation and the failure of communication as a general human predicament.
--Examples--
--Word--
pavestone

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
pavvy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A cricket pavilion.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pavia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: the red buckeye, Aesculus pavia. Later: a genus (now usually regarded as a section of the genus Aesculus) comprising buckeyes having flowers with four petals and fruits with smooth rather than prickly capsules.
--Examples--
--Word--
pavid 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Fearful, timid.
--Examples--
--Word--
pavidity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Fearfulness, timidity.
--Examples--
--Word--
pavie 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A clever or deceptive movement; a nimble gesture; a flourish. In later use also: an exaggerated or excessive movement; a commotion, a bustle, a flurry.
A clingstone peach or nectarine.
--Examples--
--Word--
pavilion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A building at a cricket ground or other sports ground, used for changing and taking refreshments.
A summer house or other decorative building used as a shelter in a park or large garden.
Used in the names of buildings used for theatrical or other entertainments.
A detached or semi-detached block at a hospital or other building complex.
A large tent with a peak and crenellated decorations, used at a show or fair.
A temporary building, stand, or other structure in which items are displayed at a trade exhibition.
--Examples--
‘the resort's Spa Pavilion’
‘the form of alternating pavilions also allows the site to be developed in depth’
‘they designed the British pavilion at Shanghai World Expo 2010’

pavisade 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a defence or screen made of pavises or other shields joined in a continuous line (either in land warfare or on board ship). In later use also: a screen of canvas erected around the sides of a ship to protect and conceal the crew.

--Word--
Pavlov, Ivan 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1849–1936), Russian physiologist; full name Ivan Petrovich Pavlov. He was awarded a Nobel Prize in 1904 for his work on digestion, but is best known for his studies on the conditioned reflex. He showed by experiment with dogs how the secretion of saliva can be stimulated not only by food but also by the sound of a bell associated with the presentation of food.
--Examples--
--Word--
pavlova 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dessert consisting of a meringue base or shell filled with whipped cream and fruit.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pavlovian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to classical conditioning as described by I. P. Pavlov.
--Examples--
‘the sound of the tea trolley created a Pavlovian reaction among the men’
--Word--
Pavo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A southern constellation (the Peacock), between Grus and Triangulum Australe. Its brightest star is itself sometimes called ‘the Peacock’.
Used with preceding letter or numeral to designate a star in the constellation Pavo.
--Examples--
‘the star Beta Pavonis’

paw 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An animal's foot having claws and pads.
A person's hand.
(of an animal) feel or scrape with a paw or hoof.
(of a person) touch or handle clumsily or lasciviously.
--Examples--
‘the Internet is the easiest way to get your paws on mucky pictures’
‘the horse rose up, its forelegs pawing the air’
‘young dogs may paw at the floor and whine’
‘some overweight Casanova had tried to paw her’

pawl 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A pivoted curved bar or lever whose free end engages with the teeth of a cogwheel or ratchet so that the wheel or ratchet can only turn or move one way.
Each of a set of short bars that engage with the whelps and prevent a capstan, windlass, or winch from recoiling.

--Word--
pawn 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A chess piece of the smallest size and value, that moves one square forwards along its file if unobstructed (or two on the first move), or one square diagonally forwards when making a capture. Each player begins with eight pawns on the second rank, and can promote a pawn to become any other piece (typically a queen) if it reaches the opponent's end of the board.
A person used by others for their own purposes.
Deposit (an object) with a pawnbroker as security for money lent.
An object left as security for money lent.
--Examples--
‘he was a pawn in the game of power politics’
‘I pawned the necklace to cover the loan’
‘the bank did lend money upon pawns at low interest’

--Word--
Pawnee 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a group of North American peoples formerly living in Nebraska, and now mainly in Oklahoma.
The language of the Pawnee, belonging to the Caddoan family and now almost extinct.
Relating to the Pawnee or their language.

pax 
--Type--
noun, noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A call for a truce, used especially by schoolchildren when playing.
(in the Christian Church) the kissing by all the participants at a mass of a tablet depicting the Crucifixion or other sacred object; the kiss of peace.
(chiefly in commercial use) a person or persons.
The goddess of peace.

‘the buffet costs $53 per pax’

--Word--
paxilla 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An ossicle in the endoderm of the aboral surface of some starfishes, having a column-like part projecting above the body surface which has a flattened top covered with small hinged spines which may be lowered to create a cavity next to the aboral surface.

Paxton, Sir Joseph 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1801–65), English gardener and architect. He became head gardener at Chatsworth House in Derbyshire in 1826 and designed a series of glass-and-iron greenhouses. He later reworked these in his design for the Crystal Palace (1851).
--Examples--

Paz, Octavio 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1914–98), Mexican poet and essayist. His poems reflect a preoccupation with Aztec mythology. He is also noted for his essays written in response to the brutal suppression of student demonstrations in 1968. Nobel Prize for Literature (1990).
--Examples--

Pazand 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A method of transcribing Persian (Zoroastrian) sacred texts from Pahlavi into the Avestan script, substituting Persian for Aramaic words; a transcription made in this way.
Designating, relating to, or using this method of transcription or the Avestan script employed for it.

--Word--
pea 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A spherical green seed that is eaten as a vegetable or as a pulse when dried.
Any of the edible seeds of several other plants of the pea family, especially (in the West Indies and the southern US) the pigeon pea or the cowpea.
The hardy Eurasian climbing plant which yields pods containing peas.
Used in names of plants or seeds that are similar or related to the pea, e.g. chickpea, sweet pea.
--Examples--
‘steak and ale pie with peas and new potatoes’
‘pea soup’
--Word--
peaberry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A coffee berry containing one rounded seed instead of the usual two, through non-fertilization of one ovule or subsequent abortion. Such beans are esteemed for their fine strong flavour.
--Examples--
--Word--
pea-bird 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The northern wryneck, Jynx torquilla. Now English regional (southern).

pea-bush 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various Australian leguminous shrubs, especially of the genus Sesbania (family Fabaceae (Leguminosae)).
--Examples--
--Word--
peace 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Freedom from disturbance; tranquillity.
Mental or emotional calm.
A state or period in which there is no war or a war has ended.
A treaty agreeing peace between warring states.
The state of being free from civil disorder.
The state of being free from dissension.
A ceremonial handshake or kiss exchanged during a service in some Churches (now usually only in the Eucharist), symbolizing Christian love and unity.
--Examples--
‘he just wanted to drink a few beers in peace’
‘the peace of mind this insurance gives you’
‘the Straits were to be open to warships in time of peace’
‘the peace didn't last’
‘support for a negotiated peace’
‘police action to restore peace’
‘the 8.8 per cent offer promises peace with the union’
--Word--
abiding 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a feeling or memory) lasting a long time; enduring.
--Examples--
‘he had an abiding respect for her’

peaceable

--Meanings--

‘peaceable demonstrations for democratic reform’

--Word--
blessed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Made holy; consecrated.
A title preceding the name of a dead person considered to have led a holy life, especially a person formally beatified by the Roman Catholic Church.
Endowed with divine favour and protection.
Those who live with God in heaven.
Bringing pleasure or relief as a welcome contrast to what one has previously experienced.
Used in mild expressions of annoyance or exasperation.
--Examples--
‘the Blessed Sacrament’
‘the Convent of the Blessed Agnes’
‘blessed are the meek’
‘he felt blessed, fortunate to be in her company’
‘he half stumbled out of the room up to his bed and blessed, blessed sleep’
‘he'll want to go and see his blessed allotment’
--Word--
peace-breaker 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who violates peace or stirs up strife; a disputatious or quarrelsome person; a person who commits a breach of the peace, a violator of public order.
--Examples--
--Word--
breathing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process of taking air into and expelling it from the lungs.
A sign in Greek (῾ or ᾿) indicating the presence of an aspirate (rough breathing) or the absence of an aspirate (smooth breathing) at the beginning of a word.
--Examples--
‘his breathing was shallow’
--Word--
peace 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Freedom from disturbance; tranquillity.
Mental or emotional calm.
A state or period in which there is no war or a war has ended.
A treaty agreeing peace between warring states.
The state of being free from civil disorder.
The state of being free from dissension.
A ceremonial handshake or kiss exchanged during a service in some Churches (now usually only in the Eucharist), symbolizing Christian love and unity.
--Examples--
‘he just wanted to drink a few beers in peace’
‘the peace of mind this insurance gives you’
‘the Straits were to be open to warships in time of peace’
‘the peace didn't last’
‘support for a negotiated peace’
‘police action to restore peace’
‘the 8.8 per cent offer promises peace with the union’

--Word--
lull 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Calm or send to sleep, typically with soothing sounds or movements.
Make (someone) feel deceptively secure or confident.
(of noise or a storm) abate or fall quiet.
A temporary interval of quiet or lack of activity.
--Examples--
‘the rhythm of the boat lulled her to sleep’
‘the rarity of earthquakes there has lulled people into a false sense of security’
‘conversation lulled for an hour’
‘for two days there had been a lull in the fighting’

--Word--
restoring force 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A force that acts to return a perturbed system to equilibrium or to restore a deformed body to its original form; specifically such a force in an elastic object (e.g. a spring), the magnitude of which is proportional to the displacement.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
peacock fish 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various fishes with brilliant colours or markings, including the cuckoo wrasse, Labrus mixtus, and the peacock bass, Cichla ocellaris; (also) any of various fishes with conspicuous fan-shaped fins or tails, including the guppy, Poecilia reticulata, and tropical fishes of the genus Pterois (family Scorpaenidae).
--Examples--
--Word--
peacock flower 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Either of two trees of the family Caesalpiniaceae (Leguminosae) with showy flowers, widely planted in the tropics, the royal poinciana, Delonix regia (also "royal peacock flower"), and the pride of Barbados, Caesalpinia pulcherrima.
Any of various other plants with showy flowers or inflorescences, or with clusters of stamens resembling a peacock's crest, including Spiloxene capensis (family Hypoxidaceae), native to southern Africa, and the peacock tiger-flower, Tigridia pavonia.
--Examples--

--Word--
peacock's tail 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The tail coverts of a peacock collectively, which the bird is able to erect and expand like a fan behind its body..
Alchemy. An iridescent or multicoloured stage in the preparation of the philosopher's stone. Now historical.
The seaweed Padina pavonia, which has broadly fan-shaped fronds marked with fringed bands in shades of brown and green.

adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
peak 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
The pointed top of a mountain.
A mountain with a pointed top.
A projecting pointed part or shape.
A stiff brim at the front of a cap.
The narrow part of a ship's hold at the bow or stern.
The upper, outer corner of a sail extended by a gaff.
The point of highest activity, quality, or achievement.
A point in a curve or on a graph, or a value of a physical quantity, higher than those around it.
Reach a highest point, either of a specified value or at a specified time.
At the highest level; maximum.
Characterized by maximum activity or demand.
Decline in health and spirits; waste away.
--Examples--
‘tatters of fog clung to the peak of the mountain’
‘he climbed his last Swiss peak at the age of 80’
‘whisk two egg whites to stiff peaks’
‘further storage is found in the bow peak’
‘the peak halyard’
‘he was at his peak as a cricketer’
‘package holiday sales hit a peak of around 12 million’
‘a slight increase in velocity provides a second peak on the general velocity curve’
‘the disease peaked in summer’
‘the canal was restored to peak condition’
‘traffic speeds are reduced at peak hours’
‘she sat all day, peaking and pining, at the fire-side’
--Word--
péage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In France: a section of autoroute on which toll must be paid; a gate or barrier at which motorists pay the toll.
--Examples--

--Word--
peakedness 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
The quality or condition of having or terminating in a peak or point. Now rare.
Statistics. The extent to which distribution, as expressed in a graph, is concentrated in a peak or series of peaks.
Pinched or sickly appearance; the state of being in poor health.
--Examples--

--Word--
peak 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
The pointed top of a mountain.
A mountain with a pointed top.
A projecting pointed part or shape.
A stiff brim at the front of a cap.
The narrow part of a ship's hold at the bow or stern.
The upper, outer corner of a sail extended by a gaff.
The point of highest activity, quality, or achievement.
A point in a curve or on a graph, or a value of a physical quantity, higher than those around it.
Reach a highest point, either of a specified value or at a specified time.
At the highest level; maximum.
Characterized by maximum activity or demand.
Decline in health and spirits; waste away.
--Examples--
‘tatters of fog clung to the peak of the mountain’
‘he climbed his last Swiss peak at the age of 80’
‘whisk two egg whites to stiff peaks’
‘further storage is found in the bow peak’
‘the peak halyard’
‘he was at his peak as a cricketer’
‘package holiday sales hit a peak of around 12 million’
‘a slight increase in velocity provides a second peak on the general velocity curve’
‘the disease peaked in summer’
‘the canal was restored to peak condition’
‘traffic speeds are reduced at peak hours’
‘she sat all day, peaking and pining, at the fire-side’

peal 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A loud ringing of a bell or bells.
A series of changes (strictly, at least five thousand) rung on a set of bells.
A set of bells.
A loud repeated or reverberating sound of thunder or laughter.
(of a bell or bells) ring loudly or in a peal.
(of laughter or thunder) sound in a peal.
Convey by the ringing of bells.
--Examples--
‘the bell rang again, a long, loud peal’
‘Ross burst into peals of laughter’
‘all the bells of the city began to peal’
‘Aunt Edie's laughter pealed around the parlour’
‘the carillon pealed out the news to the waiting city’
--Word--
Peale, Norman Vincent 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1898–1993), US clergyman. The pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church in New York City 1932–84, he preached “applied Christianity,” which encouraged people to think positively. His books included The Art of Living (1937), The Art of Loving (1948), and The Power of Positive Thinking (1952).
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The oval seed of a tropical South American plant, often roasted and salted and eaten as a snack or used to make oil or animal feed.

‘he pays peanuts’

--Word--
pearl 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A hard, lustrous spherical mass, typically white or bluish-grey, formed within the shell of a pearl oyster or other bivalve mollusc and highly prized as a gem.
An artificial imitation of a pearl.
A necklace of pearls.
Something resembling a pearl.
A very pale bluish grey or white colour like that of a pearl.
A person or thing of great worth.
Form drops resembling pearls.
Make bluish-grey.
Dive or fish for pearl oysters.
--Examples--
‘a linen garment decorated with pearls’
‘necklaces of amethyst and pearl’
‘a pair of pearl earrings’
‘tweeds look traditional teamed with twinset and pearls’
‘the sweat stood in pearls along his forehead’
‘her dress was a lovely pearl grey’
‘he has some pearls of wisdom to offer’
‘raindrops pearled on water-soaked windowpanes’
‘sunset pearling the sky above the hills’
‘the pearling industry’

--Word--
bearing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person's way of standing or moving.
The way a person behaves or conducts themselves.
Relation; relevance.
The ability to tolerate something bad or to be tolerated.
A part of a machine that allows one part to rotate or move in contact with another part with as little friction as possible.
The direction or position of something, or the direction of movement, relative to a fixed point. It is usually measured in degrees, typically with magnetic north as zero.
Awareness of one's position relative to one's surroundings.
A device or charge.
--Examples--
‘a man of precise military bearing’
‘she has the bearing of a First Lady’
‘the case has no direct bearing on the issues being considered’
‘school was bad enough, but now it's past bearing’
‘the Point is on a bearing of 015°’
‘there were no steeples or bridges from which to take a bearing’
‘he flashed the torch around, trying to get his bearings’
‘armorial bearings’

Pearly kings and queens.
A pearly king's or queen's clothes or pearl buttons.
A person's teeth.
--Examples--
‘nice pearly teeth’
‘her mum and dad had been pearlies’
‘Joe gleaming and sparkling in his pearlies’
--Word--
pearlized 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Made to have or give a lustre like that of mother-of-pearl.
--Examples--
‘pearlized paint finishes’
--Word--
pearl-like 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling a pearl.
--Examples--
--Word--
pearl 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A hard, lustrous spherical mass, typically white or bluish-grey, formed within the shell of a pearl oyster or other bivalve mollusc and highly prized as a gem.
An artificial imitation of a pearl.
A necklace of pearls.
Something resembling a pearl.
A very pale bluish grey or white colour like that of a pearl.
A person or thing of great worth.
Form drops resembling pearls.
Make bluish-grey.
Dive or fish for pearl oysters.
--Examples--
‘a linen garment decorated with pearls’
‘necklaces of amethyst and pearl’
‘a pair of pearl earrings’
‘tweeds look traditional teamed with twinset and pearls’
‘the sweat stood in pearls along his forehead’
‘her dress was a lovely pearl grey’
‘he has some pearls of wisdom to offer’
‘raindrops pearled on water-soaked windowpanes’
‘sunset pearling the sky above the hills’
‘the pearling industry’
--Word--
lipped 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
‘her pale-lipped mouth’
--Word--
pearl oyster 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tropical marine bivalve mollusc with a ridged scaly shell, which produces pearls.
--Examples--
--Word--
pale 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Light in colour or shade; containing little colour or pigment.
(of a person or their complexion) having less colour than usual, typically as a result of shock, fear, or ill health.
(of a light) not strong or bright.
Inferior or unimpressive.
Become pale in one's face from shock or fear.
Seem or become less important.
--Examples--
‘choose pale floral patterns for walls’
‘she looked pale and drawn’
‘a pale dawn’
‘the new cheese is a pale imitation of continental cheeses’
‘I paled at the thought of what she might say’
‘all else pales by comparison’
--Word--
pure 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Not mixed or adulterated with any other substance or material.
Without any extraneous and unnecessary elements.
Free of any contamination.
(of an animal or plant) of unmixed origin or descent; pedigree.
(of a sound) perfectly in tune and with a clear tone.
Wholesome and untainted by immorality, especially that of a sexual nature.
(of a subject of study) dealing with abstract concepts and not practical application.
Involving or containing nothing else but; sheer (used for emphasis)
(of a vowel) not joined with another to form a diphthong.
--Examples--
‘cars can run on pure alcohol’
‘the jacket was pure wool’
‘the romantic notion of pure art devoid of social responsibility’
‘the pure, clear waters of Scotland’
‘the pure Charolais is white or light wheat in the coat’
‘80 pure-bred stallions were on parade’
‘these small cymbals produce a quiet but high pitched and very pure note’
‘our fondness for each other is pure and innocent’
‘a theoretical discipline such as pure physics’
‘a shout of pure anger’
‘an outcome which may be a matter of pure chance’
‘it was revenge, pure and simple’

--Word--
pearl white 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A shade of white resembling the typical colour of a pearl.
A white pigment containing bismuth, especially one made from basic bismuth nitrate and formerly used as a cosmetic. Also: a white pigment made from crushed mother-of-pearl. Now historical and rare.
Of a shade of white resembling the typical colour of a pearl.

pear

noun

A sweet yellowish- or brownish-green edible fruit that is typically narrow at the stalk and wider towards the base, with sweet, slightly gritty flesh.

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

(of a person) having hips that are disproportionately wide in relation to the upper part of the body.

--Word--
Pearson, Karl 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1857–1936), English mathematician, the principal founder of 20th-century statistics. He defined the concept of standard deviation and devised the chi-square test.
--Examples--

--Word--
pearwood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The wood of the pear tree, Pyrus communis.
Chiefly with distinguishing word: the wood of any of several African trees, especially (in full "African pearwood") that of Manilkara obovata and Minus djave (both family Sapotaceae).
--Examples--
--Word--
pea 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A spherical green seed that is eaten as a vegetable or as a pulse when dried.
Any of the edible seeds of several other plants of the pea family, especially (in the West Indies and the southern US) the pigeon pea or the cowpea.
The hardy Eurasian climbing plant which yields pods containing peas.
Used in names of plants or seeds that are similar or related to the pea, e.g. chickpea, sweet pea.
--Examples--
‘steak and ale pie with peas and new potatoes’
‘pea soup’
--Word--
peaness

noun
--Meanings--
The characteristic or defining quality of a pea; conformity to an ideal notion of what a typical pea is like.

--Word--
peasantism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Politics. The doctrine that power should be vested in the peasant class. Also Russian History: the doctrine that the peasant class and the intelligentsia are the only true revolutionary forces; Narodnikism.
The state or condition of being a peasant; conduct or attitudes characteristic of or attributed to peasants; identification or sympathy with peasant life.
--Examples--
--Word--
peasantize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To give the characteristics of a peasant economy to (an economy or social system); to make a peasant of (a person). Also without object with object implied.

peat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A brown deposit resembling soil, formed by the partial decomposition of vegetable matter in the wet acidic conditions of bogs and fens, and often cut out and dried for use as fuel and in gardening.
A cut piece of peat.

‘a peat bog’
‘he reached forward to add a couple of peats to the fire’

--Word--
pebbling 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of treating leather with a roller to produce a rough or indented surface, as if impressed by pebbles; the pattern itself. Also in extended use: a similar texture or pattern on other surfaces.
Pebbles used as paving; pebblestone.
--Examples--

pebble stone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Pebble.
Usually in form pebblestone. Pebbles collectively, as a material; coarse gravel, conglomerate. Also: any of various decorative or building materials incorporating pebbles or having a surface resembling pebbles.

pébrine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A disease of silkworms caused by the microsporidian parasite Nosema bombycis, and characterized by the appearance of dark spots on the insect and the stunting of its growth. Also "pébrine disease".

pech 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Breathe hard or with difficulty; pant.
A gasping or laboured breath; a pant.
--Examples--
‘by the time he reached the second floor, he was peching’
‘a pech uphill takes us to the canal’
--Word--
Pechenga 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A region of north-western Russia, lying west of Murmansk on the border with Finland. Formerly part of Finland, it was ceded to the Soviet Union in 1940. It was known by its Finnish name, Petsamo, from 1920 until 1944.
--Examples--
--Word--
pech 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Breathe hard or with difficulty; pant.
A gasping or laboured breath; a pant.
--Examples--
‘by the time he reached the second floor, he was peching’
‘a pech uphill takes us to the canal’
--Word--
Pechora 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river of northern Russia, which rises in the Urals and flows some 1,800 km (1,125 miles) north and east to the Barents Sea.
--Examples--
--Word--
pech 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Breathe hard or with difficulty; pant.
A gasping or laboured breath; a pant.
--Examples--
‘by the time he reached the second floor, he was peching’
‘a pech uphill takes us to the canal’
--Word--
peck 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
(of a bird) strike or bite something with its beak.
Make (a hole) by striking with the beak.
Kiss (someone) lightly or perfunctorily.
(of a person) eat (food) listlessly or daintily.
Type (something) laboriously.
Strike with a pick or other tool.
A stroke or bite by a bird with its beak.
A light or perfunctory kiss.
Food.
A measure of capacity for dry goods, equal to a quarter of a bushel (2 imperial gallons = 9.092 litres, or 8 US quarts = 8.81 l).
A large number or amount of something.
(of a horse) pitch forward or stumble as a result of striking the ground with the front rather than the flat of the hoof.
--Examples--
‘two geese were pecking at some grain’
‘vultures pecked out the calf's eyes’
‘robins are the worst culprits, pecking holes in every cherry’
‘she pecked him on the cheek’
‘don't peck at your food, eat a whole mouthful’
‘Paul was pecking out letters with two fingers on his typewriter’
‘part of a wall was pecked down and carted away’
‘the bird managed to give its attacker a sharp peck’
‘a fatherly peck on the cheek’
‘he wants a little more peck’
‘a peck of dirt’
‘her father's horse had pecked slightly on landing’

--Word--
pecky 
--Type--
adjective, adjective
--Meanings--
Of timber, especially cypress: showing signs of localized decay, often in small rounded patches running with the grain, caused by various fungi affecting the heartwood of the living tree.
Like the peck of a bird, specifically (of a kiss) consisting of a peck.
--Examples--
--Word--

adjective, adjective
--Meanings--
Of timber, especially cypress: showing signs of localized decay, often in small rounded patches running with the grain, caused by various fungi affecting the heartwood of the living tree.

--Word--
Pecksniff 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An unctuous hypocrite, a person who affects benevolence or pretends to have high moral principles; (also) a person who interferes officiously in the business of others. Frequently attributive Also (occasionally) as adjective.
To speak or act like a Pecksniff.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pecksniffery 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Language or behaviour reminiscent of Pecksniff; hypocrisy, officiousness.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pecksniffian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Affecting benevolence or high moral principles.
--Examples--
‘he adopted a Pecksniffian tone’
--Word--
Pecksniffianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of being Pecksniffian.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pecksniffism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= Pecksniffery.
--Examples--

Peconic Bay 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An inlet of the Atlantic Ocean at the eastern end of Long Island in New York that separates the North Fork and the South Fork of the island.

Pecos River 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river that flows for 925 miles (1,490 km) from northern New Mexico through western Texas to the Rio Grande.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pécs 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An industrial city in south-western Hungary; population 156,974 (2009). It was formerly the capital of the southern part of the Roman province of Pannonia.

--Word--
pecten 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a number of comblike structures occurring in animal bodies.
A pigmented vascular projection from the choroid in the eye of a bird.
An appendage of an insect consisting of or bearing a row of bristles or chitinous teeth.
A sensory appendage on the underside of a scorpion.
A scallop.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Meanings--

--Word--
pectin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A soluble gelatinous polysaccharide which is present in ripe fruits and is used as a setting agent in jams and jellies.
--Examples--
‘the very early stalks may not have quite enough natural pectin to set properly’
‘two common types of soluble fibre are pectins and gums’
--Word--
pectinal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Zoology. Of the nature of or resembling a comb; of or relating to a pecten. Compare "pectinate".
--Examples--
--Word--
pectinase 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a class of enzymes which hydrolyse pectin to its constituent monosaccharides, found chiefly in plants and in certain bacteria and fungi.
--Examples--

adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
pecten 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a number of comblike structures occurring in animal bodies.
A pigmented vascular projection from the choroid in the eye of a bird.
An appendage of an insect consisting of or bearing a row of bristles or chitinous teeth.
A sensory appendage on the underside of a scorpion.
A scallop.
--Examples--
--Word--
pectinesterase 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An enzyme found in the cells of plants, and of certain bacteria and fungi, which hydrolyses pectin by the removal of methyl ester groups to produce pectinic acids, pectic acids, and methanol.
--Examples--
--Word--
pectineus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A flat muscle arising from the front of the pubis and inserted into the femur just behind the small trochanter.
--Examples--
--Word--
pectinibranch 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to, characterized by, or designating a type of gill structure found in mesogastropod and neogastropod molluscs, in which parallel filaments are borne along one side of the gill axis; (of a gill) monopectinate. Also: of or relating to a subclass or order Pectinibranchia in which these molluscs are placed in some classifications.
A pectinibranch mollusc. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
pectinic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a class of colloidal polymers of galacturonic acid containing a significant proportion of methyl ester groups, produced by partial hydrolysis of pectins.
--Examples--
--Word--
pectinid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A marine bivalve mollusc of the family Pectinidae; a scallop.
Of, relating to, or designating the family Pectinidae of marine bivalve molluscs.
--Examples--
--Word--
pectiniform 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling or having the form of a scallop; pectinoid.
Shaped like a comb; pectinate.
--Examples--
--Word--
pectinoid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Resembling a pecten or scallop; belonging to or characteristic of the family Pectinidae or related families.
A pectinoid bivalve.

adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or of the nature of pectins or their derivatives; pectic.

pectin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A soluble gelatinous polysaccharide which is present in ripe fruits and is used as a setting agent in jams and jellies.
--Examples--
‘the very early stalks may not have quite enough natural pectin to set properly’
‘two common types of soluble fibre are pectins and gums’
--Word--
pectolite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A whitish or greyish mineral of the pyroxenoid group which occurs in igneous rocks in aggregates of needle-like crystals and consists of a basic silicate of calcium and sodium.
--Examples--

pectoriloquy

noun

--Word--
pectus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Anatomy and Medicine. The front of the thorax; the chest. In later use frequently attributive, especially in relation to congenital deformities of the chest.
Entomology. The lower surface of the thorax or prothorax of an insect or a spider.

--Word--
peculiar 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Different to what is normal or expected; strange.
Slightly and indefinably unwell.
Particular; special.
Belonging exclusively to.
A parish or church exempt from the jurisdiction of the diocese in which it lies, and subject to the direct jurisdiction of the monarch or an archbishop.
--Examples--
‘he gave her some very peculiar looks’
‘Stella thought the play peculiar’
‘I felt a little peculiar for a while’
‘any attempt to explicate the theme is bound to run into peculiar difficulties’
‘some languages are peculiar to one region’
‘deans and canons of royal peculiars, notably Westminster Abbey and Windsor’
--Word--
peculiarize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To give or impart a particular character to; to characterize uniquely or distinctively.
--Examples--
--Word--
peculiarism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(A) Christian Church (depreciative). Evangelicalism. Compare "peculiar". Now historical and rare. (b) generally. Exclusivity; adherence to a distinctive doctrine or practice.
--Examples--
--Word--
peculiarity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A strange or unusual feature or habit.
A characteristic that is distinctive of a particular person or place.
The quality of being peculiar.
--Examples--
‘for all his peculiarities, she finds him quite endearing’
‘his essays characterized decency as a British peculiarity’
‘the peculiarity of their upbringing’

--Word--
peculiarly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
More than usually; especially.
In an unusual way; oddly.
Used to emphasize restriction to an individual or group.
--Examples--
‘some patients were peculiarly difficult to cure’
‘the town is peculiarly built’
‘the peculiarly British hobby of brass rubbing’

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
peculiar 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Different to what is normal or expected; strange.
Slightly and indefinably unwell.
Particular; special.
Belonging exclusively to.
A parish or church exempt from the jurisdiction of the diocese in which it lies, and subject to the direct jurisdiction of the monarch or an archbishop.
--Examples--
‘he gave her some very peculiar looks’
‘Stella thought the play peculiar’
‘I felt a little peculiar for a while’
‘any attempt to explicate the theme is bound to run into peculiar difficulties’
‘some languages are peculiar to one region’
‘deans and canons of royal peculiars, notably Westminster Abbey and Windsor’
--Word--
peculium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
That which is allocated to a particular individual; a private or exclusive possession; (also) the particular concern of an individual. Also figurative. Now literary and historical.
Roman Law. The property which a paterfamilias allowed a member of his family, or a master allowed his slave, to hold and administer, and, within limits, to alienate, as though it were his or her own.
--Examples--
--Word--
pecuniary 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘he admitted obtaining a pecuniary advantage by deception’

pecuniarily

--Meanings--

--Word--
pecunious 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Well provided with money; moneyed, wealthy. Now chiefly literary and humorous.
Money-loving, avaricious; miserly, ungenerous.

--Type--
adjective, plural noun
--Meanings--
Relating to teaching.
Of or characteristic of a pedagogue.
--Examples--
‘they show great pedagogic skills’
--Word--
pedagogical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to teaching.
--Examples--
‘innovative pedagogical methods’
--Word--
pedagogically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
pedagogy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The method and practice of teaching, especially as an academic subject or theoretical concept.
--Examples--
‘the relationship between applied linguistics and language pedagogy’
‘subject-based pedagogies’
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--

noun

‘subject-based pedagogies’
--Word--
pedagogist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who studies theories of education; (also occasionally) a teacher.
--Examples--
--Word--
pedagogue 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A teacher, especially a strict or pedantic one.
--Examples--
--Word--
pedagoguery 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The occupation or practice of a pedagogue, teaching; (in later use) specifically unwelcome, dogmatic, or empty teaching; didacticism.
--Examples--
--Word--
pedagogue 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A teacher, especially a strict or pedantic one.
--Examples--
--Word--
pedagoguish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Characteristic or reminiscent of a pedagogue.
--Examples--
--Word--
pedal 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Each of a pair of foot-operated levers used for powering a bicycle or other vehicle propelled by the legs.
A foot-operated throttle, brake, or clutch control in a motor vehicle.
Each of a set of two or three levers on a piano, particularly (also sustaining pedal) one which, when depressed, prevents the dampers from stopping the sound when the keys are released. The second is the soft pedal; a third, if present, produces either selective sustaining or complete muffling of the tone.
A foot-operated lever on other musical instruments, such as an organ.
A foot-operated device for producing a sound effect on an electric guitar.
Move by working the pedals of a bicycle.
Move (a bicycle) by working its pedals.
Work the pedals of a bicycle.
Use the pedals of a piano, organ, or other keyboard instrument, especially in a particular style.
--Examples--
‘a brake pedal’
‘they pedalled along the canal towpath’
‘she was pedalling a bicycle around town’
‘he was coming down the path on his bike, pedalling hard’
‘the organist pedalled furiously, her feet travelling musical miles’
--Word--
pedal 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Each of a pair of foot-operated levers used for powering a bicycle or other vehicle propelled by the legs.
A foot-operated throttle, brake, or clutch control in a motor vehicle.
Each of a set of two or three levers on a piano, particularly (also sustaining pedal) one which, when depressed, prevents the dampers from stopping the sound when the keys are released. The second is the soft pedal; a third, if present, produces either selective sustaining or complete muffling of the tone.
A foot-operated lever on other musical instruments, such as an organ.
A foot-operated device for producing a sound effect on an electric guitar.
Move by working the pedals of a bicycle.
Move (a bicycle) by working its pedals.
Work the pedals of a bicycle.
Use the pedals of a piano, organ, or other keyboard instrument, especially in a particular style.
--Examples--
‘a brake pedal’
‘they pedalled along the canal towpath’
‘she was pedalling a bicycle around town’
‘he was coming down the path on his bike, pedalling hard’
‘the organist pedalled furiously, her feet travelling musical miles’
--Word--
pedaller 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who rides a bicycle; a cyclist.
--Examples--
‘the motorway route was not the right environment for pedallers’
--Word--
pedalfer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A soil in which there is no layer of accumulated calcium carbonate, but in which oxides of iron and aluminium have tended to accumulate (usually acidic and characteristic of humid climates).
--Examples--
--Word--
pedalferic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or of the nature of a pedalfer.
--Examples--
--Word--
pedalfer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A soil in which there is no layer of accumulated calcium carbonate, but in which oxides of iron and aluminium have tended to accumulate (usually acidic and characteristic of humid climates).
--Examples--
--Word--
pedalian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Chiefly humorous. Of or relating to a foot or feet.
--Examples--
--Word--
pedalier 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The pedalboard of an organ; a similar set of pedals attached to a piano or harpsichord (sometimes provided with its own soundboard and strings in an oblong box, to be placed under the main instrument).
--Examples--
--Word--
pedalier 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The pedalboard of an organ; a similar set of pedals attached to a piano or harpsichord (sometimes provided with its own soundboard and strings in an oblong box, to be placed under the main instrument).
--Examples--
--Word--
pedalling 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of working the pedals of a bicycle.
Use of the pedals of a piano, organ, etc., especially in a particular style.
--Examples--
‘I have to do some fast pedalling to get the chain to engage properly’
‘Chopin gave no indications of pedalling in his manuscript’

noun
--Meanings--

pedal 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Each of a pair of foot-operated levers used for powering a bicycle or other vehicle propelled by the legs.
A foot-operated throttle, brake, or clutch control in a motor vehicle.
Each of a set of two or three levers on a piano, particularly (also sustaining pedal) one which, when depressed, prevents the dampers from stopping the sound when the keys are released. The second is the soft pedal; a third, if present, produces either selective sustaining or complete muffling of the tone.
A foot-operated lever on other musical instruments, such as an organ.
A foot-operated device for producing a sound effect on an electric guitar.
Move by working the pedals of a bicycle.
Move (a bicycle) by working its pedals.
Work the pedals of a bicycle.
Use the pedals of a piano, organ, or other keyboard instrument, especially in a particular style.
--Examples--
‘a brake pedal’
‘they pedalled along the canal towpath’
‘she was pedalling a bicycle around town’
‘he was coming down the path on his bike, pedalling hard’
‘the organist pedalled furiously, her feet travelling musical miles’

--Word--
pedant 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who is excessively concerned with minor details and rules or with displaying academic learning.
--Examples--
‘the royal palace (some pedants would say the ex-royal palace)’
--Word--
pedantic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘his analyses are careful and even painstaking, but never pedantic’

--Word--
pedate 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Shaped like a foot, especially that of a bird; (Botany) designating or characterized by a leaf shape or venation pattern similar to a palmate or digitate arrangement, but with the lobes, leaflets, or veins not all arising from a single central point, the lateral divisions being further subdivided or fused near the base; (also) designating or characterized by the arrangement of other parts in such a pattern, with successive lateral branches arising near the base of earlier branches.
Zoology. Having feet, footed. rare.
Expanded (at the end) so as to resemble a foot at the end of a leg.
--Examples--
--Word--
pedate 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Shaped like a foot, especially that of a bird; (Botany) designating or characterized by a leaf shape or venation pattern similar to a palmate or digitate arrangement, but with the lobes, leaflets, or veins not all arising from a single central point, the lateral divisions being further subdivided or fused near the base; (also) designating or characterized by the arrangement of other parts in such a pattern, with successive lateral branches arising near the base of earlier branches.
Zoology. Having feet, footed. rare.
Expanded (at the end) so as to resemble a foot at the end of a leg.

--Word--
peddle 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Try to sell (something, especially small goods) by going from place to place.
Sell (an illegal drug or stolen item)
Promote (an idea or view) persistently or widely.
--Examples--
‘he peddled printing materials around the country’
‘he was arrested after trying to peddle guns’
‘he criticized his fellow candidate for peddling risky ideas’

--Word--
pedestal 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The base or support on which a statue, obelisk, or column is mounted.
Each of the two supports of a kneehole desk or table.
The supporting column or base of a washbasin or toilet pan.
Used in reference to a situation in which someone is greatly or uncritically admired.
Set or support on a pedestal.
--Examples--
‘a bronze bust on a marble pedestal’
‘a pedestal washbasin’
‘it's as if I'm on a pedestal and he worships me—I hate that’
‘last week's leaders were knocked off their pedestal, losing their first game of the season’
‘pedestalled dishes’

pedestrial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Going or walking on foot; performed on foot; pedestrian. In later use also: of, relating to, or designed for pedestrians.

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Word--
pedestrian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person walking rather than travelling in a vehicle.
Lacking inspiration or excitement; dull.
--Examples--
‘the road is so dangerous pedestrians avoid it’
‘a pedestrian bridge’
‘disenchantment with their pedestrian lives’

pediculate 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Zoology, Botany, and Medicine= pediculated.
Zoology. Of or relating to the order Pediculati of fishes (now usually called Lophiiformes), containing the anglerfishes, members of which are characterized by pectoral fins having an armlike base of elongated radials. Now rare.

pedigree 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The record of descent of an animal, showing it to be pure-bred.
A pure-bred animal.
The recorded ancestry or lineage of a person or family.
The history or provenance of a person or thing, especially as conferring distinction.
A genealogical table.
(of an animal) pure-bred.
--Examples--
‘they are looking for animals with pedigrees’
‘a spaniel of distinguished pedigree’
‘with a pedigree equal to many of the gentry’
‘the debate about pedigree and family fortunes’
‘the scheme has a long pedigree’
‘my host showed me his family pedigree’
‘pedigree cats’

pedion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A crystal form, shown by triclinic minerals, consisting of a single face bounded by other faces having no simple symmetrical relation to it (or to each other).
--Examples--
--Word--
pedipalp 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of the second pair of appendages attached to the cephalothorax of most arachnids. They are variously specialized as pincers in scorpions, sensory organs in spiders, and locomotory organs in horseshoe crabs.
--Examples--
--Word--
pedipalpal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
pedipalp 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of the second pair of appendages attached to the cephalothorax of most arachnids. They are variously specialized as pincers in scorpions, sensory organs in spiders, and locomotory organs in horseshoe crabs.
--Examples--
--Word--
pedipalp 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of the second pair of appendages attached to the cephalothorax of most arachnids. They are variously specialized as pincers in scorpions, sensory organs in spiders, and locomotory organs in horseshoe crabs.
--Examples--
--Word--
pedipalpus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Pedipalp. Usually in plural.
In plural (usually in form Pedipalpi). Members of an arachnid order Pedipalpi, including the whip scorpions and similar forms with large pedipalps (now usually separated into distinct orders). Now rare.

peel 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Remove the outer covering or skin from (a fruit, vegetable, or prawn)
Remove (the outer covering or skin) from a fruit or vegetable.
(of a fruit or vegetable) have a skin that can be removed.
Remove a thin outer covering or part.
Remove an item of clothing.
(of a surface or object) lose parts of its outer layer or covering in small strips or pieces.
(of an outer layer) come off in strips or small pieces.
The outer covering or rind of a fruit or vegetable.
An act of exfoliating dead skin in the cosmetic treatment of microdermabrasion.
peel off
Leave a formation or group by veering away.
peel out
Leave quickly.
A flat implement like a shovel, especially one used by a baker for carrying loaves or similar items of food into or out of an oven.
A small square defensive tower of a kind built in the 16th century in the border counties of England and Scotland.
Send (another player's ball) through a hoop.
--Examples--
‘she watched him peel an apple with deliberate care’
‘peel off the skins and thickly slice the potatoes’
‘oranges that peel easily’
‘I peeled off the tissue paper’
‘Suzy peeled off her white pullover’
‘the walls are peeling’
‘if it's paper you're washing, make sure it won't peel off if it gets damp’
‘paint was peeling from the shopfronts’
‘pieces of potato peel’
‘the pace was much too hot for Beris, and he peeled off after five laps’
‘he peeled out down the street’
‘a wooden pizza peel’
‘the better players are capable of peeling a ball through two or three hoops’

proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1940), Brazilian footballer; born Edson Arantes do Nascimento. Regarded as one of the greatest footballers of all time, he appeared 111 times for Brazil and is credited with over 1,200 goals in first-class soccer.

peep 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Look quickly and furtively at something, especially through a narrow opening.
Come gradually or partially into view.
A quick or furtive look.
A momentary or partial view of something.
A feeble, high-pitched sound made by a young bird or mammal.
A slight sound, utterance, or complaint.
A brief, high-pitched electronic sound.
A small sandpiper or similar wading bird.
A group of chickens.
Make a brief, high-pitched sound.
--Examples--
‘his door was ajar and she couldn't resist peeping in’
‘the sun began to peep out’
‘Jonathan took a little peep at his watch’
‘black curls and a peep of gold earring’
‘not a peep out of them since shortly after eight’
‘the phone gives three sharp peeps’
‘the peeps have returned to Fundy’
‘a peep of chickens pecking and scratching around the gate’
‘Don peeped on his whistle’

noun, noun
--Meanings--
A person who peeps at someone or something, especially in a voyeuristic way.
A person's eyes.
A small North American tree frog with a dark cross on the back, the males of which sing in early spring.
--Examples--
‘keep your peepers peeled for a familiar face’
--Word--
peephole 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small hole that may be looked through, especially one in a door through which callers may be identified before the door is opened.
--Examples--
‘she peered through the security peephole in the solid oak door’
‘he saw a peephole in the clouds’
‘she was wearing a black peephole bra’
--Word--

--Word--
peep 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Look quickly and furtively at something, especially through a narrow opening.
Come gradually or partially into view.
A quick or furtive look.
A momentary or partial view of something.
A feeble, high-pitched sound made by a young bird or mammal.
A slight sound, utterance, or complaint.
A brief, high-pitched electronic sound.
A small sandpiper or similar wading bird.
A group of chickens.
Make a brief, high-pitched sound.
--Examples--
‘his door was ajar and she couldn't resist peeping in’
‘the sun began to peep out’
‘Jonathan took a little peep at his watch’
‘black curls and a peep of gold earring’
‘not a peep out of them since shortly after eight’
‘the phone gives three sharp peeps’
‘the peeps have returned to Fundy’
‘a peep of chickens pecking and scratching around the gate’
‘Don peeped on his whistle’
--Word--
peeps 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
People (often used to refer to a person's friends or associates)
--Examples--
‘thanks for the feedback, peeps!’
‘she's back home with her peeps in Milwaukee’
--Word--
peep show 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sequence of pictures viewed through a lens or hole set into a box, formerly offered as a public entertainment.
An erotic or pornographic film viewed from a coin-operated booth.

--Word--
peer 
--Type--
verb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Look with difficulty or concentration at someone or something.
Be just visible.
Come into view; appear.
A member of the nobility in Britain or Ireland, comprising the ranks of duke, marquess, earl, viscount, and baron.
A person of the same age, status, or ability as another specified person.
Make or become equal with.
--Examples--
‘Faye peered at her with suspicion’
‘the towers peer over the roofs’
‘for yet a many of your horsemen peer’
‘hereditary peers could still dominate the proceedings of the House of Lords’
‘he has incurred much criticism from his academic peers’
‘the Thames could not peer with the mill-streamlet close to my home’
‘of Homer it is said that none could ever peer him for poetry’
--Word--
peerage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The title and rank of peer or peeress.
Peers as a class.
A book containing a list of peers and peeresses, with their genealogy and history.
--Examples--
‘on his retirement as cabinet secretary, he was given a peerage’
‘he was elevated to the peerage two years ago’

peerdom 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The rank of peer or peeress; the condition of being a peer or peeress.
The territory or fief of a French peer. Now historical.
The condition of being the peer or equal of another; equality.

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

Parity, equality. Now rare.

--Word--
peg 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A short pin or bolt, typically tapered at one end, that is used for securing something in place, hanging things on, or marking a position.
A pin or bolt driven into the ground to hold one of the ropes or corners of a tent in position.
A bung for stoppering a cask.
A footrest on a motorbike.
A point or limit on a scale, especially of exchange rates.
A measure of spirits.
A place marked by a peg and allotted to a competitor to fish or shoot from.
A person's leg.
A strong throw.
Fix, secure, or mark with a peg or pegs.
Hang (washing) on a line with clothes pegs.
Allot a specified place to (a competitor) in a fishing or shooting competition by means of a marker.
Fix (a price, rate, or amount) at a particular level.
Form a fixed opinion of; categorize.
Throw (a ball) hard and low.
--Examples--
‘she put her mac on a peg in the hall’
‘the Mexican peso, linked to the dollar by a crawling peg, was distinctly too high’
‘have a peg of whisky’
‘I have a good right peg and the ball ended up in the back of the net’
‘drape plants with nets, pegging down the edges’
‘clothes were pegged out on a line’
‘we've been pegged next to the winning team’
‘the dividend was pegged at 23.59p’
‘the officer probably has us pegged as anarchists’
‘the catcher pegs the ball to the first baseman’
--Word--
lantern 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A lamp with a transparent case protecting the flame or electric bulb, and typically having a handle by which it may be carried or hung.
A square, curved, or polygonal structure on the top of a dome or a room, with the sides glazed or open so as to admit light.
The light chamber at the top of a lighthouse.
--Examples--
‘a paper lantern’
‘the building is well lit by the ring of windows in the octagonal lantern’

pegall

noun
--Meanings--
In Guyana and the Caribbean: a basketwork container, especially a small rectangular basket with a close-fitting cover.
--Examples--
--Word--
pegamoid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A kind of waterproof facing or substance used in upholstery, bookbinding, etc.; (hence also) imitation leather or other waterproof material.
Made of pegamoid. Also figurative: impassive, impervious, not susceptible to emotion.
--Examples--

--Word--
Pegasus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A winged horse that sprang from the blood of Medusa when Perseus cut off her head.
An imaginary animal in the form of a winged horse.
A large northern constellation, said to represent a winged horse. The three brightest stars, together with one star of Andromeda, form the prominent Square of Pegasus.
Used with preceding letter or numeral to designate a star in the constellation Pegasus.
--Examples--
‘at the end of the book he gets eaten by a dragon when he's trying to ride a Pegasus’
‘the star Zeta Pegasi’

--Word--
Pegu 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city and river port of southern Burma (Myanmar), on the Pegu River north-east of Rangoon; population 200,900 (est. 2004). Founded in 825 as the capital of the Mon kingdom, it is a centre of Buddhist culture.
--Examples--
--Word--
Peguan 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of the city or district of Pegu (now Bago) in southern Burma (Myanmar), the ancient capital of the Mon people; especially a Mon.
The Mon-Khmer language of the Peguans; = "Mon". Now rare.
Of or relating to the city or district of Pegu, the Peguans, or their language and culture.
--Examples--
--Word--
pegwood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Shoemaking wood for making pegs for shoes (now historical).
Dogwood in thin strips having one end sharpened to a point, used by jewellers for cleaning the pivot-holes of watches.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pahlavi 
--Type--
proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
The name of two shahs of Iran.
Reza (1878–1944), ruled 1925–41; born Reza Khan. An army officer, he took control of the Persian government after a coup in 1921. He was elected Shah in 1925 but abdicated following the occupation of Iran by British and Soviet forces.
Muhammad Reza (1919–80), ruled 1941–79, son of Reza Pahlavi; also known as Reza Shah. Opposition to his regime culminated in the Islamic revolution of 1979 under Ayatollah Khomeini; Reza Shah was forced into exile and died in Egypt.
An Aramaic-based writing system used in Persia from the 2nd century BC to the advent of Islam in the 7th century AD. It was also used for the recording of ancient Avestan sacred texts.
The form of the Middle Persian language written in Pahlavi, used in the Sassanian empire.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pehuenche 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of an Araucanian Indian people chiefly inhabiting the Bio Bio region of Chile.
Of, relating to, or designating the Pehuenche.

--Word--
Peirce, Charles Sanders 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1839–1914), American philosopher and logician. A founder of American pragmatism, he argued that the meaning of a belief is to be understood by the actions and uses to which it gives rise.
--Examples--
--Word--
peise 
--Type--

--Meanings--

--Word--
peise 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Balance, poise, equilibrium; the action of balancing or holding something poised. Now rare (English regional in later use).
--Examples--

--Examples--
--Word--
Pisistratus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.600–c.527 BC), tyrant of Athens. He reduced aristocratic power in rural Attica and promoted the financial prosperity and cultural pre-eminence of Athens.
--Examples--
--Word--
peytral 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A piece of armour to protect the breast of a horse (often richly ornamented, and retained for ornamental purposes after its defensive use had passed away); = poitrel. Also occasionally in extended use: a breast collar.
--Examples--

pejorate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To make worse; to cause to deteriorate. In later use also: to endow (a word) with a less favourable meaning..
--Examples--
--Word--
pejoration 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly formal. Worsening, deterioration; (sometimes) specifically depreciation, disapproval, criticism; an instance of this; a depreciatory or critical expression.
Linguistics. The development of a less favourable meaning or of less pleasant connotations for a word or expression.

Pekinese 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A lapdog of a short-legged breed with long hair and a snub nose, originally brought to Europe from the Summer Palace at Beijing (Peking) in 1860.
Relating to Beijing, its citizens, or their culture or cuisine.

--Word--
pell 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A parchment; specifically either of two rolls of parchment for recording receipts (called in Latin the pellis receptorum) and issues (called in Latin the pellis exituum), formerly kept at the Exchequer. Now historical.
With the and capital initial. The Office of the Exchequer in which these rolls were kept. Now historical.
A stake or post at which to practise sword-strokes.
In full "Pell equation", "Pell's equation". A Diophantine equation of the form y 2 − ax 2 = 1, where x and y are integer variables, and a is an integer constant.

--Word--
Pelagian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the theological doctrine of Pelagius, especially in denying the doctrines of original sin and predestination, and defending innate human goodness and free will.
A person who believes in the theological doctrine of Pelagius, especially its denial of the doctrines of original sin and predestination, and defence of innate human goodness and free will.
--Examples--
‘the Pelagian definition of sin and holiness’
‘such theology is not only subjective but thoroughly Pelagian’
‘this can be affirmed by none but a Pelagian’
--Word--
Pelagianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The doctrine of Pelagius and his followers, in particular the denial of the doctrines of original sin and predestination, and the defence of innate human goodness and free will.
--Examples--
‘Pelagianism continued to find support in Britain’

verb

--Word--
pelagic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the open sea.
(chiefly of fish) inhabiting the upper layers of the open sea.
(of a bird) inhabiting the open sea and returning to the shore only to breed.
A pelagic fish or bird.
--Examples--
‘the kittiwakes return from their pelagic winter wanderings’
‘there are very few pelagic fish to be seen’
--Word--
Pelagius 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.360–c.420), British or Irish monk. He denied the doctrines of original sin and predestination, defending innate human goodness and free will. His beliefs were opposed by St Augustine of Hippo and condemned as heretical by the Synod of Carthage in about 418.
--Examples--

pelamid

--Meanings--
A young or small bonito or tunny; specifically the Atlantic bonito, Sarda sarda.

pelargonidin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An anthocyanidin (usually isolated as the chloride, C₁₅H₁₁O₅Cl) of which pelargonin and many other red plant pigments are glycosides.
--Examples--
--Word--
pelargonin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An anthocyanin (usually isolated as the red chloride, C₂₇H₃₁O₁₅Cl) that is the colouring matter of zonal pelargoniums, and on hydrolysis gives pelargonidin and glucose.
--Examples--
--Word--
pelargonium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tender shrubby plant which is widely cultivated for its red, pink, or white flowers. Some kinds have fragrant leaves which yield an essential oil.

Pelasgi 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Treated as plural. A member of a supposed pre-Hellenic people inhabiting the coasts and islands of the eastern Mediterranean and Aegean; the Pelasgians.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pelasgian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting an ancient people inhabiting the coasts and islands of the Aegean Sea and eastern Mediterranean before the arrival of Greek-speaking peoples in the Bronze Age (12th century BC).
A member of the Pelasgian people.

Pelé 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1940), Brazilian footballer; born Edson Arantes do Nascimento. Regarded as one of the greatest footballers of all time, he appeared 111 times for Brazil and is credited with over 1,200 goals in first-class soccer.

Pelean 
--Type--
adjective, adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to Peleus.
Of, relating to, or designating a type of volcanic eruption characterized by the vertical extrusion from the centre of very viscous lava which tends to form a solid plug or dome, and the lateral emission of nuées ardentes from points of weakness in the flank.

--Word--
Pelée, Mount 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A volcano on the island of Martinique, in the Caribbean. Its eruption in 1902 destroyed the island's then capital St Pierre, killing its population of some 30,000.

noun

--Examples--
--Word--
Pelion 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A wooded mountain in Greece, near the coast of south-eastern Thessaly, rising to 1,548 m (5,079 ft). It was held in Greek mythology to be the home of the centaurs, and the giants were said to have piled Mounts Olympus and Ossa on its summit in their attempt to reach heaven and destroy the gods.
--Examples--
--Word--
peliosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A condition characterized by the presence of blood-filled spaces in the liver or (rarely) other organs.

--Word--
pell 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A parchment; specifically either of two rolls of parchment for recording receipts (called in Latin the pellis receptorum) and issues (called in Latin the pellis exituum), formerly kept at the Exchequer. Now historical.
With the and capital initial. The Office of the Exchequer in which these rolls were kept. Now historical.
A stake or post at which to practise sword-strokes.
In full "Pell equation", "Pell's equation". A Diophantine equation of the form y 2 − ax 2 = 1, where x and y are integer variables, and a is an integer constant.
--Examples--
--Word--
pellagra 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A deficiency disease caused by a lack of nicotinic acid or its precursor tryptophan in the diet. It is characterized by dermatitis, diarrhoea, and mental disturbance, and is often linked to over-dependence on maize as a staple food.
--Examples--
--Word--
pellagragenic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Causing pellagra.
--Examples--
--Word--
pellagra 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A deficiency disease caused by a lack of nicotinic acid or its precursor tryptophan in the diet. It is characterized by dermatitis, diarrhoea, and mental disturbance, and is often linked to over-dependence on maize as a staple food.

--Word--
pellet 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small, rounded, compressed mass of a substance.
A piece of small shot or other lightweight bullet.
A small mass of bones and feathers regurgitated by a bird of prey.
A small round piece of animal faeces, especially from a rabbit or rodent.
Form (a substance) into pellets.
Hit with or as if with pellets.
--Examples--
‘fish food pellets’
‘he had also been struck by a number of shotgun pellets’
‘owl pellets’
‘the business made its name pelleting sugar beet seed’
‘pelleted forms of fertilizer’
‘the last drops of rain were pelleting the windshield’
--Word--
pelletizer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A machine for forming pellets.
--Examples--
