--Word--
Pelletier, Pierre-Joseph 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1788–1842), French chemist. With his friend Joseph-Bienaimé Caventou (1795–1877) he isolated a number of alkaloids for the first time. Pelletier and Caventou also isolated the green pigment of leaves and gave it the name chlorophyll.
--Examples--
--Word--
pelletierine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An oily liquid alkaloid, C₈H₁₅NO, obtained from the root bark of the pomegranate tree, Punica granatum.
--Examples--

pell-mell 
--Type--

--Meanings--
In a confused, rushed, or disorderly manner.
Hasty or disorganized.
A disorderly situation or collection of things.
--Examples--

‘steps to slow the pell-mell pace of deforestation’
‘the pell-mell of ascending gables and roof tiles’
--Word--
pell-mell 
--Type--
adverb, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
In a confused, rushed, or disorderly manner.
Hasty or disorganized.
A disorderly situation or collection of things.
--Examples--
‘they rushed pell-mell up the hill’
‘steps to slow the pell-mell pace of deforestation’
‘the pell-mell of ascending gables and roof tiles’

pellotine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An alkaloid, C₁₃H₁₉NO₃, present in the peyote and related cactuses, and formerly used as a hypnotic; 1,2-dimethyl-6,7-dimethoxy-8-hydroxy-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline.

--Word--
Pelmanism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A system of memory training originally devised by the Pelman Institute for the Scientific Development of Mind, Memory, and Personality in London.
A card game in which matching pairs must be selected from memory from cards laid face down.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pelmanist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A student or advocate of Pelmanism; (hence) a person with a well-trained memory.
--Examples--
--Word--
pelmatozoan 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An echinoderm which is fixed to the substrate by a stalk; a member of the subphylum Pelmatozoa comprising such forms, including crinoids, blastoids, and cystoids.
Of, relating to, or characteristic of those echinoderms which are fixed to the substrate by a stalk; of or relating to the subphylum Pelmatozoa.
--Examples--
--Word--
pelmatozoic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating or relating to echinoderms which are fixed to the substrate by a stalk.

A very short skirt.

--Word--
Peloponnese 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The mountainous southern peninsula of Greece, connected to central Greece by the Isthmus of Corinth. Greek name Pelopónnisos /ˌpɛlɔˈpɔnisɔs/, also called Peloponnesus /ˌpɛlɔpɔˈniːsəs/.
--Examples--
--Word--
Peloponnesian War 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The war of 431–404 BC fought between Athens and Sparta with their respective allies, occasioned largely by Spartan opposition to the Delian League. It ended in the total defeat of Athens and the transfer, for a brief period, of the leadership of Greece to Sparta.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pelops 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Son of Tantalus, brother of Niobe, and father of Atreus. He was killed by his father and served up as food to the gods, but only one shoulder was eaten, and he was restored to life with an ivory shoulder replacing the one that was missing.
--Examples--

pelt 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Hurl missiles repeatedly at.
Hurl (something) at someone or something.
(of rain, hail, or snow) fall quickly and very heavily.
Run somewhere very quickly.
An act of hurling something at someone.
--Examples--
‘two boys pelted him with rotten apples’
‘she spotted four boys pelting stones at ducks’
‘the rain was pelting down’
‘I pelted across the road’

--Word--
pelter 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
A dealer in animal skins or hides.
A person who pelts someone or something, especially with missiles.
Informal (chiefly humorous). A gun.
Informal. A pelting shower, rainstorm, etc.
Informal (chiefly regional). A rage, a temper; a state of agitation.
In plural Scottish informal. Verbal or written abuse; severe criticism. Especially in "to get (also receive) pelters", "to give a person pelters".
An old, feeble, or inferior horse.
Especially of rain: to patter or beat down; = "pelt".
To deliver repeated blows to; to go on pelting or striking.
To move quickly or vigorously; = "pelt". Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--

pelvis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The large bony frame near the base of the spine to which the hindlimbs or legs are attached in humans and many other vertebrates.

The broadened top part of the ureter into which the kidney tubules drain.

pelvigraphy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

pelvimeter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various instruments used to measure the internal or external dimensions of the pelvis, especially in order to predict possible problems during labour.

pelvimetry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Measurement of the dimensions of the bony pelvis, undertaken chiefly to help determine whether a woman can give birth normally or will require a caesarean section.

--Word--
penalization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
penalize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Subject to a penalty or punishment.
(in various sports) punish (a player or team) for a breach of the rules by awarding an advantage to the opposition.
Make or declare (an act or offence) legally punishable.
Put at an unfair disadvantage.
--Examples--
‘high-spending councils will be penalized’
‘the Scots appeared to be wrongly penalized when the umpire awarded Berlin a penalty corner’
‘section twenty penalizes possession of a firearm when trespassing’
‘if the bill is not amended genuine claimants will be penalized’

--Word--
penalty 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A punishment imposed for breaking a law, rule, or contract.
A disadvantage suffered as the result of an action or situation.
(in sports and games) a handicap imposed on a player or team for infringement of rules.
A kick or shot awarded to a team because of an infringement of the rules by an opponent.
Points won by the defenders when a declarer fails to make the contract.
--Examples--
‘the charge carries a maximum penalty of ten years' imprisonment’
‘the cold never leaves my bones these days—one of the penalties of age’
‘she only incurred 6.40 penalties for time on cross-country’
‘a penalty corner’

--Word--
penance 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Punishment inflicted on oneself as an outward expression of repentance for wrongdoing.
A sacrament in which a member of the Church confesses sins to a priest and is given absolution.
A religious observance or other duty required of a person by a priest as part of this sacrament to indicate repentance.
Impose a penance on.
--Examples--
‘he had done public penance for those hasty words’
‘the Bishop penanced him severely for his conduct’

--Meanings--

A sacrament in which a member of the Church confesses sins to a priest and is given absolution.
A religious observance or other duty required of a person by a priest as part of this sacrament to indicate repentance.
Impose a penance on.
--Examples--
‘he had done public penance for those hasty words’
‘the Bishop penanced him severely for his conduct’
--Word--
penance 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Punishment inflicted on oneself as an outward expression of repentance for wrongdoing.
A sacrament in which a member of the Church confesses sins to a priest and is given absolution.
A religious observance or other duty required of a person by a priest as part of this sacrament to indicate repentance.

--Word--
pen and ink 
--Type--

--Meanings--
A stink.
--Examples--
--Word--
Penang 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island of Malaysia, situated off the west coast of the Malay Peninsula. In 1786 it was ceded to the East India Company as a British colony by the sultan of Kedah. Known as Prince of Wales Island until 1867, it united with Malacca and Singapore in a union of 1826, which in 1867 became the British colony called the Straits Settlements. It joined the federation of Malaya in 1948.
A state of Malaysia, consisting of the island of Penang and a coastal strip on the mainland; capital, George Town (on Penang island). The mainland strip was united with the island in 1798 as part of the British colony.
--Examples--
--Word--
Penang 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island of Malaysia, situated off the west coast of the Malay Peninsula. In 1786 it was ceded to the East India Company as a British colony by the sultan of Kedah. Known as Prince of Wales Island until 1867, it united with Malacca and Singapore in a union of 1826, which in 1867 became the British colony called the Straits Settlements. It joined the federation of Malaya in 1948.
A state of Malaysia, consisting of the island of Penang and a coastal strip on the mainland; capital, George Town (on Penang island). The mainland strip was united with the island in 1798 as part of the British colony.
--Examples--
--Word--
Penang 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island of Malaysia, situated off the west coast of the Malay Peninsula. In 1786 it was ceded to the East India Company as a British colony by the sultan of Kedah. Known as Prince of Wales Island until 1867, it united with Malacca and Singapore in a union of 1826, which in 1867 became the British colony called the Straits Settlements. It joined the federation of Malaya in 1948.
A state of Malaysia, consisting of the island of Penang and a coastal strip on the mainland; capital, George Town (on Penang island). The mainland strip was united with the island in 1798 as part of the British colony.

--Word--
bearing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person's way of standing or moving.
The way a person behaves or conducts themselves.
Relation; relevance.
The ability to tolerate something bad or to be tolerated.
A part of a machine that allows one part to rotate or move in contact with another part with as little friction as possible.
The direction or position of something, or the direction of movement, relative to a fixed point. It is usually measured in degrees, typically with magnetic north as zero.
Awareness of one's position relative to one's surroundings.
A device or charge.
--Examples--
‘a man of precise military bearing’
‘she has the bearing of a First Lady’
‘the case has no direct bearing on the issues being considered’
‘school was bad enough, but now it's past bearing’
‘the Point is on a bearing of 015°’
‘there were no steeples or bridges from which to take a bearing’
‘he flashed the torch around, trying to get his bearings’
‘armorial bearings’
--Word--
cancel 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Decide or announce that (a planned event) will not take place.
Annul or revoke (a formal arrangement which is in effect)
Abolish or make void (a financial obligation)
Mark, pierce, or tear (a ticket or stamp) to show that it has been used or invalidated.
(of a factor or circumstance) neutralize or negate the force or effect of (another)
Delete (an equal factor) from both sides of an equation or from the numerator and denominator of a fraction.
A mark made on a postage stamp to show that it has been used.
A new page or section inserted in a book to replace the original text, typically to correct an error.
--Examples--
‘he was forced to cancel his visit’
‘his visa had been cancelled’
‘I intend to cancel your debt to me’
‘cancelling stamps on registered mail’
‘the electric fields may cancel each other out’
‘‘Divide by 9’ cancels out ‘multiply by 9’’
‘a stamp franked and with an adhesive cancel’
‘a cancel title page’

--Word--
pencil 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An instrument for writing or drawing, consisting of a thin stick of graphite or a similar substance enclosed in a long thin piece of wood or fixed in a cylindrical case.
Graphite or a similar substance used as a medium for writing or drawing.
A cosmetic in a long thin stick.
Something with the shape of a pencil.
A set of light rays, lines, etc. converging to or diverging narrowly from a single point.
Write, draw, or colour with a pencil.
pencil something in
Arrange, forecast, or note down something provisionally.
pencil someone in
Make a provisional arrangement with or for someone.
--Examples--
‘have a pencil and paper ready’
‘a pencil drawing’
‘the words were scribbled in pencil’
‘an eyebrow pencil’
‘a pencil of light’
‘a pencil torch’
‘a previous owner has pencilled their name inside the cover’
‘May 15 was pencilled in as the date for the meeting’
‘he was pencilled in for surgery at the end of the month’

--Word--
pend 
--Type--
noun, noun, verb, verb, verb
--Meanings--
English regional (East Anglian). Pressure, strain; an awkward or difficult situation.
An arch, an archway; an arched or vaulted roof or canopy; the vaulted ground floor of a tower or fortified building; a covered passage or entry; (in later use) especially one leading off a street frontage.
To pinch, be constricting. Also: to press or beat down. Compare pend. Now English regional (East Anglian).
Now informal. To depend on or upon.
To await conclusion or resolution.
To treat as pending; to postpone deciding on or attending to; to defer.
--Examples--
--Word--
pendant 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A piece of jewellery that hangs from a chain worn round the neck.
A necklace with a pendant.
A light designed to hang from the ceiling.
The part of a pocket watch by which it is suspended.
A short rope hanging from the head of a ship's mast, yardarm, or clew of a sail, used for attaching tackles.
An artistic, literary, or musical composition intended to match or complement another.
A tapering flag.
Hanging downwards; pendent.
--Examples--
‘a jade-green pendant on a gold chain’
‘I slipped the pendant over my neck’
‘decorative pendants may need a special ceiling fitting’
‘the triptych's pendant will occupy the corresponding wall in the south transept’
‘pendant flowers on frail stems’

--Word--
Penderecki, Krzysztof 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1933), Polish composer. His music frequently features sounds drawn from extramusical sources and note clusters, as in his Threnody for the Victims of Hiroshima (1960) for fifty-two strings. Notable religious works: Stabat Mater (1962) and Polish Requiem (1980–4).
--Examples--
--Word--
Pendergast, Thomas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1872–1945), US politician; full name Thomas Joseph Pendergast. An early supporter of Harry Truman, he was the acknowledged Democratic boss of Kansas City, Missouri. He served time in prison for income tax evasion 1939–40.
--Examples--

noun

--Word--
Penelope 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The wife of Odysseus, who was beset by suitors when her husband did not return after the fall of Troy. She put them off by saying that she would marry only when she had finished the piece of weaving on which she was engaged, and every night unravelled the work she had done during the day.

--Word--
penis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The male genital organ of higher vertebrates, carrying the duct for the transfer of sperm during copulation. In humans and most other mammals it consists largely of erectile tissue and is used also for urination.
A type of male copulatory organ present in some invertebrates, such as gastropod molluscs.

--Examples--
--Word--
penetrable

--Meanings--

‘the translation makes the original text penetrable’
--Word--
penetrate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Go into or through (something), especially with force or effort.
(of a man) insert the penis into the vagina or anus of (a sexual partner).
Gain access to (an organization, place, or system), especially when this is difficult to do.
(of a company) begin to sell its products in (a particular market or area)
Succeed in understanding or gaining insight into (something complex or mysterious)
Be fully understood or realized by someone.
--Examples--
‘the shrapnel had penetrated his head’
‘tunnels that penetrate deep into the earth's core’
‘M15 had been penetrated by Russian intelligence’
‘the company has succeeded in penetrating Western motorcycle markets’
‘I could never penetrate his thoughts’
‘as his words penetrated, she saw a mental picture of him with Dawn’
--Word--
penetrably 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a penetrable manner; so as to be penetrable.
--Examples--

penetralia 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
penetrameter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An instrument for determining the wavelength, intensity, or total received dose of X-rays by measuring photographically their transmission through layers of metal of known thickness.
--Examples--
--Word--
penetrance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The extent to which a particular gene or set of genes is expressed in the phenotypes of individuals carrying it, measured by the proportion of carriers showing the characteristic phenotype.

--Word--
penetrant 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of a gene or group of genes) producing characteristic effects in the phenotypes of individuals possessing it.
A coloured or fluorescent liquid used to penetrate cracks, pores, and other surface defects to facilitate their detection.
--Examples--
--Word--
penetrate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Go into or through (something), especially with force or effort.
(of a man) insert the penis into the vagina or anus of (a sexual partner).
Gain access to (an organization, place, or system), especially when this is difficult to do.
(of a company) begin to sell its products in (a particular market or area)
Succeed in understanding or gaining insight into (something complex or mysterious)
Be fully understood or realized by someone.
--Examples--
‘the shrapnel had penetrated his head’
‘tunnels that penetrate deep into the earth's core’
‘M15 had been penetrated by Russian intelligence’
‘the company has succeeded in penetrating Western motorcycle markets’
‘I could never penetrate his thoughts’
‘as his words penetrated, she saw a mental picture of him with Dawn’

--Word--
penetrating 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Able to make a way through or into something.
(of a sound) clearly heard through or above other sounds.
(of a person's eyes or expression) reflecting an apparent ability to see into another's mind; intense.
Having or showing clear insight.
--Examples--
‘the problem of penetrating damp’
‘her scream was sudden and penetrating’
‘her penetrating gaze’
‘the students asked some penetrating questions’

--Word--
penetration 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of penetrating something.
The insertion by a man of his penis into the vagina or anus of a sexual partner.
The selling of a company's products in a particular market or area.
The extent to which a product is recognized and bought by customers in a particular market.
The perceptive understanding of complex matters.
--Examples--
‘the zip has a Velcro-secured flap to minimize rain penetration’
‘they had failed to make any penetration into new energy markets’
‘the software has attained a high degree of market penetration’
‘the survey shows subtlety and penetration’

--Word--
Phnom Penh 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Cambodia, a port at the junction of the Mekong and Tonlé Sap Rivers; population 1,438,300 (est. 2009). It became the capital of a Khmer kingdom in the mid 15th century. Between 1975 and 1979 the Khmer Rouge forced a great many of its population (then 2.5 million) to leave the city and resettle in the country.
--Examples--
--Word--
penholder 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A cylindrical rod or tube of wood, metal, plastic, etc., into which the nib of a pen may be fixed, and which then forms the handle of the pen. Also: any container or compartment for holding or storing a pen, especially a cylindrical tube, often on its own base, into which a pen may be inserted when not in use.

pinhook

verb
--Meanings--
To buy (a commodity, originally tobacco) cheaply with the expectation of selling it later for a profit. Now: specifically to buy a very young racehorse cheaply for this purpose. Also without object. Compare pinhooking.

--Word--
penicillin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An antibiotic or group of antibiotics produced naturally by certain blue moulds, now usually prepared synthetically. Penicillin was discovered in 1928 and during the Second World War became the first antibiotic to be used by doctors.
A blue mould of a type that produces penicillin.
--Examples--
‘patients who are allergic to penicillin’
‘penicillins and cephalosporins’

--Word--
peninsularity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A narrow-minded character or outlook, of the sort supposed to result from living on a peninsula and thus having limited contact with other peoples; mental or intellectual isolation akin to insularity.
The fact of being a peninsula; peninsular nature.

penis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The male genital organ of higher vertebrates, carrying the duct for the transfer of sperm during copulation. In humans and most other mammals it consists largely of erectile tissue and is used also for urination.
A type of male copulatory organ present in some invertebrates, such as gastropod molluscs.

pennant 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tapering flag on a ship, especially one flown at the masthead of a vessel in commission.

pennated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Biology. Having branches or parts arranged like the barbs of a feather; pinnate; penniform, pennate. Now rare.
Generally. Winged; feathered; (in figurative use) swift, fleeting. Compare "pennate". rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
pennatulacean 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the order Pennatulacea of alcyonarian coelenterates, which have an elongated primary polyp anchored in sand or mud and usually bear secondary polyps on lateral branches.
A coelenterate of this order; a sea pen.
--Examples--

--Word--
pen 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An instrument for writing or drawing with ink, typically consisting of a metal nib or ball, or a nylon tip, fitted into a metal or plastic holder.
The occupation of writing.
An electronic device like a pen, used in conjunction with a writing surface to enter commands or data into a computer.
The tapering cartilaginous internal shell of a squid.
Write or compose.
--Examples--
‘she was forced to support herself by the pen’
‘Olivia penned award-winning poetry’
--Word--
penneech 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A point-trick card game in which the seven of diamonds has distinctively high value and in which the trump suit changes with every trick.
--Examples--
--Word--
Penney, James Cash 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1875–1971), US businessman. He invested in a small store (the Golden Rule) in Kemmerer, Wyoming, 1902 and by 1913 had developed 34 stores, the beginning of the J. C. Penney department store chain. He was the company's president 1913–17 and chairman 1917–46.
--Examples--
--Word--
penner 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a case of metal, leather, etc., for holding pens; a pen-case. Later also: a writing case.
A person who pens or composes a piece of writing, a document, a statement, etc.; a writer of something (either the original composer, or a copier).
A person who pens cattle. Also (chiefly Australian and NZ): a person who pens sheep ready for the shearers in a shearing shed (frequently as "penner-up").
--Examples--
--Word--
penner 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a case of metal, leather, etc., for holding pens; a pen-case. Later also: a writing case.
A person who pens or composes a piece of writing, a document, a statement, etc.; a writer of something (either the original composer, or a copier).
A person who pens cattle. Also (chiefly Australian and NZ): a person who pens sheep ready for the shearers in a shearing shed (frequently as "penner-up").
--Examples--
--Word--
penner-up 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(on a sheep station) a worker who rounds up and pens sheep preparatory to shearing.
--Examples--
‘penners-up with their own dogs shall be paid an additional allowance’
--Word--
pennet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A piece or stick of barley-sugar or a similar confection; = penide. Usually in plural.
Formerly (especially in northern England): a 19th cent. trade term for a toffee-like sweet flavoured with lemon, peppermint, etc.
--Examples--
--Word--
penni 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(until the introduction of the euro in 2002) a monetary unit of Finland, equal to one hundredth of a markka.
--Examples--
--Word--
penny 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A British bronze coin and monetary unit equal to one hundredth of a pound.
A former British coin and monetary unit equal to one twelfth of a shilling and 240th of a pound.
A one-cent coin.
(in biblical use) a denarius.
A small sum of money.
Used for emphasis to denote no money at all.
--Examples--
‘calls are charged at fifty pence a minute’
‘a fifty-pence piece’
‘any chance to save a few pennies is welcome’
‘we didn't get paid a penny’
--Word--
penni 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(until the introduction of the euro in 2002) a monetary unit of Finland, equal to one hundredth of a markka.
--Examples--
--Word--
penny-a-line 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a writer: paid at the rate of a penny a line. Hence, of writing: long-winded, verbose; superficial, of little literary value.
--Examples--
--Word--
penny-a-liner 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person, especially a journalist, who practises penny-a-line writing; a writer of material of low literary quality.

penny 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A British bronze coin and monetary unit equal to one hundredth of a pound.
A former British coin and monetary unit equal to one twelfth of a shilling and 240th of a pound.
A one-cent coin.
(in biblical use) a denarius.
A small sum of money.
Used for emphasis to denote no money at all.

‘a fifty-pence piece’
‘any chance to save a few pennies is welcome’
‘we didn't get paid a penny’

--Word--
pennyland 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In Orkney, Caithness, and Shetland: a division of land on which a tax of one silver penny was owed to the overlord (probably originally the king of Norway), comprising one eighteenth of a urisland. Also: (in the Hebrides and parts of the western mainland) a similar division of land equal to one twentieth of a tirung or ounceland.

Pennine Hills 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A range of hills in northern England, extending from the Scottish border southwards to the Peak District in Derbyshire. Its highest peak is Cross Fell in Cumbria, which rises to 893 m (2,930 ft).

--Word--
Pennsylvania 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state in the north-eastern US; population 12,448,279 (est. 2008); capital, Harrisburg. Founded in 1682 by William Penn, it became one of the original thirteen states of the Union in 1787.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pennsylvanian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the state of Pennsylvania.
Relating to or denoting the later part of the Carboniferous period in North America, following the Mississippian and preceding the Permian, and corresponding to the Upper Carboniferous of Europe. This period lasted from about 323 to 290 million years ago.
A native or inhabitant of Pennsylvania.
The Pennsylvanian period or the system of rocks deposited during it.
--Examples--

--Word--
pension 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A regular payment made by the state to people of or above the official retirement age and to some widows and disabled people.
A regular payment made during a person's retirement from an investment fund to which that person or their employer has contributed during their working life.
A regular payment made to a royal favourite or to an artist or scholar to enable them to carry on work of public interest or value.
Dismiss someone from employment, typically because of age or ill health, and pay them a pension.
Discard something because it is too old or no longer wanted.
A small hotel or boarding house in France and other European countries.
--Examples--
‘men can draw a pension from the age of sixty-five’
‘the company pension scheme’
‘he was pensioned off from the army after the war’
‘garden sheds were raided to bring out machines long since pensioned off’
--Word--

pensionably 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
So as to be entitled to a pension.
--Examples--
--Word--
pensionary 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Forming or serving as a pension.

A person who receives a pension.
--Examples--
‘the reduction of pensionary benefits’
‘she was a pensionary of the family’

pentadecane 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a series of saturated hydrocarbons (alkanes) with the formula C₁₅H₃₂, especially (also n-"pentadecane") the unbranched isomer, CH₃(CH₂)₁₃CH₃, a liquid present in petroleum.

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of the series of hydrocarbon radicals —C₁₅H₃₁ derived from the pentadecanes; specifically the straight-chain radical —CH₂(CH₂)₁₃CH₃. Usually attributive or a formative element in chemical names.
--Examples--
--Word--
pentadelphous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(Of stamens) arranged in five groups; (of a plant) having the stamens so arranged.
--Examples--
--Word--
pentadic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the nature of a pentad; relating to or consisting of five people or things.
--Examples--
--Word--
pentadic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the nature of a pentad; relating to or consisting of five people or things.
--Examples--

pentadodecahedron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A regular dodecahedron; a dodecahedron having twelve pentagonal faces.
--Examples--
--Word--
pentadrachm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An ancient Cyrenaic coin worth five drachmas.
--Examples--

pentad 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A group or set of five.
--Examples--
--Word--
pentaerythritol 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A colourless, crystalline, synthetic compound, C(CH₂OH)₄, which is a tetrahydric alcohol and is used as a raw material in chemical manufacture, especially of paints and varnishes.
--Examples--
--Word--
pentafid 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Cleft into five; compare earlier quinquefid.
--Examples--

Pentagynia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the Linnaean artificial system: an order comprising plants having flowers with five pistils or styles.

--Word--
pentaglot 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A work written in or dealing with five different languages.
Of a dictionary or other work: relating to or composed in five languages.
--Examples--
--Word--
pentagon 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A plane figure with five straight sides and five angles.
The pentagonal building serving as the headquarters of the US Department of Defense, near Washington DC. Part of the building was badly damaged in the terrorist attacks of 11 September 2001.
The US Department of Defense.
--Examples--
‘the Pentagon said that ten soldiers had been killed’

pentagonoid 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling a pentagon, somewhat pentagonal; (Physical Anthropology) denoting a skull having a roughly pentagonal cross-section when viewed from above.

pen-tailed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a tail resembling a feather, or a quill pen. Chiefly in "pen-tailed tree shrew"noun a very small tree shrew, Ptilocercus lowii (family Tupaiidae), of the Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, and Borneo, having a fringe of long, stiff hairs at the end of its tail.

pentameroid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the extinct superfamily Pentameroidea or family Pentameridae of articulate brachiopods having roughly pentagonal shells, known from fossils of Ordovician to Devonian age.
A pentameroid brachiopod.

Pentandria 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the Linnaean artificial system: the fifth class of plants, comprising those having hermaphrodite flowers with five stamens; (also) an order characterized by flowers with five stamens in any of certain other classes.
--Examples--
--Word--
pentandrous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Originally: †designating or belonging to the Linnaean class or order Pentandria (obsolete). In later use: having five stamens.

pentanol 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any saturated monohydric alcohol of the formula C₅H₁₁OH, of which several isomeric forms exist; specifically (also "n-pentanol" or "1-pentanol") the primary straight-chain alcohol CH₃(CH₂)₃CH₂OH (n-amyl alcohol).

--Meanings--

A pentaploid organism, variety, or species.

pentaprism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A prism having a five-sided cross section with two silvered surfaces, giving a constant deviation of all rays of light through 90°, used chiefly in the viewfinders of single-lens reflex cameras.

pentarchy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A group or league of five provinces, sees, kingdoms, etc., each under its own ruler; the rulers of these collectively. Now chiefly historical.
A governing body made up of five people, organizations, political parties, etc.
A group or confederation of five leading nations.
Figurative. A group or association of five related or dominant persons or things.

--Word--
Pentateuch 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The first five books of the Old Testament (Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, and Deuteronomy). Traditionally ascribed to Moses, it is now held by scholars to be a compilation from texts of the 9th to 5th centuries BC.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pentateuchal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or contained in the first five books of the Old Testament.
--Examples--
‘the Pentateuchal sources’

pentathionic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An unstable polythionic acid having five atoms of sulphur per molecule, H₂S₅O₆, known only in solution.

--Word--
pentathlon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An athletic event comprising five different events for each competitor, in particular (also modern pentathlon) an event involving fencing, shooting, swimming, riding, and cross-country running.
--Examples--

pentatomid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Any of numerous plant-feeding heteropteran insects (bugs) constituting the family Pentatomidae, many members of which are brilliantly coloured; a shield bug, a stink bug.
Of or relating to the family Pentatomidae.

pentatonic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to, based on, or denoting a scale of five notes, especially one without semitones equivalent to an ordinary major scale with the fourth and seventh omitted.

‘pentatonic scales in the key of G Major’
‘a simple pentatonic idea repeated chromatically’

pentene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of a number of isomeric liquid alkenes with the formula C₅H₁₀; especially either of the straight-chain isomers CH₂=CH(CH₂)₂CH₃ ("1-pentene") or CH₃CH=CH(CH₂)CH₃ ("2-pentene").
--Examples--
--Word--
pentene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of a number of isomeric liquid alkenes with the formula C₅H₁₀; especially either of the straight-chain isomers CH₂=CH(CH₂)₂CH₃ ("1-pentene") or CH₃CH=CH(CH₂)CH₃ ("2-pentene").

penthemimer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A metrical unit consisting of two and a half feet, especially constituting half of a pentameter, or the first part of an iambic trimeter or hexameter when the caesura occurs in the middle of the third foot.
--Examples--

penthemimeral 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Type--

--Word--
pentyne 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: any of a number of unsaturated hydrocarbons with the formula C₅H₈. Now specifically: an alkyne with this formula, especially (also 1-"pentyne") the unbranched isomer CH≡CCH₂CH₂CH₃.
--Examples--
--Word--
pentyne 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: any of a number of unsaturated hydrocarbons with the formula C₅H₈. Now specifically: an alkyne with this formula, especially (also 1-"pentyne") the unbranched isomer CH≡CCH₂CH₂CH₃.
--Examples--
--Word--
pentitol 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several isomeric pentahydric alcohols of the formula CH₂OH·(CHOH)₃·CH₂OH, derived from pentose sugars and often present in plant tissues, such as arabitol, ribitol, and xylitol.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pentland Firth 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A channel separating the Orkney Islands from the northern tip of mainland Scotland. It links the North Sea with the Atlantic.

pentose 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of the class of simple sugars whose molecules contain five carbon atoms, such as ribose and xylose. They generally have the chemical formula C₅H₁₀O₅.
--Examples--
--Word--
pentose 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of the class of simple sugars whose molecules contain five carbon atoms, such as ribose and xylose. They generally have the chemical formula C₅H₁₀O₅.
--Examples--
--Word--
pentoside 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A glycoside, usually a nucleoside, which yields a pentose on hydrolysis.
--Examples--
--Word--
pentosuria 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Abnormal excretion of pentoses in the urine; specifically a benign inherited (autosomal recessive) condition characterized by the excretion of L-xylulose in the urine.

--Word--
penuche 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A kind of coarse brown sugar used especially in Mexico.
A kind of sweet similar to fudge, made with brown sugar, butter, milk or cream, and (usually) nuts. More fully "penuche fudge".
--Examples--
--Word--
penuche 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A kind of coarse brown sugar used especially in Mexico.
A kind of sweet similar to fudge, made with brown sugar, butter, milk or cream, and (usually) nuts. More fully "penuche fudge".
--Examples--

penumbra 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The partially shaded outer region of the shadow cast by an opaque object.
The shadow cast by the earth or moon over an area experiencing a partial eclipse.
The less dark outer part of a sunspot, surrounding the core.
A peripheral or indeterminate area or group.
--Examples--
‘an immense penumbra of theory surrounds any observation’

--Word--
Penutian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a proposed superfamily or phylum of North American languages including Chinook, Klamath, and Nez Percé, most of which are now extinct or nearly so. Some scholars include certain living languages of Central and South America, principally Mayan and Mapuche, in this group.
The Penutian family of languages.
--Examples--
--Word--
penwiper 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small brush or wad of folded cloth (in earlier use frequently of a decorative design) used for cleaning a pen by wiping the ink from it. Now chiefly historical.
--Examples--

Penza 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in south central Russia; population 507,800 (est. 2008). Situated on the River Sura, a tributary of the River Volga, it is an industrial and transportation centre.

--Word--
people 
--Type--
plural noun, verb
--Meanings--
Human beings in general or considered collectively.
The citizens of a country, especially when considered in relation to those who govern them.
The members of a society without special rank or position.
The state prosecution in a trial.
The members of a particular nation, community, or ethnic group.
The supporters or employees of a person in a position of power or authority.
One's parents or relatives.
(of a group of people) inhabit (a place)
Fill or be present in (a place or domain)
Fill (a place) with inhabitants.
--Examples--
‘the earthquake killed 30,000 people’
‘people think I'm mad’
‘his reforms no longer have the support of the people’
‘she is a favourite of the people’
‘pre-trial statements made by the People's witnesses’
‘the native peoples of Canada’
‘I've had my people watching the house for some time now’
‘my people live in Warwickshire’
‘an arid mountain region peopled by warring clans’
‘in her imagination the flat was suddenly peopled with ghosts’
‘it was his intention to people the town with English colonists’
--Word--
blinding 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of light) very bright and likely to dazzle or cause temporary blindness.
Temporarily obstructing the vision.
(especially of pain) very intense.
(of an action) remarkably skilful and exciting.
The process of covering a newly made road with grit to fill cracks.
Grit used to cover a newly made road.
A thin bed of concrete laid down over an area before the main mass of concrete is put in place.
--Examples--
‘the sunlight outside was blinding’
‘a blinding flash of inspiration’
‘blinding rain’
‘I've got a blinding headache’
‘he denied Norwich victory with two blinding saves’
--Word--
born 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Existing as a result of birth.
Having a specific nationality.
Having a natural ability to do a particular job.
Perfectly suited or trained to do a particular job.
(of an organization, movement, or idea) brought into existence.
Existing as a result of (a particular situation or feeling)
--Examples--
‘she was born in Aberdeen’
‘I was born with a sense of curiosity’
‘a newly born baby’
‘a German-born philosopher’
‘he's a born engineer’
‘men born to rule’
‘on 1 January 1992, the new company was born’
‘his work is born of despair’

Peoria 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river port and industrial city in central Illinois, on the Illinois River; population 114,114 (est. 2008). The city developed around a fort built by the French in 1680.
--Examples--
--Word--
Peorian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Peoria, Illinois. Also allusively: a member of any American community in which plain, down-to-earth, conventional tastes and attitudes prevail.
Geology. The Peorian deposits; the Peorian interglacial period.
Geology. Of, relating to, or designating extensive deposits, especially of loess, laid down during the final Pleistocene (Wisconsin) glaciation of North America. Also: designating an interglacial period between the Iowan and Wisconsin glaciations.

pep 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, abbreviation
--Meanings--
Energy and high spirits; liveliness.
Make someone or something more lively or interesting.
(in the UK) personal equity plan, a scheme allowing individuals to hold shares and unit trusts free of tax on dividends and capital gains (replaced in 1999 by the ISA).
Political and Economic Planning.
--Examples--
‘he was an enthusiastic player, full of pep’
‘measures to pep up the economy’

Pepys, Samuel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1633–1703), English diarist and naval administrator. He is particularly remembered for his Diary (1660–9), which describes events such as the Great Plague and the Fire of London.
--Examples--

Pepysian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, belonging to, or characteristic of Samuel Pepys, his library, or the age in which he lived; (of a written record or account) resembling the diaries of Pepys, especially in being frank and full of personal detail.

pep 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, abbreviation
--Meanings--

--Word--
pepper 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A pungent hot-tasting powder prepared from dried and ground peppercorns, used as a spice or condiment to flavour food.
A reddish hot-tasting spice prepared from various forms of capsicum.
A capsicum, especially a sweet pepper.
A climbing vine with berries that are dried as black or white peppercorns.
Used in names of other plants which are related or similar to the pepper, e.g. Jamaica pepper, water pepper.
A practice game in which a fielder throws at close range to a batter who hits back to the fielder.
Sprinkle or season (food) with pepper.
Cover or fill with a liberal amount of scattered items.
Hit repeatedly with small missiles or gunshot.
Inflict severe punishment or suffering upon.
--Examples--
‘season to taste with salt and pepper’
‘he liked to play pepper’
‘peppered beef’
‘the script is peppered with four-letter words’
‘another burst of enemy bullets peppered his defenceless body’
‘if he finds out my haunts he swears he'll pepper me’
--Word--
pepper-and-salt

adjective

--Examples--
‘his pepper-and-salt beard’

--Word--
castor 
--Type--
noun, noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
Each of a set of small swivelling wheels fixed to the legs or base of a heavy piece of furniture so that it can be moved easily.
A small container with holes in the top, especially one used for sprinkling sugar or pepper.
An oily reddish-brown substance secreted by beavers, used in medicine and perfumes.
The twin brother of Pollux.
The second-brightest star in the constellation Gemini, close to Pollux. It is a multiple star system, the three components visible in a moderate telescope being close binaries.
--Examples--
--Word--
peppercorn 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The dried berry of a climbing vine, used whole as a spice or ground to make pepper.

--Examples--
‘an old man with greying peppercorns’
‘her peppercorn hair’

Strongly flavoured with pepper or other hot spices.
Having a flavour or scent like that of pepper.
(of a person) irritable and sharp-tongued.
--Examples--
‘a hot, peppery dish’
‘nasturtiums have a peppery taste’
‘retired generals are expected to be peppery’
--Word--
pepperidge 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A deciduous North American tree with colourful autumn foliage.
--Examples--

--Type--

--Meanings--

pepperiness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
pepper 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A pungent hot-tasting powder prepared from dried and ground peppercorns, used as a spice or condiment to flavour food.
A reddish hot-tasting spice prepared from various forms of capsicum.
A capsicum, especially a sweet pepper.
A climbing vine with berries that are dried as black or white peppercorns.
Used in names of other plants which are related or similar to the pepper, e.g. Jamaica pepper, water pepper.
A practice game in which a fielder throws at close range to a batter who hits back to the fielder.
Sprinkle or season (food) with pepper.
Cover or fill with a liberal amount of scattered items.
Hit repeatedly with small missiles or gunshot.
Inflict severe punishment or suffering upon.
--Examples--
‘season to taste with salt and pepper’
‘he liked to play pepper’
‘peppered beef’
‘the script is peppered with four-letter words’
‘another burst of enemy bullets peppered his defenceless body’
‘if he finds out my haunts he swears he'll pepper me’
--Word--
pepperish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling or redolent of pepper; peppery. Also figurative: irritable, testy, angry.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--

--Meanings--
Resembling or redolent of pepper; peppery. Also figurative: irritable, testy, angry.

peppermint 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The aromatic leaves of a plant of the mint family, or an essential oil obtained from them, used as a flavouring in food.
A sweet flavoured with peppermint oil.
The cultivated Old World plant which yields peppermint leaves or oil.
Any of a number of trees or shrubs with peppermint-scented foliage.
--Examples--
‘peppermint creams’
‘peppermint tea’
‘she sucked on her peppermints’

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Word--
pepperwood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "pepperwood tree". Any of various trees with spicy or pungently aromatic wood, bark, or leaves, especially (a) any of the lauraceous trees Umbellularia californica of California, Cinnamomum laubatii of Queensland, and Dicypellium caryophyllaceum and Licaria guianensis of tropical America; (b) US either of the prickly ashes, Zanthoxylum clava-herculis and Z. americanum (family Rutaceae); (c) NZ the horopito, Pseudowintera axillaris (family Winteraceae).
--Examples--

noun

--Word--
pep 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, abbreviation
--Meanings--
Energy and high spirits; liveliness.
Make someone or something more lively or interesting.
(in the UK) personal equity plan, a scheme allowing individuals to hold shares and unit trusts free of tax on dividends and capital gains (replaced in 1999 by the ISA).
Political and Economic Planning.
--Examples--
‘he was an enthusiastic player, full of pep’
‘measures to pep up the economy’

--Word--
peptide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A compound consisting of two or more amino acids linked in a chain, the carboxyl group of each acid being joined to the amino group of the next by a bond of the type OCNH.
--Examples--
--Word--
peptide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A compound consisting of two or more amino acids linked in a chain, the carboxyl group of each acid being joined to the amino group of the next by a bond of the type OCNH.

peptizer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A substance which causes peptization, or which serves to prevent the coagulation of a colloid suspension; specifically a catalyst used to facilitate the process of mastication or vulcanization of rubber, by preventing the recombination of broken polymer chains.

peracetic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A colourless, corrosive, pungent liquid, CH₃CO·O·OH, that is explosive when hot and is widely used, usually dissolved in acetic acid, as an oxidizing agent in synthesis and as a bleach, sterilizing agent, etc.

peramble 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
English regional (chiefly northern and Lincolnshire). A long rambling tale or speech.
A walk, a ramble; a short excursion with no particular route or aim. rare.
To wander or ramble in speaking. Now English regional (Lincolnshire).

perambulant 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
perambulate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Walk or travel through or round a place or area, especially for pleasure and in a leisurely way.
Walk round (a parish, forest, etc.) in order to officially assert and record its boundaries.
--Examples--
‘the locals perambulate up and down the thoroughfare’
‘she perambulated the square’
‘commissioners were appointed to perambulate the Devon forests before Whitsun 1319’

Perameles 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of marsupials comprising the long-nosed bandicoots of Australia (and formerly all other bandicoots); (also perameles) an animal of this genus (now rare).
--Examples--
--Word--
perameloid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Originally: resembling a marsupial of the family Peramelidae. Later: of, relating to, or designating marsupials of the superfamily Perameloidea, which includes Peramelidae and related families.
A perameloid marsupial.
--Examples--
--Word--
perborate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A salt which is an oxidized borate containing a peroxide linkage, especially a sodium salt of this kind used as a bleach.
--Examples--
‘one of the common peroxide bleaches, perborate, produces boron when it breaks down’
‘it is obtained by action of acids on hydrated barium dioxide or from perborates’

perceiver 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
perceiver 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
perceive 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Become aware or conscious of (something); come to realize or understand.
Become aware of (something) by the use of one of the senses, especially that of sight.
Interpret or regard (someone or something) in a particular way.
--Examples--
‘his mouth fell open as he perceived the truth’
‘he was quick to perceive that there was little future in such arguments’
‘he perceived the faintest of flushes creeping up her neck’
‘if Guy does not perceive himself as disabled, nobody else should’
‘some geographers perceive hydrology to be a separate field of scientific enquiry’
--Word--

verb
--Meanings--

--Word--
per cent 
--Type--
adverb, noun
--Meanings--
By a specified amount in or for every hundred.
One part in every hundred.
The rate, number, or amount in each hundred.
--Examples--
‘new car sales may be down nineteen per cent’
‘staff rejected a 1.8 per cent increase’
‘a reduction of half a per cent or so in price’
--Word--
percentage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A rate, number, or amount in each hundred.
Any proportion or share in relation to a whole.
An amount, such as an allowance or commission, that is a proportion of a larger sum of money.
Personal benefit or advantage.
--Examples--
‘the percentage of Caesareans at the hospital was three per cent higher than the national average’
‘a large percentage increase’
‘only a tiny percentage of the day trippers are aware of the village's gastronomic distinction’
‘I hope to be on a percentage’
‘I don't see the percentage in selling perfectly good furniture’
--Word--
percentaged 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Expressed or stated as a percentage.
--Examples--
--Word--
percentage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A rate, number, or amount in each hundred.
Any proportion or share in relation to a whole.
An amount, such as an allowance or commission, that is a proportion of a larger sum of money.
Personal benefit or advantage.
--Examples--
‘the percentage of Caesareans at the hospital was three per cent higher than the national average’
‘a large percentage increase’
‘only a tiny percentage of the day trippers are aware of the village's gastronomic distinction’
‘I hope to be on a percentage’
‘I don't see the percentage in selling perfectly good furniture’
--Word--
percental 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Reckoned by the hundred; calculated as a percentage.
--Examples--
--Word--
-percenter 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
Denoting a member of a group forming a specified and usually small percentage of the population.
Denoting a person who takes commission at a specified rate.
Denoting something whose value is estimated as a specified percentage.
--Examples--
‘he was a one-percenter, riding outside of the law’
‘ten-percenter agents’
‘five-percenter Treasury bonds’
--Word--
percentile 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of the 100 equal groups into which a population can be divided according to the distribution of values of a particular variable.
Each of the 99 intermediate values of a random variable which divide a frequency distribution into 100 such groups.
--Examples--
‘the tenth percentile for weight’
‘she passed the state board exam in the top percentile’
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

‘she passed the state board exam in the top percentile’
--Word--
a (or one) hundred percent 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--
Entirely; completely.
Completely fit and healthy.
Maximum effort and commitment.
--Examples--
‘I'm one hundred percent sure’
‘I wasn't exactly one hundred percent’
‘he always gave one hundred percent for the team’

adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
perception 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The ability to see, hear, or become aware of something through the senses.
Awareness of something through the senses.
The neurophysiological processes, including memory, by which an organism becomes aware of and interprets external stimuli.
The way in which something is regarded, understood, or interpreted.
Intuitive understanding and insight.
--Examples--
‘the normal limits to human perception’
‘the perception of pain’
‘Hollywood's perception of the tastes of the American public’
‘we need to challenge many popular perceptions of old age’
‘‘He wouldn't have accepted,’ said my mother with unusual perception’

--Word--
perceptionism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The theory that all knowledge derives ultimately from sense-perception. Also: the theory that everything can be explained by human perceptions of reality rather than by external reality.
--Examples--

--Word--
Perceval 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A legendary figure dating back to ancient times, found in French, German, and English poetry from the late 12th century onwards. He is the father of Lohengrin and the hero of a number of legends, some of which are associated with the Holy Grail.
--Examples--
--Word--
perch 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An object on which a bird alights or roosts, typically a branch or horizontal bar.
A place where someone or something rests or sits, especially one that is high or precarious.
(of a bird) alight or rest on something.
(of a person) sit on something high or narrow.
(of a building) be situated above or on the edge of something.
Set or balance someone or something on.
--Examples--
‘the budgerigar shuffled along its perch’
‘Marian looked down from her perch in a beech tree above the road’
‘a herring gull perched on the rails’
‘Eve perched on the side of the armchair’
‘the fortress is perched on a crag in the mountains’
‘Peter perched a pair of gold-rimmed spectacles on his nose’
--Word--
gutta-percha 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hard tough thermoplastic substance which is the coagulated latex of certain Malaysian trees. It consists chiefly of a hydrocarbon isomeric with rubber and is now used chiefly in dentistry and for electrical insulation.

--Word--
perciform 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to fishes of an order (Perciformes ) that comprises those resembling the perches. This is the largest vertebrate order and includes nearly half of all bony fishes.
A perciform fish.
--Examples--
--Word--
percylite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A substance originally regarded as a mineral, a hydroxychloride of lead and copper, but now thought to be a mixture of boleite and pseudoboleite.

--Word--
Lowell, Percival 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1855–1916), American astronomer. Lowell inferred the existence of a ninth planet beyond Neptune, and when it was eventually discovered in 1930 it was given the name Pluto, with a symbol that also included his initials. He was the brother of Amy Lowell.

percolative 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Allowing or involving the gradual filtering of a liquid or gas through a porous surface or substance.
--Examples--

--Word--
percolate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of a liquid or gas) filter gradually through a porous surface or substance.
Spread gradually through an area or group of people.
(of coffee) be prepared in a percolator.
Prepare (coffee) in a percolator.
Be or become full of lively activity or excitement.
--Examples--
‘the water percolating through the soil may leach out minerals’
‘continental ideas on art, science, and architecture percolated from Venice to London’
‘he put some coffee on to percolate’
‘it will have to be instant coffee—there's no time to percolate any’
‘the night was percolating with an expectant energy’
--Word--
percolated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of coffee) prepared in a percolator.
--Examples--
‘freshly percolated coffee’

--Word--
percussion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Musical instruments played by striking with the hand or with a stick or beater, or by shaking, including drums, cymbals, xylophones, gongs, bells, and rattles.
The striking of one solid object with or against another with some degree of force.
The action of tapping a part of the body as part of a diagnosis.
--Examples--
‘percussion instruments’
‘the clattering percussion of objects striking the walls and the shutters’
‘the chest sounded dull on percussion’

perdrigon

--Word--
oeil-de-perdrix 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "oeil-de-perdrix champagne", "oeil-de-perdrix wine". A pale red or rosé wine or champagne; the pink or pale red colour of such a wine.
A repeating pattern of dotted circles, usually on a coloured background, used to decorate some French pottery and porcelain. Frequently attributive, especially in "oeil-de-perdrix pattern".
Lacemaking. A similar design consisting of small whole-stitch hexagonals inside a hexagonal mesh, used as a ground or filling in bobbin lace.

--Word--
cire perdue 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A method of bronze casting using a clay core and a wax coating placed in a mould. The wax is melted in the mould and drained out, and bronze poured into the space left, producing a hollow bronze figure when the core is discarded.

--Meanings--
Foreignness in style, fashion, dialect, etc.; strangeness, outlandishness. Now rare.
The condition or quality of being a foreigner or (resident) alien; (Roman Law) the condition of being a peregrine. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
peregrinity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Foreignness in style, fashion, dialect, etc.; strangeness, outlandishness. Now rare.
The condition or quality of being a foreigner or (resident) alien; (Roman Law) the condition of being a peregrine. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
pereion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The part of a crustacean between the head and the abdomen, bearing the pereiopods; the crustacean thorax, especially those thoracic segments that are not fused with the head.
--Examples--
--Word--
pereiopod 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of the eight walking limbs of a crustacean such as a crab or lobster, growing from the thorax.
--Examples--
--Word--
Perelman, S. J. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1904–79), American humorist and writer; full name Sidney Joseph Perelman. In the early 1930s he worked in Hollywood as a scriptwriter, and from 1934 his name is linked with the New Yorker magazine, for whom he wrote most of his short stories and sketches.
--Examples--

--Meanings--
To do away with or quash (a thing, especially a legal process or suit).

peremption 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Law. The action of quashing a suit, legal process, etc., after the expiry of a fixed period of time; the expiry of a right, etc., after a fixed period of time. Now US.

--Word--
perennial 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Lasting or existing for a long or apparently infinite time; enduring or continually recurring.
Apparently permanently engaged in a specified role or way of life.
(of a plant) living for several years.
(of a stream or spring) flowing throughout the year.
A perennial plant.
--Examples--
‘his perennial distrust of the media’
‘perennial manifestations of urban crisis’
‘he's a perennial student’
‘cow parsley is perennial’
‘spring streams rise from perennial springs’
‘perennials will transform the garden in summer’
--Word--
perenniality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or quality of being perennial.
--Examples--

perennialize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To make perennial or permanent.
--Examples--
--Word--
perennially 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that continues for a long or apparently infinite time; permanently.
On a yearly basis for several years.
--Examples--
‘a new blow to the perennially struggling economy’
‘perennially popular destinations like Rome’
‘a lily that grows perennially from bulbs’

--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating tailed amphibians that retain their gills throughout life; (formerly) specifically †belonging to the division Perennibranchia or Perennibranchiata (obsolete). Opposed to "caducibranchiate".
A perennibranchiate amphibian.

--Word--
Peres, Shimon 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1923–2016), Polish-born Israeli statesman, prime minister 1984–6 and 1995–6; president 2007–2014; Polish name Szymon Perski. As Foreign Minister under Yitzhak Rabin he played a major role in negotiating the PLO–Israeli peace accord (1993). Nobel Peace Prize (1994), shared with Rabin and Yasser Arafat.
--Examples--

--Word--
perfect 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Having all the required or desirable elements, qualities, or characteristics; as good as it is possible to be.
Free from any flaw or defect in condition or quality; faultless.
Precisely accurate; exact.
Highly suitable for someone or something; exactly right.
Thoroughly trained in or conversant with.
Absolute; complete (used for emphasis)
(of a number) equal to the sum of its positive divisors, e.g. the number 6, whose divisors (1, 2, 3) also add up to 6.
(of a tense) denoting a completed action or a state or habitual action which began in the past. The perfect tense is formed in English with have or has and the past participle, as in they have eaten and they have been eating (present perfect), they had eaten (past perfect), and they will have eaten (future perfect).
(of a flower) having both stamens and carpels present and functional.
Denoting the stage or state of a fungus in which the sexually produced spores are formed.
(of an insect) fully adult and (typically) winged.
Make (something) completely free from faults or defects; make as good as possible.
Bring to completion; finish.
Complete (a printed sheet of paper) by printing the second side.
Satisfy the necessary conditions or requirements for the transfer of (a gift, title, etc.)
The perfect tense.
--Examples--
‘life certainly isn't perfect at the moment’
‘a perfect summer's day’
‘the equipment was in perfect condition’
‘a perfect circle’
‘with a little help you can create a room that is perfect for you’
‘the perfect present for golfers everywhere’
‘she was perfect in French’
‘a perfect stranger’
‘all that Joseph said made perfect sense to me’
‘he's busy perfecting his bowling technique’
‘then urg'd, she perfects her illustrious toils’
‘the heap was normally printed as white paper in the morning, turned at the midday break, and perfected in the afternoon’
‘equity will not perfect an imperfect gift’

perfecta

noun
--Meanings--
A bet in which the first two places in a race must be predicted in the correct order.

noun

perfector 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Perfecter.
Printing. = perfecting machine.

--Word--
perforation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hole made by boring or piercing.
A small hole or row of small holes punched in a sheet of paper, e.g. of postage stamps, so that a part can be torn off easily.
The action or state of perforating or being perforated.
--Examples--
‘the perforations allow water to enter the well’
‘memos are produced in a continuous strip divided by perforations so that the forms can be detached’
‘there was evidence of intestinal perforation’
--Word--
perforation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hole made by boring or piercing.
A small hole or row of small holes punched in a sheet of paper, e.g. of postage stamps, so that a part can be torn off easily.
The action or state of perforating or being perforated.
--Examples--
‘the perforations allow water to enter the well’
‘memos are produced in a continuous strip divided by perforations so that the forms can be detached’
‘there was evidence of intestinal perforation’

--Word--
perform 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Carry out, accomplish, or fulfil (an action, task, or function)
Work, function, or do something well or to a specified standard.
Have successful or satisfactory sexual intercourse with someone.
Present (a form of entertainment) to an audience.
Entertain an audience, typically by acting, singing, or dancing on stage.
--Examples--
‘I have my duties to perform’
‘the car performs well at low speeds’
‘our £120 million investment in the company is not performing at present’
‘when I go to bed with any other woman I am quite unable to perform’
‘the play has already been performed in Britain’
‘the band will be performing live in Hyde Park’

--Meanings--
An act of presenting a play, concert, or other form of entertainment.
An act of performing a dramatic role, song, or piece of music.
A display of exaggerated behaviour or a process involving a great deal of unnecessary time and effort; a fuss.
The action or process of performing a task or function.
A task or operation seen in terms of how successfully it is performed.
The capabilities of a machine, product, or vehicle.
The extent to which an investment is profitable, especially in relation to other investments.
An individual's use of a language, i.e. what a speaker actually says, including hesitations, false starts, and errors.
--Examples--
‘Don Giovanni had its first performance in 1787’
‘Bailey gives a sound performance as the doctor’
‘he stopped to fasten his shoelace and seemed to be making quite a performance of it’
‘the continual performance of a single task reduces a man to the level of a machine’
‘pay increases are now being linked more closely to performance’
‘it was a tremendous all-round performance by Wigan’
‘the hardware is put through tests which assess the performance of the processor’
‘a performance car’
‘unit-trust performance’
--Word--
performance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An act of presenting a play, concert, or other form of entertainment.
An act of performing a dramatic role, song, or piece of music.
A display of exaggerated behaviour or a process involving a great deal of unnecessary time and effort; a fuss.
The action or process of performing a task or function.
A task or operation seen in terms of how successfully it is performed.
The capabilities of a machine, product, or vehicle.
The extent to which an investment is profitable, especially in relation to other investments.
An individual's use of a language, i.e. what a speaker actually says, including hesitations, false starts, and errors.
--Examples--
‘Don Giovanni had its first performance in 1787’
‘Bailey gives a sound performance as the doctor’
‘he stopped to fasten his shoelace and seemed to be making quite a performance of it’
‘the continual performance of a single task reduces a man to the level of a machine’
‘pay increases are now being linked more closely to performance’
‘it was a tremendous all-round performance by Wigan’
‘the hardware is put through tests which assess the performance of the processor’
‘a performance car’
‘unit-trust performance’

--Meanings--

--Word--
performant 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Functioning well or as expected.
A person who performs a duty or ceremony.
--Examples--
‘a highly performant database which is easy to use’
--Word--
performative 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or of the nature of dramatic or artistic performance.
Characterized by the performance of a social or cultural role.
Relating to or denoting an utterance by means of which the speaker performs a particular act (e.g. I bet, I apologize, I promise).
A performative utterance.
--Examples--
‘films which push past the limits of current performative trends’
‘teaching is a performative act’
‘many feminist theorists have come to stress the contextual and performative aspects of gender’
‘here statements are not descriptive utterances but performatives’

--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
perform 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Carry out, accomplish, or fulfil (an action, task, or function)
Work, function, or do something well or to a specified standard.
Have successful or satisfactory sexual intercourse with someone.
Present (a form of entertainment) to an audience.
Entertain an audience, typically by acting, singing, or dancing on stage.
--Examples--
‘I have my duties to perform’
‘the car performs well at low speeds’
‘our £120 million investment in the company is not performing at present’
‘when I go to bed with any other woman I am quite unable to perform’
‘the play has already been performed in Britain’
‘the band will be performing live in Hyde Park’

--Word--
perfume 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A fragrant liquid typically made from essential oils extracted from flowers and spices, used to give a pleasant smell to one's body.
A pleasant smell.
Give a pleasant smell to.
Impregnate with perfume or a sweet-smelling substance.
Apply perfume to.
--Examples--
‘I caught a whiff of her fresh lemony perfume’
‘musk-based perfumes’
‘the heady perfume of lilacs’
‘just one bloom of jasmine has the power to perfume a whole room’
‘the cream is perfumed with rosemary and iris extracts’
‘her hair was oiled and perfumed’

--Word--
perfuse 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Permeate or suffuse with a liquid, colour, or quality.
Supply (an organ or tissue) with a fluid, typically treated blood or a blood substitute, by circulating it through blood vessels or other natural channels.
--Examples--
‘the yellow light is perfused with white’
‘the transplanted kidney is perfused at low pressure by retrograde flow’
‘the isolated perfused rat liver’

--Word--
Pergamum 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in ancient Mysia, in western Asia Minor, situated to the north of Izmir on a rocky hill close to the Aegean coast. The capital in the 3rd and 2nd centuries BC of the Attalid dynasty, it was one of the greatest and most beautiful of the Hellenistic cities and was famed for its cultural institutions, especially its library, which was second only to that at Alexandria.

adverb

--Word--
Pericles 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.495–429 BC), Athenian statesman and general. A champion of Athenian democracy, he pursued an imperialist policy and masterminded Athenian strategy in the Peloponnesian War. He commissioned the building of the Parthenon in 447 and promoted a flourishing of Athenian culture.

--Word--
peridermis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Botany= "periderm". rare.
Embryology= "periderm".
--Examples--
--Word--
periderm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The corky outer layer of a plant stem formed in secondary thickening or as a response to injury or infection.
--Examples--

peridium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The outer skin of a sporangium or other fruiting body of a fungus.

peridinian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A dinoflagellate of the chiefly marine order Peridinales.

peridotite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

noun
--Meanings--

adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
Périgord 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An area of south-western France, in the south-western Massif Central. A former countship, it became a part of Navarre in 1470, becoming united with France in 1670.
--Examples--
--Word--
Perigordian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the Périgord region in the department of Dordogne in south-west France.
Archaeology. Designating or relating to a French Upper Palaeolithic culture characterized by flint tools of the kind found at Laugerie-Haute in the Périgord region.
Chiefly Archaeology. A person of the Perigordian culture.
Archaeology. The Perigordian period or culture.
--Examples--
--Word--
perigraph 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Physical Anthropology. An instrument for drawing the contour lines on skulls or bones. rare.
--Examples--

noun

--Word--
insular 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Ignorant of or uninterested in cultures, ideas, or peoples outside one's own experience.
Lacking contact with other people.
Relating to or from an island.
Relating to a form of Latin handwriting used in Britain and Ireland in the early Middle Ages.
(of climate) equable because of the influence of the sea.
Relating to the insula of the brain.
--Examples--
‘a stubbornly insular farming people’
‘people living restricted and sometimes insular existences’
‘goods of insular origin’
‘insular illumination of the 6th century’

noun

--Word--
peril 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Serious and immediate danger.
The dangers or difficulties that arise from a particular situation or activity.
Expose to danger; threaten.
--Examples--
‘you could well place us both in peril’
‘the movement is in peril of dying’
‘a setback to the state could present a peril to the regime’
‘she first witnessed the perils of pop stardom a decade ago’
‘Jonathon perilled his life for love of David’

--Word--
perimeter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The continuous line forming the boundary of a closed geometrical figure.
The outermost parts or boundary of an area or object.
An area away from the basket, beyond the reach of the defensive team.
An instrument for measuring the extent and characteristics of a person's field of vision.
--Examples--
‘the perimeter of a rectangle’
‘the perimeter of the garden’
‘a perimeter fence’
‘he was very patient in working the ball around the perimeter’
--Word--
perimeter-less 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Boundless, infinite; (in later use in Sport), having inadequate or no defensive perimeters.

perine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In early use: the outermost layer of the exine of a pollen grain (now disused). Later: an outer layer surrounding the wall of the spore in ferns, mosses, and clubmosses; a perispore.

--Word--
perineuritis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: †inflammation of the peripheral portion of the optic disc or of the adjacent retina (obsolete). In later use: inflammation of the perineurium of a nerve or nerves.

--Word--
period 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A length or portion of time.
A portion of time in the life of a nation, civilization, etc. characterized by the same prevalent features or conditions.
A major division of geological time that is a subdivision of an era and is itself subdivided into epochs.
Each of the set divisions of the day in a school allocated to a lesson or other activity.
Each of the divisions of the playing time of a sporting event.
The interval of time between successive occurrences of the same state in an oscillatory or cyclic phenomenon, such as a mechanical vibration, an alternating current, a variable star, or an electromagnetic wave.
The time taken by a celestial object to rotate about its axis, or to make one circuit of its orbit.
The interval between successive equal values of a periodic function.
A flow of blood and other material from the lining of the uterus, lasting for a few days and occurring in sexually mature women who are not pregnant at intervals of about one lunar month until the menopause.
A punctuation mark (.) used at the end of a sentence or an abbreviation; a full stop.
Added to the end of a statement to indicate that no further discussion is possible or desirable.
A set of elements occupying a horizontal row in the periodic table.
A complex sentence, especially one consisting of several clauses, constructed as part of a formal speech or oration.
A complete idea, typically consisting of two or four phrases.
Belonging to or characteristic of a past historical time, especially in style or design.
--Examples--
‘he had long periods of depression’
‘the period 1977–85’
‘the training period is between 16 and 18 months’
‘the early medieval period’
‘the Cretaceous period’
‘two periods of PE are allocated on the timetable’
‘he interviewed the teachers when they had a free period’
‘the Lightnings ran at the Leafs hard in a very rough first period’
‘she's got her period’
‘period pains’
‘he is the sole owner of the trademark, period’
‘an attractive and beautifully modernized period house’
‘a splendid selection of period furniture’

periodate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

adjective
--Meanings--
Appearing or occurring at intervals.

--Examples--
‘the periodic visits she made to her father’

--Word--
periodide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
periodization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
periodize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Divide (a portion of time) into periods.
--Examples--
‘this illustrates the dangers of periodizing history and of ignoring the carry-over of medieval ideas’
--Word--
periodogram 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A diagram or method of graphical representation which is designed to detect or display any periodicity (usually with time) in a set of measurements; specifically one in which the results of harmonic analysis of the data, performed on the assumption in turn of different periods of variation, are plotted as a function of the period.
--Examples--
--Word--
periodograph 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A periodogram; (originally) specifically a curve drawn in a periodogram. Now disused.
An instrument for automatically making a periodogram analysis or Fourier analysis of a curve by optical means.
--Examples--
--Word--
periodology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The division of historical events, literature, artefacts, etc., into chronological periods; periodization; an instance of this. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--

adjective
