--Word--
periodontium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: †the periodontal ligament, which invests the root of a tooth (obsolete). In later use: all the tissues surrounding and supporting a tooth, including the alveolar process, the cementum, and the gingiva, as well as the periodontal ligament.
--Examples--
--Word--
periodontoclasia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Destruction or degeneration of periodontal tissue.
--Examples--
--Word--
periodontology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
periodontosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Periodontal disease; specifically loss of alveolar bone without inflammation, leading to displacement or loosening of the teeth.
--Examples--
--Word--
periodontosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Periodontal disease; specifically loss of alveolar bone without inflammation, leading to displacement or loosening of the teeth.
--Examples--
--Word--
periodontium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: †the periodontal ligament, which invests the root of a tooth (obsolete). In later use: all the tissues surrounding and supporting a tooth, including the alveolar process, the cementum, and the gingiva, as well as the periodontal ligament.
--Examples--
--Word--
period 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A length or portion of time.
A portion of time in the life of a nation, civilization, etc. characterized by the same prevalent features or conditions.
A major division of geological time that is a subdivision of an era and is itself subdivided into epochs.
Each of the set divisions of the day in a school allocated to a lesson or other activity.
Each of the divisions of the playing time of a sporting event.
The interval of time between successive occurrences of the same state in an oscillatory or cyclic phenomenon, such as a mechanical vibration, an alternating current, a variable star, or an electromagnetic wave.
The time taken by a celestial object to rotate about its axis, or to make one circuit of its orbit.
The interval between successive equal values of a periodic function.
A flow of blood and other material from the lining of the uterus, lasting for a few days and occurring in sexually mature women who are not pregnant at intervals of about one lunar month until the menopause.
A punctuation mark (.) used at the end of a sentence or an abbreviation; a full stop.
Added to the end of a statement to indicate that no further discussion is possible or desirable.
A set of elements occupying a horizontal row in the periodic table.
A complex sentence, especially one consisting of several clauses, constructed as part of a formal speech or oration.
A complete idea, typically consisting of two or four phrases.
Belonging to or characteristic of a past historical time, especially in style or design.
--Examples--
‘he had long periods of depression’
‘the period 1977–85’
‘the training period is between 16 and 18 months’
‘the early medieval period’
‘the Cretaceous period’
‘two periods of PE are allocated on the timetable’
‘he interviewed the teachers when they had a free period’
‘the Lightnings ran at the Leafs hard in a very rough first period’
‘she's got her period’
‘period pains’
‘he is the sole owner of the trademark, period’
‘an attractive and beautifully modernized period house’
‘a splendid selection of period furniture’
--Word--
periodizer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who arranges the past or things in the past into periods.
--Examples--

perioecus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Ancient Greek History. A member of a community in the area surrounding a city, usually having the status of a half-citizen, subject, or slave. Chiefly in plural.

periotic 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The bone forming the otic capsule of the inner ear, consisting of fused prootic, epiotic, and opisthotic bones.
Surrounding the ear, especially the inner ear; specifically designating each of the three bones (prootic, epiotic, and opisthotic) which constitute the otic capsule; designating the capsule itself.

--Word--
peripatetic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Travelling from place to place, in particular working or based in various places for relatively short periods.
(of a teacher) working in more than one school or college.
Aristotelian.
A person who travels from place to place, especially a teacher who works in more than one school or college.
An Aristotelian philosopher.
--Examples--
‘the peripatetic nature of military life’
‘a peripatetic music teacher’
‘peripatetics have been cut under local management of schools’

--Word--
peripheral 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or situated on the edge or periphery of something.
Of secondary or minor importance; marginal.
Near the surface of the body, with special reference to the circulation and nervous system.
(of a device) able to be attached to and used with a computer, though not an integral part of it.
A peripheral device.
--Examples--
‘the peripheral areas of Europe’
‘she will see their problems as peripheral to her own’
‘lymphocytes from peripheral blood’
‘a peripheral control processor’
‘printers and other peripherals’

noun

--Word--
periphractic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating a region of space having one or more internal bounding surfaces (or curves, when the region is two-dimensional) unconnected with the external boundary (e.g. a globe with an internal cavity, or an annulus), so that a closed surface (or curve, when the region is two-dimensional) may be drawn within the region which cannot be contracted to a point without passing out of the region.
--Examples--

--Examples--
--Word--
periphrasis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The use of indirect and circumlocutory speech or writing.
An indirect and circumlocutory phrase.
The use of separate words to express a grammatical relationship that is otherwise expressed by inflection, e.g. did go as opposed to went and more intelligent as opposed to cleverer.
--Examples--
‘a rather pompous periphrasis’
--Word--
periphrase 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Periphrasis.
--Examples--
--Word--
periphrasis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The use of indirect and circumlocutory speech or writing.
An indirect and circumlocutory phrase.
The use of separate words to express a grammatical relationship that is otherwise expressed by inflection, e.g. did go as opposed to went and more intelligent as opposed to cleverer.
--Examples--
‘a rather pompous periphrasis’
--Word--
periphrastic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of speech or writing) indirect and circumlocutory.
(of a case or tense) formed by a combination of words rather than by inflection (such as did go and of the people rather than went and the people's).
--Examples--
‘the periphrastic nature of legal syntax’

--Type--
adjective

--Word--
periplasm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Mycology. In an oomycete, especially one of the order Peronosporales: the outer portion of the cytoplasm in an oogonium or antheridium.
Entomology. The cytoplasm just inside the vitelline membrane of an insect's egg, surrounding the yolk.
Microbiology. The region of a bacterial or other cell between the plasma membrane and the cell wall or outer membrane.
--Examples--
--Word--
periplast 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: †a cell wall (obsolete). Now: specifically the wall of a unicellular organism, especially that of an alga of the division Cryptophyta, consisting of stiff proteinaceous plates.
--Examples--
--Word--
periplus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly with reference to the titles of books by Arrian and Hanno: an account or narrative of a circumnavigation or other voyage; a manual of navigation.
A circuit; a circumnavigation; a voyage or journey round a coastline; an epic journey, an odyssey.
Ancient Greek Nautical. A manoeuvre in naval warfare involving sailing round an enemy fleet.
--Examples--
--Word--
peripneumonia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Medicine. Inflammation of the lung; pneumonia or pneumonitis; an instance or case of this. Compare "peripneumony". Now historical.
Veterinary Medicine. More fully "bovine peripneumonia". Bovine pleuropneumonia. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
peripneustic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating or having a respiratory system in which there is a row of spiracles along each side of the body, all or almost all of which are fully functional.

periscope

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
perish 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Die, especially in a violent or sudden way.
Suffer complete ruin or destruction.
(of rubber, food, etc.) lose its normal qualities; rot or decay.
Be suffering from extreme cold.
--Examples--
‘a great part of his army perished of hunger and disease’
‘must these noble hopes perish so soon?’
‘an abandoned tyre whose rubber had perished’
‘I was perished with cold before the end of the day’
--Word--
perishability 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
perishable 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(especially of food) likely to decay or go bad quickly.
(of something abstract) having a brief life or significance; transitory.
Things, especially foodstuffs, likely to decay or go bad quickly.
--Examples--
‘the storage of perishable foods’
‘caviar is extremely perishable’
‘ballet is the most perishable of arts’
‘the shipment was delivered eventually though some of the perishables had gone off’

--Word--
proctor 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An officer (usually one of two) at certain universities, appointed annually and having mainly disciplinary functions.
An invigilator at a university or college examination.
(in the Church of England) an elected representative of the clergy in the convocation of Canterbury or York.
A qualified practitioner of law in ecclesiastical and certain other courts.
Invigilate (an examination)
--Examples--
‘18% of the faculty reported that graduate assistants frequently proctored exams’

proctoral 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Proctorial.

--Word--
proctotrupid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating a wasp of the family Proctotrupidae (or, formerly, the superfamily Proctotrupoidea), which comprises small parasitoids of insects (especially beetles and fungus gnats) and spiders.
A proctotrupid wasp.
--Examples--
--Word--
proctotrupoid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating a wasp of the superfamily Proctotrupoidea, which includes proctotrupids (in some schemes), platygasterids, and other small parasitoids of insects and spiders.
A proctotrupoid wasp. Now rare.

procurator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An agent representing others in a court of law in countries retaining Roman civil law.

A treasury officer in a province of the Roman Empire.

--Type--

--Word--
procurator general 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A chief legal representative or agent; specifically (a) the chief prosecuting attorney of a court; compare "procureur general"; (b) (especially in Russian or Soviet contexts) the chief legal officer of the state.
British. More fully "Her (also His) Majesty's Procurator General": = "Queen's (also King's) Proctor".
Roman Catholic Church.(a) The official representative of a religious order at the Vatican; (b) the head of a Jesuit mission (now historical).
--Examples--
--Word--
procuratory 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Scottish Law and Civil Law. Authorization for one person to act for another; an instrument or clause in an instrument giving such power. Now historical.
Of, relating to, or originating from a procurator; of or relating to procuration.

procuratrix 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A female procurator or agent. Compare factrix. Now historical and rare.
A nun who has responsibility for the temporal, especially financial, affairs of a nunnery. Compare "procurator". Now historical.

--Word--
procure 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Obtain (something), especially with care or effort.
Obtain (someone) as a prostitute for another person.
Persuade or cause (someone) to do something.
Cause (something) to happen.
--Examples--
‘food procured for the rebels’
‘he persuaded a friend to procure him a ticket’
‘he haunted railway stations to procure young girls for immoral purposes’
‘he procured his wife to sign the mandate for the joint account’
‘he was charged with procuring the death of the Earl of Lancaster’

--Word--
procurrent 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Running forwards; continuing or tapering forward at the base; specifically (in bony fishes) designating or relating to the slender, unbranched, unsegmented fin rays at the leading edges of a caudal fin, anterior to the principal rays.
--Examples--
--Word--
procursive 
--Type--
adjective, adjective
--Meanings--
That comes before, forerunning; = "precursive".
Originally: (Medicine) designating a form of epilepsy in which the seizures are characterized by a sudden, impulsive running forward; also figurative; (disused). Later: (more generally) characterized by running forward (rare).
--Examples--
--Word--
procurved 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Curved forwards; specifically (in spiders) designating a row of eyes arranged in an arc with the ends foremost.
--Examples--
--Word--
Czech 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of the Czech Republic or (formerly) Czechoslovakia, or a person of Czech descent.
The Western Slavic language spoken in the Czech Republic, closely related to Slovak. It has over 10 million speakers.
Relating to the Czechs or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
Czechoslovakian 
--Type--
adjective, noun

--Word--
prod 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Poke with a finger, foot, or pointed object.
Stimulate or persuade (someone who is reluctant or slow) to do something.
A poke with a finger, foot, or pointed object.
An act of stimulating or reminding someone to do something.
A pointed implement, typically one discharging an electric current and used as a goad.
--Examples--
‘he prodded her in the ribs’
‘she took up a fork and prodded at the food’
‘they attempted to prod the central bank into cutting interest rates’
‘he gave the wire netting an experimental prod’
‘you need a gentle prod to remind you that life is only what you make it’
‘a cattle prod’

prodroma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A symptom or sign that is characteristic or premonitory of the onset of a disease (chiefly in plural). Also: a set of such symptoms or signs; the initial, usually non-specific stage of a disease.

--Word--
produce 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Make or manufacture from components or raw materials.
(of a place or process) yield, grow, or supply.
Create or form (something) as part of a physical, biological, or chemical process.
Make (something) using creative skills.
Cause (a particular result or situation) to happen or exist.
Show or provide (something) for consideration, inspection, or use.
Administer the financial and managerial aspects of (a film or broadcast) or the staging of (a play, opera, etc.)
Supervise the making of (a musical recording), especially by determining the overall sound.
Extend or continue (a line)
Agricultural and other natural products collectively.
The result of a person's work or efforts.
--Examples--
‘the company have just produced a luxury version of the aircraft’
‘the vineyards in the Val d'Or produce excellent wines’
‘the plant produces blue flowers in late autumn’
‘the garden where the artist produced many of his flower paintings’
‘no conventional drugs had produced any significant change’
‘he produced a sheet of paper from his pocket’
‘the video was produced and directed by film-maker Neil Campbell’
‘the album was produced by reggae master mixer Groucho Smykle’
‘one side of the triangle was produced’
‘dairy produce’
‘the work was in some degree the produce of their joint efforts’
--Word--
produceable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Able to be brought forward or presented to notice or view; that can be produced, especially in a court of law; adducible; obtainable, available.
Capable of being brought into being; able or likely to be made or created.
--Examples--
--Word--
producible 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
produce 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Make or manufacture from components or raw materials.
(of a place or process) yield, grow, or supply.
Create or form (something) as part of a physical, biological, or chemical process.
Make (something) using creative skills.
Cause (a particular result or situation) to happen or exist.
Show or provide (something) for consideration, inspection, or use.
Administer the financial and managerial aspects of (a film or broadcast) or the staging of (a play, opera, etc.)
Supervise the making of (a musical recording), especially by determining the overall sound.
Extend or continue (a line)
Agricultural and other natural products collectively.
The result of a person's work or efforts.
--Examples--
‘the company have just produced a luxury version of the aircraft’
‘the vineyards in the Val d'Or produce excellent wines’
‘the plant produces blue flowers in late autumn’
‘the garden where the artist produced many of his flower paintings’
‘no conventional drugs had produced any significant change’
‘he produced a sheet of paper from his pocket’
‘the video was produced and directed by film-maker Neil Campbell’
‘the album was produced by reggae master mixer Groucho Smykle’
‘one side of the triangle was produced’
‘dairy produce’
‘the work was in some degree the produce of their joint efforts’
--Word--
producement 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The fact of producing, or the condition of being produced; production.
--Examples--
--Word--
producent 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who or thing which produces; a producer; (formerly specifically) the party producing a witness or document in the Ecclesiastical Courts (now historical).
--Examples--
--Word--
producer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person, company, or country that makes, grows, or supplies goods or commodities for sale.
A person or thing that makes or causes something.
A person responsible for the financial and managerial aspects of the making of a film or broadcast or for staging a play, opera, etc.
A person who supervises the making of a musical recording.
--Examples--
‘an oil producer’
‘the mould is the producer of the toxin aflatoxin’
‘a film producer’
‘he's the executive producer of weekday daytime shows’
‘a record producer’
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

‘he's the executive producer of weekday daytime shows’
‘a record producer’
--Word--
producership 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The position, role, or function of a producer.
--Examples--

--Word--
product 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An article or substance that is manufactured or refined for sale.
A substance produced during a natural, chemical, or manufacturing process.
Commercially manufactured articles, especially recordings, viewed collectively.
A thing or person that is the result of an action or process.
A person whose character and identity have been formed by a particular period or situation.
A quantity obtained by multiplying quantities together, or from an analogous algebraic operation.
--Examples--
‘food products’
‘waste products’
‘too much product of too little quality’
‘her perpetual suntan was the product of a solarium’
‘an ageing academic who is a product of the 1960s’
--Word--
productor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who or thing which produces; a producer, source.
--Examples--
--Word--
productibility 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality or fact of being producible.
--Examples--
--Word--
productible 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That may be productive; = "producible".
--Examples--
--Word--
productid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An articulate brachiopod of the extinct family Productidae or order Productida, found from the Ordovician to the Permian periods and characterized by spines or projections from the shell which are thought to have anchored the animal to the substrate.
Of, relating to, or characteristic of the family Productidae or the order Productida.
--Examples--
--Word--
production 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of making or manufacturing from components or raw materials, or the process of being so manufactured.
The harvesting or refinement of something natural.
The total amount of something that is produced.
The creation of something as part of a physical, biological, or chemical process.
Denoting a car or other vehicle which has been manufactured in large numbers, as opposed to a prototype or other special version.
The provision of something for consideration, inspection, or use.
The process of or management involved in making a film, play, or record.
A film, record, play, etc., viewed in terms of its making or staging.
The overall sound of a musical recording, as determined by the way in which it is produced.
--Examples--
‘banning the production of chemical weapons’
‘the car is no longer in production’
‘non-intensive methods of food production’
‘steel production had peaked in 1974’
‘excess production of collagen by the liver’
‘a production model’
‘members are entitled to a discount on production of their membership card’
‘the film was still in production’
‘an exciting new production of La Traviata’
‘the record's production is gloriously relaxed’
--Word--
productional 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
productionist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person involved in production, a producer. Also: a believer in or advocator of productionism. Sometimes with modifying word, as "co-operative productionist", etc.
That advocates or is based on productionism.
--Examples--
--Word--
production 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

productionized

adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
productive 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Producing or able to produce large amounts of goods, crops, or other commodities.
Relating to or engaged in the production of goods, crops, or other commodities.
Achieving a significant amount or result.
Producing or giving rise to.
(of a prefix, suffix, or other linguistic unit) currently used in forming new words or expressions.
(of a cough) that raises mucus from the respiratory tract.
--Examples--
‘the most productive employees’
‘the country's productive capacity’
‘a long and productive career’
‘the therapy sessions became more productive’
‘the hotel was not productive of amusing company’
‘many suffixes are common and productive’
--Word--
productively 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that produces or increases something, especially wealth or resources; profitably.
--Examples--
‘research on growing tomatoes as productively and efficiently as possible’
‘he continued to work productively until a few weeks before his death’
--Word--
productiveness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
productivity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or quality of being productive.
The effectiveness of productive effort, especially in industry, as measured in terms of the rate of output per unit of input.
The rate of production of new biomass by an individual, population, or community; the fertility or capacity of a given habitat or area.
--Examples--
‘the long-term productivity of land’
‘workers have boosted productivity by 30 per cent’
‘nutrient-rich waters with high primary productivity’
--Word--
productivity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or quality of being productive.
The effectiveness of productive effort, especially in industry, as measured in terms of the rate of output per unit of input.

--Examples--
‘the long-term productivity of land’
‘workers have boosted productivity by 30 per cent’
‘nutrient-rich waters with high primary productivity’

noun, adjective, noun

(especially among cockneys) one's wife.

adjective

--Word--
Ecuador 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An equatorial republic in South America, on the Pacific coast; population 16,100,000 (estimated 2015); languages, Spanish (official), Quechua; capital, Quito.

--Word--
Egyptian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Egypt or its people.
Relating to the culture or language of ancient Egypt.
A native of ancient or modern Egypt, or a person of Egyptian descent.
The Afro-Asiatic language used in ancient Egypt, attested from c.3000 BC. It is represented in its oldest stages by hieroglyphic inscriptions and in its latest form by Coptic; it has been replaced in modern use by Arabic.
--Examples--
‘an Egyptian obelisk’
--Word--
proegumenal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a cause of an effect, disease, etc.: preceding, predisposing; designating an original or primary cause, as opposed to an immediate or exciting cause. Also (Logic): of or relating to an internal cause.
--Examples--
--Word--

proem

noun
--Meanings--
A preface or preamble to a book or speech.
--Examples--
--Word--
proembryo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several other embryonic structures or stages of plants; (now) specifically the group of cells formed by the earliest divisions of the spermatophyte zygote, before the embryo proper and the suspensor become differentiated.
--Examples--
--Word--
proembryonic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or of the nature of a proembryo.

--Word--
entente 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A friendly understanding or informal alliance between states or factions.
A group of states in an informal alliance.
The understanding between Britain and France reached in 1904, forming the basis of Anglo-French cooperation in the First World War.
--Examples--
‘the emperor hoped to bring about an entente with Russia’
‘the unsuccessful scheme to lure Greece into the war on the side of the entente’
--Word--
proenzyme 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A biologically inactive substance which is metabolized into an enzyme.
--Examples--

proepimeron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Eskimo 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of an indigenous people inhabiting northern Canada, Alaska, Greenland, and eastern Siberia, and traditionally living by hunting seals and other Arctic animals and birds and by fishing.
Either of the two main languages spoken by indigenous peoples of the Arctic (Inuit and Yupik), comprising a major division of the Eskimo-Aleut family.
Relating to the Eskimos or their languages.
--Examples--
--Word--
Esperantist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Esperanto 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An artificial language devised in 1887 as an international medium of communication, based on roots from the chief European languages. It retains the structure of these languages and has the advantage of grammatical regularity and ease of pronunciation.
--Examples--
--Word--
Estonian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Estonia or its people or their language.
A native or inhabitant of Estonia, or a person of Estonian descent.
The Finno-Ugric language of Estonia, which is closely related to Finnish and is spoken by about a million people.
--Examples--
--Word--
Ethiopian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Ethiopia, or a person of Ethiopian descent.
A black person.
Relating to Ethiopia or its people.
Relating to or denoting a zoogeographical region comprising Africa south of the Sahara, together with the tropical part of the Arabian peninsula and (usually) Madagascar. Distinctive animals include the giraffes, hippopotamuses, aardvark, elephant shrews, tenrecs, and lemurs.
--Examples--
--Word--
pro-ethnic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or belonging to the period prior to the division of the Indo-Europeans into separate peoples. Also more generally: prior to the division of any people or race into separate tribes or ethnic groups.
--Examples--
--Word--
proette

--Meanings--
A female professional golfer.

proette 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A female professional golfer.

--Word--
Euclidean 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the system of geometry based on the work of Euclid and corresponding to the geometry of ordinary experience.
Of such a nature that the postulates of the Euclidean system of geometry are valid.
--Examples--
‘Euclidean geometry’
‘all points on a Euclidean circle are equidistant from the centre’
‘Euclidean space’

adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of mixed European (or European-American) and Asian parentage.
Relating to Eurasia.
A person of mixed European (or European-American) and Asian parentage.

--Word--
evangelical 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or according to the teaching of the gospel or the Christian religion.
Of or denoting a tradition within Protestant Christianity emphasizing the authority of the Bible, personal conversion, and the doctrine of salvation by faith in the Atonement.
Zealous in advocating or supporting a particular cause.
A member of the evangelical tradition in the Christian Church.
--Examples--
‘she was evangelical about organic farming’

--Word--
profane 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Not relating to that which is sacred or religious; secular.
(of a person) not initiated into religious rites or any esoteric knowledge.
(of a person or their behaviour) not respectful of religious practice; irreverent.
(of language) blasphemous or obscene.
Treat (something sacred) with irreverence or disrespect.
--Examples--
‘a talk that tackled topics both sacred and profane’
‘he was an agnostic, a profane man’
‘a profane person might be tempted to violate the tomb’
‘it was a serious matter to profane a tomb’

--Word--
fascism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An authoritarian and nationalistic right-wing system of government and social organization.
(in general use) extreme authoritarian, oppressive, or intolerant views or practices.
--Examples--
‘this is yet another example of health fascism in action’
--Word--
fascist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An advocate or follower of the political philosophy or system of fascism.
A person who is extremely right-wing or authoritarian.
A person who is very intolerant or domineering in a particular area.
Relating to fascism.
--Examples--
‘he went to Spain to fight against the fascists’
‘Eastern European fascists could win power only with support from the Nazis’
‘thousands of fascists and nationalists marched in the capital’
‘I'm a bit of a spelling fascist, but still have blind spots over words like ‘privilege’ or ‘separate’’
‘if I were being a culinary fascist, I would possibly moan about the overdone cooked tomatoes’
‘a military coup threw out the old fascist regime’
--Word--
pro- 
--Type--
prefix, prefix
--Meanings--
Favouring; supporting.
Acting as a substitute or deputy for.
Denoting motion forwards, out, or away.
Before in time, place, order, etc.
--Examples--
‘pro-choice’
‘proconsul’
‘proceed’
‘propel’
‘prostrate’
‘proactive’
‘prothalamium’
--Word--
profection 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or fact of going forward; progression, advance; (Astrology) the movement of a celestial body in the order of the zodiacal signs; = "progression"; an instance of this.
--Examples--
--Word--
profectitious 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of property or money: that proceeds or is derived from a parent or ancestor (applied especially to a dowry given to a woman by her paterfamilias). Contrasted with adventitious.
--Examples--

Prof.

abbreviation

--Word--
profert 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In early use: the production or exhibition of a deed in a court of law; (subsequently) a formal allegation that a deed is produced in court. Especially in "to make profert of": to produce or allege the production of (a document, deed, etc.) in court.
--Examples--
--Word--
profess 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Claim that one has (a quality or feeling), especially when this is not the case.
Have or claim knowledge or skill in (a subject or accomplishment)
Affirm one's faith in or allegiance to (a religion or set of beliefs)
Be received into a religious order under vows.
Teach (a subject) as a professor.
--Examples--
‘he had professed his love for her only to walk away’
‘I don't profess to be an expert’
‘he professed himself amazed at the boy's ability’
‘though knowing little of the arts I professed, he proved a natural adept’
‘a people professing Christianity’
‘she entered St Margaret's Convent, and was professed in 1943’
‘a professor—what does he profess?’
--Word--
professable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Capable of being professed; able to profess; able to be publicly taught or lectured on by a professor.
--Examples--
--Word--
professed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a quality, feeling, or belief) claimed openly but often falsely.
(of a person) openly declared to be.
(of a monk or nun) having taken the vows of a religious order.
Claiming to be qualified as a particular specialist; professional.
--Examples--
‘for all her professed populism, she was seen as remote from ordinary people’
‘a professed and conforming Anglican’
‘a professed nun’
--Word--
professedly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Ostensibly; apparently (used in reference to something claimed or asserted, possibly falsely)
--Examples--
‘restrictions professedly designed to stop the use of political propaganda’

--Word--
profession 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A paid occupation, especially one that involves prolonged training and a formal qualification.
A body of people engaged in a particular profession.
An act of declaring that one has a particular feeling or quality, especially when this is not the case.
A declaration of belief in a religion.
The declaration or vows made on entering a religious order.
The ceremony or fact of being professed in a religious order.
--Examples--
‘his chosen profession of teaching’
‘a barrister by profession’
‘the legal profession has become increasingly business-conscious’
‘his profession of delight rang hollow’
‘a profession of faith in Jesus Christ’
‘they were baptized on profession of faith’
‘after profession she taught in Maidenhead’
--Word--
professional 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or belonging to a profession.
Worthy of or appropriate to a professional person; competent, skilful, or assured.
Engaged in a specified activity as one's main paid occupation rather than as an amateur.
Habitually making a feature of a particular activity or attribute.
A person engaged or qualified in a profession.
A person engaged in a specified activity, especially a sport, as a main paid occupation rather than as a pastime.
A person competent or skilled in a particular activity.
--Examples--
‘young professional people’
‘his professional expertise’
‘their music is both memorable and professional’
‘a professional boxer’
‘a professional gloom-monger’
‘professionals such as lawyers and surveyors’
‘his first season as a professional’
‘she was a real professional on stage’

noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

professionalize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Give (an occupation, activity, or group) professional qualities, typically by increasing training or raising required qualifications.
--Examples--
‘attempts to professionalize the police are resisted by many’

--Word--
profile 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An outline of something, especially a person's face, as seen from one side.
A vertical cross section of a structure.
An outline of part of the earth's surface, e.g. the course of a river, as seen in a vertical section.
A flat outline piece of scenery on stage.
A short article giving a description of a person or organization.
(on a social media website or application) a user's summary of their personal details or current situation.
The extent to which a person or organization attracts public notice.
A graphical or other representation of information relating to particular characteristics of something, recorded in quantified form.
A record of a person's psychological or behavioural characteristics, preferences, etc.
Describe (a person or organization) in a short article.
Represent in outline from one side.
Have a specified shape in outline.
Shape (something), especially by means of a tool guided by a template.
--Examples--
‘the man turned and she caught his profile’
‘skilfully made vessels with an S-shaped profile’
‘in soft rocks a profile drawn normally to the beach would show a concave form comparable with the long profile of a river’
‘a profile of a Texas tycoon’
‘he posted the pictures on his Facebook profile’
‘raising the profile of women in industry’
‘a sleep profile for someone on a shift system’
‘they had been using personal details to build customer profiles’
‘he was to profile a backbench MP’
‘he was standing motionless, profiled on the far side of the swimming pool’
‘a proud bird profiled like a phoenix’
‘I use my angle grinder all the time for profiling tiles’
--Word--
profiled 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Shaped, especially by means of a tool guided by a template.
--Examples--
‘profiled and plain tiles’
--Word--
profiler 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who records and analyses someone's psychological and behavioural characteristics, so as to assess or predict their capabilities or to assist in identifying categories of people.
An instrument or device for making scientific measurements, for example of the atmosphere or physical features.
--Examples--
‘psychological profilers are being used to help officers build a picture of the attacker’
‘certain men have been targeted by our profilers and asked to provide DNA samples’
‘a wind profiler for winds in the upper atmosphere’
‘pavement roughness may be measured by laser profilers’

--Word--
profiling 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The recording and analysis of a person's psychological and behavioural characteristics, so as to assess or predict their capabilities in a certain sphere or to assist in identifying categories of people.
--Examples--
‘we put everyone through psychometric profiling’

--Word--
profilograph 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: an instrument which automatically records the contour line of the ground over which it travels; (later also) = profilometer.
--Examples--
--Word--
profilometer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(A trademark for) an instrument for measuring or recording the roughness or irregularity of a surface; specifically (a) one in which a fine stylus is drawn over a surface (especially that of a metal); (b) one consisting of a wheeled frame for travelling along a road; (c) one in which the surface of a material is scanned optically.
--Examples--
--Word--
Finnish 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the Finns or their language.
The language of the Finns, spoken by about 4.6 million people in Finland, and also in parts of Russia and Sweden. It is a Finno-Ugric language related to Estonian, and more distantly to Hungarian, and is noted for its morphological complexity.
--Examples--
--Word--
profit 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A financial gain, especially the difference between the amount earned and the amount spent in buying, operating, or producing something.
Advantage; benefit.
Obtain a financial advantage or benefit.
Obtain an advantage or benefit.
Be beneficial to.
--Examples--
‘record pre-tax profits’
‘his eyes brightened at the prospect of profit’
‘there's no profit in screaming at referees from the bench’
‘the only people to profit from the episode were the lawyers’
‘not all children would profit from this kind of schooling’
‘it would profit us to change our plans’

--Word--
profit and loss account 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An account in the books of an organization to which incomes and gains are credited and expenses and losses debited, so as to show the net profit or loss over a given period.
A financial statement showing a company's net profit or loss in a given period.

--Word--
profit 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A financial gain, especially the difference between the amount earned and the amount spent in buying, operating, or producing something.
Advantage; benefit.
Obtain a financial advantage or benefit.
Obtain an advantage or benefit.
Be beneficial to.
--Examples--
‘record pre-tax profits’
‘his eyes brightened at the prospect of profit’
‘there's no profit in screaming at referees from the bench’
‘the only people to profit from the episode were the lawyers’
‘not all children would profit from this kind of schooling’
‘it would profit us to change our plans’

pro forma 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
Done or produced as a matter of form.
Denoting a standard document or form, especially an invoice sent in advance of or with goods supplied.
(of a financial statement) showing potential or expected income, costs, assets, or liabilities, especially in relation to some planned act or situation.
As a matter of form or politeness.
A pro forma document or form.
--Examples--
‘pro forma reports’
‘a pro forma invoice’
‘revenues in excess of 35 million dollars on a pro forma basis’
‘he nodded to him pro forma’
‘please return the enclosed pro forma’
--Word--
profound 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of a state, quality, or emotion) very great or intense.
(of a disease or disability) very severe.
(of a person or statement) having or showing great knowledge or insight.
(of a subject or idea) demanding deep study or thought.
Very deep.
The deepest part of something, especially the ocean.
Profound quality.
--Examples--
‘profound feelings of disquiet’
‘the implications of this discovery are profound’
‘a case of profound liver failure’
‘a profound philosopher’
‘expressing profound truths in simple language’
‘profound crevasses’
‘nor billowy surge disturbs the vast profound’
‘her work is an often eerie mix of the banal and the profound’

prog 
--Type--
noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A television or radio programme.
A computer program.
A style of rock music popular especially in the 1970s and characterized by classical influences, the use of keyboard instruments, and lengthy compositions.
An advocate of social reform; a progressive.
Relating to or denoting rock music characterized by classical influences, the use of keyboard instruments, and lengthy compositions; progressive.
--Examples--
‘I don't watch cookery progs’
‘there are progs for the PC that will convert images to sound’
‘the band's blend of prog, psychedelia, and '60s pop’
‘I'm a child of the 60s and love prog rock’
‘a prog rock band’
‘if she decides to run, the hard-core progs will not support her anyway’
‘one of the most important prog albums of all time’
‘Tesseract sound very prog to me’

noun, noun, adjective

--Word--
Gaelic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the Goidelic group of Celtic languages, particularly Scottish Gaelic, and the speakers of these languages and their culture.
A Celtic language spoken mainly in the highlands and islands of western Scotland. It was brought from Ireland in the 5th and 6th centuries AD and is now spoken by about 58,000 people.

progger 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
British regional and Irish English. A person who solicits for something, especially habitually; a beggar. Now rare.

A butcher's spike or knife; (also generally) any sharp implement used for stabbing or piercing.

Progymnasium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In some European countries (chiefly parts of Germany and Switzerland): a school that prepares pupils for the gymnasium or upper school after primary school, sometimes incorporated within the gymnasium itself and regarded as its lower level; (also) a gymnasia not having the top forms which qualify for university entrance (now rare).

noun
--Meanings--
The likely course of a medical condition.
An opinion, based on medical experience, of the likely course of a medical condition.
A forecast of the likely outcome of a situation.
--Examples--
‘the disease has a poor prognosis’
‘it is very difficult to make an accurate prognosis’
‘gloomy prognoses about overpopulation’
--Word--
prognostic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or serving to predict the likely course of a medical condition.
An advance indication of a future event; an omen.
--Examples--
‘the prognostic importance of the antibody’
‘a pale moon and watery sun are known as prognostics of rain’

--Word--
Gothic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the Goths or their extinct language, which belongs to the East Germanic branch of the Indo-European language family. It provides the earliest manuscript evidence of any Germanic language (4th–6th centuries AD).
Of or in the style of architecture prevalent in western Europe in the 12th–16th centuries (and revived in the mid 18th to early 20th centuries), characterized by pointed arches, rib vaults, and flying buttresses, together with large windows and elaborate tracery. English Gothic architecture is divided into Early English, Decorated, and Perpendicular.
Belonging to or redolent of the Dark Ages; portentously gloomy or horrifying.
(of lettering) of or derived from the angular style of handwriting with broad vertical downstrokes used in western Europe from the 13th century, including Fraktur and black-letter typefaces.
Relating to goths or goth music.
The extinct language of the Goths.
The Gothic style of architecture.
Gothic type.
--Examples--
‘19th-century Gothic horror’
--Word--
government 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The group of people with the authority to govern a country or state; a particular ministry in office.
The system by which a state or community is governed.
The action or manner of controlling or regulating a state, organization, or people.
The relation between a governed and a governing word.
--Examples--
‘the government's economic record’
‘successive Labour governments’
‘a democratic form of government’
‘rules for the government of the infirmary’
--Word--
prograde 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
(of planetary motion) proceeding from west to east; direct.
(of a metamorphic change) resulting from an increase in temperature or pressure.
(of a coastline) advance towards the sea as a result of the accumulation of waterborne sediment.
--Examples--
‘these oolites were probably deposited as part of the coastal sand-barrier complex as it prograded basinwards’

--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
programmable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a computer or other machine) able to be provided with coded instructions for the automatic performance of a task.
--Examples--
‘a programmable thermostat allows you to preset your home's heating patterns’
‘the camera is fully programmable’
--Word--
programme 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A set of related measures or activities with a particular long-term aim.
A planned series of future events or performances.
A series of coded software instructions to control the operation of a computer or other machine.
A presentation or item on television or radio, especially one broadcast regularly between stated times.
A radio or television channel.
A sheet or booklet giving details of items or performers at an event or performance.
Provide (a computer or other machine) with coded instructions for the automatic performance of a task.
Write computer programs.
Input (instructions for the automatic performance of a task) into a computer or other machine.
Cause (a person or animal) to behave in a predetermined way.
Arrange according to a plan or schedule.
Schedule (an item) within a plan.
Broadcast (an item)
--Examples--
‘an extensive programme of reforms’
‘the British nuclear power programme’
‘a weekly programme of films’
‘the programme includes Dvořák's New World symphony’
‘a nature programme’
‘a theatre programme’
‘it is a simple matter to program the computer to recognize such symbols’
‘I've programmed for 25 years and have used many languages’
‘simply program in your desired volume level’
‘all members of a species are programmed to build nests in the same way’
‘we learn how to programme our own lives’
‘the next stage of the treaty is programmed for next year’
‘the station does not program enough contemporary works’
--Word--
programmer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who writes computer programs.
A device that automatically controls the operation of something in accordance with a prescribed program.
--Examples--
‘computer programmers and analysts’

--Word--
programma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Classical History, and formerly in some universities. A written notice, proclamation, or edict, especially one posted up in a public place; a public notice.
A public notice relating to a function or celebration about to take place, with a list of the proceedings in order; (hence) a prospectus, agenda, programme. Now historical.
--Examples--

Greek 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Greece, its people, or their language.
A native or inhabitant of modern Greece, or a person of Greek descent.
A Greek-speaking person in the ancient world, especially a native of one of the city states of Greece and the eastern Mediterranean.
The ancient or modern language of Greece, the only representative of the Hellenic branch of the Indo-European family.
A member of a fraternity or sorority having a Greek-letter name.
--Examples--
--Word--
progress 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Forward or onward movement towards a destination.
A state journey or official tour, especially by royalty.
Development towards an improved or more advanced condition.
Move forward or onward in space or time.
Calculate the position of (a planet) or of all the planets and coordinates of (a chart) according to the technique of progression.
Develop towards an improved or more advanced condition.
Cause (a task or undertaking) to make progress.
--Examples--
‘the darkness did not stop my progress’
‘they failed to make any progress up the estuary’
‘we are making progress towards equal rights’
‘as the century progressed the quality of telescopes improved’
‘work on the pond is progressing’
‘I cannot predict how quickly we can progress the matter’

--Word--
progression 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process of developing or moving gradually towards a more advanced state.
A passage or movement from one note or chord to another.
A predictive technique in which the daily movement of the planets, starting from the day of birth, represents a year in the subject's life.
A number of things in a series.
--Examples--
‘good opportunities for career progression’
‘a steady progression towards your goals’
‘a blues progression’
‘the vista unfolds in a progression of castles and vineyards as seemingly endless as the Rhine itself’

progressist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--

Favouring or characterized by innovation or reform; progressive.
--Examples--
--Word--
progressive 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Happening or developing gradually or in stages.
(of a medical condition) increasing in severity.
(of taxation or a tax) increasing as a proportion of the sum taxed as that sum increases.
(of a person or idea) favouring social reform.
Favouring change or innovation.
Relating to or denoting a style of rock music popular especially in the 1970s and characterized by classical influences, the use of keyboard instruments, and lengthy compositions.
Denoting an aspect or tense of a verb that expresses an action in progress, e.g. am writing, was writing.
(of a card game or dance) involving a series of sections for which participants successively change place or relative position.
Engaging in or constituting forward motion.
An advocate of social reform.
A progressive tense or aspect.
Each of a set of proofs of colour work, showing all the colours separately and the cumulative effect of overprinting them.
--Examples--
‘a progressive decline in popularity’
‘progressive liver failure’
‘steeply progressive income taxes’
‘a relatively progressive Minister of Education’
‘the most progressive art school in Britain’
‘classic progressive albums’
‘progressive bands like Black Sabbath and the Edgar Broughton Band’
‘people tend to present themselves either as progressives or traditionalists on this issue’
‘the present progressive’
--Word--
progressively 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Steadily; in stages.
In a forward-looking, innovative manner.
--Examples--
‘successive governments progressively increased expenditure on welfare’
‘symptoms become progressively worse over a period of years’
‘we have a strong product but to retain this momentum we must think progressively’
‘a circle of progressively minded reformers’

prog 
--Type--
noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A television or radio programme.
A computer program.
A style of rock music popular especially in the 1970s and characterized by classical influences, the use of keyboard instruments, and lengthy compositions.
An advocate of social reform; a progressive.
Relating to or denoting rock music characterized by classical influences, the use of keyboard instruments, and lengthy compositions; progressive.
--Examples--
‘I don't watch cookery progs’
‘there are progs for the PC that will convert images to sound’
‘the band's blend of prog, psychedelia, and '60s pop’
‘I'm a child of the 60s and love prog rock’
‘a prog rock band’
‘if she decides to run, the hard-core progs will not support her anyway’
‘one of the most important prog albums of all time’
‘Tesseract sound very prog to me’

--Word--
pro- 
--Type--
prefix, prefix
--Meanings--
Favouring; supporting.
Acting as a substitute or deputy for.
Denoting motion forwards, out, or away.
Before in time, place, order, etc.
--Examples--
‘pro-choice’
‘proconsul’
‘proceed’
‘propel’
‘prostrate’

--Word--

noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Hawaii.
The Austronesian language of Hawaii, now spoken by fewer than 2,000 people.
Relating to Hawaii, its people, or their language.

prohibit 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Formally forbid (something) by law, rule, or other authority.
Formally forbid someone from doing something.
(of a fact or situation) make (something) impossible; prevent.
--Examples--
‘all ivory trafficking between nations is prohibited’
‘he is prohibited from becoming a director’
‘the budget agreement had prohibited any tax cuts’

--Word--
malum prohibitum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Something which is not intrinsically wicked, but which is regarded as wrong because it contravenes a law or regulation. Also as adjective: evil by convention rather than by inherent nature.

Hohenstaufen 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A German dynastic family, some of whom ruled as Holy Roman emperors between 1138 and 1254, among them Frederick I (Barbarossa).

Hohenzollern 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A German dynastic family from which came the kings of Prussia from 1701 to 1918 and German emperors from 1871 to 1918.

Hungarian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Hungary, its people, or their language.
A native or inhabitant of Hungary, or a person of Hungarian descent.
The official language of Hungary, spoken also by some 2.5 million people in Romania. Hungarian is a Finno-Ugric language and is the only major language of the Ugric branch.

Icelandic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Iceland or its language.
The language of Iceland. A Scandinavian language, it has remained closely similar to Old Norse, due partly to the geographical isolation of Iceland and partly to a policy of avoiding loanwords.

Irishism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A statement which is manifestly self-contradictory or inconsistent.
A characteristically Irish word, phrase, or idiom. Also occasionally more generally: a characteristically Irish belief, attitude, or trait.
Chiefly depreciative. The fact or quality of being Irish; Irishness.

--Word--
Israel 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A country in the Middle East, on the Mediterranean Sea; population 8,100,000 (estimated 2015); languages, Hebrew (official), English, Arabic; capital (not recognized as such by the United Nations), Jerusalem.
The Hebrew nation or people. According to tradition they are descended from the twelve sons of the patriarch Jacob (also named Israel).
The northern kingdom of the Hebrews (c.930–721 BC), formed after the reign of Solomon, whose inhabitants were carried away to captivity in Assyria.

--Word--
project 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An individual or collaborative enterprise that is carefully planned to achieve a particular aim.
A piece of research work undertaken by a school or college student.
A proposed or planned undertaking.
A government-subsidized housing development with relatively low rents.
Estimate or forecast (something) on the basis of present trends.
Plan (a scheme or undertaking)
Extend outwards beyond something else; protrude.
Throw or cause to move forward or outward.
Cause (light, shadow, or an image) to fall on a surface.
Cause (a sound) to be heard at a distance.
Imagine (oneself, a situation, etc.) as having moved to a different place or time.
Present or promote (a particular view or image)
Present (someone or something) in a particular way.
Display (an emotion or quality) in one's behaviour.
Attribute or transfer an emotion or desire to (another person), especially unconsciously.
Draw straight lines through (a given figure) to produce a corresponding figure on a surface or a line.
Make a projection of (the earth, sky, etc.) on a plane surface.
--Examples--
‘a research project’
‘a project to build a new power station’
‘a history project’
‘the novel undermines its own stated project of telling a story’
‘her family still lives in the projects’
‘spending was projected at £72,900 million’
‘a projected exhibition of contemporary art’
‘I noticed a slip of paper projecting from the book’
‘seeds are projected from the tree’
‘the one light projected shadows on the wall’
‘being audible depends on your ability to project your voice’
‘people may be projecting the present into the past’
‘he strives to project an image of youth’
‘she liked to project herself more as a friend than a doctor’
‘everyone would be amazed that a young girl could project such depths of emotion’
‘men may sometimes project their own fears on to women’

adjective
--Meanings--

‘Simon was projectile vomiting’

--Word--
projection 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An estimate or forecast of a future situation based on a study of present trends.
The presentation of an image on a surface, especially a cinema screen.
An image projected on a surface.
The ability to make a sound heard at a distance.
The presentation or promotion of someone or something in a particular way.
A mental image viewed as reality.
The unconscious transfer of one's desires or emotions to another person.
A thing that extends outwards from something else.
The action of projecting a figure.
The representation on a plane surface of part of the surface of the earth or a celestial sphere.
A method for representing part of the surface of the earth or a celestial sphere on a plane surface.
--Examples--
‘plans based on projections of slow but positive growth’
‘population projection is essential for planning’
‘quality illustrations for overhead projection’
‘the band use stage projections featuring moon shots’
‘I taught him voice projection’
‘the legal profession's projection of an image of altruism’
‘monsters can be understood as mental projections of mankind's fears’
‘we protect the self by a number of defence mechanisms, including repression and projection’
‘the chipboard covered all the sharp projections’
‘the use of different map projections’

projectional 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or characterized by projection.
--Examples--

--Word--
projectionism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The theory that some apparent properties of objective reality in fact belong to the mind of the person perceiving it. Also: the theory that religious belief represents a projection of social desires or pressures and is not an innate aspect of humanity.
--Examples--
--Word--
projective 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or derived by projection.
(of a property of a figure) unchanged by projection.
Relating to the unconscious transfer of one's desires or emotions to another person.
Relating to the unconscious expression or introduction of one's impressions or feelings.
--Examples--
‘projective transformations’
‘the projective contents of wish fantasies’

noun

--Word--
Jordan 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A country in the Middle East, east of the River Jordan; population 7,600,000 (estimated 2015); official language, Arabic; capital, Amman.
A river flowing southward for 320 km (200 miles) from the Anti-Lebanon Mountains through the Sea of Galilee into the Dead Sea. John the Baptist baptized Christ in the River Jordan. It is regarded as sacred not only by Christians but also by Jews and Muslims.

--Word--
prokaryote 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A microscopic single-celled organism which has neither a distinct nucleus with a membrane nor other specialized organelles, including the bacteria and cyanobacteria.

proke

--Meanings--
To make a thrust at; to poke. Formerly also: †to goad, stir, incite, provoke (a person) to do something (obsolete).

--Word--
Prokofiev, Sergei 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1891–1953), Russian composer; full name Sergei Sergeevich Prokofiev. Notable works include seven symphonies, the opera The Love for Three Oranges (1919), the ballet music for Romeo and Juliet (1935–6), and Peter and the Wolf (1936), a young person's guide to the orchestra in the form of a fairy tale.
--Examples--
--Word--
Prokopyevsk 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A coal-mining city in southern Russia, in the Kuznets Basin industrial region to the south of Kemerovo; population 213,200 (est. 2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
Korean 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to North or South Korea or its people or language.
A native or inhabitant of North or South Korea, or a person of Korean descent.
The language of Korea, which has roughly 68 million speakers worldwide. It has its own writing system, and is now generally regarded as distantly related to Japanese.

--Word--
pro- 
--Type--
prefix, prefix
--Meanings--
Favouring; supporting.
Acting as a substitute or deputy for.
Denoting motion forwards, out, or away.
Before in time, place, order, etc.
--Examples--
‘pro-choice’
‘proconsul’
‘proceed’
‘propel’
‘prostrate’
‘proactive’
‘prothalamium’
--Word--
Kuwait 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A country on the north-western coast of the Persian Gulf; population 3,900,000 (estimated 2015); official language, Arabic; capital, Kuwait City.
--Examples--

prolactin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hormone released from the anterior pituitary gland that stimulates milk production after childbirth.
--Examples--
--Word--
Lamarckian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the French naturalist Jean Baptiste de Lamarck or his theory about the cause of organic evolution.
An adherent of the French naturalist Jean Baptiste de Lamarck's theory about the cause of organic evolution.
--Examples--
‘the mechanism of Lamarckian evolution’
‘a Lamarckian who believes that acquired characteristics can be inherited’
--Word--
prolamine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a class of proline-rich proteins which occur in the seeds of cereals and are characterized by solubility in strong alcohol solutions but insolubility in absolute alcohol or water.
--Examples--

--Word--
prolapse 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A slipping forward or down of a part or organ of the body.
A prolapsed part or organ, especially a uterus or rectum.
(of a part or organ of the body) slip forward or down.
--Examples--
‘a rectal prolapse’
‘a prolapsed uterus’

--Word--
Latin 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The language of ancient Rome and its empire, widely used historically as a language of scholarship and administration.
An inhabitant of ancient Latium in Ιtaly.
A native or inhabitant of a country whose language developed from Latin, especially a Latin American.
Music of a kind originating in Latin America, characterized by dance rhythms and extensive use of indigenous percussion instruments.
Relating to Latin.
Relating to the Western or Roman Catholic Church (as historically using Latin for its rites)
Relating to ancient Latium.
Relating to the countries using languages, such as French and Spanish, that developed from Latin.
Relating to or characteristic of Latin American music.
--Examples--
‘eclectic jazz through Latin into soulful grooves’
‘Latin poetry’
‘the Latin patriarch of Antioch’
‘Mexico and other Latin countries’
‘snapping his fingers to a Latin beat’

prolation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of uttering a word or sound; utterance, articulation.
Theology. The sending out or emission of the divine Word or Logos.
Early Music. The relation between the time values of a semibreve and a minim, determining the rhythm of a piece of music.

noun, verb

prolepsis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The anticipation and answering of possible objections in rhetorical speech.
The representation of a thing as existing before it actually does or did so, as in he was a dead man when he entered.
--Examples--
‘the destruction of the Vendôme Column and his part in it are foreshadowed in moments of haunting prolepsis’

noun

proliferate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Increase rapidly in number; multiply.
(of a cell, structure, or organism) reproduce rapidly.
Cause (cells, tissue, structures, etc.) to reproduce rapidly.
--Examples--
‘the science fiction magazines which proliferated in the 1920s’
‘cultured cells often proliferate indefinitely’
‘electromagnetic radiation can only proliferate cancers already present’

noun
--Meanings--
Rapid increase in the number or amount of something.

--Examples--

‘stress levels are high, forcing upon them a proliferation of ailments’

--Word--
prolific 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a plant, animal, or person) producing much fruit or foliage or many offspring.
(of an artist, author, or composer) producing many works.
(of a sports player) high-scoring.
Present in large numbers or quantities; plentiful.
Characterized by plentiful wildlife or produce.
--Examples--
‘in captivity tigers are prolific breeders’
‘he was a prolific composer of operas’
‘a prolific goalscorer’
‘mahogany was once prolific in the tropical forests’
‘the prolific rivers around Galway’

--Word--
prologue 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A separate introductory section of a literary, dramatic, or musical work.
The actor who delivers the prologue in a play.
An event or act that leads to another.
(in professional cycling) a short preliminary time trial held before a race to establish a leader.
--Examples--
‘the suppressed prologue to Women in Love’
‘the events from 1945 to 1956 provided the prologue to the post-imperial era’
‘I got third in the prologue and eighth on the hardest stage’
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--

prolong 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Extend the duration of.

--Examples--

‘the line of his lips was prolonged in a short red scar’

prolusory 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
Lutheran 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A follower of Martin Luther.
A member of the Lutheran Church.
Of or characterized by the theology of Martin Luther.
Relating to the Lutheran Church.
--Examples--
--Word--
prom 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A paved public walk, typically one along the seafront at a resort.
A ball or formal dance at a school or college, especially one held at the end of the academic year for students who are in their final year.
A concert of classical music at which part of the audience stands, in particular one of a series of concerts performed annually at the Royal Albert Hall in London.
--Examples--
‘she took a shortcut along the prom’
‘he asked me to the school prom but I turned him down’
‘a prom queen’
‘the last night of the Proms’

prom. 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--

--Word--
Macedonian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of the republic of Macedonia.
A native of ancient Macedonia.
A native or inhabitant of Macedonia in modern Greece.
The Southern Slavic language of the republic of Macedonia and adjacent parts of Bulgaria.
The language of ancient Macedonia, probably a dialect of Greek.
Relating to Macedonia or Macedonian.

Madagascan 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of Madagascar or its inhabitants.

--Word--
Magyar 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a people who originated in the Urals and migrated westwards to settle in what is now Hungary in the 9th century AD.
The Uralic language of the Magyars; Hungarian.
Relating to the Magyars or their language.
--Examples--

Malayan 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to Malays, the Malay language, or Malaya (now part of Malaysia).

Malaysian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Malaysia or its people.
A native or inhabitant of Malaysia, or a person of Malaysian descent.
--Examples--
‘I often eat at Malaysian restaurants’
‘his mother is Malaysian’
‘a 24-year-old Malaysian studying at the University of Tennessee’
--Word--
Maltese 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Malta or a person of Maltese descent.
The national language of Malta, a Semitic language related to Arabic but much influenced by Italian, Spanish, and Norman French.
Relating to Malta, its people, or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
Malthusian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the English economist and clergyman Thomas Robert Malthus or his ideas about population.
A person who supports the theories about population proposed by the English economist and clergyman Thomas Robert Malthus.
--Examples--
‘it seems we face a curious Malthusian catastrophe’
‘Malthusians spoke of moral restraint’
--Word--
promammalian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or designating a group of (actual or hypothetical) animals representing the ancestors of mammals, or the most primitive form of mammal.
--Examples--
--Word--
pro- 
--Type--
prefix, prefix
--Meanings--
Favouring; supporting.
Acting as a substitute or deputy for.
Denoting motion forwards, out, or away.
Before in time, place, order, etc.
--Examples--
‘pro-choice’
‘proconsul’
‘proceed’
‘propel’
‘prostrate’
‘proactive’
‘prothalamium’

--Word--
promazine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A drug of the phenothiazine class, used as a tranquillizer and antipsychotic. Also: any of a group of compounds structurally related to this. Compare earlier "chlorpromazine".
--Examples--
--Word--
Mediterranean 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or characteristic of the Mediterranean Sea, the countries bordering it, or their inhabitants.
Relating to or denoting a dark-complexioned human physical type found in some Mediterranean countries.
The Mediterranean Sea or the countries bordering it.
A native of a Mediterranean country.
--Examples--
‘a leisurely Mediterranean cruise’
‘our temperatures are Mediterranean’
‘she had curly hair and warm Mediterranean colouring’
‘a permanent American naval presence in the Mediterranean’
‘feta is made throughout the eastern Mediterranean’
‘an admiring audience of Mediterraneans’
--Word--
promenade 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A paved public walk, typically one along the seafront at a resort.
A leisurely walk, or sometimes a ride or drive, taken in a public place so as to meet or be seen by others.
(in country dancing) a movement in which couples follow one another in a given direction, each couple having both hands joined.
Take a leisurely public walk, ride, or drive so as to meet or be seen by others.
Take a promenade through (a place)
Escort (someone) about a place, especially so as to be seen by others.
--Examples--
‘an evening promenade’
‘they promenaded along the waterfront’
‘people began to promenade the streets’
‘the governor of Utah promenades the daughter of the Maryland governor’

--Word--
promeristem 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An apical meristem; specifically the region of a meristem comprising cells that have not yet undergone any of the changes associated with tissue differentiation.
--Examples--
--Word--
promerops 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Either of two southern African songbirds constituting the genus Promerops, now usually placed in their own family (Promeropidae); a sugarbird; (formerly also) †any of various similar slender-billed birds formerly included in this genus, such as certain birds of paradise and sunbirds (obsolete). Now only (in form Promerops) as a genus name.
--Examples--
--Word--
promethazine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A synthetic antihistamine drug derived from phenothiazine, used chiefly to treat the symptoms of allergies and motion sickness.
--Examples--
--Word--
promethea 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In full "promethea moth". A large North American saturniid silk moth, Callosamia promethea, the male of which has dark brown wings with pale margins. Compare slightly earlier "Prometheus".
--Examples--
--Word--
Promethean 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the demigod Prometheus, especially in being rebelliously creative and innovative.
--Examples--
‘the Promethean scientist who unlocked the mysteries of the cosmos’
--Word--
Prometheus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A demigod, one of the Titans, who was worshipped by craftsmen. When Zeus hid fire away from man Prometheus stole it by trickery and returned it to earth. As punishment Zeus chained him to a rock where an eagle fed each day on his liver, which grew again each night; he was rescued by Hercules.
--Examples--
--Word--
promethium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 61, a radioactive metal of the lanthanide series. It was first produced artificially in a nuclear reactor and occurs in nature in traces as a product of uranium fission.
--Examples--
--Word--
Methodist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a Christian Protestant denomination originating in the 18th-century evangelistic movement of Charles and John Wesley and George Whitefield.
Relating to Methodists or Methodism.
--Examples--
‘it is next to impossible to swerve a determined Methodist from his inspired path’
‘a Methodist chapel’

Mexican

adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Mexico or its people.
A native or inhabitant of Mexico, or a person of Mexican descent.
--Examples--
‘authentic Mexican cuisine’
‘urban scenes depicting the daily life of Mexicans’

prommer

noun
--Meanings--

‘the prommers kept audience participation to a minimum’
--Word--
promycelium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The basidium of a smut or rust fungus, a club-shaped structure bearing sporidia.
--Examples--
--Word--
promin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bacteriostatic antibiotic structurally related to dapsone, used chiefly in the treatment of leprosy.
--Examples--
--Word--
prominence 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state of being important, famous, or noticeable.
The fact or state of projecting from something.
A thing that projects from something, such as a projecting feature of the landscape or a protuberance on a part of the body.
A stream of incandescent gas projecting above the sun's chromosphere.
--Examples--
‘she came to prominence as an artist in the 1960s’
‘the commission gave the case a prominence which it might otherwise have escaped’
‘radiographs showed enlargement of the right heart with prominence of the pulmonary outflow tract’
‘the steep, rocky prominence resembled a snow-capped mountain’

--Word--
prominent 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Important; famous.
Projecting from something; protuberant.
Situated so as to catch the attention; noticeable.
A stout drab-coloured moth with tufts on the forewings which stick up while at rest, the caterpillars of which typically have fleshy growths on the back.
--Examples--
‘she was a prominent member of the city council’
‘a man with big, prominent eyes like a lobster's’
‘the new housing estates are prominent landmarks’
--Word--
prominently 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
With an important role; to a large extent.
In a manner that projects or protrudes from something.
So as to catch the attention; conspicuously.
--Examples--
‘the actor is to figure prominently in the marketing campaign’
‘his wife was prominently involved in local politics’
‘because of their height, the towers stand out prominently’
‘he left his comb protruding prominently from a pile of objects’
‘posters were prominently displayed in the hall’
‘Paxton's name appears prominently above the title’

promiscuous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

‘promiscuous teenagers’
‘they ran wild, indulging in promiscuous sex and experimenting with drugs’
‘the city fathers were promiscuous with their honours’
‘Americans are free to choose from a promiscuous array of values’

--Word--
promise 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A declaration or assurance that one will do something or that a particular thing will happen.
An indication that something is likely to occur.
The quality of potential excellence.
Assure someone that one will definitely do something or that something will happen.
Pledge (someone, especially a woman) to marry someone else; betroth.
Give good grounds for expecting (a particular occurrence)
Announce (something) as being expected to happen.
Contemplate the pleasant expectation of.
--Examples--
‘what happened to all those firm promises of support?’
‘I did not keep my promise to go home early’
‘dawn came with the promise of fine weather’
‘he showed great promise even as a junior officer’
‘he promised to forward my mail’
‘she made him promise that he wouldn't do it again’
‘‘I'll bring it straight back,’ she promised’
‘he promised her the job’
‘I've been promised to him for years’
‘forthcoming concerts promise a feast of music’
‘it promised to be a night that all would remember’
‘forecasters were promising a record snowfall in Boston’
‘we're promised more winter weather tonight’
‘he tidied up the sitting room, promising himself an early night’

‘it promised to be a night that all would remember’
‘forecasters were promising a record snowfall in Boston’
‘we're promised more winter weather tonight’
‘he tidied up the sitting room, promising himself an early night’
--Word--
promiseless 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Devoid of promise.
--Examples--
--Word--
promise 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A declaration or assurance that one will do something or that a particular thing will happen.
An indication that something is likely to occur.
The quality of potential excellence.
Assure someone that one will definitely do something or that something will happen.
Pledge (someone, especially a woman) to marry someone else; betroth.
Give good grounds for expecting (a particular occurrence)
Announce (something) as being expected to happen.
Contemplate the pleasant expectation of.
--Examples--
‘what happened to all those firm promises of support?’
‘I did not keep my promise to go home early’
‘dawn came with the promise of fine weather’
‘he showed great promise even as a junior officer’
‘he promised to forward my mail’
‘she made him promise that he wouldn't do it again’
‘‘I'll bring it straight back,’ she promised’
‘he promised her the job’
‘I've been promised to him for years’
‘forthcoming concerts promise a feast of music’
‘it promised to be a night that all would remember’
‘forecasters were promising a record snowfall in Boston’
‘we're promised more winter weather tonight’
‘he tidied up the sitting room, promising himself an early night’
