--Word--
modern 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the present or recent times as opposed to the remote past.
Characterized by or using the most up-to-date techniques, ideas, or equipment.
Denoting the form of a language that is currently used, as opposed to any earlier form.
Denoting a current or recent style or trend in art, architecture, or other cultural activity marked by a significant departure from traditional styles and values.
A person who advocates or practises a departure from traditional styles or values.
--Examples--
‘the pace of modern life’
‘modern European history’
‘they do not have modern weapons’
‘modern German’
‘Matisse's contribution to modern art’
‘they were moderns, they must not look back towards the old generation’
--Word--
Mohammedan blue 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A cobalt blue pigment, chiefly imported from Iran, used as an underglaze colour on Chinese porcelain of the Ming dynasty.
--Examples--
--Word--
Monaco 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A principality forming an enclave within French territory, on the Mediterranean coast near the Italian frontier; population 38,000 (estimated 2015); official language, French.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mongolian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Mongolia.
The language of Mongolia, a member of the Altaic family with an unusual vertical cursive script. It has some 2 million speakers, and related forms are spoken by over 3 million people in northern China.
Relating to Mongolia, its people, or their language.

--Word--
promorphology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The science of the fundamental morphology of organisms, which aims to describe in mathematical terms the stereometry and symmetries of organic forms; the features of organisms so studied. Now chiefly historical.
The physical organization of the ovum or very early embryo, considered as prefiguring the subsequent morphology of the embryo or of the mature organism.
--Examples--
--Word--
promorphological 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or derived from promorphology.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

--Word--
pro- 
--Type--
prefix, prefix
--Meanings--
Favouring; supporting.
Acting as a substitute or deputy for.
Denoting motion forwards, out, or away.
Before in time, place, order, etc.
--Examples--
‘pro-choice’
‘proconsul’
‘proceed’
‘propel’
‘prostrate’
‘proactive’
‘prothalamium’
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
promotable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
promote 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Support or actively encourage (a cause, venture, etc.); further the progress of.
Give publicity to (a product, organization, or venture) so as to increase sales or public awareness.
Attempt to ensure the passing of (a private Act of Parliament)
Raise (someone) to a higher position or rank.
Transfer (a sports team) to a higher division of a league.
Exchange (a pawn) for a more powerful piece of the same colour, typically a queen, when it reaches the opponent's end of the board.
Enable (a relatively low card) to win a trick by playing off the higher ones first.
(of an additive) act as a promoter of (a catalyst).
--Examples--
‘some regulation is still required to promote competition’
‘they are using famous personalities to promote the library nationally’
‘the government of the day would not be promoting the bill’
‘she was promoted to General Manager’
‘they were promoted from the Third Division last season’
‘East will win with the ace and lead a heart, promoting the ♠9’

--Word--
promoter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or company that finances or organizes a sporting event, concert, or theatrical production.
A person involved in setting up and funding a new company.
A supporter of a cause or aim.
An additive that increases the activity of a catalyst.
A region of a DNA molecule which forms the site at which transcription of a gene starts.
--Examples--
‘a boxing promoter’
‘Mitterrand was a fierce promoter of European integration’

--Word--
promotion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Activity that supports or encourages a cause, venture, or aim.
The publicizing of a product, organization, or venture so as to increase sales or public awareness.
A publicity campaign.
The activity of organizing publicity campaigns.
A sporting event, especially a series of boxing matches, staged for profit.
The action of promoting someone or something to a higher position or rank or the fact of being so promoted.
The action of promoting a catalyst.
--Examples--
‘the promotion of cultural and racial diversity’
‘a sales promotion company’
‘the paper is reaping the rewards of a series of promotions’
‘she's the promotions manager for EMI’
‘a boxing promotion’
‘majors designated for promotion to lieutenant colonel’
‘United won promotion last season’
‘a promotion to Sales Director’

--Meanings--

--Word--
prompt 
--Type--
verb, noun, adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
(of an event or fact) cause or bring about (an action or feeling)
Cause someone to take a course of action.
Encourage (a hesitating speaker) to say something.
Supply a forgotten word or line to (an actor) during the performance of a play.
(of a computer) request input from (a user)
An act of encouraging a hesitating speaker.
A word or phrase spoken as a reminder to an actor of a forgotten word or line.
A word or symbol on a screen to show that the system is waiting for input.
The time limit for the payment of an account, stated on a prompt note.
Done without delay; immediate.
(of a person) acting without delay.
(of goods) for immediate delivery and payment.
Exactly (with reference to a specified time)
--Examples--
‘the violence prompted a wave of refugees to flee the country’
‘curiosity prompted him to look inside’
‘‘And the picture?’ he prompted’
‘the online form prompts users for data’
‘with barely a prompt, Barbara talked on’
‘she would have died but for the prompt action of two ambulancemen’
‘the fans were prompt in complying with police requests’
‘I set off at three-thirty prompt’

noun

--Word--
promptly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
With little or no delay; immediately.
Used to express surprise, and slight disapproval, when someone does something shortly after something else.
At exactly a specified time; punctually.
--Examples--
‘he paid the fine promptly’
‘I won my appeal, but instead of reinstating me, they promptly sacked me again’
‘Jamie arrived promptly at 8:30’
--Word--
promptitude 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of acting quickly and without delay.
--Examples--
‘he arranges everything with extraordinary promptitude and foresight’

--Word--
prom 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A paved public walk, typically one along the seafront at a resort.
A ball or formal dance at a school or college, especially one held at the end of the academic year for students who are in their final year.
A concert of classical music at which part of the audience stands, in particular one of a series of concerts performed annually at the Royal Albert Hall in London.
--Examples--
‘she took a shortcut along the prom’
‘he asked me to the school prom but I turned him down’
‘a prom queen’
‘the last night of the Proms’

pronate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Turn or hold (a hand, foot, or limb) so that the palm or sole is facing downwards or inwards.
Walk or run with most of the weight on the inside edge of the feet.
--Examples--
‘the patient is asked to maintain this position while the examiner attempts to pronate the foot’

pronephros 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The most anterior (or superior) and first-developing part of the nephrogenic tissue of vertebrate embryos, which is functional only in the larvae of fishes and amphibians, and persists into adult life only in hagfishes and a few teleosts.

--Word--
pronymph 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In certain holometabolous insects (e.g. sawflies): an individual in a distinct larval or prepupal stage in which larval tissue is broken down and adult tissues begin to be formed within the larval cuticle.
In hemimetabolous insects: an individual in the stage of late embryonic development immediately preceding the moult into the first nymphal instar, which in some groups (e.g. dragonflies) persists for a brief period after hatching from the egg.

--Word--
Norman 
--Type--
proper noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A city in central Oklahoma, south of Oklahoma City, home to the University of Oklahoma; population 106,957 (est. 2008).
A member of a people of mixed Frankish and Scandinavian origin who settled in Normandy from about AD 912 and became a dominant military power in western Europe and the Mediterranean in the 11th century.
Any of the Normans who conquered England in 1066, or their descendants.
A native or inhabitant of modern Normandy.
The form of French spoken by the Normans.
Relating to the Normans.
Denoting or relating to the style of Romanesque architecture used in Britain under the Normans.
Relating to modern Normandy.
--Examples--
‘the castle goes right back to the Normans’
‘born c.1080, he was presumably a Norman from Calvados’
‘the Norman invasion’
‘the 11th-century Norman crypt of Winchester Cathedral’
‘Willy rambled on about Norman archways and Perpendicular naves’
‘Norman ore was to have been smelted there with Ruhr coal’

pronotum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The dorsal sclerite or tergum of the prothorax of an insect, which in certain groups such as coleopterans (beetles) and orthopterans (crickets, etc.) forms a protective shield over the thorax.

--Word--
proof 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Evidence or argument establishing a fact or the truth of a statement.
The spoken or written evidence in a trial.
The action of establishing the truth of a statement.
A series of stages in the resolution of a mathematical or philosophical problem.
A trial impression of a page, taken from type or film and used for making corrections before final printing.
A trial photographic print made for initial selection.
Each of a number of impressions from an engraved plate, especially (in commercial printing) of a limited number before the ordinary issue is printed and before an inscription or signature is added.
A specially struck specimen coin with a polished or frosted finish.
The strength of distilled alcoholic spirits, relative to proof spirit taken as a standard of 100.
A test or trial of something.
A trial or a civil case before a judge without a jury.
Able to withstand something damaging; resistant.
Denoting a trial impression of a page or printed work.
Make (fabric) waterproof.
Make a proof of (a printed work, engraving, etc.)
Proofread (a text)
Activate (yeast) by the addition of liquid.
Knead (dough) until light and smooth.
(of dough) prove.
--Examples--
‘you will be asked to give proof of your identity’
‘this is not a proof for the existence of God’
‘spatial dimensions whose very existence is beyond all hope of proof’
‘powerful 132-proof rum’
‘the marine battle armour was proof against most weapons’
‘the system comes with idiot-proof instructions’
‘a proof copy is sent up for checking’
‘if you are using a piece of lightweight canvas it will be necessary to proof the fabric when complete’
‘proof each plate and print it on acetate first’
‘William proofed much of her work’
‘proof the yeast with the teaspoon of sugar’
‘shape into a baguette and let proof for a few minutes’
--Word--
correct 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Free from error; in accordance with fact or truth.
Not mistaken in one's opinion or judgement; right.
Meeting the requirements of or most appropriate for a particular situation or activity.
(of a person or their appearance or behaviour) conforming to accepted social standards; proper.
Conforming to a particular political or ideological orthodoxy.
Put right (an error or fault)
Mark the errors in (a written or printed text)
Tell (someone) that they are mistaken.
Counteract or rectify.
Adjust (an instrument) to function accurately or accord with a standard.
Adjust (a numerical result or reading) to allow for departure from standard conditions.
--Examples--
‘make sure you have been given the correct information’
‘the government was correct to follow a course of defeating inflation’
‘cut the top and bottom tracks to the correct length with a hacksaw’
‘he was a polite man, invariably correct and pleasant with Mrs Collins’
‘the materials used are as environmentally correct as possible’
‘the Council issued a statement correcting some points in the press reports’
‘he corrected Dixon's writing for publication’
‘he had assumed she was married and she had not corrected him’
‘the steel industry's current overcapacity will be corrected this year’
‘motorists can have their headlights tested and corrected at a reduced price on Saturday’
‘data were corrected for radionuclide decay’

A trial photographic print made for initial selection.
Each of a number of impressions from an engraved plate, especially (in commercial printing) of a limited number before the ordinary issue is printed and before an inscription or signature is added.
A specially struck specimen coin with a polished or frosted finish.
The strength of distilled alcoholic spirits, relative to proof spirit taken as a standard of 100.
A test or trial of something.
A trial or a civil case before a judge without a jury.
Able to withstand something damaging; resistant.
Denoting a trial impression of a page or printed work.
Make (fabric) waterproof.
Make a proof of (a printed work, engraving, etc.)
Proofread (a text)
Activate (yeast) by the addition of liquid.
Knead (dough) until light and smooth.
(of dough) prove.
--Examples--
‘you will be asked to give proof of your identity’
‘this is not a proof for the existence of God’
‘spatial dimensions whose very existence is beyond all hope of proof’
‘powerful 132-proof rum’
‘the marine battle armour was proof against most weapons’
‘the system comes with idiot-proof instructions’
‘a proof copy is sent up for checking’
‘if you are using a piece of lightweight canvas it will be necessary to proof the fabric when complete’
‘proof each plate and print it on acetate first’
‘William proofed much of her work’
‘proof the yeast with the teaspoon of sugar’
‘shape into a baguette and let proof for a few minutes’
--Word--
proofread 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Read (printer's proofs or other written or printed material) and mark any errors.
--Examples--
‘they must revise and proofread their work’
‘typesetting from the writer's keystrokes reduces the need for proofreading’

A test or trial of something.

Able to withstand something damaging; resistant.

Make (fabric) waterproof.
Make a proof of (a printed work, engraving, etc.)
Proofread (a text)
Activate (yeast) by the addition of liquid.
Knead (dough) until light and smooth.
(of dough) prove.

--Word--
proof spirit 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mixture of alcohol and water containing (in the UK) 57.1 per cent alcohol by volume or (in the US) 50 per cent alcohol by volume, used as a standard of strength of distilled alcoholic spirits.

oriental 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, from, or characteristic of Asia, especially East Asia.
Relating to or denoting a zoogeographical region comprising Asia south of the Himalayas and Indonesia west of Wallace's line. Distinctive animals include pandas, gibbons, tree shrews, tarsiers, and moonrats.
(of a pearl or other jewel) orient.
A person of East Asian descent.

--Word--
prop 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A pole or beam used as a temporary support or to keep something in position.
A person or thing that is a major source of support or assistance.
A word used to fill a syntactic role without any specific meaning of its own, for example it in it is raining.
A forward at either end of the front row of a scrum.
A sudden stop made by a horse moving at speed.
Support or keep in position.
Lean (something) against something else.
Use an object to keep (something) in position.
(of a horse) come to a dead stop with the forelegs rigid.
--Examples--
‘he looked around for a prop to pin the door open’
‘he found himself becoming the emotional prop of the marriage’
‘she propped her chin in the palm of her right hand’
‘a jug of milk with a note propped against it’
‘she propped the picture up on the mantlepiece’
‘he found that the door was propped open’

--Word--
propagate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Breed specimens of (a plant or animal) by natural processes from the parent stock.
(of a plant or animal) reproduce by natural processes.
Spread and promote (an idea, theory, etc.) widely.
(with reference to motion, light, sound, etc.) transmit or be transmitted in a particular direction or through a medium.
--Examples--
‘try propagating your own houseplants from cuttings’
‘the plant propagates freely from stem cuttings’
‘the French propagated the idea that the English were drunkards’
‘electromagnetic effects can be propagated at a finite velocity only through material substances’
‘a hydraulic fracture is generally expected to propagate in a vertical plane’

noun

propatagium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In bats, gliding mammals, pterosaurs, etc.: the part of the patagium (the wing or gliding membrane) anterior to the forelimb. In birds: the fold of skin running between the shoulder and the front edge of the wing.

propellant 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A substance that propels something.
An inert fluid, liquefied under pressure, in which the active contents of an aerosol are dispersed.
An explosive that fires bullets from a firearm.
A substance used as a reagent in a rocket engine to provide thrust.
Capable of propelling something.
--Examples--
‘the main uses of CFCs are in aerosols as propellants’
‘aerosols are wastefully packaged, because they contain a lot of propellant as well as the product’
‘the common gun propellants are either nitrocellulose or a mixture of nitrocellulose and nitroglycerine’
‘the company produced all sizes of propellant for weapons’
‘rocket propellants’
‘propellant gases’

verb
--Meanings--
Drive or push something forwards.
Spur or drive into a particular situation.
--Examples--
‘the boat is propelled by using a very long paddle’
‘a rocket-propelled grenade launcher’
‘fear propelled her out of her stillness’
--Word--
propeller 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mechanical device for propelling a boat or aircraft, consisting of a revolving shaft with two or more broad, angled blades attached to it.
--Examples--
--Word--
propelment 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of propelling; propulsion. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
propel 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Drive or push something forwards.
Spur or drive into a particular situation.
--Examples--
‘the boat is propelled by using a very long paddle’
‘a rocket-propelled grenade launcher’
‘fear propelled her out of her stillness’

propense 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That has an inclination to or towards a particular action, habit, quality, etc.; that has a propensity to do something; disposed, inclined. Now rare.

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--

‘their innate propensity to attack one another’
--Word--
propensity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An inclination or natural tendency to behave in a particular way.
--Examples--
‘his propensity for violence’
‘their innate propensity to attack one another’
--Word--
propensitude 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Inclination, tendency, or propensity to or towards a person or thing. Compare "propensity". archaic and humorous in later use. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
proper 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
Denoting something that is truly what it is said or regarded to be; genuine.
Strictly so called; in its true form.
Used as an intensifier, especially in derogatory contexts.
Of the required or correct type or form; suitable or appropriate.
According to or respecting social standards or conventions; respectable, especially excessively so.
Belonging or relating exclusively or distinctively to; particular to.
(of a psalm, lesson, prayer, etc.) appointed for a particular day, occasion, or season.
Belonging to oneself or itself; own.
In the natural colours.
(of a person) good-looking.
Denoting a subset or subgroup that does not constitute the entire set or group, especially one that has more than one element.
Satisfactorily or correctly.
Thoroughly.
The part of a church service that varies with the season or feast.
--Examples--
‘she's never had a proper job’
‘a proper meal’
‘after this event, three countries will progress to the World Cup proper’
‘a proper little do-gooder, aren't I?’
‘an artist needs the proper tools’
‘they had not followed the proper procedures’
‘her parents' view of what was proper for a well-bred girl’
‘a very prim and proper Swiss lady’
‘the two elephant types proper to Africa and to southern Asia’
‘to judge with my proper eyes’
‘he is a proper youth!’
‘my eyes were all blurry and I couldn't see proper’
‘he blotted his copybook good and proper’
‘we go to the High Mass, with plainsong propers sung by the Ritual Choir’
--Word--
properdin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A protein present in the blood, involved in the body's response to certain kinds of infection.

--Examples--
--Word--
properly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Correctly or satisfactorily.
Appropriately for the circumstances; suitably or respectably.
In the strict sense; exactly.
Thoroughly; completely.
--Examples--
‘ensuring the work is carried out properly’
‘a properly drafted agreement’
‘I'm trying to get my mother to behave properly’
‘algebra is, properly speaking, the analysis of equations’
‘on the first day she felt properly well, Millie sat out on the front steps’

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
proper 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
Denoting something that is truly what it is said or regarded to be; genuine.
Strictly so called; in its true form.
Used as an intensifier, especially in derogatory contexts.
Of the required or correct type or form; suitable or appropriate.
According to or respecting social standards or conventions; respectable, especially excessively so.
Belonging or relating exclusively or distinctively to; particular to.
(of a psalm, lesson, prayer, etc.) appointed for a particular day, occasion, or season.
Belonging to oneself or itself; own.
In the natural colours.
(of a person) good-looking.
Denoting a subset or subgroup that does not constitute the entire set or group, especially one that has more than one element.
Satisfactorily or correctly.
Thoroughly.
The part of a church service that varies with the season or feast.
--Examples--
‘she's never had a proper job’
‘a proper meal’
‘after this event, three countries will progress to the World Cup proper’
‘a proper little do-gooder, aren't I?’
‘an artist needs the proper tools’
‘they had not followed the proper procedures’
‘her parents' view of what was proper for a well-bred girl’
‘a very prim and proper Swiss lady’
‘the two elephant types proper to Africa and to southern Asia’
‘to judge with my proper eyes’
‘he is a proper youth!’
‘my eyes were all blurry and I couldn't see proper’
‘he blotted his copybook good and proper’
‘we go to the High Mass, with plainsong propers sung by the Ritual Choir’
--Word--
Persian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of ancient or modern Persia (or Iran), or a person of Persian descent.
A long-haired domestic cat of a breed originating in Persia, having a broad round head, stocky body, and short thick legs.
A sheep of a breed common in South Africa.
The modern Persian language, a member of the Iranian branch of the Indo-European family written in Arabic script.
An earlier form of Persian spoken in ancient or medieval Persia.
Relating to ancient Persia or modern Iran or its people or language.
--Examples--
--Word--
property 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A thing or things belonging to someone; possessions collectively.
A building or buildings and the land belonging to it or them.
Shares or investments in property.
The right to the possession, use, or disposal of something; ownership.
An attribute, quality, or characteristic of something.
--Examples--
‘she wanted Oliver and his property out of her flat’
‘the stolen property was not recovered’
‘he's expanding now, buying property’
‘the renovation of council properties’
‘properties ran into profit-taking, with Haslemere 176p’
‘rights of property’
‘the property of heat to expand metal at uniform rates’

propertied 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a person or group) owning property and land, especially in large amounts.
--Examples--
‘a propertied country gentleman’

propertyless 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Especially of a person, or a group or class of people: devoid of property; having no property. Also occasionally as noun (with the): propertyless people as a class.

--Word--
Propertius, Sextus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.50–c.16 BC), Roman poet. His four books of elegies are largely concerned with his love affair with a woman whom he called Cynthia.
--Examples--

--Word--
prophage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The genetic material of a bacteriophage, incorporated into the genome of a bacterium and able to produce phages if specifically activated.
--Examples--
--Word--
prophage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The genetic material of a bacteriophage, incorporated into the genome of a bacterium and able to produce phages if specifically activated.
--Examples--
--Word--
prophase 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The first stage of cell division, before metaphase, during which the chromosomes become visible as paired chromatids and the nuclear envelope disappears. The first prophase of meiosis includes the reduction division.
--Examples--
--Word--
prophase 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The first stage of cell division, before metaphase, during which the chromosomes become visible as paired chromatids and the nuclear envelope disappears. The first prophase of meiosis includes the reduction division.

--Word--
prophet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person regarded as an inspired teacher or proclaimer of the will of God.
(among Muslims) Muhammad.
(among Mormons) Joseph Smith or one of his successors.
A person who advocates or speaks in a visionary way about a new cause or theory.
A person who predicts what will happen in the future.
(in Christian use) the books of Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel, Daniel, and the twelve minor prophets.
(in Jewish use) one of the three canonical divisions of the Hebrew Bible, distinguished from the Law and the Hagiographa, and comprising the books of Joshua, Judges, Samuel, Kings, Jeremiah, Ezekiel, Isaiah, and the twelve minor prophets.
--Examples--
‘the Old Testament prophet, Jeremiah’
‘he is repeatedly hailed as a prophet of modernism’
‘the prime minister ignored the prophets of doom’
--Word--
bard 
--Type--
noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
A poet, traditionally one reciting epics and associated with a particular oral tradition.
Shakespeare.
The winner of a prize for Welsh verse at an Eisteddfod.
A rasher of fat bacon placed on meat or game before roasting.
Cover (meat or game) with rashers of fat bacon.
--Examples--
‘our national bard, Robert Burns’
‘he was admitted as a Bard at the National Eisteddfod’
‘the venison was barded and marinated’

--Word--
Prophet flower 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several yellow- and black-flowered plants constituting the genus Arnebia (family Boraginaceae), characterized by flowers with evanescent dark spots and including A. pulchra, native from Armenia to Iran, and A. griffithii, of Pakistan, Afghanistan, etc., both sometimes grown elsewhere for ornament.

adjective

prophyll 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The first leaf, or either of the first two leaves, on a lateral shoot, distinguishable (often smaller) in shape and form from later leaves. Compare earlier prophyllum.
= protophyllrare.

propygidium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The segment or tergite immediately in front of the pygidium in certain beetles, especially those with short elytra.

propylamine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Either of two isomeric amines that are colourless liquids with a strong ammoniacal odour; specifically (also "n-propylamine") the straight-chain isomer, CH₃CH₂CH₂NH₂.

--Type--

--Meanings--
Nearby, adjacent; = propinquitous.
--Examples--
--Word--
propinquity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state of being close to someone or something; proximity.
Close kinship.
--Examples--
‘he kept his distance as though afraid propinquity might lead him into temptation’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A colourless, liquid ketone; also called pentan-3-one,diethyl ketone.

propionibacterium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bacterium which metabolizes carbohydrate, some kinds being involved in the fermentation of dairy products and the aetiology of acne.

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Propliopithecus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An extinct ape-like primate of the genus Propliopithecus, known from early Oligocene fossil remains found in the Fayum Depression of Egypt, and dated to about 35 million years ago.
--Examples--
--Word--
propodeal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the propodeum of an insect.
--Examples--
--Word--
propodeum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The segment anterior to and partly surrounding the petiole of hymenopterans.
--Examples--
--Word--
propodial 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Designating a bone of the proximal or upper segment of the limb of a tetrapod (especially a reptile or amphibian); of or relating to the propodium of a tetrapod.
Of or relating to the propodium of a mollusc.
A propodial bone.
--Examples--
--Word--
propodite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The penultimate joint of a crustacean endopodite, borne on the carpopodite.
--Examples--
--Word--
propodium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The anterior lobe of the foot in some molluscs, especially gastropods.
A bone of the proximal or upper segment of the limb of a tetrapod (especially a reptile or amphibian), i.e. the humerus or femur; this segment of the limb.
--Examples--
--Word--
Polynesian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Polynesia, its people, or their languages.
A native or inhabitant of Polynesia, or a person of Polynesian descent.
A group of Austronesian languages spoken in Polynesia, including Maori, Hawaiian, and Samoan.
--Examples--
--Word--
propolis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A red or brown resinous substance collected by honeybees from tree buds, used by them to fill crevices and to fix and varnish honeycombs.
--Examples--
--Word--
polish 
--Type--
verb, noun, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Make the surface of (something) smooth and shiny by rubbing it.
Improve, refine, or add the finishing touches to.
A substance used to give something a smooth and shiny surface when rubbed in.
An act of rubbing something to give it a shiny surface.
Smoothness or glossiness produced by rubbing or friction.
Refinement or elegance in a person or thing.
polish something off
Quickly finish or consume something.
Relating to Poland, its inhabitants, or their language.
The Western Slavic language of Poland, spoken by more than 40 million people.
--Examples--
‘behind the bar the steward polished glasses busily’
‘he's got to polish up his French for his job’
‘a tin of shoe polish’
‘I could give the wardrobe a polish’
‘the machine refines the shape of the stone and gives it polish’
‘his poetry has clarity and polish’
‘they polished off most of the sausages’

--Examples--
--Word--
proportion 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A part, share, or number considered in comparative relation to a whole.
The relationship of one thing to another in terms of quantity, size, or number; ratio.
The comparative measurements or size of different parts of a whole.
Dimensions; size.
The correct, attractive, or ideal relationship between one thing and another or between the parts of a whole.
Adjust or regulate (something) so that it has a particular or suitable relationship to something else.
--Examples--
‘the proportion of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere is rising’
‘the proportion of examination to coursework’
‘the bleach can be diluted with water in the proportion one part bleach to ten parts water’
‘the view of what constitutes perfect bodily proportions changes from one generation to the next’
‘the room, despite its ample proportions, seemed too small for him’
‘perceptions of colour, form, harmony, and proportion’
‘a life after death in which happiness can be proportioned to virtue’

--Meanings--
= proportionableness.

--Word--
proportional 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Corresponding in size or amount to something else.
(of a variable quantity) having a constant ratio to another quantity.
--Examples--
‘the punishment should be proportional to the crime’
--Word--
proportionalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An arrangement or system in which the components or constituent parts of something are dealt with in accordance with their relative proportions; proportionate treatment.
Politics. Proportional representation; the adoption or advocacy of a system of proportional representation.
Christian Church. Chiefly in Catholic theology: an ethical system that takes into consideration the context or consequences of an action when judging its morality.
--Examples--
--Word--
proportionality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of corresponding in size or amount to something else.
The fact of a variable quantity having a constant ratio to another quantity.
--Examples--
‘the requirement of proportionality of punishment to offence’
‘they try to ensure some proportionality between input and output’
‘the constant of proportionality between the two curves’
‘qualitative proportionalities’
--Word--
proportionally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that corresponds in size or amount to something else.
--Examples--
‘health problems increased proportionally to the number of hours worked’
‘the benefits paid out are proportionally greater for lower-wage workers’

--Meanings--

‘a small rise in price will cause a proportionately smaller drop in sales’

proposal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plan or suggestion, especially a formal or written one, put forward for consideration by others.
The action of proposing a plan or suggestion.
An offer of marriage.
--Examples--

‘the proposal of a flexible school-leaving age’
‘surely a woman as beautiful as you has had proposals?’

--Word--
propose 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Put forward (a plan or suggestion) for consideration by others.
Nominate (someone) for an elected office or as a member of a society.
Put forward (a motion) to a legislature or committee.
Intend to do something.
Make an offer of marriage to someone.
--Examples--
‘he proposed a new nine-point peace plan’
‘I proposed that the government should retain a 51 per cent stake in the company’
‘Roy Thomson was proposed as chairman’
‘the government put its slim majority to the test by proposing a vote of confidence’
‘he proposed to attend the meeting’
‘I have already proposed to Sarah’
‘one girl proposed marriage to him on the spot’

--Word--
proposition 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A statement or assertion that expresses a judgement or opinion.
A statement that expresses a concept that can be true or false.
A formal statement of a theorem or problem, typically including the demonstration.
A suggested scheme or plan of action, especially in a business context.
A constitutional proposal; a bill.
An offer of sexual intercourse made to a person with whom one is not involved, especially one that is made in an unsubtle way.
A project, task, idea, etc. considered in terms of its likely success or difficulty.
Make a suggestion of sexual intercourse to (someone), especially in an unsubtle way.
Make an offer or suggestion to.
--Examples--
‘the proposition that high taxation is undesirable’
‘a detailed investment proposition’
‘Californian voters rejected by a two-to-one majority proposition 128’
‘needless to say, she refused his frank sexual proposition’
‘setting up your own business can seem an attractive proposition’
‘she had been propositioned at the party by a subeditor with bad breath’
‘I was propositioned by the editor about becoming film critic of the paper’
--Word--
propositional 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to, consisting of, or based on propositions.
--Examples--
‘the propositional content of our thoughts’
--Word--
propositionally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In the form or capacity of a proposition; in terms of propositions.
--Examples--

--Word--
propositus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person from whom a line of descent is derived; an individual from whom family relationships are calculated or on whom a genealogy or pedigree is based.
Law. The person whose entitlement, status, etc., is the subject of a given legal process; especially the testator or other person the devolution of whose property has to be determined.
Medicine. The first member of a family to be diagnosed with a hereditary disease or trait; the individual with whom the investigation of a family for an inherited disorder or trait begins.
--Examples--
--Word--
propound 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Put forward (an idea or theory) for consideration by others.
--Examples--
‘he began to propound the idea of a ‘social monarchy’ as an alternative to Franco’

A pole or beam used as a temporary support or to keep something in position.
A person or thing that is a major source of support or assistance.
A word used to fill a syntactic role without any specific meaning of its own, for example it in it is raining.
A forward at either end of the front row of a scrum.
A sudden stop made by a horse moving at speed.
Support or keep in position.
Lean (something) against something else.
Use an object to keep (something) in position.
(of a horse) come to a dead stop with the forelegs rigid.
--Examples--
‘he looked around for a prop to pin the door open’
‘he found himself becoming the emotional prop of the marriage’
‘she propped her chin in the palm of her right hand’
‘a jug of milk with a note propped against it’
‘she propped the picture up on the mantlepiece’
‘he found that the door was propped open’
--Word--
propper 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who or thing which props something or someone.
--Examples--

--Word--
propterygium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The anterior of three principal cartilages which primitively comprise the base of each pectoral and pelvic fin in cartilaginous fishes (though in later forms often modified or absent, especially in the pelvic fin). Also: the corresponding structure in embryonic (and certain primitive adult) bony fishes.

--Word--
Quaker 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of the Religious Society of Friends, a Christian movement founded by George Fox c.1650 and devoted to peaceful principles. Central to the Quakers' belief is the doctrine of the ‘Inner Light’, or sense of Christ's direct working in the soul. This has led them to reject both formal ministry and all set forms of worship.
--Examples--
‘a Quaker burial ground’

prorogate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Chiefly Law. To prolong, lengthen; to extend in time or duration; to cause to last longer; to continue, to protract. Compare "prorogue". Now rare.
Law. To extend (the jurisdiction of a court or judge) to a cause which is not properly or usually within the competence of the court or judge.
To defer, postpone; = "prorogue". Now rare.
To discontinue (a regular meeting, assembly, parliament, etc.).
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--

‘politically motivated prorogations’

Denouncing or condemning something.
--Examples--
‘a proscriptive and draconian policy’
‘proscriptive rebukes’

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
prosecute 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Institute or conduct legal proceedings against (a person or organization)
Institute legal proceedings in respect of (a claim or offence)
Continue with (a course of action) with a view to its completion.
Carry on (a trade or pursuit)
--Examples--
‘they were prosecuted for obstructing the highway’
‘the company didn't prosecute because of his age’
‘the state's attorney's office seemed to decide that this was a case worth prosecuting’
‘a serious threat to the government's ability to prosecute the war’
‘I am waiting for permission to prosecute my craft’

--Word--
prosecution 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The institution and conducting of legal proceedings against someone in respect of a criminal charge.
The party instituting or conducting legal proceedings against someone in a lawsuit.
The continuation of a course of action with a view to its completion.
--Examples--
‘the organizers are facing prosecution for noise nuisance’
‘they lacked the funds to embark on private prosecutions’
‘the main witness for the prosecution’
‘the BBC's prosecution of its commercial ends’

--Word--
Slavic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the branch of the Indo-European language family that includes Russian, Ukrainian, and Belorussian (Eastern Slavic), Polish, Czech, Slovak, and Sorbian (Western Slavic), and Bulgarian, Serbian, Croatian, Macedonian, and Slovene (Southern Slavic).
Relating to or denoting the peoples of central and eastern Europe who speak any of these languages.
The Slavic languages collectively.
--Examples--
--Word--
Slavonic 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
prosneusis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In Ptolemy's third lunar model: the angle between the true apogee of an epicycle (as used in the second lunar model) and a point on the epicycle designated the mean apogee (introduced by Ptolemy in order to correct a discrepancy observed at the octants). historical.
The angle between the ecliptic and the great circle joining the centres of the moon and of the earth's shadow in a lunar eclipse, which indicates the position of the part of the moon that is first eclipsed. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
proso 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In full "proso millet". A kind of millet, Panicum miliaceum (family Poaceae (Gramineae)), thought to be of central Asian origin and grown as a cereal and forage crop in Asia and North America.
--Examples--
--Word--
prosobranch 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Prosobranchia 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A group of molluscs which includes the limpets, abalones, and many terrestrial and aquatic snails. They all have a shell, and many have an operculum.

prosody 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The patterns of rhythm and sound used in poetry.
The theory or study of prosody.
The patterns of stress and intonation in a language.
--Examples--
‘the translator is not obliged to reproduce the prosody of the original’
‘a general theory of prosody’
‘the salience of prosody in child language acquisition’
‘early English prosodies’
--Word--
prosodiac 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A form of ancient Greek verse, used especially in processional hymns, consisting of three anapaests, for the first of which a spondee or iambus may be substituted.
Of a hymn: used as a prosodion; processional. Also (of verse): having the form of or constituting a prosodiac.
--Examples--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
= prosomal.
--Examples--
--Word--
prosonomasia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Punning or playing on words.
--Examples--
--Word--
prosopalgia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Neuralgia affecting the face; specifically trigeminal neuralgia.
--Examples--
--Word--
prosopyle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In sponges (other than those having a simple asconoid structure): a minute pore by which water passes from an incurrent canal into a radial canal or flagellated chamber (in which choanocytes trap food particles).
--Examples--
--Word--
Prosopis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of mostly spiny or prickly trees and shrubs of the family Fabaceae (Leguminosae), native to warm arid regions of America, Asia, and Africa, and bearing spikes of small green or yellow flowers and usually fleshy pods; (in form prosopis) a tree or shrub of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
prosopite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fluoride mineral usually occurring as minute, tabular crystals of a colourless, white, or greyish colour, often altered into pseudomorphs such as fluorite, apatite, and kaolin.
--Examples--
--Word--
prosopography 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A description of a person's appearance, personality, career, etc., or a collection of such descriptions.
The study of prosopographies, especially as an aspect of the study of Roman history.
--Examples--
‘Genet's prosopography of the members of the University of Paris in the Middle Ages’
--Word--
prosopographical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
prosopon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Theology. Any one of the three Persons of the Trinity, especially regarded in terms of outward appearance or manifestation.
--Examples--
--Word--
prosopopoeia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A figure of speech in which an abstract thing is personified.
A figure of speech in which an imagined, absent, or dead person or thing is represented as speaking.
--Examples--
--Word--
prosopopoeial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
= prosopopoeic.
--Examples--
--Word--
proso 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In full "proso millet". A kind of millet, Panicum miliaceum (family Poaceae (Gramineae)), thought to be of central Asian origin and grown as a cereal and forage crop in Asia and North America.
--Examples--
--Word--
pro- 
--Type--
prefix, prefix
--Meanings--
Favouring; supporting.
Acting as a substitute or deputy for.
Denoting motion forwards, out, or away.
Before in time, place, order, etc.
--Examples--
‘pro-choice’
‘proconsul’
‘proceed’
‘propel’
‘prostrate’
‘proactive’
‘prothalamium’
--Word--
southern 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Situated in the south or directed towards or facing the south.
(of a wind) blowing from the south.
Living in or originating from the south.
Relating to or characteristic of the south or its inhabitants.
--Examples--
‘the southern hemisphere’
‘the warm southern wind’
‘the southern rural poor’
‘a faintly southern accent’
--Word--
soviet 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An elected local, district, or national council in the former Soviet Union.
A revolutionary council of workers or peasants in Russia before 1917.
A citizen of the former Soviet Union.
Of or concerning the former Soviet Union.
--Examples--
‘the Soviet leader’
--Word--
Spain 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A country in south-western Europe, occupying the greater part of the Iberian peninsula; population 46,100,000 (estimated 2015); languages, Spanish (official), Catalan; capital, Madrid.
--Examples--
--Word--
Spanish 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Spain, its people, or its language.
The people of Spain.
A Romance language spoken in Spain and in much of Central and South America (except Brazil) and several other countries. It is the second most widely spoken first language in the world, with more than 400 millon speakers.
--Examples--
--Word--
spartan 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Showing or characterized by austerity or a lack of comfort or luxury.
A citizen of Sparta.
Relating to Sparta in ancient Greece.
A Canadian dessert apple of a variety with crisp white flesh and maroon-flushed yellow skin.
--Examples--
‘the accommodation was fairly spartan’
--Word--
prospect 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The possibility or likelihood of some future event occurring.
A mental picture of a future or anticipated event.
Chances or opportunities for success or wealth.
A person regarded as likely to succeed or as a potential customer, client, etc.
A place likely to yield mineral deposits.
An extensive view of landscape.
Search for mineral deposits, especially by drilling and excavation.
Search for; seek.
--Examples--
‘there was no prospect of a reconciliation’
‘some training which offered a prospect of continuous employment’
‘this presents a disturbing prospect of one-party government’
‘the poor prospects for the steel industry’
‘Norwich's unbeaten heavyweight prospect’
‘clients deemed likely prospects for active party membership’
‘additional exploration prospects have been identified in this area’
‘a viewpoint commanding a magnificent prospect of the estuary’
‘the company is also prospecting for gold’
‘many charities are prospecting for new donors’

prospective 
--Type--
adjective

--Word--
prospective glass 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A magic glass, mirror, or crystal in which it is supposed that distant or future events can be seen. Also figurative. Now historical.
A telescope or pair of binoculars. In plural: spectacles or binoculars. Compare "perspective". Now historical.

noun
--Meanings--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

prosthesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An artificial body part, such as a limb, a heart, or a breast implant.
The addition of a letter or syllable at the beginning of a word, as in Spanish escuela derived from Latin scola.
--Examples--
‘his upper jaw was removed and a prosthesis was fitted’
--Word--
prosthesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An artificial body part, such as a limb, a heart, or a breast implant.
The addition of a letter or syllable at the beginning of a word, as in Spanish escuela derived from Latin scola.
--Examples--
‘his upper jaw was removed and a prosthesis was fitted’
--Word--
prosthetic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Denoting an artificial body part, such as a limb, a heart, or a breast implant.
Denoting a material designed to alter a person's physical appearance temporarily.
Denoting a letter or syllable added at the beginning of a word, as in Spanish escuela derived from Latin scola.
An artificial body part; a prosthesis.
The branch of surgery concerned with the making and fitting of artificial body parts.
An artificial feature or piece of flexible material applied to a person's face or body to change their appearance temporarily.
--Examples--
‘she has learnt to walk again using prosthetic legs’
‘an actor transformed by layers of prosthetic make-up’
‘three charities working there make prosthetics and help amputees to walk’
‘he plays all the parts, using various wigs and prosthetics’
‘my prosthetic was made by a special effects makeup artist for The Walking Dead’
--Word--
prosthetically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--

prosthetic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--

Denoting a letter or syllable added at the beginning of a word, as in Spanish escuela derived from Latin scola.

--Examples--

prostitute 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A person, in particular a woman, who engages in sexual activity for payment.
A person who misuses their talents or behaves unworthily for personal or financial gain.
Offer (someone) for sexual activity in exchange for payment.
Put (oneself or one's talents) to an unworthy or corrupt use for personal or financial gain.
--Examples--
‘careerist political prostitutes’
‘although she was paid £15 to join a man at his table, she never prostituted herself’
‘his willingness to prostitute himself to the worst instincts of the electorate’

--Word--
prostomial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Anterior to the mouth; especially of or relating to the prostomium of an invertebrate.
--Examples--
--Word--
prostomium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In various invertebrates: a part of the body situated in front of or anterior to the mouth; especially (in annelid worms) the lobe or region anterior to the mouth (and to the first metameric segment), which in polychaetes contains the brain and bears eyes and sensory appendages.
--Examples--
--Word--
prostrate 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Lying stretched out on the ground with one's face downwards.
Completely overcome or helpless, especially with distress or exhaustion.
Growing along the ground.
Throw oneself flat on the ground so as to be lying face downwards, especially in reverence or submission.
Reduce (someone) to extreme physical weakness.
--Examples--
‘there was a man praying before an idol, lying prostrate’
‘they surged forward around the prostrate figure on the ground’
‘his wife was prostrate with shock’
‘mats of prostrate herbs can be used to break up expanses of soil’
‘she prostrated herself on the bare floor of the church’
‘she was so prostrated by migraine that she could scarcely totter up the stairs to bed’

--Word--
prostration 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of lying stretched out on the ground.
The state of being extremely weak or subservient.
Extreme physical weakness or emotional exhaustion.
--Examples--
‘the refusal to call a strike reflects the union leadership's prostration before the company’

--Word--
prostrator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who prostrates, especially as part of a religious observance; (in the early Orthodox Church) specifically a person belonging to the third order of penitents, permitted to attend services in a kneeling or prostrate position. Compare "kneeler", "prostrate". Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
prostrator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who prostrates, especially as part of a religious observance; (in the early Orthodox Church) specifically a person belonging to the third order of penitents, permitted to attend services in a kneeling or prostrate position. Compare "kneeler", "prostrate". Now rare.

--Word--
strike 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Hit forcibly and deliberately with one's hand or a weapon or other implement.
Inflict (a blow)
Accidentally hit (a part of one's body) against something.
Come into forcible contact or collision with.
(of a beam or ray of light or heat) fall on (an object or surface)
(in sporting contexts) hit or kick (a ball)
Produce (a musical note) by pressing or hitting a key.
(of a disaster, disease, or other unwelcome phenomenon) occur suddenly and have harmful or damaging effects on.
Carry out an aggressive or violent action, typically without warning.
Kill or seriously incapacitate (someone)
Cause or create a particular strong emotion in (someone)
Cause (someone) to be in a specified state.
(of a thought or idea) come into the mind of (someone) suddenly or unexpectedly.
Cause (someone) to have a particular impression.
Find particularly interesting, noticeable, or impressive.
Be deeply fond of or infatuated with.
(of a clock) indicate the time by sounding a chime or stroke.
(of time) be indicated by a clock sounding a chime or stroke.
Ignite (a match) by rubbing it briskly against an abrasive surface.
Produce (fire or a spark) as a result of friction.
Bring (an electric arc) into being.
(of employees) refuse to work as a form of organized protest, typically in an attempt to obtain a particular concession or concessions from their employer.
Undertake strike action against (an employer)
Cancel, remove, or cross out with or as if with a pen.
Officially remove someone from membership of a professional group.
Abolish a law or regulation.
Make (a coin or medal) by stamping metal.
(in cinematography) make (another print) of a film.
Reach, achieve, or agree to (something involving agreement, balance, or compromise)
(in financial contexts) reach (a figure) by balancing an account.
Form (a committee)
Discover (gold, minerals, or oil) by drilling or mining.
Come to or reach.
Discover or think of, especially unexpectedly or by chance.
Move or proceed vigorously or purposefully.
Start out on a new or independent course or endeavour.
Take down (a tent or the tents of an encampment)
Dismantle (theatrical scenery)
Lower or take down (a flag or sail), especially as a salute or to signify surrender.
Insert (a cutting of a plant) in soil to take root.
(of a plant or cutting) develop roots.
(of a young oyster) attach itself to a bed.
Secure a hook in the mouth of a fish by jerking or tightening the line after it has taken the bait or fly.
A refusal to work organized by a body of employees as a form of protest, typically in an attempt to gain a concession or concessions from their employer.
An organized refusal to do something expected or required, with a similar aim.
A sudden attack, typically a military one.
(in sporting contexts) an act of hitting or kicking a ball.
(in tenpin bowling) an act of knocking down all the pins with one's first ball.
An act or instance of jerking or tightening the line to secure a fish that has already taken the bait or fly.
A discovery of gold, minerals, or oil by drilling or mining.
A batter's unsuccessful attempt to hit a pitched ball.
A pitch that passes through the strike zone.
Something to one's discredit.
The horizontal or compass direction of a stratum, fault, or other geological feature.

--Word--
protanomaly 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A form of defective colour vision in which perception of light at the red end of the spectrum is reduced, resulting in a form of anomalous trichromatism that requires an excess of red in colour matching; partial protanopia.
--Examples--
--Word--
protanomalous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Affected by protanomaly; of, relating to, or of the nature of protanomaly. Also as noun (with the): people with protanomaly collectively (rare).
--Examples--
--Word--
protanope 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person suffering from protanopia.
--Examples--
--Word--
protanopia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Colour blindness resulting from insensitivity to red light, causing confusion of greens, reds, and yellows. It is hereditary, and is the commonest form of colour blindness.
--Examples--
--Word--
protanopic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Affected by protanopia; of or relating to protanopia.
--Examples--
--Word--
protargol 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A colloidal combination of protein and silver salts, used originally as an antiseptic and later chiefly as a stain for light and electron microscopy.

--Word--
protect 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Keep safe from harm or injury.
Aim to preserve (a threatened species or area) by legislating against collecting, hunting, or development.
(of an insurance policy) promise to pay (someone) an agreed amount in the event of loss, injury, fire, theft, or other misfortune.
Shield (a domestic industry) from competition by imposing import duties on foreign goods.
Restrict access to or use of (data or a memory location)
--Examples--
‘he tried to protect Kelly from the attack’
‘use a sunscreen that protects against both UVA and UVB’
‘the natterjack toad is a protected species’
‘logging is continuing in protected areas in violation of an international agreement’
‘in the event of your death, your family will be protected against any financial problems that may arise’
‘Japan's Ministry of Trade & Industry erected barriers to protect the country's infant computer industry’
‘security products are designed to protect information from unauthorized access’

--Word--
protection 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of protecting, or the state of being protected.
A person or thing that protects someone or something.
A legal or other formal measure intended to preserve civil liberties and rights.
A document guaranteeing immunity from harm to the person specified in it.
The practice of paying money to criminals so as to prevent them from attacking oneself or one's property.
Protection money paid to criminals, especially on a regular basis.
The number and quality of running belays or other equipment employed to safeguard a pitch.
Used euphemistically to refer to the keeping of a mistress by her lover in a separate establishment.
--Examples--
‘the B vitamins give protection against infection’
‘his son was put under police protection’
‘the castle was built as protection against the Saxons’
‘a protection against the evil eye’
‘most Western countries provide constitutional protections for the civil and political rights of their citizens’
‘a protection racket’
‘protection money’
‘most European climbers drill bolts into rock rather than using removable protection’
‘she was living under his lordship's protection at Gloucester Gate’

protégé 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--

--Word--
protégé 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who is guided and supported by an older and more experienced or influential person.
--Examples--
‘Ruskin submitted his protégé's name for election’
--Word--
protegulum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In brachiopods: the initial or embryonic form of the shell, or of each valve of the shell.
--Examples--
--Word--
proteic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the nature of or consisting of protein; proteinaceous.
--Examples--
--Word--
proteid 
--Type--
noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A proteinaceous substance, a protein. Also: a protein combined with a sugar, phosphate, metal, or other atom or group.
A salamander of the family Proteidae, which comprises the olm of Europe (Proteus anguinus) and the mud puppy and waterdogs of North America (genus Necturus).
Belonging to or characteristic of the family Proteidae.
--Examples--
--Word--
proteid 
--Type--
noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A proteinaceous substance, a protein. Also: a protein combined with a sugar, phosphate, metal, or other atom or group.
A salamander of the family Proteidae, which comprises the olm of Europe (Proteus anguinus) and the mud puppy and waterdogs of North America (genus Necturus).
Belonging to or characteristic of the family Proteidae.

proteiform 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Changeable in form, assuming many forms; protean, multiform; extremely variable or various.
--Examples--
--Word--
protein 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a class of nitrogenous organic compounds which have large molecules composed of one or more long chains of amino acids and are an essential part of all living organisms, especially as structural components of body tissues such as muscle, hair, etc., and as enzymes and antibodies.
Proteins collectively, especially as a dietary component.
--Examples--
‘a protein found in wheat’
‘animal proteins’
‘a diet high in protein’
--Word--
proteinaceous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Consisting of or containing protein.
--Examples--
‘cysts containing proteinaceous fluid’
--Word--
proteinase 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
‘the genetic study of pancreatic proteinase in mice’
‘proteinases play an important role in lung injury after smoke inhalation’

--Type--
noun

--Word--
protend 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To cause to project; to put forth, stretch forth; to thrust forward. Also figurative. Now rare.
Philosophy. In phenomenology: to extend (the consciousness or perception of a present act or event) into the future.

proteolipid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A complex that contains protein and lipid moieties and occurs especially in cell membranes, distinguished from lipoproteins by being soluble in some organic solvents but not in water.

--Word--
proterandrous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Botany= "protandrous".
Zoology= "protandrous". Also: designating insects in which the emergence of male individuals occurs before the females. Compare proterogynous. rare.

--Word--
proteroglyphous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating or characteristic of a venomous snake having fixed fangs in the front of the jaw with grooves or channels to conduct the venom, characteristic of snakes of the family Elapidae.
--Examples--
--Word--
Proterozoic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the aeon that constitutes the later part of the Precambrian, between the Archaean aeon and the Cambrian period, in which the earliest forms of life evolved.
The Proterozoic aeon or the system of rocks deposited during it.
--Examples--
--Word--
protervity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Waywardness, stubbornness; impudence; petulance; an instance of this. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
protest 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A statement or action expressing disapproval of or objection to something.
An organized public demonstration expressing strong objection to an official policy or course of action.
A written declaration, typically by a notary public, that a bill has been presented and payment or acceptance refused.
Express an objection to what someone has said or done.
Publicly demonstrate strong objection to an official policy or course of action.
Declare (something) firmly and emphatically in response to doubt or accusation.
Write or obtain a protest in regard to (a bill).
--Examples--
‘the British team lodged an official protest’
‘two senior scientists resigned in protest’
‘a protest over planned pit closures’
‘a protest march’
‘before Muriel could protest, he had filled both glasses’
‘doctors and patients protested against plans to cut services at the hospital’
‘the workers were protesting economic measures enacted a week earlier’
‘‘I'm not being coy!’ Lucy protested’
‘she has always protested her innocence’
--Word--
protester 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who publicly demonstrates opposition to something; a demonstrator.
--Examples--
‘the decision was hailed by protesters against the closure as a triumph’
--Word--
Protestancy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Protestantism; specifically (in the 17th cent.) the system of the reformed Church of England, as distinguished from Catholicism, Presbyterianism, and Puritanism. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
Protestant 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member or follower of any of the Western Christian Churches that are separate from the Roman Catholic Church in accordance with the principles of the Reformation, including the Baptist, Presbyterian, and Lutheran Churches.
Relating to or belonging to any of the Protestant Churches.
--Examples--
‘the Protestant religion’
‘the family were staunchly Protestant’
--Word--
Protestantish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
= Protestantical.
--Examples--
--Word--
Protestantish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
= Protestantical.
--Examples--
--Word--
Protestantism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The faith, practice, and Church order of the Protestant Churches.
Adherence to the forms of Christian doctrine which are generally regarded as Protestant rather than Catholic or Eastern Orthodox.
--Examples--
--Word--
Protestantize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make Protestant; convert to Protestantism.
--Examples--
‘an attempt to Protestantize Catholic traditions’
‘he grew up in the Protestantized England of Elizabeth I’
--Word--
Protestantizer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who Protestantizes something.

--Word--
protest 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A statement or action expressing disapproval of or objection to something.
An organized public demonstration expressing strong objection to an official policy or course of action.
A written declaration, typically by a notary public, that a bill has been presented and payment or acceptance refused.

‘a protest march’

‘the workers were protesting economic measures enacted a week earlier’

--Word--
proteus 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A bacterium found in the intestines of animals and in the soil.
A minor sea god who had the power of prophecy but would assume different shapes to avoid answering questions.
A satellite of Neptune, the sixth closest to the planet, discovered by the Voyager 2 space probe in 1989 (diameter 400 km).
--Examples--
--Word--
Teuton 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a people who lived in Jutland in the 4th century BC and fought the Romans in France in the 2nd century BC.
A German.
--Examples--
--Word--
Teutonic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the Teutons.
Displaying the characteristics popularly attributed to Germans.

The language of the Teutons.
--Examples--
‘making preparations with Teutonic thoroughness’

pan-Teutonism

noun
--Meanings--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
protheca 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An enclosing structure or sheath, or a part of one, which is primary in nature or basal in position; especially (a) (in a coral polyp) the theca in its initial or rudimentary form (rare); (b) (in a foraminiferan of the superfamily Fusulinacea) an unmodified primary wall; (c) (in a graptolite of the order Graptoloidea) the basal part of a theca, attached to the sicula.
--Examples--
--Word--
prothesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(especially in the Orthodox Church) the action of placing the Eucharistic elements on the credence table.
A credence table.
The part of a church where the credence table stands.

prothetely 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In certain insect larvae: the development of one part of the body, especially the wings, at a faster rate than that of the rest, typically as a result of abnormally high temperature or abnormal hormonal influence.

--Word--
protist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A single-celled organism of the kingdom Protista, such as a protozoan or simple alga.
--Examples--
‘protists living in the surface layers of soil’
--Word--
Protista 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A kingdom or large grouping that comprises mostly single-celled organisms such as the protozoa, simple algae and fungi, slime moulds, and (formerly) the bacteria. They are now divided among up to thirty phyla, and some have both plant and animal characteristics.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The Semitic language of the Arabs, spoken by some 150 million people throughout the Middle East and North Africa.
Relating to the literature or language of Arab people.
--Examples--
‘Arabic literature’
‘a fluent Arabic-speaker’
--Word--
proto-architect 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A chief or principal architect (now historical).
An early architect (also figurative).
--Examples--
--Word--
Aryan 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a people speaking an Indo-European language who invaded northern India in the 2nd millennium BC, displacing the Dravidian and other aboriginal peoples.
(in Nazi ideology) relating to or denoting people of Caucasian race not of Jewish descent.
A member of the ancient Aryan people.
The language of the Aryan people.
(in Nazi ideology) a person of Caucasian race not of Jewish descent.
--Examples--
‘the Aryans brought Hindu religious thought to India’
‘he looked the image of the ideal Aryan: tall, with Nordic blonde hair’
--Word--
Armenian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Armenia or to the Armenian Church.
A native of Armenia, or a person of Armenian descent.
The Indo-European language of Armenia, spoken by around 4 million people and written in a distinctive alphabet of thirty-eight letters.
--Examples--
--Word--
attic 
--Type--
noun, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
A space or room inside or partly inside the roof of a building.
Relating to ancient Athens or Attica, or the dialect of Greek spoken there.
The dialect of Greek used by the ancient Athenians. It was the chief literary form of classical Greek.
--Examples--
‘I discovered a dozen rolls of the original wallpaper in a tin trunk in the attic’
‘there are five attic bedrooms’

Australoid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the broad division of humankind represented by Australian Aboriginal peoples.

Babylonian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An inhabitant of Babylon or Babylonia.
The dialect of Akkadian spoken in ancient Babylon.
Relating to Babylon or Babylonia.
--Examples--
--Word--
Berber 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of the indigenous people of North Africa, among whom are the nomadic Tuareg.
The Afro-Asiatic language of the Berber peoples, spoken by about 11 million people. There are several different dialects; some of them, e.g. Tamashek, are regarded by some scholars as separate languages.
Relating to the Berber peoples or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
protocanonical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating those books of scripture accepted into the biblical canon at an early date with little or no debate. Opposed to deuterocanonical.
--Examples--
--Word--
protocatechuic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
"protocatechuic acid" an organic acid having a structure related to, but simpler than, that of catechuic acid (catechin).

--Word--
Celtic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the Celts or their languages, which constitute a branch of the Indo-European family and include Irish, Scottish Gaelic, Welsh, Breton, Manx, Cornish, and several extinct pre-Roman languages such as Gaulish.
The Celtic language group.
--Examples--
--Word--
protoceratops 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small quadrupedal dinosaur of the late Cretaceous period, having a bony frill above the neck and probably ancestral to triceratops.
--Examples--
--Word--
protocercal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(In fishes) of, relating to, or designating a tail of a primitive (or larval) type, in which the end of the vertebral column is straight and the caudal fin is symmetrical and often continuous with the dorsal and anal fins.
--Examples--

--Word--
protochordate 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Any of the small marine animals belonging to the phylum Hemichordata or to either of the chordate subphyla Urochordata and Cephalochordata, characterized (at some point in the life cycle) by a hollow dorsal nerve cord, a notochord, and gill slits; a hemichordate, urochordate, or cephalochordate, or a hypothetical ancestral form of any of these.
Of or designating a protochordate.
--Examples--
--Word--
protocneme 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In zoantharian coelenterates, especially sea anemones and stony corals: any of the primary mesenteries, which are usually arranged in six pairs.
--Examples--

--Word--
Protococcus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of the family Ctenocladaceae (formerly Protococcaceae) of unicellular freshwater green algae, chiefly of spherical shape; (also protococcus) an alga of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
protocol 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The official procedure or system of rules governing affairs of state or diplomatic occasions.
The accepted or established code of procedure or behaviour in any group, organization, or situation.
The original draft of a diplomatic document, especially of the terms of a treaty agreed to in conference and signed by the parties.
An amendment or addition to a treaty or convention.
A formal or official record of scientific experimental observations.
A procedure for carrying out a scientific experiment or a course of medical treatment.
A set of rules governing the exchange or transmission of data between devices.
--Examples--
‘protocol forbids the prince from making any public statement in his defence’
‘what is the protocol at a smart lunch if one's neighbour dozes off during the speeches?’
‘signatories to the Montreal Protocol’
‘Hungary and the Soviet Union signed a trade protocol’
‘a protocol to the treaty allowed for this Danish referendum’
‘protocols of published cases frequently lack this vital information’
‘a study protocol approved by the ethics committee of the hospital’
‘the low doses of morphine recommended in the protocol’
--Word--
protocolar 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or governed by protocol; formal, ceremonial.
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--
The action or fact of recording, drawing up, or negotiating a protocol.

protocolling 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or fact of recording, drawing up, or negotiating a protocol.

Doric 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a classical order of architecture characterized by a sturdy fluted column and a thick square abacus resting on a rounded moulding.
Relating to the ancient Greek dialect of the Dorians.
(of a dialect) broad; rustic.
The Doric order of architecture.
The ancient Greek dialect of the Dorians.
A broad or rustic dialect, especially the dialect spoken in the north-east of Scotland.
--Examples--
--Word--
Egyptian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Egypt or its people.
Relating to the culture or language of ancient Egypt.
A native of ancient or modern Egypt, or a person of Egyptian descent.
The Afro-Asiatic language used in ancient Egypt, attested from c.3000 BC. It is represented in its oldest stages by hieroglyphic inscriptions and in its latest form by Coptic; it has been replaced in modern use by Arabic.
--Examples--
‘an Egyptian obelisk’
--Word--
proto-Elamite

adjective, noun

Designating or relating to the earliest indigenous writing system known from Iran; designating or relating to the period during which this script was in use or the culture associated with it.

--Examples--
--Word--
Etruscan 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to ancient Etruria, its people, or their language. The Etruscan civilization was at its height c.500 BC and was an important influence on the Romans, who had subdued the Etruscans by the end of the 3rd century BC.
A native of ancient Etruria.
The language of ancient Etruria, which was written in an alphabet derived from Greek but is not related to any known language.

Greek 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Greece, its people, or their language.

--Examples--
--Word--
Hattic 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An ancient language of NW Anatolia, spoken in the 3rd millennium BC, in which a few cuneiform tablets survive, some bilingual with Hittite. It was neither an Indo-European nor a Semitic language, but it had a strong influence on the vocabulary of Hittite, which eventually displaced it.
Relating to Hattic.
--Examples--
--Word--
Hellenic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Greek.
Relating to or denoting Iron Age and Classical Greek culture (between Helladic and Hellenistic).
The branch of the Indo-European language family comprising classical and modern Greek.
The Greek language.
--Examples--
--Word--
Protohippus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of three-toed quadrupeds related to the ancestors of the modern horse, known from North American fossil remains of the late Miocene and early Pliocene epochs; (also protohippus) an animal of this genus.

protohuman 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--

‘this primitive hunter-gatherer society was certainly protohuman’

noun

--Word--
protonema 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The juvenile form of a bryophyte (usually consisting of a branched filamentous structure, but sometimes flat or platelike), developing on the germination of a spore and producing buds from which the adult plants arise.
An analogous thread-like structure in other lower plants; specifically the filamentous form of a developing gametophyte of a fern or charophytic alga.

noun
--Meanings--
A branched, blind-ended nephridium containing flame cells (as in flatworms and nemertines) or solenocytes (as in some annelids); a nephridium of this type found in the larvae of other animal groups.
