--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A water-insoluble pectic substance containing glucuronic acid monomers, which is present as a binding substance between plant cell walls, and which breaks down during the ripening of fruits and fleshy roots, giving rise to pectin.
--Examples--
--Word--
protopectinase 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A pectinase that converts protopectin to a soluble form by hydrolysis.
--Examples--
--Word--
protophyll 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In a clubmoss: a primitive leaf-like structure produced on the upper surface of the protocorm or tuber.
--Examples--
--Word--
Protophyta 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
With singular or plural concord. A class of primitive plants or plantlike organisms regarded as forming the lowest division of the vegetable kingdom (corresponding to the Protozoa in the animal kingdom), specifically one comprising unicellular and other simple green algae. Also, treated as plural (also protophyta): such plants and organisms collectively.
--Examples--
--Word--
protophyte 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An organism belonging to the class Protophyta; especially a unicellular alga.
--Examples--
--Word--
protophytic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Belonging or relating to the class Protophyta.
--Examples--
--Word--
protophloem 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The first-formed elements of the primary phloem, the cells of which mature before the elongation of the surrounding plant tissue.
--Examples--
--Word--
Phoenician 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a Semitic people inhabiting ancient Phoenicia and its colonies. The Phoenicians prospered from trade and manufacturing until the capital, Tyre, was sacked by Alexander the Great in 332 BC.
The Semitic language of the Phoenicians, written in an alphabet that was the ancestor of the Greek and Roman alphabets.
Relating to Phoenicia, its people, or its language.
--Examples--
--Word--
protopine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A white crystalline alkaloid present in many plants, especially of the families Papaveraceae and Fumariaceae.
--Examples--
--Word--
protopyramid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The primitive pyramid of a crystal system, in which the horizontal axes of the system intersect the edges of the pyramid (as opposed to one in which the axes intersect the faces midway between the edges).
--Examples--
--Word--
protoplanet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large body of matter in orbit around the sun or a star and thought to be developing into a planet.
--Examples--
‘this analysis supported the view that the moon originated from a glancing collision between the earth and another protoplanet 4,500 million years ago’

Polynesian 
--Type--

protopope 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the Orthodox and Eastern Catholic Churches: a senior priest; an archpriest.
--Examples--
--Word--
protoporphyrin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a group of fifteen isomeric porphyrins having the formula C₃₄H₃₄N₄O₄, in which the porphin nucleus has four methyl, two vinyl, and two propionic acid substituents; especially (more fully "protoporphyrin IX") the isomer which occurs widely in living organisms, mainly as haem (in which it is bonded to an iron atom).
--Examples--
--Word--
proto-presbyter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= protopapas.
--Examples--
--Word--
Protopterus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of dipnoan fishes comprising four African lungfishes, which have long, fringed, filamentous pectoral and pelvic fins and are usually placed in their own family, Protopteridae; (also †protopterus) a fish of this genus.
--Examples--

proto-rebel

noun
--Meanings--
A chief or principal rebel (now historical).
An early rebel; a person who has the potential to become a rebel.

Renaissance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The revival of European art and literature under the influence of classical models in the 14th–16th centuries.
The culture and style of art and architecture developed during the Renaissance.
A revival of or renewed interest in something.
--Examples--
‘cinema-going is enjoying something of a renaissance’

protorosaur 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An early fossil reptile of the genus Protorosaurus or the order Protorosauria (now often called Araeoscelidia).
--Examples--
--Word--
protorosaurian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating fossil reptiles of the genus Protorosaurus and their allies; specifically belonging to the order Protorosauria.
= protorosaurrare.
--Examples--
--Word--
Protorosaurus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of diapsid reptiles known from European fossils of the late Permian period, which are among the earliest known reptiles; (also protorosaurus) a reptile of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
protosalt 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A salt in which the anion occurs in the smallest possible proportion relative to the metal cation (i.e. in which the metal occurs in its lowest oxidation state).
--Examples--
--Word--
protoscientific 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to primitive science, or an early stage in the development of modern science.
--Examples--
--Word--
Semitic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a family of languages that includes Hebrew, Arabic, and Aramaic and certain ancient languages such as Phoenician and Akkadian, constituting the main subgroup of the Afro-Asiatic family.
Relating to the peoples who speak Semitic languages, especially Hebrew and Arabic.
--Examples--
--Word--
Solutrean 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting an Upper Palaeolithic culture of central and south-western France and parts of Iberia. It is dated to about 21,000–18,000 years ago, following the Aurignacian and preceding the Magdalenian.
The Solutrean culture or period.
--Examples--
--Word--
protospore 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Mycology. Originally: an early stage in fungal spore development believed to be analogous to the prothallus in ferns. In later use: specifically a uninucleate segment formed by the cleavage of a multinucleate mass of cytoplasm from which the spore or sporangium develops.
Biology. In a slime mould: a uninucleate segment of a multinucleate fruiting body from which the spore develops.
--Examples--
--Word--
protostar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A contracting mass of gas which represents an early stage in the formation of a star, before nucleosynthesis has begun.
--Examples--
--Word--
protostele 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of stele typical of primitive plants (still found in, e.g., the seedling stages of many ferns) that lacks pith and consists of a solid core of xylem surrounded by a cylinder of phloem.
--Examples--
--Word--
protostelic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to a protostele; possessing a protostele.
--Examples--
--Word--
protostome 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A multicellular organism whose mouth develops from a primary embryonic opening, such as an annelid, mollusc, or arthropod.
--Examples--
--Word--
protosulphate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sulphate in which the sulphate anion occurs in its smallest possible proportion relative to the other element (i.e. one in which the other element occurs in its lowest oxidation state).
--Examples--

--Type--

--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
prototype 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A first or preliminary version of a device or vehicle from which other forms are developed.
The first, original, or typical form of something; an archetype.
A basic filter network with specified cut-off frequencies, from which other networks may be derived to obtain sharper cut-offs, constancy of characteristic impedance with frequency, etc.
Make a prototype of (a product)
--Examples--
‘the firm is testing a prototype of the weapon’
‘these objects are the prototypes of a category of rapidly spinning neutron stars’
‘the construction of bandpass networks from low-pass prototypes’
‘Mercedes is prototyping a car sunroof which changes from clear to tinted’

prototrophic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a microorganism: able to grow in a simple artificial medium without the specific supplementary nutrition required by an auxotrophic counterpart, especially as a result of genetic reversion to the wild-type condition.

--Word--
protovertebra 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Embryology. Each of the segments of the embryonic mesoderm which subsequently develop into the vertebrae and associated muscles. Formerly also: †a myotome, regarded as having a similar role (obsolete). Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
protovestiary 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chief official in charge of a vestiary or wardrobe in a palace or other large establishment.

--Word--
protoxide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An oxide which contains the smallest possible proportion of oxygen in relation to the other element (i.e. one in which the other element occurs in its lowest oxidation state).
--Examples--
--Word--
protoxylem 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The first-formed elements of the primary xylem in a plant organ, maturing before elongation of the surrounding plant tissue is complete and therefore often subsequently distorted or destroyed by this process.
--Examples--
--Word--
Protozoa 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A phylum or grouping of phyla which comprises the single-celled microscopic animals, which include amoebas, flagellates, ciliates, sporozoans, and many other forms. They are now usually treated as a number of phyla belonging to the kingdom Protista.
Organisms of the Protozoa group.
--Examples--
--Word--
protozoal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--

protozoan

noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A single-celled microscopic animal of a group of phyla of the kingdom Protista, such as an amoeba, flagellate, ciliate, or sporozoan.
Relating to or denoting protozoans.

--Word--
Protura 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
An order of minute white wingless insects with slender bodies. They lack eyes and antennae, using the first pair of legs as sensory organs.
--Examples--

proturan 
--Type--
UnKnownKind

Turk 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Turkey, or a person of Turkish descent.

--Examples--
--Word--
turkey 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large mainly domesticated game bird native to North America, having a bald head and (in the male) red wattles. It is a popular food on festive occasions such as Christmas and (in the US) Thanksgiving.
The flesh of the turkey as food.
Something that is extremely or completely unsuccessful, especially a play or film.
A stupid or inept person.
--Examples--
‘the movie flopped—the second in a trio of turkeys’
‘I felt like such a turkey spying on his house’
--Word--
Turkish 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Turkey or to the Turks or their language.
Relating to or associated with the Ottoman Empire.
The official language of Turkey, a Turkic language spoken by about 50 million people. It was written in the Arabic script until 1928, when the Roman alphabet was adopted.
--Examples--
--Word--
pro-tutor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In Scottish law (now historical): a person who performed the duties of tutor or guardian towards a minor without having been legally appointed to do so. Also (in some civil codes): a person who oversees a tutor or guardian.
--Examples--
--Word--
proud 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Feeling deep pleasure or satisfaction as a result of one's own achievements, qualities, or possessions or those of someone with whom one is closely associated.
(of an event, achievement, etc.) causing someone to feel proud.
Having or showing a high or excessively high opinion of oneself or one's importance.
Conscious of one's own dignity.
Imposing; splendid.
Slightly projecting from a surface.
Denoting flesh that has grown round a healing wound with excessive granulation of the tissues.
--Examples--
‘a proud grandma of three boys’
‘she got nine passes and he was so proud of her’
‘we have a proud history of innovation’
‘he was a proud, arrogant man’
‘I was too proud to go home’
‘bulrushes emerge tall and proud from the middle of the pond’
‘balls standing proud of the fabric’

--Word--
Proudhon, Pierre Joseph 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1809–65), French social philosopher and journalist. His pamphlet What is Property? (1840) argues that property, in the sense of the exploitation of one person's labour by another, is theft.

--Word--
Unitarian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who asserts the unity of God and rejects the doctrine of the Trinity.
A member of a Church or religious body maintaining this belief and typically rejecting formal dogma in favour of a rationalist and inclusivist approach to belief.

--Word--
Proust, Marcel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1871–1922), French novelist, essayist, and critic. He devoted much of his life to writing his novel À la recherche du temps perdu (published in seven sections between 1913 and 1927). Its central theme is the recovery of the lost past and the releasing of its creative energies through the stimulation of unconscious memory.
--Examples--
--Word--
Proustian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the French writer Marcel Proust or his works, particularly with reference to the recovery of the lost past and the stimulation of unconscious memory.
--Examples--
‘childhood memories are triggered by a Proustian moment of Bayley 's catching his vest on a chair’
--Word--
proustite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mineral which is a sulphide of silver and arsenic and usually occurs as masses of prismatic, scarlet crystals.
--Examples--
--Word--
Prout, William 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1785–1850), English chemist and biochemist. He developed the hypothesis that hydrogen is the primary substance from which all other elements are formed, which although incorrect stimulated research in atomic theory.

--Word--
prove 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Demonstrate the truth or existence of (something) by evidence or argument.
Establish the genuineness and validity of (a will).
Demonstrate to be the specified thing by evidence or argument.
Be seen or found to be.
Demonstrate one's abilities or courage.
Test the accuracy of (a mathematical calculation).
(of bread dough) become aerated by the action of yeast; rise.
Subject (a gun) to a testing process.
--Examples--
‘the concept is difficult to prove’
‘if they are proved guilty we won't trade with them’
‘the scheme has proved a great success’
‘she displayed an ingenuousness which sprung from a yearning need to prove herself’
‘firearms proved for black powder should not be used with smokeless ammunition’
--Word--
provect 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Linguistics. To cause (a consonant) to undergo provection. Also without object. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
provection 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The devoicing of a consonant; specifically (in Celtic languages) the change over a period of time of voiced consonants to the corresponding voiceless consonants (e.g. of g, d, b, v to k, t, p, f) under the influence of another consonant.
The transposition of the final letter of a word to the beginning of the word that follows. Compare "metanalysis"rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
prove 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Demonstrate the truth or existence of (something) by evidence or argument.
Establish the genuineness and validity of (a will).
Demonstrate to be the specified thing by evidence or argument.
Be seen or found to be.
Demonstrate one's abilities or courage.
Test the accuracy of (a mathematical calculation).
(of bread dough) become aerated by the action of yeast; rise.
Subject (a gun) to a testing process.

‘the concept is difficult to prove’
‘if they are proved guilty we won't trade with them’
‘the scheme has proved a great success’
‘she displayed an ingenuousness which sprung from a yearning need to prove herself’
‘firearms proved for black powder should not be used with smokeless ammunition’
--Word--
proveditor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Frequently with capital initial. (A title given to) any of various officials of the Venetian Republic, Florence, and elsewhere in northern Italy, especially to a high-ranking civilian officer in charge of supplies, provisions, and artillery for the city or a dependency. Hence more generally: a governor, overseer, legate, inspector. Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
proveditor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Frequently with capital initial. (A title given to) any of various officials of the Venetian Republic, Florence, and elsewhere in northern Italy, especially to a high-ranking civilian officer in charge of supplies, provisions, and artillery for the city or a dependency. Hence more generally: a governor, overseer, legate, inspector. Now historical.
--Examples--

provenance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The place of origin or earliest known history of something.

--Word--
Provence 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A former province of south-eastern France, on the Mediterranean coast east of the River Rhône. Settled by the Greeks in the 6th century BC, the area around Marseilles became, in the 1st century BC, part of the Roman colony of Gaul. It was united with France in 1481 and is now part of the region of Provence–Alpes–Côte d'Azur.
--Examples--
--Word--
provend 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Food, provisions; especially (in early use always) dry food for horses, as hay, etc.; = "provender". Occasionally as a count noun: an item or portion of food. Now archaic, historical, or regional.
--Examples--

--Word--
proverbial 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of a word or phrase) referred to in a proverb or idiom.
Well known, especially so as to be stereotypical.
Used to stand for a word or phrase that is normally part of a proverb or idiom but is not actually uttered.
--Examples--
‘I'm going to stick out like the proverbial sore thumb’
‘the Welsh people, whose hospitality is proverbial’
‘one word out of line, and the proverbial hits the fan’

--Meanings--
Make available for use; supply.
Equip or supply someone with (something useful or necessary)
Present or yield (something useful)
Make adequate preparation for (a possible event)
Supply sufficient money to ensure the maintenance of (someone)
(of a law) enable or allow (something to be done)
Stipulate in a will or other legal document.
Appoint an incumbent to (a benefice).
--Examples--
‘these clubs provide a much appreciated service for this area’
‘we were provided with a map of the area’
‘neither will provide answers to these problems’
‘new qualifications must provide for changes in technology’
‘Emma was handsomely provided for in Frannie's will’
‘the Bill provides for the setting of guaranteed service standards’
‘the order should be varied to provide that there would be no contact with the father’
--Word--
provide 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make available for use; supply.
Equip or supply someone with (something useful or necessary)
Present or yield (something useful)
Make adequate preparation for (a possible event)
Supply sufficient money to ensure the maintenance of (someone)
(of a law) enable or allow (something to be done)
Stipulate in a will or other legal document.
Appoint an incumbent to (a benefice).
--Examples--
‘these clubs provide a much appreciated service for this area’
‘we were provided with a map of the area’
‘neither will provide answers to these problems’
‘new qualifications must provide for changes in technology’
‘Emma was handsomely provided for in Frannie's will’
‘the Bill provides for the setting of guaranteed service standards’
‘the order should be varied to provide that there would be no contact with the father’
--Word--
provided 
--Type--
conjunction
--Meanings--
On the condition or understanding that.
--Examples--
‘cutting corners was acceptable, provided that you could get away with it’
--Word--
providence 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
The protective care of God or of nature as a spiritual power.
God or nature as providing protective care.
Timely preparation for future eventualities.
The state capital of Rhode Island, a port on the Atlantic coast; population 171,557 (est. 2008). It was founded in 1636 as a haven for religious dissenters.
--Examples--
‘they found their trust in divine providence to be a source of comfort’
‘I live out my life as Providence decrees’
‘it was considered a duty to encourage providence’

adjective

--Word--
Vietnamese 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Vietnam, its people, or their language.
A native or inhabitant of Vietnam, or a person of Vietnamese descent.
The language of Vietnam, spoken by about 60 million people. It probably belongs to the Mon-Khmer group, although much of its vocabulary is derived from Chinese.

--Word--
province 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A principal administrative division of a country or empire.
Northern Ireland.
A district under an archbishop or a metropolitan.
A territory outside Italy under a Roman governor.
The whole of a country outside the capital, especially when regarded as lacking in sophistication or culture.
An area of special knowledge, interest, or responsibility.
--Examples--
‘Chengdu, capital of Sichuan province’
‘all-party talks on the future of the Province’
‘I made my way home to the dreary provinces by train’
‘she knew little about wine—that had been her father's province’

--Word--
provincial 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or concerning a province of a country or empire.
Of or concerning the regions outside the capital city of a country, especially when regarded as unsophisticated or narrow-minded.
An inhabitant of a province of a country or empire.
(in Canada) sporting contests held between teams representing the country's administrative divisions.
An inhabitant of the regions outside the capital city of a country, especially when regarded as unsophisticated or narrow-minded.
Local newspapers, as contrasted with national ones.
The head or chief of a province or of a religious order in a province.
--Examples--
‘provincial elections’
‘provincial towns’
‘the whole exhibition struck one as being very provincial’
‘a town populated by money-grubbers, philistines, and self-satisfied provincials’
--Word--
provincialate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The position or period of office of a provincial; an instance of this.
--Examples--
--Word--
provincialism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The way of life characteristic of the regions outside the capital city of a country, especially when regarded as unsophisticated or narrow-minded.
Narrow-mindedness, insularity, or lack of sophistication.
Concern for one's own area or region at the expense of national or supranational unity.
A word or phrase peculiar to a local area.
The degree to which plant or animal communities are restricted to particular areas.
--Examples--
‘book-loving Belle was burning to escape the provincialism of her village’
‘the provincialism of modern novelists’
‘the President warned that focusing on relations with close neighbours would lead to political provincialism’
‘if an idiom is a provincialism, it is likely to be found in a dialect dictionary’
‘the lack of provincialism in Silurian fauna’
--Word--

--Word--
prove 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Demonstrate the truth or existence of (something) by evidence or argument.
Establish the genuineness and validity of (a will).
Demonstrate to be the specified thing by evidence or argument.
Be seen or found to be.
Demonstrate one's abilities or courage.
Test the accuracy of (a mathematical calculation).
(of bread dough) become aerated by the action of yeast; rise.
Subject (a gun) to a testing process.
--Examples--
‘the concept is difficult to prove’
‘if they are proved guilty we won't trade with them’
‘the scheme has proved a great success’
‘she displayed an ingenuousness which sprung from a yearning need to prove herself’
‘firearms proved for black powder should not be used with smokeless ammunition’

Virginian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the US state of Virginia or its inhabitants.
Relating to or made from a type of tobacco grown and manufactured in Virginia.
A native or inhabitant of the US state of Virginia.
A type of tobacco grown and manufactured in Virginia.
A cigarette made of tobacco grown in Virginia.
--Examples--
‘a Virginian family’
‘his favourite blend of Virginian tobacco’
‘the scent of a Virginian cigarette was wafted to them’
‘a Virginian who did social work’
‘he was the sort of type that would only appreciate and only smoke Virginian’
‘he was smoking a Virginian while playing backgammon with a friend’
‘under stress, the raw crude lift of the Virginian is what men need’

--Word--
provision 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The action of providing or supplying something for use.
Financial or other arrangements for future eventualities or requirements.
An amount set aside out of profits in the accounts of an organization for a known liability, especially a bad debt or the diminution in value of an asset.
An amount or thing supplied or provided.
Supplies of food, drink, or equipment, especially for a journey.
A condition or requirement in a legal document.
An appointment to a benefice, especially directly by the Pope rather than by the patron, and originally before it became vacant.
Supply with food, drink, or equipment, especially for a journey.
Set aside an amount in an organization's accounts for a known liability.
--Examples--
‘new contracts for the provision of services’
‘farmers have been slow to make provision for their retirement’
‘changing levels of transport provision’
‘the first private prosecution under the provisions of the 1989 Water Act’
‘civilian contractors were responsible for provisioning these armies’
‘the provisioning of US ships’
‘financial institutions have to provision against loan losses’
--Word--
provisional 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Arranged or existing for the present, possibly to be changed later.
(of a driving licence) to be obtained before starting to learn to drive and upgraded to a full licence on passing a driving test.
(of a postage stamp) put into circulation temporarily, usually owing to the unavailability of the definitive issue.
Denoting the unofficial wings of the IRA and Sinn Fein established in 1969 and advocating terrorism.
A provisional stamp.
A member of the Provisional wings of the IRA or Sinn Fein.
--Examples--
‘a provisional government’
‘provisional bookings’
‘Norman as yet had only a provisional licence’
‘the Provisional IRA’

provisionality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

adverb
--Meanings--
Subject to further confirmation; for the time being.
--Examples--
‘the film, provisionally entitled Skin, is due to be released next year’

--Word--
provocation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Action or speech that makes someone angry, especially deliberately.
Action or speech held to be likely to prompt physical retaliation.
The action of arousing sexual desire or interest, especially deliberately.
Testing to elicit a particular response or reflex.
--Examples--
‘you should remain calm and not respond to provocation’
‘he burst into tears at the slightest provocation’
‘the assault had taken place under provocation’
‘walking with deliberate provocation, she struck a pose, then giggled’
‘twenty patients had a high increase of serum gastrin after provocation with secretin’

--Word--
provoke 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Stimulate or give rise to (a reaction or emotion, typically a strong or unwelcome one) in someone.
Stimulate or incite (someone) to do or feel something, especially by arousing anger in them.
Deliberately make (someone) annoyed or angry.
--Examples--
‘the decision provoked a storm of protest from civil rights organizations’
‘a teacher can provoke you into working harder’
‘Rachel refused to be provoked’

provost 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The head of certain university colleges, especially at Oxford or Cambridge, and public schools.
A senior administrative officer in certain universities.
(in Scotland) the civic head of some regional Scottish councils, analogous to a mayor in England, Wales, and Northern Ireland.
The head of a chapter in a cathedral.
The Protestant minister of the principal church of a town or district in Germany and certain other European countries.
The head of a Christian community.
The chief magistrate of a French or other European town.
--Examples--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
provostry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The office, territory, or jurisdiction of a provost; specifically (a) a Roman praetorship or prefecture; (b) the provostship of a Scots burgh. Now chiefly historical.
The benefice of an ecclesiastical provost; the revenue derived from such a benefice; (occasionally) the provostship of an educational college; = "provostship". Now rare.
A church or cathedral under a provost.
--Examples--

prowed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a prow, especially of a specified kind.
--Examples--
--Word--
pro- 
--Type--
prefix, prefix
--Meanings--
Favouring; supporting.
Acting as a substitute or deputy for.
Denoting motion forwards, out, or away.
Before in time, place, order, etc.
--Examples--
‘pro-choice’
‘proconsul’
‘proceed’
‘propel’
‘prostrate’
‘proactive’
‘prothalamium’

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
prowess 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Skill or expertise in a particular activity or field.
Bravery in battle.
--Examples--
‘his prowess as a fisherman’
‘her culinary prowess’
‘the hereditary nobility had no monopoly of skill and prowess in war’
--Word--
prowessed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Possessing or endowed with prowess; valiant, brave, skilful. Also occasionally as noun, with the and plural concord: people showing prowess as a class.
--Examples--

--Word--
western 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Situated in the west, or directed towards or facing the west.
(of a wind) blowing from the west.
Living in or originating from the West, in particular Europe or the United States.
Relating to or characteristic of the West or its inhabitants.
Of or originating from the non-Communist states of Europe and North America in contrast to the Eastern bloc.
A film, television drama, or novel about cowboys in western North America, set especially in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
--Examples--
‘there will be showers in some western areas’
‘Western society’
‘the history of Western art’
‘the President threatened to end Western aid for an oil pipeline in Siberia’
--Word--
westerner 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of the west, especially of western Europe or North America.
--Examples--
--Word--
prowfish 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a number of marine fishes that typically have dark spots and a dorsal fin extending the length of the body.

--Word--
Whig 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of the British reforming and constitutional party that sought the supremacy of Parliament and was eventually succeeded in the 19th century by the Liberal Party.
A supporter of the American side during the War of American Independence.
A member of an American political party in the 19th century, succeeded by the Republicans.
A 17th-century Scottish Presbyterian.
Denoting a historian who interprets history as the continuing and inevitable victory of progress over reaction.
--Examples--
--Word--
prowl 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of a person or animal) move about restlessly and stealthily, especially in search of prey.
An act of prowling.
--Examples--
‘lions prowling in the bush’
‘youngsters were prowling the streets in droves’
‘I met her once on one of my off-duty bookshop prowls’

--Word--
proxy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The authority to represent someone else, especially in voting.
A person authorized to act on behalf of another.
A document authorizing a person to vote on another's behalf.
A figure that can be used to represent the value of something in a calculation.
--Examples--
‘Britons overseas may register to vote by proxy’
‘the use of a US wealth measure as a proxy for the true worldwide measure’

--Word--
Proxima Centauri 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A faint red dwarf star associated with the bright binary star Alpha Centauri. It is the closest known star to the solar system (distance 4.24 light years).
--Examples--

--Meanings--

proximate 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(especially of the cause of something) closest in relationship; immediate.
Closest in space or time.
Nearly accurate; approximate.
--Examples--
‘the fact that a storm may show up the poor condition of a flat roof does not signify that storm was the proximate cause of damage to it’
‘the failure of the proximate military power to lend assistance’
‘he would try to change her speech into proximate ladylikeness’

--Word--
Zionism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A movement for (originally) the re-establishment and (now) the development and protection of a Jewish nation in what is now Israel. It was established as a political organization in 1897 under Theodor Herzl, and was later led by Chaim Weizmann.
(in southern Africa) a religious movement represented by a group of independent Churches which practise a form of Christianity incorporating elements of traditional African beliefs.
The beliefs and practices of the African Zionist movement.
--Examples--
--Word--
Zionist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A supporter of Zionism; a person who believes in the development and protection of a Jewish nation in what is now Israel.
(in southern Africa) a member of any of a group of independent Churches which practise a form of Christianity incorporating elements of traditional African beliefs.
Relating to or advocating Zionism.
Relating to a group of independent Churches in southern Africa which practise a form of Christianity incorporating elements of traditional African beliefs.
--Examples--
‘the artist's parents were committed Zionists’
‘mainstream Zionist thinking’
--Word--
prozone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in testing for antigens) the range of relative quantities of precipitin (or agglutinin) and antigen within which any precipitation (or agglutination) is inhibited by the predominance of one component.
--Examples--

prudhomme 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Historical or archaic. A man of valour and discretion; a knight or freeholder who is summoned to sit on a jury or to serve in the king's council. Now rare.
In France: a member of a tribunal, especially one appointed to decide labour disputes.

--Word--
prunase 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An enzyme which hydrolyses β-glucosides (notably prunasin), liberating glucose, and occurs chiefly in bitter almonds and yeast, as well as in the fruit of several trees of the genus Prunus.
--Examples--
--Word--
prunasin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A crystalline, cyanogenic glycoside related to amygdalin, found in a number of trees (notably the bird cherry, Prunus padus).
--Examples--
--Word--
prune 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A plum preserved by drying and having a black, wrinkled appearance.
An unpleasant or disagreeable person.
Trim (a tree, shrub, or bush) by cutting away dead or overgrown branches or stems, especially to encourage growth.
Cut away (a branch or stem) from a tree, shrub, etc.
Reduce the extent of (something) by removing superfluous or unwanted parts.
Remove (superfluous or unwanted parts) from something.
An instance of trimming a tree, shrub, or bush.
--Examples--
‘he was a good leader, but a right miserable old prune’
‘now is the time to prune roses’
‘to limit growth, prune in summer’
‘prune back the branches’
‘the workforce was pruned’
‘Eliot deliberately pruned away details’
‘they need little care other than an annual prune’

--Word--
prunella 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A plant of a genus that includes self-heal. Several kinds are cultivated as ground cover and rockery plants.
A strong silk or worsted fabric used formerly for barristers' gowns and the uppers of women's shoes.

prunello 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a small kind of plum, either fresh or dried. Later: specifically the sloe, the bitter fruit of the blackthorn (Prunus spinosa), which may be dried or used to make a liqueur.

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a small kind of plum, either fresh or dried. Later: specifically the sloe, the bitter fruit of the blackthorn (Prunus spinosa), which may be dried or used to make a liqueur.

--Word--
Prussia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A former kingdom of Germany. Originally a small country on the south-eastern shores of the Baltic, under Frederick the Great it became a major European power covering much of modern north-eastern Germany and Poland. After the Franco-Prussian War of 1870–1 it became the centre of Bismarck's new German Empire, but following Germany's defeat in the First World War the Prussian monarchy was abolished.
--Examples--
--Word--
Prussian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the former kingdom of Prussia.
A native or inhabitant of Prussia.
--Examples--
‘her eldest daughter was married to the Prussian Crown Prince’
‘a general advance pushed the Prussians from the field’
--Word--
Prussianize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To make Prussian; to cause to resemble Prussia, its people, or its institutions, especially in terms of organization, character, or ideology. Also without object: to adopt a manner regarded as typically Prussian.
--Examples--
--Word--
Prussianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The political system or ideology of Prussia; the political concepts or philosophies considered characteristic of Prussia, especially militarism or nationalism.
--Examples--
--Word--
Prussianization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of making something Prussian in character.
--Examples--
--Word--
Prussianize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To make Prussian; to cause to resemble Prussia, its people, or its institutions, especially in terms of organization, character, or ideology. Also without object: to adopt a manner regarded as typically Prussian.

--Examples--
--Word--
Prut 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river of south-eastern Europe, which rises in the Carpathian Mountains in southern Ukraine and flows south-east for 850 km (530 miles), joining the River Danube near Galaţi in Romania. For much of its course it forms the border between Romania and Moldova.
--Examples--
--Word--
prutah 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bronze coin issued in Palestine from about 200 b.c. into New Testament times, of the same weight as the Roman quadrans.
An aluminium coin issued in Israel between 1948 and 1960, of the value of 1/1000 of an Israeli pound.
--Examples--
--Word--
Prutenic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating the planetary tables Prutenicae tabulae coelestium motuum (1551) by Erasmus Reinhold (1511–53), a revised and expanded version of Copernicus’ tables in his De revolutionibus (1543). Chiefly in "Prutenic tables". Now historical.
--Examples--

Probability.

(on an automatic gear shift) park.
(on road signs and street plans) parking.

Portugal (international vehicle registration).
Proprietary.
The chemical element phosphorus.
The sixteenth letter of the alphabet.

--Word--
psammite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: †a fine or smooth-grained sandstone (obsolete). In later use: a sedimentary rock composed of medium-sized particles (commonly defined as those with a diameter between 1/16 mm and either 2 or 4 mm).
--Examples--
--Word--
psammite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: †a fine or smooth-grained sandstone (obsolete). In later use: a sedimentary rock composed of medium-sized particles (commonly defined as those with a diameter between 1/16 mm and either 2 or 4 mm).

--Word--
Pseudechis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of Australasian snakes of the family Elapidae, which consists of large, smooth-scaled venomous snakes, some of which can flatten the neck like a cobra when threatened, and comprises the black snakes and the king brown snake (Pseudechis australis); (also pseudechis) a snake of this genus.

--Word--
pseudo-acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A compound which is not itself an acid but which exists in equilibrium with, or is easily converted into, an acidic form and thus undergoes some typical reactions of acids.

--Examples--
--Word--
Dionysius the Areopagite 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1st century AD), Greek churchman. His conversion by St Paul is recorded in Acts 17:34 and according to tradition he went on to become the first bishop of Athens. He was later confused with St Denis and with a mystical theologian, Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite, who exercised a profound influence on medieval theology.
--Examples--

--Word--
pseudobranch 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A structure resembling a gill, but not functioning as one; specifically (in many fishes) a structure anterior to the gills that in adults receives blood that has already been oxygenated in the gills, but which may have had a respiratory function in early life.
--Examples--

noun

A bulbous enlargement of the stem in many orchids, especially tropical and epiphytic ones.
--Examples--
--Word--
pseudobulbar 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating or relating to a syndrome resembling bulbar palsy, with paralysis of the muscles of the face, tongue, and pharynx, but caused by supranuclear (upper motor neuron) lesions.
--Examples--

--Word--
pseudodiphtheria 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Attributive Designating the bacterium Corynebacterium pseudodiphtheriticum, which resembles the causal agent of diphtheria, C. diphtheriae, and is found in the nasopharynx of humans, but is non-pathogenic. Chiefly in "pseudodiphtheria bacillus". Compare pseudodiphtheritic. Now historical.
Any of various forms of pharyngitis or tonsillitis resembling diphtheria, especially by the presence of a pseudomembrane. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
pseudodiphtheritic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling diphtheria or its manifestations; pseudomembranous.
--Examples--
--Word--
pseudodipteral 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a temple or other building: having a single peristyle or surrounding row of columns, placed at the same distance from the walls as the outer of the two rows in the dipteros.

pseudogastrula 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A blastula which has undergone invagination prior to gastrulation; specifically (in certain calcareous sponges) one in which the archaeocytes of one hemisphere have become completely enclosed by flagellated cells of the other (before half of these lose their flagella to produce the amphiblastula).

--Examples--
--Word--
pseudogenus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A spurious or invalid genus of plants or animals, such as one based on superficial similarities between unrelated species, or on forms (e.g. developmental stages) that have been mistakenly regarded as distinct. Also: a name used for a group of hybrid forms, especially intergeneric hybrids.
--Examples--
--Word--
pseudogenus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A spurious or invalid genus of plants or animals, such as one based on superficial similarities between unrelated species, or on forms (e.g. developmental stages) that have been mistakenly regarded as distinct. Also: a name used for a group of hybrid forms, especially intergeneric hybrids.
--Examples--
--Word--
Georgian 
--Type--
adjective, adjective, noun, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or characteristic of the reigns of the British Kings George I–IV (1714–1830).
Relating to British architecture of the Georgian period, characterized by restrained elegance and the use of neoclassical styles.
Of or characteristic of the reigns of the British Kings George V and VI (1910–52).
Relating to British literature of 1910–20, in particular pastoral poetry of a type strongly attacked by the early modernists.
Relating to the country of Georgia, its people, or their language.
A native or inhabitant of Georgia, or a person of Georgian descent.
The official language of Georgia, spoken by around 4 million people. It is the main member of the small South Caucasian (or Kartvelian) language family, and has its own alphabet.
Relating to the state of Georgia in the US.
A native or inhabitant of Georgia.

Germanic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the branch of the Indo-European language family that includes English, German, Dutch, Frisian, and the Scandinavian languages.
Relating to or denoting the peoples of ancient northern and western Europe speaking Germanic languages.
Having characteristics of or attributed to Germans or Germany.
The Germanic languages collectively.
The unrecorded ancient language from which the Germanic languages developed, thought to have been spoken on the shores of the Baltic Sea in the 3rd millennium BC.
--Examples--
‘she had an almost Germanic regard for order’

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
pseudohalogen 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a group of compounds (in some cases hypothetical) which have small molecules built up from atoms of electronegative elements and which closely resemble the halogens in many respects.

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Hittite 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of an ancient people who established an empire in Asia Minor and Syria that flourished from c.1700 to c.1200 BC.
A subject of the Hittite empire or one of their descendants, including a Canaanite or Syrian people mentioned in the Bible (11th to 8th century BC).
The language of the Hittites, the oldest attested Indo-European language. Written in both hieroglyphic and cuneiform scripts, it was deciphered in the early 20th century.
Relating to the Hittites, their empire, or their language.

Hungarian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Hungary, its people, or their language.
A native or inhabitant of Hungary, or a person of Hungarian descent.
The official language of Hungary, spoken also by some 2.5 million people in Romania. Hungarian is a Finno-Ugric language and is the only major language of the Ugric branch.

--Examples--
--Word--
ionone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Frequently with distinguishing Greek letter. Each of a number of fragrant unsaturated isomeric ketones which are products of the breakdown of carotenoids and occur naturally in some essential oils; specifically (more fully "β-ionone") a compound that arises as a product of ψ-ionone in the synthesis of vitamin A.
In full "ψ-ionone". An acyclic compound isomeric with α- and β-ionone which can be cyclized to form those compounds and is used in the synthesis of vitamin A.

Of or having equal dimensions.
Relating to or denoting muscular action in which tension is developed without contraction of the muscle.
(in technical or architectural drawing) incorporating a method of showing projection or perspective in which the three principal dimensions are represented by three axes 120° apart.
(of a transformation) without change of shape or size.
--Examples--

adjective, noun

Relating to Italy, its people, or their language.
A native or inhabitant of Italy, or a person of Italian descent.
The Romance language of Italy, descended from Latin and with roughly 60 million speakers worldwide. It is also one of the official languages of Switzerland.

--Word--
pseudopupa 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In oil and blister beetles: a larval instar which resembles a pupa in being immobile and coarctate but is followed by another (apodous) larval stage. In certain other insects (e.g. thrips, whiteflies, mealy bugs) and mites: a quiescent, non-feeding larval stage preceding the emergence of the adult. Also: an abnormal or mutant form resembling a pupa but incapable of further development.
--Examples--

Resembling syphilis or its symptoms or signs.
--Examples--
--Word--
pseudo-social 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Exhibiting or designating apparently social behaviour that arises from individual reactions to a personal need or external stimulus, rather than from genuinely social impulses; (more generally) seemingly sociable or friendly.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Socrates or his philosophy.
A follower of Socrates.

noun
--Meanings--
A sham or spurious philosopher; a person who falsely believes himself or herself to be wise.

pseudosophy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Spanish 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Spain, its people, or its language.
The people of Spain.
A Romance language spoken in Spain and in much of Central and South America (except Brazil) and several other countries. It is the second most widely spoken first language in the world, with more than 400 millon speakers.

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The pseudospherical surface that is generated by rotating a tractrix about its asymptote.

--Word--
pseudostereoscopic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating a three-dimensional image in which left and right images, and hence the impression of depth, are reversed; = pseudoscopic. Later also: of or relating to an apparently three-dimensional image produced other than by ordinary binocular vision.
--Examples--
--Word--
pseudostigma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In certain mites (especially oribatids and trombiculids): either of a pair of pits in the integument, each serving as the socket of a sensillum (pseudostigmatic organ).
--Examples--
--Word--
pseudostigmatic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Botany. Designating or involving a structure resembling the stigma of a flower in form or function. rare.
Zoology. Designating a sensory seta arising from a pit in the integument of various mites. Chiefly in "pseudostigmatic organ".
--Examples--
--Word--
pseudostoma 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A former genus of pocket gophers (now called Geomys); a member of this genus.
Botany. A pore in the capsule of a sphagnum moss resembling a stoma. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
pseudostratum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mass of rock resembling a stratum but produced by a process other than sedimentary deposition, e.g. in an igneous rock as a result of parallel fractures.
--Examples--
--Word--
pseudosuchian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating small extinct reptiles of the thecodont suborder Pseudosuchia, which includes primitive, often bipedal, carnivores that were probably ancestral to dinosaurs, pterosaurs, and crocodiles, and are known from remains found mainly in Triassic deposits.
A pseudosuchian reptile.
--Examples--
--Word--
Swedish 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Sweden, its people, or their language.
The Scandinavian language of Sweden, also spoken in parts of Finland. It has over 8 million speakers.
--Examples--
--Word--
pseudotachylite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dark, fine-grained or glassy intrusive rock resembling tachylite that results from vitrification by frictional heat generated during dynamic metamorphism and typically occurs in faults and veins.
--Examples--
--Word--
pseudotetragonal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating a crystal in which the crystal structure simulates the symmetry of the tetragonal system but actually has lower symmetry.
--Examples--
--Word--
pseudotetramerous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Apparently but not actually tetramerous; (Entomology) designating tarsi with five segments which appear as four, the fourth segment being very small and hidden between the lobes of the third; (of a beetle) having such tarsi (obsolete rare).
--Examples--
--Word--
pseudotrachea 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fine ridged food channel on the ventral surface of the labellum in many flies; (also) an air-filled tubule in certain woodlice which resembles an insect's trachea.
--Examples--
--Word--
pseudotracheal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling a trachea; having a series of rings like those of the trachea; of, relating to, or of the nature of a pseudotrachea.
--Examples--
--Word--
pseudotuberculosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any disease producing granulomatous inflammation similar to that of tuberculosis; especially caseous lymphadenitis of sheep, caused by Corynebacterium pseudotuberculosis, and yersiniosis.
--Examples--
--Word--
pseudotuberculous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling tuberculosis; granulomatous; of or relating to pseudotuberculosis.
--Examples--
--Word--
Turk 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Turkey, or a person of Turkish descent.
A member of any of the ancient central Asian peoples who spoke Turkic languages, including the Seljuks and Ottomans.
A member of the ruling Muslim population of the Ottoman Empire.
--Examples--
--Word--
Turkish 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Turkey or to the Turks or their language.
Relating to or associated with the Ottoman Empire.
The official language of Turkey, a Turkic language spoken by about 50 million people. It was written in the Arabic script until 1928, when the Roman alphabet was adopted.

urea 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A colourless crystalline compound which is the main nitrogenous breakdown product of protein metabolism in mammals and is excreted in urine.

pseudo-uric acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A crystalline acid, structurally similar to uric acid, obtained from uramil by reaction with a cyanate; a substituted derivative of this.

pseudovelum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The velarium of a box jelly (cubozoan), which resembles the velum of a hydromedusa but lacks muscular and nervous tissue.

adjective, noun, adjective, noun

Relating to the reign of Queen Victoria.

noun

--Meanings--

pseudo-volcano 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hill or vent that emits smoke, flame, or gases, but not lava (e.g. above a coal mine that has accidentally caught fire).

pseudowhorl 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An apparent whorl of plant parts, especially of leaves, resulting from alteration of the distances between nodes spirally arranged around an axis.

--Word--
p 
--Type--
abbreviation
UnKnownKind, abbreviation
UnKnownKind, noun
--Meanings--
Page.
Para-
Penny or pence.
Piano (softly).
(in units of measurement) pico- (10^-12)
Denoting electrons and orbitals possessing one unit of angular momentum.
Pressure.
Probability.
(in tables of sports results) games played.
(on an automatic gear shift) park.
(on road signs and street plans) parking.
(in units of measurement) peta- (10¹⁵)
Poise (unit of viscosity).
Portugal (international vehicle registration).
Proprietary.
The chemical element phosphorus.
The sixteenth letter of the alphabet.
Denoting the next after O (or N if O is omitted) in a set of items, categories, etc.
--Examples--
‘see p 784’
‘p-xylene’
‘a 5p coin’
‘a 220 pf capacitor’
‘p-electrons’
‘pV = nRT’
‘this difference was significant (p = 0.0008)’
‘27 PBq of radioactive material’

psych 
--Type--
verb, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Mentally prepare (someone) for a testing task or occasion.
Excited and full of anticipation.
Analyse (something) in psychological terms.
Subject (someone) to psychological investigation or psychotherapy.
Make a psychic bid.
A psychic bid.
psych someone out
Intimidate an opponent or rival by appearing very confident or aggressive.
--Examples--
‘we had to psych ourselves up for the race’
‘we've told him you were coming—he's really psyched’
‘mother had it all psyched out in three minutes’
‘he's been psyched to the best of our skill’
‘the psych ward’
‘a psych course’
‘a rare old psych album’
‘we won't be psyched out of beating them’

psychasthenia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: neurosis, especially of a phobic or obsessive type; an instance of this; (now chiefly historical). Later also: mental lethargy, especially as a category in psychological personality testing.

--Word--
psyche 
--Type--
noun
UnKnownKind, proper noun
--Meanings--
The human soul, mind, or spirit.
A Hellenistic personification of the soul as female, or sometimes as a butterfly. The allegory of Psyche's love for Cupid is told in The Golden Ass by Apuleius.
--Examples--
‘their childhood made them want to understand the human psyche and to help others’
‘how does constant losing affect the psyches of young athletes?’
--Word--

adjective
--Meanings--

psychic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting faculties or phenomena that are apparently inexplicable by natural laws, especially involving telepathy or clairvoyance.
Appearing or considered to have powers of telepathy or clairvoyance.
Relating to the soul or mind.
Denoting a bid that deliberately misrepresents the bidder's hand, in order to mislead the opponents.
A person considered or claiming to have psychic powers; a medium.
The study of psychic phenomena.
--Examples--
‘psychic powers’
‘I could sense it—I must be psychic’
‘he dulled his psychic pain with gin’
‘pier-end palmists and fake psychics’
‘the field of psychics’

--Word--
psychoanalysis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A system of psychological theory and therapy which aims to treat mental disorders by investigating the interaction of conscious and unconscious elements in the mind and bringing repressed fears and conflicts into the conscious mind by techniques such as dream interpretation and free association.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who practises psychoanalysis.

psychodiagnosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The diagnosis of a psychiatric or abnormal psychological condition; an instance of this. Also: psychological assessment (especially of character) by such means as the Rorschach test, personality profiling, etc.; the branch of psychology that deals with this.
--Examples--
--Word--
psychodiagnostic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to psychodiagnosis.
--Examples--
--Word--
psychodiagnostics 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
With singular concord. The branch of psychology concerned with psychological assessment (especially as carried out by means of Rorschach and other projective tests, personality profiles, etc.).
--Examples--

--Word--
psychodynamics 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
The interrelation of the unconscious and conscious mental and emotional forces that determine personality and motivation.
The branch of psychology that deals with psychodynamics.
--Examples--
‘the psychodynamics of adolescent suicide’
--Word--
psychodrama 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A form of psychotherapy in which patients act out events from their past.
A play, film, or novel in which psychological elements are the main interest.
--Examples--
‘the treatment includes art therapy and psychodrama’
‘in the hospital, Hector participated in a psychodrama’
‘a psychodrama about a brain-warped prisoner-of-war survivor’
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

psychogram 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Spiritualism. A message supposed to have been written by a spirit, or by psychical means; a spirit writing. Now rare.
Chiefly Psychology. A diagrammatic representation or written summary of a person's personality; especially one based on psychological history, responses to tests, etc.

psychography 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Spiritualism. The production of writing, drawing, etc., supposedly by a spiritual or psychical agency, especially through the hand of a medium; writing or drawing produced in this way.
The description, delineation, or history of the psyche; descriptive psychology.
Psychology. The systematic examination of an individual's psyche or personality; the making of a psychogram or psychograms. Now rare.

psychological

adjective

(of an ailment or problem) having a mental rather than a physical cause.

‘it was concluded that her pain was psychological’

psychologist's fallacy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

Relating to or denoting drugs which are capable of producing an effect on the mind similar to a psychotic state.
A psychotomimetic drug.
--Examples--
‘such altered states of consciousness follow ingestion of LSD and other psychotomimetic drugs’
--Word--
psychotropic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting drugs that affect a person's mental state.
A psychotropic drug.
--Examples--
‘a psychotropic drug’
‘myristicin has psychotropic properties’
--Word--
psycho-vital 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Both psychical and vital; specifically designating a supposed basic vital force which determines mental processes.
--Examples--
--Word--
psychozoic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Geology (now rare) designating or relating to the period of geological time characterized by the presence of human intelligence.
--Examples--
--Word--
psychrometer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hygrometer consisting of wet-bulb and dry-bulb thermometers, the difference in the two thermometer readings being used to determine atmospheric humidity.
--Examples--
--Word--
psychrometry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The measurement of humidity by means of a psychrometer; psychrometric character.
--Examples--
--Word--
psychrometric 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or involving psychrometry.
--Examples--
--Word--
psychrometrically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
By means of a psychrometer.

psychrophobia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Fear or hatred of cold, especially of cold water.
--Examples--
--Word--
psychrophore 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A kind of catheter kept at a low temperature by a flow of cold water, inserted into the urethra in order to cool it.
--Examples--
--Word--
psych 
--Type--
verb, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Mentally prepare (someone) for a testing task or occasion.
Excited and full of anticipation.
Analyse (something) in psychological terms.
Subject (someone) to psychological investigation or psychotherapy.
Make a psychic bid.
A psychic bid.
psych someone out
Intimidate an opponent or rival by appearing very confident or aggressive.
--Examples--
‘we had to psych ourselves up for the race’
‘we've told him you were coming—he's really psyched’
‘mother had it all psyched out in three minutes’
‘he's been psyched to the best of our skill’
‘the psych ward’
‘a psych course’
‘a rare old psych album’
‘we won't be psyched out of beating them’
--Word--
psychurgy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The supposed ability to understand and enhance the structure, operation, and capabilities of the mind through thinking and self-analysis; the study of this considered as a science.
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--
An open-topped jar used for cooling wine, typically made of earthenware or metal, with a narrow, high-lipped opening widening to a bulbous central bowl, which tapers to a tall narrow base; (in later use also) a replica piece imitating Greek originals.

psilocybin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

psilocin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
psilomelane 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hard black ore of manganese which consists of a mechanical mixture of manganese oxides and hydroxides, usually also containing barium and other metals.
--Examples--
--Word--
psilophyte 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Ecology. A plant that is adapted for a dry savannah environment; the growth form characteristic of such a plant.
Botany and Palaeontology. Any of various extinct primitive vascular plants of the Upper Silurian and Devonian periods, lacking true roots and leaves but having a creeping rhizome and a cylindrical branching stem with a central vascular strand, sometimes bearing scales or leaf-like branchlets. Also: a member of the extant order Psilotales, comprising two genera (Psilotum and Tmesipteris) of small tropical and subtropical plants that superficially resemble these fossils.
--Examples--
--Word--
psilosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Linguistics. Chiefly with reference to Greek: the substitution of plosive for aspirated or fricative consonants (as p for ph) or of smooth breathings for rough ones; an instance of this.

psoas 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of a pair of large muscles which run from the lumbar spine through the groin on either side and, with the iliacus, flex the hip. A second muscle, the psoas minor, has a similar action but is often absent.
--Examples--

psocid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small or minute insect of an order that includes the booklice. Many psocids are wingless and somewhat resemble lice or aphids, and most live on bark and among foliage.

--Word--
psorosperm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various unicellular parasites found in an encysted stage in the tissues of a host; (also) any of the organisms which form such cysts, now variously identified as sporozoans (especially coccidia and gregarines), microsporidians, and myxosporidians.
--Examples--
--Word--
psorospermosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A disease caused by certain sporozoans or other unicellular parasites.

abbreviation
UnKnownKind, abbreviation
UnKnownKind, noun
--Meanings--
Page.
Para-
Penny or pence.
Piano (softly).
(in units of measurement) pico- (10^-12)
Denoting electrons and orbitals possessing one unit of angular momentum.
Pressure.
Probability.
(in tables of sports results) games played.
(on an automatic gear shift) park.
(on road signs and street plans) parking.
(in units of measurement) peta- (10¹⁵)
Poise (unit of viscosity).
Portugal (international vehicle registration).
Proprietary.
The chemical element phosphorus.
The sixteenth letter of the alphabet.
Denoting the next after O (or N if O is omitted) in a set of items, categories, etc.

‘p-xylene’

Ptah 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient deity of Memphis, creator of the universe, god of artisans, and husband of Sekhmet. He became one of the chief deities of Egypt, and was identified by the Greeks with Hephaestus.

ptenoglossate 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the radula of a gastropod: having no median teeth but a large number of lateral teeth resembling the barbs of a feather. Of a gastropod: having such a radula; belonging to a taxon Ptenoglossa so characterized (variously ranked between superfamily and order).

pteranodon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

Pteraspis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of armoured jawless fossil fishes (ostracoderms) of the Lower Devonian with the anterior end enclosed by a shield of bony plates; a fish of this genus.

Pterichthys 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A former genus of placoderm fishes of the Devonian period (now called Pterychthyodes) having wing-like pectoral appendages encased in bony plates; a fish of this genus.

--Word--
pterygium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Ophthalmology. An abnormal triangular growth of fibrovascular tissue beneath the bulbar conjunctiva of the eye, typically having its base at the medial canthus and its apex towards or into the cornea, and often associated with excessive exposure to ultraviolet light.
An abnormal condition of the nail in which the cuticle extends forward over the nail plate. More fully "pterygium unguis".
An abnormal web of skin, especially situated on the neck (more fully "pterygium colli") or in the antecubital, popliteal, or interdigital regions.
--Examples--
--Word--
pterygium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Ophthalmology. An abnormal triangular growth of fibrovascular tissue beneath the bulbar conjunctiva of the eye, typically having its base at the medial canthus and its apex towards or into the cornea, and often associated with excessive exposure to ultraviolet light.
An abnormal condition of the nail in which the cuticle extends forward over the nail plate. More fully "pterygium unguis".
An abnormal web of skin, especially situated on the neck (more fully "pterygium colli") or in the antecubital, popliteal, or interdigital regions.
--Examples--

pteris 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: †bracken, Pteridium aquilinum (formerly Pteris aquilina) (obsolete). In later use (in form Pteris): a genus of ferns, now comprising largely tropical and subtropical species but formerly including bracken; (also in form pteris) a fern of this genus (also "pteris fern").

--Word--
Pterocarpus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of tropical trees of the family Fabaceae (Leguminosae) noted for their broadly winged circular fruits and including many kinds valued for their hard, often red, wood, such as the padauks (Pterocarpus dalbergioides, P. soyauxii, etc.) and P. indicus, the source of amboyna wood; (also pterocarpus) a tree of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
pterodactyl 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A pterosaur of the late Jurassic period, with a long slender head and neck and a very short tail.
(in general use) any pterosaur.

pterodactyloid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having the form or character of a pterodactyl; specifically belonging to the suborder or superfamily Pterodactyloidea of pterosaurs of the late Jurassic and the Cretaceous, characterized by a long neck and a small or vestigial tail.
A pterodactyloid pterosaur.
--Examples--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the nature of a pterodactyl; (figurative) antiquated, out of date.

pterodactyl 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A pterosaur of the late Jurassic period, with a long slender head and neck and a very short tail.
(in general use) any pterosaur.
--Examples--
--Word--
pteroid 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having the characteristics of a fern of the genus Pteris or the family Pteridaceae; resembling a fern, filicoid.
A pteroid fern.
Chiefly Palaeontology. Especially of the shell of a bivalve mollusc: resembling a wing. rare.
Palaeontology. Designating various body parts of a pterosaur associated with the small anterior flight membrane, especially a small, pointed bone that extends from the carpal region towards the shoulder and supports this membrane.
Palaeontology. The pteroid bone of a pterosaur.

pteroma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Classical Architecture. The walkway between the cella of a Greek or Roman temple and the surrounding colonnade.

pteropine 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the genus Pteropus of Old World fruit bats (family Pteropodidae), which comprises the flying foxes.

--Word--
pteropod 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sea butterfly.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pteropoda 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A former class or order of pelagic opisthobranch molluscs comprising the pteropods (sea butterflies). Treated as plural (also pteropoda): the members of this class collectively.
--Examples--
--Word--
pteropodial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating the winglike lobes of the foot of a pteropod. Also (of a mollusc): having a foot with winglike lobes; that is a pteropod.
--Examples--
--Word--
pteropod 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sea butterfly.
--Examples--
--Word--
Pteropus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of large fruit-eating bats comprising most of the flying foxes; a bat of this genus, a flying fox.
--Examples--
--Word--
pterosaur 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fossil flying reptile of the Jurassic and Cretaceous periods, with membranous wings supported by a greatly lengthened fourth finger.
--Examples--
--Word--
pterosaurian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A pterosaur. Now rare.
Of, relating to, or characteristic of pterosaurs or the order Pterosauria.
--Examples--
--Word--
pterostigma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A pigmented spot on the anterior margin of the wings of certain insects that is denser than the surrounding (typically transparent) parts of the wing and influences the motion of the wing membrane during flight.
--Examples--
--Word--
pterostigmal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or characterized by a pterostigma.
--Examples--
--Word--
pterotheca 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The part of the pupal skin of an insect that covers the wings.
--Examples--
--Word--
pterotic 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A bone in the upper posterior part of the skull in many fishes and some other lower vertebrates, often bearing a distinct crest or flange; a corresponding element in the wall of the auditory capsule in some other vertebrate groups.
Designating, relating to, or corresponding to this bone or element.

ptilinum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A structure on the head of cyclorrhaphous dipteran flies which can be inflated (especially to rupture the puparium) and later atrophies, leaving a suture.

noun, adjective, adjective, noun

= Ptolemaist.
--Examples--
--Word--
Ptolemy 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
The name of all the Macedonian rulers of Egypt, a dynasty founded by Ptolemy, the close friend and general of Alexander the Great, who took charge of Egypt after the latter's death and declared himself king (Ptolemy I) in 304 BC. The dynasty ended with the death of Cleopatra in 30 BC.
(2nd century) Greek astronomer and geographer. His teachings had enormous influence on medieval thought, the geocentric view of the cosmos being adopted as Christian doctrine until the late Renaissance. Ptolemy's Geography, giving lists of places with their longitudes and latitudes, was also a standard work for centuries, despite its inaccuracies.
--Examples--
--Word--
Ptolemy 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
The name of all the Macedonian rulers of Egypt, a dynasty founded by Ptolemy, the close friend and general of Alexander the Great, who took charge of Egypt after the latter's death and declared himself king (Ptolemy I) in 304 BC. The dynasty ended with the death of Cleopatra in 30 BC.
(2nd century) Greek astronomer and geographer. His teachings had enormous influence on medieval thought, the geocentric view of the cosmos being adopted as Christian doctrine until the late Renaissance. Ptolemy's Geography, giving lists of places with their longitudes and latitudes, was also a standard work for centuries, despite its inaccuracies.

Portugal (international vehicle registration).
Proprietary.
The chemical element phosphorus.
The sixteenth letter of the alphabet.
Denoting the next after O (or N if O is omitted) in a set of items, categories, etc.

--Word--
public 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or concerning the people as a whole.
Open to or shared by all the people of an area or country.
Of or involved in the affairs of the community, especially in government or entertainment.
Done, perceived, or existing in open view.
Of or provided by the state rather than an independent, commercial company.
Of, for, or acting for a university.
Ordinary people in general; the community.
A section of the community having a particular interest or connection.
The people who watch or are interested in an artist, writer, or performer.
--Examples--
‘public concern’
‘public affairs’
‘a public library’
‘he was forced to withdraw from public life’
‘a public figure’
‘he wanted a public apology in the Wall Street Journal’
‘we should talk somewhere less public’
‘public spending’
‘public services’
‘public examination results’
‘the library is open to the public’
‘the general public have a right to know’
‘the reading public’
‘some famous last words to give my public’

--Word--
Publicanism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The fact or occupation of being a publican or tax-gatherer; frequently in allusion to Luke 18:10–11, and contrasted with Pharisaism. In later use also (in form publicanism): the fact or occupation of being a publican or licensee.

--Word--
utility 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The state of being useful, profitable, or beneficial.
(in game theory or economics) a measure of that which is sought to be maximized in any situation involving a choice.
An organization supplying the community with electricity, gas, water, or sewerage.
Stocks and bonds in public utilities.
A utility program.
A utility vehicle.
Useful, especially through being able to perform several functions.
Denoting a player capable of playing in several different positions in a sport.
Functional rather than attractive.
--Examples--
‘he had a poor opinion of the utility of book learning’
‘a handy utility for converting one graphics file type to another’
‘a utility truck’
‘a utility player’
‘utility clothing’

--Word--
publish 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Prepare and issue (a book, journal, or piece of music) for public sale.
Print (something) in a book or journal so as to make it generally known.
Make (content) available online.
Prepare and issue the works of (a particular writer)
Formally announce or read (an edict or marriage banns).
Communicate (a libel) to a third party.
--Examples--
‘we publish practical reference books’
‘the pressures on researchers to publish’
‘we pay £5 for every letter we publish’
‘a few hours after publishing the post I received a response from the founder of the company’
‘the photo has not been published on her Instagram account’
‘a published author’

--Examples--
‘the publishers of Vogue’
‘a commercial music publisher’
--Word--
publisheress

--Meanings--

publisher 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A company or person that prepares and issues books, journals, or music for sale.
A newspaper proprietor.

‘the publishers of Vogue’
‘a commercial music publisher’

--Examples--
--Word--
publish 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Prepare and issue (a book, journal, or piece of music) for public sale.
Print (something) in a book or journal so as to make it generally known.
Make (content) available online.
Prepare and issue the works of (a particular writer)
Formally announce or read (an edict or marriage banns).
Communicate (a libel) to a third party.
--Examples--
‘we publish practical reference books’
‘the pressures on researchers to publish’
‘we pay £5 for every letter we publish’
‘a few hours after publishing the post I received a response from the founder of the company’
‘the photo has not been published on her Instagram account’
‘a published author’
--Word--
publishing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The occupation or activity of preparing and issuing books, journals, and other material for sale.
--Examples--
‘she worked in publishing’
--Word--
publishment 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of publishing, publication; proclamation, announcement; an instance of this; (US regional, New England) the publication of banns of marriage.
--Examples--
--Word--
Statius, Publius Papinius 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.45–96 AD), Roman poet. He is best known for the Silvae, a miscellany of poems addressed to friends, and the Thebais, an epic concerning the bloody quarrel between the sons of Oedipus.

--Type--
adjective

Of, relating to, or connecting the pubis and prostate gland; specifically designating a ligament (or thickening of the pelvic fascia) extending from the pubic bone to the prostate gland and neck of the bladder.

pubovesical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or connecting the pubic bone and the bladder; specifically designating a ligament (or thickening of the pelvic fascia) connecting the pubic bone with the neck of the bladder (and with the prostate in males).

Puccini, Giacomo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1858–1924), Italian composer. Puccini's sense of the dramatic, gift for melody, and skilful use of the orchestra have contributed to his enduring popularity. Notable operas: La Bohème (1896), Tosca (1900), and Madama Butterfly (1904).
--Examples--
--Word--
Puccinia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large genus of parasitic basidiomycete fungi of the order Uredinales, many of which have several hosts and include some serious agricultural and horticultural pests (rusts); (also puccinia) a fungus of this genus, especially black stem rust of cereals, Puccinia graminis, which passes its winter stage on the leaves of barberry.
--Examples--

--Meanings--
(1961–2006) US baseball player. An outfielder for the Minnesota Twins 1984–96, he was noted for both his hitting and fielding. He helped his team to win two World Series 1987 and 1991. Baseball Hall of Fame (2001).
