--Word--
puddle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small pool of liquid, especially of rainwater on the ground.
Clay and sand mixed with water and used as a watertight covering for embankments.
A circular patch of disturbed water made by the blade of an oar at each stroke.
Wet or cover (a surface) with water, especially rainwater.
(of liquid) form a small pool.
Dabble or wallow in mud or shallow water.
Occupy oneself in a disorganized or unproductive way.
Line (a hole) with puddle.
Knead (clay and sand) into puddle.
Work (mixed water and clay) to separate gold or opal.
Stir (molten iron) with iron oxide in a furnace, to produce wrought iron by oxidizing carbon.
--Examples--
‘splashing through deep puddles’
‘a little puddle of light’
‘the cobbles under our feet were wet and puddled’
‘rivulets of water coursed down the panes, puddling on the sill’
‘children are playing and puddling about in the dirt’
‘the Internet is just the latest excuse for puddling around at work’
‘he dug and puddled a large pond’

Puebla 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state of south central Mexico.
The capital city of the state of Puebla; population 1,399,519 (2005). It lies at the edge of the central Mexican plateau at an altitude of 2,150 m (7,055 ft). Full name Puebla de Zaragoza /deɪ ˌsarəˈɡɒsə/.

noun, adjective

Relating to or denoting the Pueblo or their culture.

‘the Pueblo people’

puerilism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or condition of behaving like a child; childish behaviour or childishness; specifically (a) (in an adult) a reversion to infantile behaviour, usually as a symptom of mental disorder; (b) (in a child) the stage of normal development which follows infantilism and precedes puberty.

--Examples--
--Word--
Puerto Rico 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island of the Greater Antilles in the Caribbean; population 3,700,000 (estimated 2015); official languages, Spanish and English; capital, San Juan. One of the earliest Spanish settlements in the New World, it was ceded to the US in 1898 after the Spanish-American War, and in 1952 it became a commonwealth in voluntary association with the US, with full powers of local government.
--Examples--
--Word--
puff 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A short, explosive burst of breath or wind.
The sound of air or vapour escaping suddenly.
A small quantity of vapour or smoke, emitted in one blast.
An act of drawing quickly on a pipe, cigarette, or cigar.
Breath.
A light pastry case, typically one made of puff pastry, containing a sweet or savoury filling.
A review of a work of art, book, or theatrical production, especially an excessively complimentary one.
An advertisement, especially one exaggerating the value of the goods advertised.
A gathered mass of material in a dress or other garment.
A rolled protuberant mass of hair.
An eiderdown.
A powder puff.
Breathe in repeated short gasps.
Move with short, noisy breaths or bursts of air or steam.
Smoke a pipe, cigarette, or cigar.
Blow (dust, smoke, or a light object) with a quick breath or blast of air.
Move through the air in short bursts.
Swell or become swollen.
Be conceited.
Advertise with exaggerated or false praise.
--Examples--
‘a puff of wind swung the weathercock round’
‘the whistle and puff of steam’
‘the fire breathed out a puff of blue smoke’
‘he took a puff of his cigar’
‘after a chase of over three miles he had finally run out of puff’
‘a jam puff’
‘the publishers sent him a copy of the book hoping for a puff’
‘the distinction between a trader's puff and a statement having legal significance is a fine one’
‘extravagant statements are regarded as salesman's puff’
‘her hair was drawn up into a series of padded puffs and curves’
‘the snowy beds were piled with plump pillows and puffs’
‘she sent her a box of dusting powder with a swansdown puff’
‘exercises that make you puff’
‘the train came puffing in’
‘he puffed on his pipe contentedly’
‘he puffed out smoke through his long cigarette holder’
‘his breath puffed out like white smoke’
‘he suddenly sucked his stomach in and puffed his chest out’
‘when he was in a temper, his cheeks puffed up and his eyes shrank’
‘he was never puffed up about his writing’
‘publishers have puffed the book on the grounds that it contains new discoveries’
--Word--
puff adder 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large, sluggish, mainly nocturnal African viper which inflates the upper part of its body and hisses loudly when under threat.
--Examples--

puffback 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small black-and-white African shrike, the male of which displays by puffing up the feathers of the lower back.

noun
--Meanings--
A fungus that produces a spherical or pear-shaped fruiting body which ruptures when ripe to release a cloud of spores.
A short full skirt gathered around the hemline to produce a soft puffy shape.
--Examples--
‘she chose a multicolour puffball creation for her wedding’

adjective
--Meanings--

Swollen.

‘symptoms include puffed eyelids’
‘a dress with huge puffed sleeves’

--Word--
puff 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A short, explosive burst of breath or wind.
The sound of air or vapour escaping suddenly.
A small quantity of vapour or smoke, emitted in one blast.
An act of drawing quickly on a pipe, cigarette, or cigar.
Breath.
A light pastry case, typically one made of puff pastry, containing a sweet or savoury filling.
A review of a work of art, book, or theatrical production, especially an excessively complimentary one.
An advertisement, especially one exaggerating the value of the goods advertised.
A gathered mass of material in a dress or other garment.
A rolled protuberant mass of hair.
An eiderdown.
A powder puff.
Breathe in repeated short gasps.
Move with short, noisy breaths or bursts of air or steam.
Smoke a pipe, cigarette, or cigar.
Blow (dust, smoke, or a light object) with a quick breath or blast of air.
Move through the air in short bursts.
Swell or become swollen.
Be conceited.
Advertise with exaggerated or false praise.
--Examples--
‘a puff of wind swung the weathercock round’
‘the whistle and puff of steam’
‘the fire breathed out a puff of blue smoke’
‘he took a puff of his cigar’
‘after a chase of over three miles he had finally run out of puff’
‘a jam puff’
‘the publishers sent him a copy of the book hoping for a puff’
‘the distinction between a trader's puff and a statement having legal significance is a fine one’
‘extravagant statements are regarded as salesman's puff’
‘her hair was drawn up into a series of padded puffs and curves’
‘the snowy beds were piled with plump pillows and puffs’
‘she sent her a box of dusting powder with a swansdown puff’
‘exercises that make you puff’
‘the train came puffing in’
‘he puffed on his pipe contentedly’
‘he puffed out smoke through his long cigarette holder’
‘his breath puffed out like white smoke’
‘he suddenly sucked his stomach in and puffed his chest out’
‘when he was in a temper, his cheeks puffed up and his eyes shrank’
‘he was never puffed up about his writing’
‘publishers have puffed the book on the grounds that it contains new discoveries’
--Word--
puffy 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(especially of part of the body) unusually swollen.
Soft, rounded, and light.
(of a garment) padded or gathered to give a rounded shape.
(of wind or breath) coming in short bursts.
--Examples--
‘her eyes were puffy and full of tears’
‘small puffy clouds’
‘a puffy blue ski-jacket’
‘his breath was puffy and fast’

--Word--
pug 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
A dog of a dwarf breed like a bulldog with a broad flat nose and deeply wrinkled face.
A small, slender moth which rests with its wings stretched out to the sides.
Work (clay) into a soft, plastic condition suitable for making bricks or pottery, without air pockets.
Pack (a space) with pug, sawdust, or other material in order to deaden sound.
Pugged clay.
A boxer.
The footprint of an animal.
Track (an animal) by its footprints.
--Examples--
‘bricks set in pugged clay’
‘old-fashioned pugging with dry sand cannot be carried out’
‘a come-from-nowhere pug gets a shot at the heavyweight title’
‘I saw the pug marks of the tigress in the soft earth’
--Word--
Puget Sound 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An inlet of the Pacific on the coast of Washington State in the US. It is linked to the ocean by the Strait of Juan de Fuca.

--Word--
Pugin, Augustus Welby Northmore 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1812–52), English architect, theorist, and designer. He believed that the Gothic style was the only proper architectural style because of its origins in medieval Christian society. He is known particularly for his work on the external detail and internal fittings for the Houses of Parliament, designed by Sir Charles Barry.

--Word--
puya 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of numerous, often giant, terrestrial bromeliads constituting the genus Puya, chiefly of dry regions of the Andes, having rosettes of stiff, spiny leaves, and blue or yellow flowers borne singly or in spikes or racemes, and including P. raimondii, the largest known bromeliad. Also (in form Puya): the genus itself.

pukatea 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tall New Zealand forest tree, Laurelia novae-zelandiae (family Monimiaceae), which has glossy aromatic leaves and small racemes of tiny yellowish flowers and is noted for having plank buttresses at its base. Also: the tough pale brown wood of this tree, used for boatbuilding and furniture.

pukeweed 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Indian tobacco, Lobelia inflata, an erect, usually branched herb bearing racemes of bluish-violet or white flowers, which yields the alkaloid lobeline and was formerly used as an emetic.

--Word--
pukish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Prone to puking, queasy; (also) characteristic or reminiscent of puke or vomit, disgusting. Compare earlier "pukishness".
--Examples--
--Word--
pukish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Prone to puking, queasy; (also) characteristic or reminiscent of puke or vomit, disgusting. Compare earlier "pukishness".
--Examples--
--Word--
pukka 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Genuine.
Of or appropriate to high or respectable society.
Excellent.
--Examples--
‘the more expensive brands are pukka natural mineral waters’
‘it wouldn't be considered the pukka thing to do’
‘hey, man, that shirt's pukka’
--Word--
puku 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
An antelope with a shaggy golden-yellow coat and short thick horns, native to wetland areas of southern Africa.
A person's stomach or belly.
--Examples--
‘Uncle Pita, he had a big puku’
--Word--
pul 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A monetary unit of Afghanistan, equal to one hundredth of an afghani.
--Examples--
--Word--
pula 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The basic monetary unit of Botswana, equal to 100 thebe.
--Examples--
--Word--
palas 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tree of eastern India and Burma (Myanmar), the dhak, Butea monosperma (family Fabaceae (Leguminosae)).
--Examples--
--Word--
pulaski 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hatchet with a head that forms an axe blade on one side and an adze on the other.
--Examples--
--Word--
pulaskite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An alkali syenite containing a small proportion of nepheline.

--Meanings--

--Examples--

--Word--
pulegone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A liquid terpenoid ketone with an odour of peppermint, present in pennyroyal (Mentha pulegium) and some related plants.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who pules; one who is whining or weak. Now rare.

--Word--
pulicat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In singular and plural A type of coloured material, a length of this, or a coloured handkerchief made from this, originally from Pulicat; (hence) a material made in imitation of these, woven from dyed yarn.

Pulitzer Prize 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An award for an achievement in American journalism, literature, or music. There are thirteen made each year.

--Word--
pulk 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of sledge without runners, pulled by a person or dog and used especially to transport equipment and supplies.
--Examples--
‘the teams will endure temperatures as low as −45C as they pull their pulks towards the southernmost point on the globe’
--Word--
pulk 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of sledge without runners, pulled by a person or dog and used especially to transport equipment and supplies.
--Examples--
‘the teams will endure temperatures as low as −45C as they pull their pulks towards the southernmost point on the globe’
--Word--
pull 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Exert force on (someone or something) so as to cause movement towards oneself.
(of an animal or vehicle) be attached to the front and be the source of forward movement of (a vehicle)
(of an engine) exert propulsive force; deliver power.
Work oars to cause a boat to move.
Move in a specified direction with effort, especially by taking hold of something and exerting force.
Remove or extract (something) by grasping and exerting force on it.
Damage (a muscle, ligament, etc.) by abnormal strain.
Bring out (a weapon) for use against someone.
Draw (beer) from a barrel to serve.
Inhale deeply while smoking (a pipe, cigarette, or cigar)
Retrieve (an item of data) from the top of a stack.
Move steadily in a specified direction or manner.
Move one's body in a specified direction, especially against resistance.
Attract (someone) as a customer; cause to show interest in something.
Succeed in attracting sexually.
Carry out or achieve (something clever or duplicitous)
Cancel or withdraw (an entertainment or advertisement)
Withdraw or disqualify (a player) from a game.
Arrest.
Check the speed of (a horse), especially so as to make it lose a race.
Play (the ball) round to the leg side from the off.
Strike (the ball) in the direction of one's follow-through so that it travels to the left (or, with a left-handed player, the right).
(of a lineman) withdraw from and cross behind the line of scrimmage to block opposing players and clear the way for a runner.
Print (a proof).
An act of pulling something.
A handle to hold while pulling.
A deep draught of a drink.
An act of inhaling while smoking a pipe, cigarette, or cigar.
An act of moving steadily or with effort.
An injury to a muscle or ligament caused by abnormal strain.
A force drawing someone or something in a particular direction.
Something exerting an influence or attraction.
Ability to exercise influence.
An attempt to attract someone sexually.
(in sport) a pulling stroke.
A printer's proof.
--Examples--
‘he pulled them down on to the couch’
‘I pulled the heavy blue curtain aside’
‘I pulled the door shut behind me’
‘they are pulled in incompatible directions by external factors and their own beliefs’
‘the little boy pulled at her skirt’
‘the carriage was pulled by four horses’
‘the engine warmed up quickly and pulled well’
‘he pulled at the oars and the boat moved swiftly through the water’
‘she looked at the waves and pulled hard with her oars’
‘he pulled himself into the saddle’
‘she pulled a handkerchief out of her pocket’
‘he pulled on his boots’
‘I pulled up some onions’
‘he pulled a calf muscle in the first half of the game and had to be replaced’
‘it's not every day a young woman pulls a gun on a burglar’
‘he ordered three beers and the barman pulled them’
‘she pulled on her cigarette and blew the smoke at him’
‘the bus was about to pull away’
‘the boy pulled ahead and disappeared round the corner’
‘she tried to pull away from him’
‘anyone can enter the show if they have a good act and the ability to pull a crowd’
‘tourist attractions which pull in millions of foreign visitors’
‘I used my sense of humour to pull girls’
‘the magazine pulled its trick of producing the right issue at the right time’
‘the gig was pulled at the first sign of difficulty’
‘four of the leading eight runners were pulled’
‘I am never likely to get pulled for speeding’
‘he may be their best ever lineman—he can run and pull with the best’
‘give the hair a quick pull and it comes out by the roots’
‘the car didn't have external door handles, just pulls inside’
‘he unscrewed the cap from the flask and took another pull’
‘he took a pull on his cheroot’
‘a pull for ten minutes brought me to the summit’
‘he was ruled out of the game with a hamstring pull’
‘the pull of the water tore her away’
‘the pull of her home town was a strong one’
‘one of the pulls of urban life is the opportunity of finding employment’
‘the team might be seeded because of their pull within soccer's international body’
‘an eligible bachelor on the pull’
--Word--
pull 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Exert force on (someone or something) so as to cause movement towards oneself.
(of an animal or vehicle) be attached to the front and be the source of forward movement of (a vehicle)
(of an engine) exert propulsive force; deliver power.
Work oars to cause a boat to move.
Move in a specified direction with effort, especially by taking hold of something and exerting force.
Remove or extract (something) by grasping and exerting force on it.
Damage (a muscle, ligament, etc.) by abnormal strain.
Bring out (a weapon) for use against someone.
Draw (beer) from a barrel to serve.
Inhale deeply while smoking (a pipe, cigarette, or cigar)
Retrieve (an item of data) from the top of a stack.
Move steadily in a specified direction or manner.
Move one's body in a specified direction, especially against resistance.
Attract (someone) as a customer; cause to show interest in something.
Succeed in attracting sexually.
Carry out or achieve (something clever or duplicitous)
Cancel or withdraw (an entertainment or advertisement)
Withdraw or disqualify (a player) from a game.
Arrest.
Check the speed of (a horse), especially so as to make it lose a race.
Play (the ball) round to the leg side from the off.
Strike (the ball) in the direction of one's follow-through so that it travels to the left (or, with a left-handed player, the right).
(of a lineman) withdraw from and cross behind the line of scrimmage to block opposing players and clear the way for a runner.
Print (a proof).
An act of pulling something.
A handle to hold while pulling.
A deep draught of a drink.
An act of inhaling while smoking a pipe, cigarette, or cigar.
An act of moving steadily or with effort.
An injury to a muscle or ligament caused by abnormal strain.
A force drawing someone or something in a particular direction.
Something exerting an influence or attraction.
Ability to exercise influence.
An attempt to attract someone sexually.
(in sport) a pulling stroke.
A printer's proof.

‘I pulled the heavy blue curtain aside’
‘I pulled the door shut behind me’

‘the boy pulled ahead and disappeared round the corner’
‘she tried to pull away from him’

‘tourist attractions which pull in millions of foreign visitors’

--Word--
pull-boat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A boat propelled by pulling on a rope.
US regional (chiefly southern), a flat-bottomed boat with a small engine, used for pulling logs, especially through a swamp.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
pulley 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A wheel with a grooved rim around which a cord passes, which acts to change the direction of a force applied to the cord and is used to raise heavy weights.
A wheel or drum fixed on a shaft and turned by a belt, used for the application or transmission of power.
Hoist with a pulley.
--Examples--
‘the tree house was built on the ground and pulleyed into the branches’
--Word--
pulleyless 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Without a pulley or pulleys.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
pulicat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In singular and plural A type of coloured material, a length of this, or a coloured handkerchief made from this, originally from Pulicat; (hence) a material made in imitation of these, woven from dyed yarn.
--Examples--
--Word--
pully-hauling 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of pulling or hauling; (in extended use) an action which involves a great deal of effort but demonstrates little skill.
--Examples--
--Word--
pully-hauly 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly Nautical. The action or work of pulling and hauling; use of all one's strength; an instance of this.
--Examples--
--Word--
pull-in 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A roadside cafe.

(in sport) a pulling stroke.
A printer's proof.
--Examples--
‘he pulled them down on to the couch’
‘I pulled the heavy blue curtain aside’
‘I pulled the door shut behind me’
‘they are pulled in incompatible directions by external factors and their own beliefs’
‘the little boy pulled at her skirt’
‘the carriage was pulled by four horses’
‘the engine warmed up quickly and pulled well’
‘he pulled at the oars and the boat moved swiftly through the water’
‘she looked at the waves and pulled hard with her oars’
‘he pulled himself into the saddle’
‘she pulled a handkerchief out of her pocket’
‘he pulled on his boots’
‘I pulled up some onions’
‘he pulled a calf muscle in the first half of the game and had to be replaced’
‘it's not every day a young woman pulls a gun on a burglar’
‘he ordered three beers and the barman pulled them’
‘she pulled on her cigarette and blew the smoke at him’
‘the bus was about to pull away’
‘the boy pulled ahead and disappeared round the corner’
‘she tried to pull away from him’
‘anyone can enter the show if they have a good act and the ability to pull a crowd’
‘tourist attractions which pull in millions of foreign visitors’
‘I used my sense of humour to pull girls’
‘the magazine pulled its trick of producing the right issue at the right time’
‘the gig was pulled at the first sign of difficulty’
‘four of the leading eight runners were pulled’
‘I am never likely to get pulled for speeding’
‘he may be their best ever lineman—he can run and pull with the best’
‘give the hair a quick pull and it comes out by the roots’
‘the car didn't have external door handles, just pulls inside’
‘he unscrewed the cap from the flask and took another pull’
‘he took a pull on his cheroot’
‘a pull for ten minutes brought me to the summit’
‘he was ruled out of the game with a hamstring pull’
‘the pull of the water tore her away’
‘the pull of her home town was a strong one’
‘one of the pulls of urban life is the opportunity of finding employment’
‘the team might be seeded because of their pull within soccer's international body’
‘an eligible bachelor on the pull’
--Word--
pull-out 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of a section of a magazine, newspaper, or other publication) designed to be detached and kept.
A pull-out section of a magazine or newspaper.
A withdrawal, especially from military involvement or participation in a commercial venture.
--Examples--
‘the figures are presented in a pull-out annual report’
‘don't miss Monday's 8-page Games pull-out’
‘the peace plan was based on a pull-out from the occupied territory’

A commercial city in south-eastern Washington State, on the Palouse River, home to Washington State University; population 26,920 (est. 2008).

--Word--
pullorum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In full "pullorum disease". An acute, infectious, often fatal disease of young poultry chicks (and other young domesticated birds), caused by a type of salmonella bacterium (Salmonella enterica serovar Pullorum).
--Examples--

A withdrawal, especially from military involvement or participation in a commercial venture.

--Word--
pull 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Exert force on (someone or something) so as to cause movement towards oneself.
(of an animal or vehicle) be attached to the front and be the source of forward movement of (a vehicle)
(of an engine) exert propulsive force; deliver power.
Work oars to cause a boat to move.
Move in a specified direction with effort, especially by taking hold of something and exerting force.
Remove or extract (something) by grasping and exerting force on it.
Damage (a muscle, ligament, etc.) by abnormal strain.
Bring out (a weapon) for use against someone.
Draw (beer) from a barrel to serve.
Inhale deeply while smoking (a pipe, cigarette, or cigar)
Retrieve (an item of data) from the top of a stack.
Move steadily in a specified direction or manner.
Move one's body in a specified direction, especially against resistance.
Attract (someone) as a customer; cause to show interest in something.
Succeed in attracting sexually.
Carry out or achieve (something clever or duplicitous)
Cancel or withdraw (an entertainment or advertisement)
Withdraw or disqualify (a player) from a game.
Arrest.
Check the speed of (a horse), especially so as to make it lose a race.
Play (the ball) round to the leg side from the off.
Strike (the ball) in the direction of one's follow-through so that it travels to the left (or, with a left-handed player, the right).
(of a lineman) withdraw from and cross behind the line of scrimmage to block opposing players and clear the way for a runner.
Print (a proof).
An act of pulling something.
A handle to hold while pulling.
A deep draught of a drink.
An act of inhaling while smoking a pipe, cigarette, or cigar.
An act of moving steadily or with effort.
An injury to a muscle or ligament caused by abnormal strain.
A force drawing someone or something in a particular direction.
Something exerting an influence or attraction.
Ability to exercise influence.
An attempt to attract someone sexually.
(in sport) a pulling stroke.
A printer's proof.
--Examples--
‘he pulled them down on to the couch’
‘I pulled the heavy blue curtain aside’
‘I pulled the door shut behind me’

‘the little boy pulled at her skirt’

‘the engine warmed up quickly and pulled well’

‘she looked at the waves and pulled hard with her oars’

‘she pulled a handkerchief out of her pocket’

‘I pulled up some onions’

pull-up 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An exercise involving raising oneself with one's arms by pulling up against a horizontal bar fixed above one's head.
A disposable nappy with an elasticated waistband enabling it to be pulled up and worn like underpants, typically worn by children during potty training.

‘if the baby cannot stand, it's not yet time for pull-up nappies’

Pulmonata 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A group of molluscs which includes the land snails and slugs and many freshwater snails. They have a modified mantle cavity which acts as a lung for breathing air.

--Word--
pulp 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A soft, wet, shapeless mass of material.
The soft fleshy part of a fruit.
A soft wet mass of fibres derived from rags or wood, used in papermaking.
Vascular tissue filling the interior cavity and root canals of a tooth.
Pulverized ore mixed with water.
Popular or sensational writing that is regarded as being of poor quality.
Crush into a soft, wet, shapeless mass.
Withdraw (a publication) from the market and recycle the paper.
--Examples--
‘boiling with soda will reduce your peas to pulp’
‘the story is a mix of pulp fiction and Greek tragedy’
‘bales of waste paper were chopped, shredded, and pulped’
‘the publisher had the right to pulp all unsold copies’

--Word--
pulpit 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A raised enclosed platform in a church or chapel from which the preacher delivers a sermon.
Religious teaching as expressed in sermons.
A raised platform in the bows of a fishing boat or whaler.
A guard rail enclosing a small area at the bow of a yacht.
--Examples--
‘many ministers delivered political guidance from their pulpits’
‘the movies could rival the pulpit as an agency moulding the ideas of the mass public’
--Word--
pulpitizing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

noun
--Meanings--
The condition or quality of displaying pulsation; the degree to which something is pulsatile.
--Examples--
--Word--
pulsatilla 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant of a genus that includes the pasque flower.
--Examples--
--Word--
pulsate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Expand and contract with strong regular movements.
Produce a regular throbbing sensation or sound.
Be very exciting.
--Examples--
‘blood vessels throb and pulsate’
‘dance the night away in one of the pulsating discos’
‘victory in a pulsating semi-final’
--Word--
pulsation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
pulsational 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or characterized by pulsation.
--Examples--
--Word--
pulsation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
pulsative 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Characterized by pulsing, beating, or throbbing; = "pulsatile".
Played or produced by percussion; = "pulsatile". rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
pulsator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A device for producing a regular mechanical or electrical pulsation or oscillation.
--Examples--
‘the pulsator gently loosens tough dirt particles to give you a better wash’
--Word--
pulsator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A device for producing a regular mechanical or electrical pulsation or oscillation.
--Examples--
‘the pulsator gently loosens tough dirt particles to give you a better wash’
--Word--
pulsatory 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
pulsator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A device for producing a regular mechanical or electrical pulsation or oscillation.
--Examples--
‘the pulsator gently loosens tough dirt particles to give you a better wash’
--Word--
pulse 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A rhythmical throbbing of the arteries as blood is propelled through them, typically as felt in the wrists or neck.
Each successive throb of the arteries or heart.
A single vibration or short burst of sound, electric current, light, or other wave.
A musical beat or other regular rhythm.
The central point of energy and organization in an area or activity.
A measured amount of an isotopic label given to a culture of cells.
Throb rhythmically; pulsate.
Modulate (a wave or beam) so that it becomes a series of pulses.
Apply a pulsed signal to (a device)
--Examples--
‘the doctor found a faint pulse’
‘the idea was enough to set my pulse racing’
‘a pulse of gamma rays’
‘a pulse generator’
‘those close to the financial and economic pulse maintain that there have been fundamental changes’
‘a knot of muscles at the side of his jaw pulsed’
‘the current was pulsed’
‘pulsed outputs’
‘a loudspeaker pulsed by a capacitor discharge’
--Word--
pulse 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A rhythmical throbbing of the arteries as blood is propelled through them, typically as felt in the wrists or neck.
Each successive throb of the arteries or heart.
A single vibration or short burst of sound, electric current, light, or other wave.
A musical beat or other regular rhythm.
The central point of energy and organization in an area or activity.
A measured amount of an isotopic label given to a culture of cells.
Throb rhythmically; pulsate.
Modulate (a wave or beam) so that it becomes a series of pulses.
Apply a pulsed signal to (a device)
--Examples--
‘the doctor found a faint pulse’
‘the idea was enough to set my pulse racing’
‘a pulse of gamma rays’
‘a pulse generator’
‘those close to the financial and economic pulse maintain that there have been fundamental changes’
‘a knot of muscles at the side of his jaw pulsed’
‘the current was pulsed’
‘pulsed outputs’
‘a loudspeaker pulsed by a capacitor discharge’
--Word--
pulse jet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of jet engine in which combustion is intermittent, the ignition and expulsion of each charge of mixture causing the intake of a fresh charge.
--Examples--
--Word--
pulse jet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of jet engine in which combustion is intermittent, the ignition and expulsion of each charge of mixture causing the intake of a fresh charge.

--Word--
pulse 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A rhythmical throbbing of the arteries as blood is propelled through them, typically as felt in the wrists or neck.
Each successive throb of the arteries or heart.
A single vibration or short burst of sound, electric current, light, or other wave.
A musical beat or other regular rhythm.
The central point of energy and organization in an area or activity.
A measured amount of an isotopic label given to a culture of cells.
Throb rhythmically; pulsate.
Modulate (a wave or beam) so that it becomes a series of pulses.
Apply a pulsed signal to (a device)
--Examples--
‘the doctor found a faint pulse’
‘the idea was enough to set my pulse racing’
‘a pulse of gamma rays’
‘a pulse generator’
‘those close to the financial and economic pulse maintain that there have been fundamental changes’
‘a knot of muscles at the side of his jaw pulsed’
‘the current was pulsed’
‘pulsed outputs’
‘a loudspeaker pulsed by a capacitor discharge’

adjective

--Meanings--

--Word--
pulsion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or an act of driving or pushing. Now rare.
Psychoanalysis. An unconscious drive or impulse influencing the development of human personality.
--Examples--
--Word--
pulsion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or an act of driving or pushing. Now rare.
Psychoanalysis. An unconscious drive or impulse influencing the development of human personality.
--Examples--
--Word--
pulsive 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having the quality of driving or impelling; constraining, compelling; impulsive; propulsive. Now rare.
Making or having a beating or throbbing sound.
--Examples--
--Word--
pulsometer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Medicine. An instrument for measuring the (rate of the) pulse.
More fully "pulsometer pump". A kind of vacuum pump with two chambers into which steam enters and condenses, creating a partial vacuum which draws water, etc., up into the chambers, one being filled while the other is emptied.
--Examples--
--Word--
pultaceous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Chiefly Medicine. Of the nature or consistency of pap; soft, semi-fluid, pulpy.
--Examples--
--Word--
pultan 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In India: a regiment of infantry (now historical).
--Examples--
--Word--
pulu 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A soft brownish silky fibre obtained from several Hawaiian tree ferns, formerly used to stuff mattresses and cushions. Also (more fully "pulu fern", "pulu tree"): any of these tree ferns, especially Cibotium glaucum.
--Examples--

pulverate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To reduce to powder; to pulverize. In later use chiefly figurative (US informal): to defeat soundly, to demolish; to thrash.

pulvillus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
pulvinar 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Roman History. The imperial seat in a Roman circus.
A cushion-like prominence in the brain occupying the posterior end of the thalamus.
Of or relating to a pulvinus.
--Examples--
--Word--
pulvinate 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Chiefly Botany and Entomology. Resembling a cushion in shape, moderately convex.
Botany. Of a leaf or leaflet: having a pulvinus; = pulvinated.
--Examples--
--Word--
pulvinated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Rounded, bulging (rare); (Architecture, of a frieze) having a convex face.
Botany. Of a leaf or leaflet: = pulvinate.
--Examples--
--Word--
pulvinately 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a pulvinate form; with a tendency towards a convex shape.
--Examples--
--Word--
pulvinus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An enlarged section at the base of a leaf stalk in some plants, which is subject to changes of rigidity leading to movements of the leaf or leaflet.

adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling a cushion in shape; bulging, convex; = pulvinate.

pulvino 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

pulvinule 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Botany. An enlargement at the base of a petiolule; a small pulvinus.

--Word--
pulvinulus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Botany. In certain lichens, especially ones of the genus Parmelia: any of a number of spongy, sometimes highly branched, outgrowths arising from the thallus. rare.
Botany= pulvinule. rare.

--Word--
pumice 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A very light and porous volcanic rock formed when a gas-rich froth of glassy lava solidifies rapidly.
A piece of pumice used as an abrasive, especially for removing hard skin.
Rub with pumice to smooth or clean.
--Examples--

--Word--
pumicite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A volcanic ash with a composition similar to pumice but deposited as powder or granules, widely used in the manufacture of lightweight concrete and for its abrasive properties; unconsolidated volcanic ash.
--Examples--
--Word--
pumicite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A volcanic ash with a composition similar to pumice but deposited as powder or granules, widely used in the manufacture of lightweight concrete and for its abrasive properties; unconsolidated volcanic ash.

--Word--
pump 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A mechanical device using suction or pressure to raise or move liquids, compress gases, or force air into inflatable objects such as tyres.
An instance of moving something by or as if by a pump.
An active transport mechanism in living cells by which specific ions are moved through the cell membrane against a concentration gradient.
A pump-action shotgun.
Force (liquid, gas, etc.) to move by or as if by means of a pump.
Move in spurts as though driven by a pump.
Draw (milk) from the breast using a breast pump, typically in order to feed a baby by means of a bottle.
Fill (something such as a tyre or balloon) with liquid or gas using a pump.
Shoot (bullets) into (a target)
Very enthusiastic or excited.
Move vigorously up and down.
Apply and release (a brake pedal or lever) several times in quick succession, typically to prevent skidding.
Try to elicit information from (someone) by persistent questioning.
--Examples--
‘a petrol pump’
‘the pump of blood to her heart’
‘the bacterium's sodium pump’
‘the shotgun was a 12-gauge pump’
‘the blood is pumped around the body’
‘blood was pumping from a wound in his shoulder’
‘she struggled with pumping enough milk’
‘I've exclusively pumped for my youngest’
‘I fetched the bike and pumped up the back tyre’
‘my veins had been pumped full of glucose’
‘he pumped two shots into the van's front tyre’
‘the team came out really pumped up’
‘we had to pump the handle like mad’
‘that's superb running—look at his legs pumping’
‘the school teaches its students to brake by pumping the pedal’
‘she began to pump her friend for details’
--Word--
pumpable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Able to be pumped, capable of being pumped.
--Examples--
--Word--
pump-action 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Denoting a repeating firearm in which a new round is brought from the magazine into the breech by a slide action in line with the barrel.
Denoting an unpressurized spray dispenser for liquid that is worked by finger action rather than by internal pressure (as in an aerosol)
--Examples--
‘a pump-action shotgun’
‘a preference for pump-action sprays and roll-on applicators’
--Word--
pumpage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A quantity of liquid pumped, especially a quantity of water pumped from an underground source.
--Examples--
--Word--
pump 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A mechanical device using suction or pressure to raise or move liquids, compress gases, or force air into inflatable objects such as tyres.

Shoot (bullets) into (a target)
Very enthusiastic or excited.
Move vigorously up and down.

--Examples--

‘the pump of blood to her heart’
‘the bacterium's sodium pump’

‘blood was pumping from a wound in his shoulder’

‘the team came out really pumped up’
‘we had to pump the handle like mad’
‘that's superb running—look at his legs pumping’
‘the school teaches its students to brake by pumping the pedal’
‘she began to pump her friend for details’
--Word--
pumpellyite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mineral, or group of minerals resembling epidote in structure, which occur as colourless, greenish, or brown crystals and are characteristic of some low-grade metamorphic rocks.
--Examples--

--Word--
handler 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who handles or deals with certain articles or commodities.
A device which handles certain articles or substances.
A person who trains or has charge of an animal, in particular a police officer in charge of a dog.
A person who trains or manages another person.
A person who trains and acts as second to a boxer.
A publicity agent.
A person who directs the activities of a spy or other freelance agent.
--Examples--
‘a baggage handler’
‘a food handler’
‘the company launched three telescopic handlers’
--Word--
pump 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A mechanical device using suction or pressure to raise or move liquids, compress gases, or force air into inflatable objects such as tyres.
An instance of moving something by or as if by a pump.
An active transport mechanism in living cells by which specific ions are moved through the cell membrane against a concentration gradient.
A pump-action shotgun.

Move in spurts as though driven by a pump.
Draw (milk) from the breast using a breast pump, typically in order to feed a baby by means of a bottle.
Fill (something such as a tyre or balloon) with liquid or gas using a pump.
Shoot (bullets) into (a target)
Very enthusiastic or excited.
Move vigorously up and down.
Apply and release (a brake pedal or lever) several times in quick succession, typically to prevent skidding.
Try to elicit information from (someone) by persistent questioning.
--Examples--
‘a petrol pump’
‘the pump of blood to her heart’
‘the bacterium's sodium pump’
‘the shotgun was a 12-gauge pump’
‘the blood is pumped around the body’
‘blood was pumping from a wound in his shoulder’
‘she struggled with pumping enough milk’
‘I've exclusively pumped for my youngest’
‘I fetched the bike and pumped up the back tyre’
‘my veins had been pumped full of glucose’
‘he pumped two shots into the van's front tyre’
‘the team came out really pumped up’
‘we had to pump the handle like mad’
‘that's superb running—look at his legs pumping’
‘the school teaches its students to brake by pumping the pedal’
‘she began to pump her friend for details’
--Word--
pumpkin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large rounded orange-yellow fruit with a thick rind, the flesh of which can be used in sweet or savoury dishes.
Used as an affectionate term of address, especially to a child.
The plant of the gourd family that produces pumpkins, having tendrils and large lobed leaves and native to warm regions of America.
--Examples--
‘listen, pumpkin, I thought you ought to know’

--Meanings--

--Word--
pumpkinification 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Transformation into a pumpkin; used especially with reference to the elevation to divine status of the Roman emperor Claudius. Hence allusively: extravagant or absurdly uncritical glorification; an instance of this.
--Examples--

pumpkinish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling or akin to a pumpkin.
--Examples--

pumpkinity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The nature, quality, or condition of a pumpkin.

pumpkinseed 
--Type--

--Word--
pump 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A mechanical device using suction or pressure to raise or move liquids, compress gases, or force air into inflatable objects such as tyres.
An instance of moving something by or as if by a pump.
An active transport mechanism in living cells by which specific ions are moved through the cell membrane against a concentration gradient.
A pump-action shotgun.
Force (liquid, gas, etc.) to move by or as if by means of a pump.
Move in spurts as though driven by a pump.
Draw (milk) from the breast using a breast pump, typically in order to feed a baby by means of a bottle.
Fill (something such as a tyre or balloon) with liquid or gas using a pump.
Shoot (bullets) into (a target)
Very enthusiastic or excited.
Move vigorously up and down.
Apply and release (a brake pedal or lever) several times in quick succession, typically to prevent skidding.
Try to elicit information from (someone) by persistent questioning.
--Examples--
‘a petrol pump’
‘the pump of blood to her heart’
‘the bacterium's sodium pump’
‘the shotgun was a 12-gauge pump’
‘the blood is pumped around the body’
‘blood was pumping from a wound in his shoulder’
‘she struggled with pumping enough milk’
‘I've exclusively pumped for my youngest’
‘I fetched the bike and pumped up the back tyre’
‘my veins had been pumped full of glucose’
‘he pumped two shots into the van's front tyre’
‘the team came out really pumped up’
‘we had to pump the handle like mad’
‘that's superb running—look at his legs pumping’
‘the school teaches its students to brake by pumping the pedal’
‘she began to pump her friend for details’

pun 
--Type--
noun, verb, verb
--Meanings--
A joke exploiting the different possible meanings of a word or the fact that there are words which sound alike but have different meanings.
Make a pun.
Consolidate (earth or rubble) by pounding it.
--Examples--
‘the Railway Society reception was an informal party of people of all stations (excuse the pun) in life’
‘Freeth adopted the nickname Free in punning allusion to his beliefs’
‘the designer is punning on the street name’

--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--

punch 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Strike with the fist.
Press (a button or key on a machine)
Enter information by punching a button or key on a machine.
Drive (cattle) by prodding them with a stick.
A blow with the fist.
The strength needed to deliver a blow.
The power to impress or attract attention; impact.
--Examples--
‘he punched her in the face and ran off’
‘I punched the button to summon the lift’
‘he crossed to the VDU on his other desk and punched in a series of numbers’
‘he reeled under the well-aimed punch’
‘he has the punch to knock out anyone in his division’
‘photos give their arguments an extra visual punch’

--Word--
punctuation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The marks, such as full stop, comma, and brackets, used in writing to separate sentences and their elements and to clarify meaning.
Rapid or sudden speciation, as suggested by the theory of punctuated equilibrium.
--Examples--
‘you will notice that no punctuation is used’
‘satisfactory standards of handwriting, spelling, grammar, and punctuation’

punctuational 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--

punctuationist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who believes in or advocates the hypothesis of punctuated equilibrium.
--Examples--
--Word--
punctuative 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or serving as punctuation in text or speech.
--Examples--
--Word--
punctuator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
With reference to Semitic writing systems: a person who inserts points indicating vowel and accentuation signs; especially a person who was the first to do this, as, in Hebrew, any of the Masoretes.
A person who inserts punctuation marks into text; a user of punctuation.
--Examples--
--Word--
punctulate 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Marked or studded with tiny dots or puncta; minutely punctate.
To mark with small points or dots. Usually in pass. Compare punctulated.
--Examples--
--Word--
punctulated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Marked or studded with small dots; = punctulate. Compare punctulate. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
punctulation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The condition of being punctulate; minute punctation. Also concrete: (each of) the tiny dots or puncta on a punctulate object or surface.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

A small, distinct point.

--Word--
puncturation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or an act of puncturing or pricking something. Formerly also: †a puncture, a prick (obsolete).
Chiefly Entomology. The condition of being marked with dots, pits, or punctures; = "punctation".
--Examples--
--Word--
puncture 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small hole in a tyre resulting in an escape of air.
A small hole in something such as the skin, caused by a sharp object.
Make a puncture in (something)
Sustain a puncture.
Cause a sudden collapse of (mood or feeling)
--Examples--
‘she was on her way home when she had a puncture’
‘a puncture wound’
‘one of the knife blows had punctured a lung’
‘the tyre had punctured and it would have to be replaced’
‘the earlier mood of optimism was punctured’

punctus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In medieval (originally liturgical) manuscripts: a point used to indicate a short pause or minor break; also called punctum.

Pune 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An industrial city in Maharashtra, western India, in the hills south-east of Mumbai (Bombay); population 3,337,500 (est. 2009). It was a military and administrative centre under British rule.
--Examples--
--Word--
pung 
--Type--
noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
A sleigh or sledge with a boxlike body, typically drawn by a single horse and used for carrying light loads.
A set of three identical tiles; the action of completing such a set in one's hand. Also occasionally as interjection: announcing this action to other players.
To take a discarded tile to complete a set of three identical tiles. Also with object: to pick up (a discarded tile) to make a set of three.
--Examples--
--Word--
ponga 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tree fern found in forests throughout New Zealand.
--Examples--
--Word--
pungy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of boat; especially a small keel schooner used in harvesting oysters.

--Word--
pungent 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a sharply strong taste or smell.
(of comment, criticism, or humour) having a sharp and caustic quality.
--Examples--
‘the pungent smell of frying onions’
‘he has expressed some fairly pungent criticisms’

--Word--
punicin 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
An alkaloid isolated from the root of the pomegranate tree, Punica granatum, found to be identical to pelletierine.
A purple colouring matter extracted from glands of molluscs of the genus Purpura and later identified as a bromine derivative of indigo.
--Examples--
--Word--
punicin 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
An alkaloid isolated from the root of the pomegranate tree, Punica granatum, found to be identical to pelletierine.
A purple colouring matter extracted from glands of molluscs of the genus Purpura and later identified as a bromine derivative of indigo.

--Word--
punish 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Inflict a penalty or sanction on (someone) as retribution for an offence, especially a transgression of a legal or moral code.
Inflict a penalty or sanction on someone for (such an offence)
Capitalize on (an opponent's mistake), especially in sport.
Treat (someone) in an unfairly harsh way.
Subject to severe and debilitating treatment.
--Examples--
‘I have done wrong and I'm being punished for it’
‘fraudulent acts would be punished by up to two years in prison’
‘Australia punished Ireland's handling blunders and scored three tries’
‘a rise in prescription charges would punish the poor’
--Word--
punishability 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The fact or quality of being punishable.
--Examples--

punishment 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The infliction or imposition of a penalty as retribution for an offence.

Rough treatment or handling.
--Examples--
‘crime demands just punishment’
‘she assisted her husband to escape punishment for the crime’
‘he approved of stiff punishments for criminals’
‘your machine can take a fair amount of punishment before falling to bits’

--Word--
Punjab 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A region of north-western India and Pakistan, a wide, fertile plain traversed by the River Indus and the five tributaries which gave the region its name.
A province of Pakistan; capital, Lahore.
A state of India; capital, Chandigarh. Until 1966 the Punjab also encompassed what is now the state of Haryana.
--Examples--
--Word--
Punjabi 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of the region of Punjab.
An Indic language spoken mainly in north-western India and eastern Pakistan.
A long kurta (loose collarless shirt).
Relating to Punjab or its people or language.
--Examples--
--Word--
punk 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A loud, fast-moving, and aggressive form of rock music, popular in the late 1970s.
An admirer or player of punk rock, typically characterized by coloured spiked hair and clothing decorated with safety pins or zips.
A worthless person (often used as a general term of abuse)
A criminal or thug.
(in prison slang) a passive male homosexual.
An inexperienced young person.
Soft, crumbly wood that has been attacked by fungus, used as tinder.
Relating to punk rock and its associated subculture.
In poor condition.
Trick or deceive.
(chiefly in sport) defeat utterly.
--Examples--
‘punk had turned pop music and its attendant culture on its head’
‘punks fought Teds on the Kings Road on Saturday afternoons’
‘you think any of these punks they got fighting today could stand up to Joe Louis?’
‘there's never been a better time to take our streets back from the punks’
‘he determined to be made into no one's punk’
‘you were a nobody, a punk kid starting out’
‘a punk band’
‘a punk haircut’
‘I felt too punk to eat’
‘the Associated Press got punked with a fake tweet’
‘his friends punked him and told him that she was having a party, which is why he showed up unannounced’
‘the Tigers punked the Sooners 40–6’
--Word--
punkah 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in India) a large cloth fan on a frame suspended from the ceiling, moved backwards and forwards by pulling on a cord.
An electric fan.
--Examples--
‘the punkah wallah fell asleep over his task’
--Word--

punky 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Characterized by or resembling punk rock music.
Resembling an admirer or player of punk rock in appearance or attitude.
(of a person) worthless.
--Examples--
‘a punky pop band’
‘rock and blues with a punky edge’
‘punky chicks’
‘Kelly's punky little brother’
--Word--
punkie 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A biting midge of the family Ceratopogonidae; a no-see-um.
A lantern made by setting a candle in a hollowed-out mangel-wurzel or similar vegetable.

punk 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A loud, fast-moving, and aggressive form of rock music, popular in the late 1970s.
An admirer or player of punk rock, typically characterized by coloured spiked hair and clothing decorated with safety pins or zips.
A worthless person (often used as a general term of abuse)
A criminal or thug.
(in prison slang) a passive male homosexual.
An inexperienced young person.
Soft, crumbly wood that has been attacked by fungus, used as tinder.
Relating to punk rock and its associated subculture.
In poor condition.
Trick or deceive.
(chiefly in sport) defeat utterly.
--Examples--
‘punk had turned pop music and its attendant culture on its head’
‘punks fought Teds on the Kings Road on Saturday afternoons’
‘you think any of these punks they got fighting today could stand up to Joe Louis?’
‘there's never been a better time to take our streets back from the punks’

--Word--
punnable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a word or name: on which puns can be made; suitable as a subject for punning.
--Examples--
--Word--
pun 
--Type--
noun, verb, verb
--Meanings--
A joke exploiting the different possible meanings of a word or the fact that there are words which sound alike but have different meanings.
Make a pun.
Consolidate (earth or rubble) by pounding it.
--Examples--
‘the Railway Society reception was an informal party of people of all stations (excuse the pun) in life’
‘Freeth adopted the nickname Free in punning allusion to his beliefs’
‘the designer is punning on the street name’

--Word--
punt 
--Type--
noun, verb, verb, noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A long, narrow flat-bottomed boat, square at both ends and propelled with a long pole, used on inland waters chiefly for recreation.
Travel or convey in a punt.
Kick (the ball) a long distance upfield.
Kick the ball after it has dropped from the hands and before it reaches the ground.
An act of punting a ball.
(in some gambling card games) lay a stake against the bank.
Bet or speculate on something.
A bet.
--Examples--
‘in summer you can enjoy punting along the river’
‘the Leeds player kindly punted the ball back to them’
‘he used to be able to punt a football farther than anyone’
‘the Raiders could get nowhere with their possession, and had to punt’
‘Wood failed to cut out a long punt from Nicholas’
‘investors are punting on a takeover’
‘those taking a punt on the company's success’
--Word--
punta riversa 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A thrust made with the point of the sword and typically delivered from the executant's left side with the palm up.
--Examples--
--Word--
puntabout 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of kicking a rugby ball about for practice; an instance of this. Also (chiefly Rugby School): a ball used for this (now historical).
--Examples--
--Word--
Puntal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A defensive fortification at the entrance to the harbour at Cadiz (originally consisting of a blockhouse erected on a point of sand); a similar fortification elsewhere.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
punter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who gambles, places a bet, or makes a risky investment.
A customer or client, especially a member of an audience.
A prostitute's client.
A player who punts.
A person who propels or travels in a punt.
--Examples--

punt 
--Type--
noun, verb, verb, noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A long, narrow flat-bottomed boat, square at both ends and propelled with a long pole, used on inland waters chiefly for recreation.
Travel or convey in a punt.
Kick (the ball) a long distance upfield.
Kick the ball after it has dropped from the hands and before it reaches the ground.
An act of punting a ball.
(in some gambling card games) lay a stake against the bank.
Bet or speculate on something.
A bet.
--Examples--
‘in summer you can enjoy punting along the river’
‘the Leeds player kindly punted the ball back to them’
‘he used to be able to punt a football farther than anyone’
‘the Raiders could get nowhere with their possession, and had to punt’
‘Wood failed to cut out a long punt from Nicholas’
‘investors are punting on a takeover’
‘those taking a punt on the company's success’
--Word--
punto 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Glass-making. = "pontil". Now rare (historical in later use).
A thrust with the point of the sword.
In ombre and quadrille: the ace of trumps when trumps are either hearts or diamonds.
--Examples--
--Word--

puntsman 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who propels or handles a punt, or (especially in earlier use) who goes fishing or shooting in a punt.
--Examples--
--Word--
Punxsutawney 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A borough in west central Pennsylvania, the home of Punxsutawney Phil, a groundhog whose movements are closely observed by the media each February 2 in order to predict the length of winter.
--Examples--
--Word--
pup 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A young dog.
A young wolf, seal, rat, or other mammal.
A cheeky or arrogant boy or young man.
(of bitches and certain other female animals) give birth to young.
--Examples--
‘you saucy young pup!’
‘our Doberman just pupped’
‘pupping females’
--Word--
pupa 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An insect in its inactive immature form between larva and adult, e.g. a chrysalis.
--Examples--

puparium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The hardened last larval skin which encloses the pupa in some insects, especially higher diptera.
A pupa enclosed in a puparium.
--Examples--
--Word--
puparial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to a puparium; (more generally) pupal.

--Word--
pupiform 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling the pupa of an insect; especially (of a gastropod shell or protoconch) somewhat cylindrical and bluntly rounded.
--Examples--
--Word--
pupil 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A person who is taught by another, especially a schoolchild or student in relation to a teacher.
A trainee barrister.
The dark circular opening in the centre of the iris of the eye, which varies in size to regulate the amount of light reaching the retina.
--Examples--
‘they are former pupils of the school’
‘will you take me on as your pupil?’
--Word--
pupillizing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of teaching a pupil or pupils; tutoring.
--Examples--
--Word--
pupillage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state of being a pupil or student.
(in the UK) apprenticeship to a member of the Bar, which qualifies a barrister to practise independently.
--Examples--
‘Mr Nash asked for information on pupillage’
‘he began a three-year pupillage’
‘the first six months of pupillage’
‘a few chambers will grant pupillages by open competition’
--Word--

--Meanings--

--Word--
pupillarity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Civil Law and Scottish Law. The state of being below the legal age of puberty; the period during which a person remains in this state. Compare "pupil". Now chiefly historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
pupildom 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= pupilhood.
--Examples--
--Word--
pupilled 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Entomology. Having an ocellated eyespot with a contrasting central spot resembling the pupil of an eye; (of an eyespot) having a central pupil (sometimes, of a specified colour). Now rare.
With modifying word: designating or having eyes with pupils of a specified type.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of teaching a pupil or pupils; tutoring.

--Word--
Pupipara 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Treated as plural. A group of dipteran flies comprising bloodsucking parasites of mammals and birds which produce fully-developed young which immediately pupariate; insects of this group (collectively or individually).
--Examples--
--Word--
pupiparous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of certain flies, e.g. the tsetse) producing young which are already ready to pupate.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
= pupiform.

--Word--
puppet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A movable model of a person or animal that is typically moved either by strings controlled from above or by a hand inside it.
A person, group, or country under the control of another.
--Examples--
‘a puppet show’
‘a former revolutionary hero who is now a puppet of the state’

puppetry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The art of operating puppets, typically either by strings controlled from above or by hand.

‘the leadership is phony with their religio-political puppetry’

--Word--
Puppis 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A southern constellation (the Poop or Stern), lying partly in the Milky Way south of Canis Major and originally part of Argo.
Used with preceding letter or numeral to designate a star in the constellation Puppis.
--Examples--
‘the star Zeta Puppis’

Purana 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a class of Sanskrit sacred writings on Hindu mythology and folklore of varying date and origin, the most ancient of which dates from the 4th century AD.
--Examples--
--Word--
Purana 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a class of Sanskrit sacred writings on Hindu mythology and folklore of varying date and origin, the most ancient of which dates from the 4th century AD.

--Word--
Puranic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
purau 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "purau tree". In certain Polynesian islands: an evergreen shrub or small tree, Hibiscus tiliaceus (family Malvaceae), occurring widely in littoral regions of the tropics, which has pale yellow flowers turning deep red with age, and an inner bark which yields a useful fibre. Frequently attributive Compare "hau".
--Examples--
--Word--
Purbeck marble 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hard limestone from Purbeck in Dorset, which is polished and used for decorative parts of buildings, fonts, and effigies.
--Examples--
--Word--
Purbeckian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A stage in the British Upper Jurassic and Lower Cretaceous, above the Portlandian and below the Wealden, represented by prominent strata at Purbeck.
Of, relating to, or designating the Purbeckian stage.
--Examples--
--Word--
purblind 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having impaired or defective vision; partially blind.
Slow or unable to understand; dim-witted.
--Examples--
‘something is fundamentally wrong, as even the most purblind apologists must surely come to recognize’

purblindness

--Examples--
--Word--
Purcell, Henry 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1659–95), English composer. Organist for Westminster Abbey (1679–95), he composed choral odes and songs for royal occasions. His main interest was music for the theatre; he composed the first English opera Dido and Aeneas (1689) and incidental music for many plays.
--Examples--
--Word--
purchasability 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of being purchasable; the capacity to be bought. In extended use (of a person): the capacity to be bribed.
--Examples--
--Word--
purchasable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
purchase 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Acquire (something) by paying for it; buy.
Obtain or achieve with effort or suffering.
Haul up (a rope, cable, or anchor) by means of a pulley or lever.
The action of buying something.
A thing that has been bought.
The acquisition of property by one's personal action rather than by inheritance.
The annual rent or return from land.
Firm contact or grip.
A pulley or similar device for moving heavy objects.
--Examples--
‘Mr Gill spotted the manuscript at a local auction and purchased it for £1,500’
‘the victory was purchased by the death of Rhiwallon’
‘the large number of videos currently available for purchase’
‘she made her purchases carefully’
‘she stowed her purchases in the car’
‘a lease valued at seven year's purchase’
‘the horse's hooves fought for purchase on the slippery pavement’
‘an attempt to gain a purchase on the soft earth’

--Word--
purdah 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The practice in certain Muslim and Hindu societies of screening women from men or strangers, especially by means of a curtain.
A curtain used for the purpose of purdah.
A state of seclusion or secrecy.
The period leading up to an election, during which government departments generally refrain from making any new announcements.
--Examples--
‘he never required them to observe purdah’
‘she was supposed to be in purdah upstairs’
‘the supermarket's own self-imposed purdah on the GM issue’
‘expect the lawyers to re-emerge from their temporary purdah when the legislation is published’
‘it is very difficult at the moment with the election on and the government in purdah’
--Word--
purdah 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The practice in certain Muslim and Hindu societies of screening women from men or strangers, especially by means of a curtain.
A curtain used for the purpose of purdah.
A state of seclusion or secrecy.
The period leading up to an election, during which government departments generally refrain from making any new announcements.
--Examples--
‘he never required them to observe purdah’
‘she was supposed to be in purdah upstairs’
‘the supermarket's own self-imposed purdah on the GM issue’
‘expect the lawyers to re-emerge from their temporary purdah when the legislation is published’
‘it is very difficult at the moment with the election on and the government in purdah’

purty

--Examples--

‘it was a purdy terrific day’
--Word--
pure 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Not mixed or adulterated with any other substance or material.
Without any extraneous and unnecessary elements.
Free of any contamination.
(of an animal or plant) of unmixed origin or descent; pedigree.
(of a sound) perfectly in tune and with a clear tone.
Wholesome and untainted by immorality, especially that of a sexual nature.
(of a subject of study) dealing with abstract concepts and not practical application.
Involving or containing nothing else but; sheer (used for emphasis)
(of a vowel) not joined with another to form a diphthong.
--Examples--
‘cars can run on pure alcohol’
‘the jacket was pure wool’
‘the romantic notion of pure art devoid of social responsibility’
‘the pure, clear waters of Scotland’
‘the pure Charolais is white or light wheat in the coat’
‘80 pure-bred stallions were on parade’
‘these small cymbals produce a quiet but high pitched and very pure note’
‘our fondness for each other is pure and innocent’
‘a theoretical discipline such as pure physics’
‘a shout of pure anger’
‘an outcome which may be a matter of pure chance’
‘it was revenge, pure and simple’

--Word--
purge 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Rid (someone) of an unwanted feeling, memory, or condition.
Free someone from (an unwanted feeling, memory, etc.)
Remove (a group of people considered undesirable) from an organization or place in an abrupt or violent way.
Remove a group of undesirable people from (an organization or place) in an abrupt or violent way.
Atone for or wipe out (contempt of court)
Physically remove (something) completely.
Evacuate one's bowels, especially as a result of taking a laxative.
An abrupt or violent removal of a group of people.
A laxative.
--Examples--
‘Bob had helped purge Martha of the terrible guilt that had haunted her’
‘his hatred was purged’
‘he purged all but 26 of the central committee members’
‘an opportunity to purge the party of unsatisfactory members’
‘he has a right to apply to the court to purge his contempt’
‘a substance designed to purge impurities from the body’
‘sufferers eat normally in summer but overeat and purge during winter’
‘occasional binges are followed by self-induced purging or vomiting’
‘the savagery of government's political purges’
‘in this plant was a milky substance which was a drastic purge’

--Word--
purism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Scrupulous or exaggerated observance of or insistence on traditional rules or structures, especially in language or style.
An early 20th-century artistic style and movement founded by Le Corbusier and the French painter Amédée Ozenfant (1886–1966) and emphasizing purity of geometric form. It arose out of a rejection of cubism and was characterized by a return to the representation of recognizable objects.
--Examples--
‘Mrs Grundy's name is now synonymous with narrow linguistic purism’
--Word--
purism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Scrupulous or exaggerated observance of or insistence on traditional rules or structures, especially in language or style.
An early 20th-century artistic style and movement founded by Le Corbusier and the French painter Amédée Ozenfant (1886–1966) and emphasizing purity of geometric form. It arose out of a rejection of cubism and was characterized by a return to the representation of recognizable objects.
--Examples--
‘Mrs Grundy's name is now synonymous with narrow linguistic purism’

--Examples--
‘the production has yet to offend Gilbert and Sullivan purists’
‘purist fans of the original comic strip’
‘Purist painters’

--Word--
puritan 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a group of English Protestants of the late 16th and 17th centuries who regarded the Reformation of the Church under Elizabeth I as incomplete and sought to simplify and regulate forms of worship.
A person with censorious moral beliefs, especially about self-indulgence and sex.
Relating to the Puritans.
Having or displaying censorious moral beliefs, especially about self-indulgence and sex.
--Examples--
‘my mother was a puritan about sex’
‘don't be such a puritan’
‘a Puritan parliamentarian’
‘he was of Puritan stock’
‘as the puritan ethic has weakened, hedonism has replaced it’
‘a puritan conscience’

--Word--
puritanism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The beliefs or principles of a group of English Protestants of the late 16th and 17th centuries who regarded the Reformation of the Church under Elizabeth I as incomplete and sought to simplify and regulate forms of worship.
Censorious moral beliefs, especially about self-indulgence and sex.
--Examples--
‘an era of sexual puritanism’
‘the extreme puritanism of the hardliners grated on people’

noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a group of English Protestants of the late 16th and 17th centuries who regarded the Reformation of the Church under Elizabeth I as incomplete and sought to simplify and regulate forms of worship.
A person with censorious moral beliefs, especially about self-indulgence and sex.
Relating to the Puritans.
Having or displaying censorious moral beliefs, especially about self-indulgence and sex.
--Examples--
‘my mother was a puritan about sex’
‘don't be such a puritan’
‘a Puritan parliamentarian’
‘he was of Puritan stock’
‘as the puritan ethic has weakened, hedonism has replaced it’
‘a puritan conscience’
--Word--
purity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Freedom from adulteration or contamination.
Freedom from immorality, especially of a sexual nature.
--Examples--
‘the purity of our drinking water’
‘white roses represent purity and innocence’
--Word--

--Type--
noun

--Word--
purl 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Denoting or relating to a knitting stitch made by putting the needle through the front of the stitch from right to left.
Knit with a purl stitch.
A cord of twisted gold or silver wire used for bordering or edging something.
An ornamental edging of lace or ribbon.
(of a stream or river) flow with a swirling motion and babbling sound.
A purling motion or sound.
--Examples--
‘knit one, purl one’
‘large stones stood blackly in the water, making it purl as it rolled around them’
‘it was quiet except for the liquid purl of the fountain’
--Word--
purl 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--

Knit with a purl stitch.

‘knit one, purl one’
‘large stones stood blackly in the water, making it purl as it rolled around them’

--Word--
purler 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A headlong fall.
--Examples--
‘the horse went a purler at the last fence’
--Word--
purlicue 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the Presbyterian churches: a recapitulation of sermons or addresses previously delivered. Also: an exhortation traditionally delivered at the close of a sermon. See also quot. 1825. Now historical.
Originally English regional (northern). The space between a person's extended forefinger and thumb. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
purlicue 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the Presbyterian churches: a recapitulation of sermons or addresses previously delivered. Also: an exhortation traditionally delivered at the close of a sermon. See also quot. 1825. Now historical.
Originally English regional (northern). The space between a person's extended forefinger and thumb. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
purlieu 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The area near or surrounding a place.
A person's usual haunts.
A tract on the border of a forest, especially one earlier included in it and still partly subject to forest laws.
--Examples--
‘the photogenic purlieus of Cambridge’
‘they wished the purlieus to be completely free from the Forest law’
--Word--
purlieu man 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The owner of a piece of freehold land in the purlieu of a forest; specifically such a person licensed to hunt within the purlieu.
--Examples--

--Word--
purple 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A colour intermediate between red and blue.
Purple clothing or material.
A crimson dye obtained from some molluscs, formerly used for fabric worn by an emperor or senior magistrate in ancient Rome or Byzantium.
(in ancient Rome or Byzantium) clothing made from fabric dyed with Tyrian purple.
(in ancient Rome) a position of rank, authority, or privilege.
The scarlet official dress of a cardinal.
Of a colour intermediate between red and blue.
Make or become purple in colour.
--Examples--
‘the painting was mostly in shades of blue and purple’
‘he was too young to assume the purple’
‘a faded purple T-shirt’
‘Edmund's cheeks purpled’
‘the neon was purpling the horizon above the highway’
--Word--
awned 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Word--
red-spotted purple 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A North American butterfly that is a form of the white admiral, formerly considered a separate species. Its dark blue wings with red-orange bars and spots mimic the unpalatable pipevine swallowtail.
--Examples--

--Word--
ring-streaked 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
= ring-straked. Also in extended uses, and (US, chiefly derogatory) in "ring-streaked-and-striped".
--Examples--
--Word--
streaming 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A method of transmitting or receiving data (especially video and audio material) over a computer network as a steady, continuous flow, allowing playback to start while the rest of the data is still being received.
The practice of putting schoolchildren in groups of the same age and ability to be taught together.
(of a cold) accompanied by copious running of the nose and eyes.
Relating to or making use of a form of tape transport, used mainly to provide backup storage, in which data may be transferred in bulk while the tape is in motion.
Of or relating to data transmitted in a continuous stream while earlier parts are being used.
--Examples--
‘streaming within secondary schools is common practice’
‘she's got a streaming cold’
‘a streaming tape drive’
--Word--
tailed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a tail of a specified kind.
(of a garment) having a lower or hanging part, especially at the back of a coat.
--Examples--
‘a long-tailed lizard’
‘white-tailed eagles’
‘a tailed jacket’
‘he always wore a long-tailed coat’
--Word--
purple 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A colour intermediate between red and blue.
Purple clothing or material.
A crimson dye obtained from some molluscs, formerly used for fabric worn by an emperor or senior magistrate in ancient Rome or Byzantium.
(in ancient Rome or Byzantium) clothing made from fabric dyed with Tyrian purple.
(in ancient Rome) a position of rank, authority, or privilege.
The scarlet official dress of a cardinal.
Of a colour intermediate between red and blue.
Make or become purple in colour.
--Examples--
‘the painting was mostly in shades of blue and purple’
‘he was too young to assume the purple’
‘a faded purple T-shirt’
‘Edmund's cheeks purpled’
‘the neon was purpling the horizon above the highway’
--Word--
purple 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A colour intermediate between red and blue.
Purple clothing or material.
A crimson dye obtained from some molluscs, formerly used for fabric worn by an emperor or senior magistrate in ancient Rome or Byzantium.
(in ancient Rome or Byzantium) clothing made from fabric dyed with Tyrian purple.
(in ancient Rome) a position of rank, authority, or privilege.
The scarlet official dress of a cardinal.
Of a colour intermediate between red and blue.
Make or become purple in colour.
--Examples--
‘the painting was mostly in shades of blue and purple’
‘he was too young to assume the purple’
‘a faded purple T-shirt’
‘Edmund's cheeks purpled’
‘the neon was purpling the horizon above the highway’

--Word--
vested interest 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A personal reason for involvement in an undertaking or situation, especially an expectation of financial or other gain.
A person or group with a particular reason for involvement in an undertaking or situation.
An interest (usually in land or money held in trust) recognized as belonging to a particular person.
--Examples--
‘banks have a vested interest in the growth of their customers’
‘the problem is that the authorities are a vested interest’

--Word--
purpose 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The reason for which something is done or created or for which something exists.
A particular requirement or consideration, typically one that is temporary or restricted in scope or extent.
A person's sense of resolve or determination.
Have as one's intention or objective.
--Examples--
‘the purpose of the meeting is to appoint a trustee’
‘the building is no longer needed for its original purpose’
‘state pensions are considered as earned income for tax purposes’
‘there was a new sense of purpose in her step as she set off’
‘God has allowed suffering, even purposed it’

purpresture

noun

Of language or rhetoric: rich; elaborate, ornate. Compare "purple". Now rare.
