--Word--
purr 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of a cat) make a low continuous vibratory sound expressing contentment.
(of a vehicle or engine) move smoothly while making a similar sound.
Speak in a low, soft voice, especially when expressing contentment or acting seductively.
A purring sound.
--Examples--
‘the cat purred loudly, rubbing against her legs’
‘a sleek blue BMW purred past him’
‘‘Would you like a coffee?’ she purred’
‘a contented purr’
‘with a soft purr, the car headed out on to the road’

--Word--
purism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Scrupulous or exaggerated observance of or insistence on traditional rules or structures, especially in language or style.
An early 20th-century artistic style and movement founded by Le Corbusier and the French painter Amédée Ozenfant (1886–1966) and emphasizing purity of geometric form. It arose out of a rejection of cubism and was characterized by a return to the representation of recognizable objects.
--Examples--
‘Mrs Grundy's name is now synonymous with narrow linguistic purism’
--Word--
purse 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small pouch of leather or plastic used for carrying money, typically by a woman.
The money possessed by or available to a person or country.
A sum of money given as a prize in a sporting contest, especially a boxing match.
A handbag.
(with reference to the lips) pucker or contract, typically to express disapproval or irritation.
--Examples--
‘she had enough in her purse for bus fare’
‘institutions are funded from the same general purse’
‘a fight for which his purse was $400,000’
‘a young woman with a purse hanging from her elbow’
‘Marianne took a glance at her reflection and pursed her lips disgustedly’
‘under stress his lips would purse slightly’
--Word--
purse-bearer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The bearer or carrier of a purse; a person who has been given charge of money belonging to another, or to a company, etc.; a treasurer, a bursar. Now archaic and historical.
British Parliament. The official who carries the Lord Chancellor's purse on ceremonial occasions.

mad 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, verb
--Meanings--
Mentally ill; insane.
(of behaviour or an idea) extremely foolish; not sensible.
In a frenzied mental or physical state.
(of a dog) rabid.
Very enthusiastic about someone or something.
Very exciting.
Very angry.
Great; remarkable.
Very; extremely.
Make (someone) mad.
--Examples--
‘he felt as if he were going mad’
‘Antony's mother told him he was mad to be leaving Dublin’
‘she pictured loved ones mad with anxiety about her’
‘it was a mad dash to get ready’
‘he's mad about football’
‘another myth is that Scorpios are sex-mad’
‘don't be mad at me’
‘I got mad respect for him’
‘this author has mad skills with the written word’
‘he was mad cool—we immediately hit it off’
‘had I but seen thy picture in this plight, it would have madded me’

--Word--
purse string 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A string, or each of a pair of strings, which may be drawn to close the mouth of a purse; a drawstring. In later use chiefly in similative expressions.
Figurative. Chiefly in plural, especially in various phrases relating to the control of money, as "to hold the purse strings": to control expenditure.

--Word--
pursue 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Follow or chase (someone or something)
Persistently seek to form a sexual relationship with (someone)
Seek to attain or accomplish (a goal) over a long period.
(of something unpleasant) persistently afflict (someone)
Continue or proceed along (a path or route)
Engage in (an activity or course of action)
Continue to investigate or explore (an idea or argument)
--Examples--
‘the officer pursued the van’
‘a heavily indebted businessman was being pursued by creditors’
‘Sophie was being pursued by a number of men’
‘should people pursue their own happiness at the expense of others?’
‘mercy lasts as long as sin pursues man’
‘the road pursued a straight course over the scrubland’
‘Andrew was determined to pursue a computer career’
‘the council decided not to pursue an appeal’
‘we shall not pursue the matter any further’

‘mercy lasts as long as sin pursues man’
‘the road pursued a straight course over the scrubland’
‘Andrew was determined to pursue a computer career’
‘the council decided not to pursue an appeal’
‘we shall not pursue the matter any further’
--Word--
pursuer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or thing that pursues another.
A person who brings a case against another into court; a plaintiff.
--Examples--
‘the court agreed with counsel for the pursuers’

--Word--
pursue 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Follow or chase (someone or something)
Persistently seek to form a sexual relationship with (someone)
Seek to attain or accomplish (a goal) over a long period.
(of something unpleasant) persistently afflict (someone)
Continue or proceed along (a path or route)
Engage in (an activity or course of action)
Continue to investigate or explore (an idea or argument)
--Examples--
‘the officer pursued the van’
‘a heavily indebted businessman was being pursued by creditors’
‘Sophie was being pursued by a number of men’
‘should people pursue their own happiness at the expense of others?’
‘mercy lasts as long as sin pursues man’
‘the road pursued a straight course over the scrubland’
‘Andrew was determined to pursue a computer career’
‘the council decided not to pursue an appeal’
‘we shall not pursue the matter any further’

noun

The action of pursuing someone or something.

The action of the eye in following a moving object.

--Examples--
‘the cat crouched in the grass in pursuit of a bird’
‘those whose business is the pursuit of knowledge’
‘the Olympic pursuit champion’
‘a whole range of leisure pursuits’

Puschkinia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of the family Hyacinthaceae (or Liliaceae), comprising a single variable species, Puschkinia scilloides, which is a small spring-flowering bulb of Asia Minor and the Caucasus having distinctive pale blue or white flowers striped with dark blue; (also puschkinia) the striped squill, a cultivated variety of this often grown for ornament.

--Word--
push 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Exert force on (someone or something) in order to move them away from oneself.
Hold and exert force on (something) so as to cause it to move in front of one.
Move one's body or a part of it into a specified position with effort.
Press (a part of a machine or other device)
Cause to reach a particular level or state.
Move forward by using force to pass people or cause them to move aside.
(of an army) advance over territory.
Exert oneself to attain something or surpass others.
Be nearly (a particular age or amount)
Compel or urge (someone) to do something, especially to work hard.
Demand persistently.
Have very little of something, especially time.
Find it difficult to achieve something.
Promote the use, sale, or acceptance of.
Sell (a narcotic drug) illegally.
Prepare (a stack) to receive a piece of data on the top.
Transfer (data) to the top of a stack.
Develop (a film) so as to compensate for deliberate underexposure.
An act of pushing someone or something in order to move them away from oneself.
An act of pressing a part of a machine or device.
A vigorous effort to do or obtain something.
A military attack in force.
Forcefulness and enterprise.
Something that is hard to achieve.
--Examples--
‘she pushed her glass towards him’
‘Lydia pushed the door shut’
‘he pushed at the skylight, but it wouldn't budge’
‘a woman was pushing a pram’
‘she pushed her hands into her pockets’
‘the lift boy pushed the button for the twentieth floor’
‘competition in the retail sector will push down prices’
‘the political chaos could push the country into recession’
‘she pushed her way through the crowded streets’
‘he pushed past an old woman in his haste’
‘the guerrillas have pushed south to within 100 miles of the capital’
‘I was pushing hard until about 10 laps from the finish’
‘she must be pushing forty, but she's still a good looker’
‘she believed he was pushing their daughter too hard’
‘the council continued to push for the better management of water resources’
‘I'm a bit pushed for time at the moment’
‘he will be pushed to retain the title as his form this season has been below par’
‘the company has been pushing a document management system’
‘she was arrested for pushing hard drugs’
‘some films can be pushed during processing’
‘he closed the door with a push’
‘the door locks at the push of a button’
‘many clubs are joining in the fund-raising push’
‘he determined to make one last push for success’
‘the army was engaged in a push against guerrilla strongholds’
‘an investor with the necessary money and push’
‘we're managing on our own but it's a push’

push-down 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Aeronautics. A manoeuvre in which an aircraft in level flight loses altitude and then resumes level flight. rare.
Computing and Linguistics. A push-down store or list.
Computing and Linguistics. Designating a linear store or list that receives and loses items at one end only, the first to be removed being always the last to have been added; relating to or employing such a store or list.
That may be, or is designed to be, pushed down.

--Word--
Pushkin, Aleksandr 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1799–1837), Russian poet, novelist, and playwright; full name Aleksandr Sergeevich Pushkin. He wrote prolifically in many genres; his first success was the romantic narrative poem Ruslan and Ludmilla (1820). Other notable works include the verse novel Eugene Onegin (1833) and the blank-verse historical drama Boris Godunov (1831).
--Examples--
--Word--
pushmobile 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A vehicle that is pushed; (now) especially a children's cart which is pushed by hand, a soapbox cart.
--Examples--
--Word--
push off 
--Type--
phrasal verb
--Meanings--
Use an oar, boathook, etc. to exert pressure so as to move a boat out from a bank.
Go away.
--Examples--
‘we pushed off and rowed out into midstream’
‘I've got to push off and get to work’
--Word--
push-out 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who is made to leave somewhere, especially school.
That pushes out, or can be pushed out.
--Examples--
--Word--
pushover 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who is easy to overcome or influence.
A thing that is very easily done.
A try in which one side in a scrum pushes the ball over the opponents' goal line.
--Examples--
‘Colonel Moore was benevolent but no pushover’
‘this is going to be a pushover’

--Word--
push-pull 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Operated by pushing and pulling.
Having or involving two matched valves or transistors that operate 180 degrees out of phase, conducting alternately for increased output.
--Examples--
‘the controls are operated through push-pull rods’
‘a push-pull transistor amplifier’
--Word--
pushrod 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A rod operated by cams that opens and closes the valves in an internal combustion engine.
--Examples--
‘pushrod engines’

--Word--
push-start 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Start (a motor vehicle) by pushing it in order to make the engine turn.
An act of push-starting a motor vehicle.
--Examples--
‘the bus had been push-started once by the passengers’
‘a push start is required to get some of the veteran motorbikes going’
--Word--
Pashto 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The language of the Pashtuns, which belongs to the Iranian group. It is the official language of Afghanistan and is also spoken in northern areas of Pakistan.
--Examples--

--Word--
puss moth 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large furry greyish-white moth with darker markings. The boldly marked caterpillar rears up when threatened, waving whiplike appendages and spitting formic acid.
--Examples--

--Word--
put 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Move to or place in a particular position.
Cause (someone or something) to go to a particular place and remain there for a time.
(of a ship) proceed in a particular direction.
(of a river) flow in a particular direction.
Bring into a particular state or condition.
Imagine oneself in (a particular situation)
Write or print (something) in a particular place.
Express (a thought or comment) in a particular way.
Cause (someone or something) to be subject to something.
Assign a particular value, figure, or limit to.
Estimate something to be (a particular amount)
Throw (a shot or weight) as an athletic sport.
A throw of a shot or weight.
--Examples--
‘Harry put down his cup’
‘I put my hand out towards her’
‘watch where you're putting your feet!’
‘India has put three experimental satellites into space’
‘she stepped into the boat and put out to sea’
‘they put in at Cuba to refit’
‘they tried to put me at ease’
‘a large aid programme was put into practice’
‘he is putting himself at risk’
‘it was no use trying to put herself in his place’
‘they put my name on the cover page’
‘to put it bluntly, he was not really divorced’
‘commentators put some of the blame on Congress’
‘he defended his decision to put VAT on domestic fuel’
‘it is very difficult to put a figure on the size of the budget’
‘estimates put the war's cost at £1 million a day’
‘she set a women's record by putting the shot 56' 7"’

puteal 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A stone curb surrounding the mouth of a well, often decorated with figures depicting mythological scenes; (occasionally) a small building or structure housing a well.
In early use: of or relating to a well or pit. In later use (Classical Architecture): of or relating to a puteal.

--Word--
putt 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Try to hit a golf ball into the hole by striking it gently so that it rolls across the green.
A gentle stroke that hits a golf ball across the green towards the hole.
--Examples--
‘the man who can putt is a match for anyone’
‘his putting was as consistent and accurate as before’
‘there is nothing left to do except putt the ball in the hole’
‘he hit a four-iron to 20 ft and holed the putt’
‘a three-foot putt’
--Word--
putt 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Try to hit a golf ball into the hole by striking it gently so that it rolls across the green.

‘there is nothing left to do except putt the ball in the hole’

A golf club designed for use in putting, typically with a flat-faced head.
A golfer considered in terms of putting ability.
The rapid intermittent sound of a small petrol engine.
Move with or make a puttering sound.
--Examples--
‘you'll need to be a good putter to break par’
‘the putter of an old aeroplane’
‘barges puttered slowly through the water’

--Word--
putty 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A soft, malleable greyish-yellow paste, made from ground chalk and raw linseed oil, that hardens after a few hours and is used for sealing glass in window frames and filling holes in wood.
Any of a number of similar malleable substances used inside and outside buildings, e.g. plumber's putty, lime putty, or used for modelling or casting, e.g. epoxy putty.
A polishing powder, usually made from tin oxide, used in jewellery work.
Seal or cover (something) with putty.
--Examples--
‘countersink the screws so they can be covered with putty’
‘the manufacture of paints and putties’
‘give me a minute until I putty these windows in’
‘lightly puttied joints’
--Word--
putty 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--

‘countersink the screws so they can be covered with putty’
‘the manufacture of paints and putties’
‘give me a minute until I putty these windows in’
‘lightly puttied joints’

--Word--
putt 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Try to hit a golf ball into the hole by striking it gently so that it rolls across the green.
A gentle stroke that hits a golf ball across the green towards the hole.
--Examples--
‘the man who can putt is a match for anyone’
‘his putting was as consistent and accurate as before’
‘there is nothing left to do except putt the ball in the hole’
‘he hit a four-iron to 20 ft and holed the putt’
‘a three-foot putt’

--Word--
puttock 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bird of prey, especially the red kite (Milvus milvus) and the buzzard (Buteo buteo). Now English regional and Scottish rare.
Figurative (derogatory). A person likened to a bird of prey in being considered greedy, grasping, rapacious, etc.; specifically a petty officer of justice; a bailiff. Compare "hawk". Now rare (archaic in later use).
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
Putumayo River 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river that flows for 1,000 miles (1,610 km) from the Andes Mountains in southwestern Colombia along the borders with Ecuador and Peru into northwestern Brazil, where it joins the Amazon River.
--Examples--

put-up

adjective
--Meanings--

put upon 
--Type--
phrasal verb
--Meanings--

--Examples--

--Word--
puture 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The right of foresters to claim food, drink, and lodging (or the equivalent value in money) from the inhabitants of a forest for the maintenance of themselves, their attendants, and their animals; provisions claimed in this way, or the custom of providing them. Also: a similar right of other officials to claim food, accommodation, etc., on an official circuit.
--Examples--
--Word--
putz 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A stupid or worthless person.
A man's penis.

--Examples--
‘I'm not some two-bit putz who doesn't know the difference between Ouzo and Dom Perignon’
‘too much putzing around up there would ruin them’

--Word--
puzzle 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Cause (someone) to feel confused because they cannot understand something.
Think hard about something because one cannot understand it.
Solve or understand something by thinking hard.
A game, toy, or problem designed to test ingenuity or knowledge.
A jigsaw puzzle.
A person or thing that is difficult to understand or explain; an enigma.
--Examples--
‘she was puzzled by the doctor's manner’
‘she was still puzzling over this problem when she reached the office’
‘she was trying to puzzle out who the speakers were’
‘those who solve this puzzle in the shortest time are eligible for awards’
‘a book with picture puzzles’
‘a puzzle with 500 pieces’
‘realization dawned as the pieces of the puzzle fell into place’
‘the meaning of the poem has always been a puzzle’
--Word--
puzzling 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Causing one to be puzzled; perplexing.
--Examples--
‘only one very puzzling question remains unanswered’
